original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Khuddakanikāye
analyzed: khuddaka nikāye
translated: In the Khuddakanikāya

original: Petavatthu-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: peta vatthu aṭṭhakathā
translated: The Commentary on the Petavatthu

original: Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā
translated: The Introduction

original: Mahākāruṇikaṃ nāthaṃ, ñeyyasāgarapāraguṃ;
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikam nātham ñeyya sāgara pāragum
translated: The Greatly Compassionate Protector, who has gone to the other shore of the ocean of things to be known,

original: Vande nipuṇagambhīra-vicitranayadesanaṃ.🔽Vijjācaraṇasampannā, yena niyyanti lokato;
analyzed: vande nipuṇa gambhīra vicitra naya desanam  vijjā ācaraṇa sampannāḥ yena niyyanti lokataḥ
translated: I praise him, whose teaching is skillful, profound, and of various methods.🔽The supreme Dhamma, which is perfected in knowledge and conduct, and by which one goes forth from the world,

original: Vande tamuttamaṃ dhammaṃ, sammāsambuddhapūjitaṃ.🔽Sīlādiguṇasampanno, ṭhito maggaphalesu yo;🔽Vande ariyasaṅghaṃ taṃ, puññakkhettaṃ anuttaraṃ.
analyzed: vande tam uttamam dhammam sammāsambuddha pūjitam  sīla ādi guṇa sampannaḥ ṭhitaḥ magga phalesu yaḥ  vande ariya saṅgham tam puñña kkhettam anuttaram
translated: I praise that, which is worshipped by the Fully Awakened One.🔽The noble Sangha, which is perfected in virtue and so forth, and is established in the fruits and paths,🔽I praise that, which is the unsurpassed field of merit.

original: Vandanājanitaṃ puññaṃ, iti yaṃ ratanattaye;
analyzed: vandanā janitam puññam iti yam rata nattaye
translated: The merit generated by this praise, which is offered to the Three Jewels,

original: Hatantarāyo sabbattha, hutvāhaṃ tassa tejasā.
analyzed: hata antarāyaḥ sabbattha hutvā aham tassa tejasā
translated: May it, by its power, be for the complete removal of all obstacles everywhere.

original: Petehi ca kataṃ kammaṃ, yaṃ yaṃ purimajātisu;
analyzed: petehi ca katam kammam yam yam purima jātisu
translated: And whatever deeds were done by me in previous births, which led to rebirth as a ghost,

original: Petabhāvāvahaṃ taṃ taṃ, tesañhi phalabhedato.
analyzed: tam tam tesam hi phala bhedataḥ
translated: Since those are the results of my own actions,

original: Pakāsayantī buddhānaṃ, desanā yā visesato;
analyzed: pakāsayantī buddhānam desanā yā visesataḥ
translated: The teaching of the Buddhas, which is especially clear in revealing the results of kamma,

original: Saṃvegajananī kamma-phalapaccakkhakārinī.
translated: Which generates a sense of urgency, and causes one to see the results of kamma with one's own eyes,

original: Petavatthūti nāmena, supariññātavatthukā;
analyzed: nāmena su pariññāta vatthukā
translated: Is known by the name Petavatthu, and has well-known stories.

original: Yaṃ khuddakanikāyasmiṃ, saṅgāyiṃsu mahesayo.
analyzed: yam khuddaka nikāyasmim saṅgāyiṃsu mahā esayaḥ
translated: Which in the Minor Collection, the Great Seers have compiled.

original: Tassa sammāvalambitvā, porāṇaṭṭhakathānayaṃ;
analyzed: tassa sammā avalambitvā porāṇa ṭṭhakathā nayam
translated: Therein, relying on the right method, on the method of the ancient commentaries,

original: Tattha tattha nidānāni, vibhāvento visesato.🔽Suvisuddhaṃ asaṃkiṇṇaṃ, nipuṇatthavinicchayaṃ;
analyzed: tattha tattha nidānāni vibhāventaḥ visesataḥ  su visuddham asaṃkiṇṇam nipuṇa attha vinicchayam
translated: I shall, in each case, expound the nidānas, and in particular🔽The well-purified, unadulterated, subtle, and well-ascertained meaning,

original: Mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ, samayaṃ avilomayaṃ.🔽Yathābalaṃ karissāmi, atthasaṃvaṇṇanaṃ subhaṃ;
analyzed: mahā vihāra vāsīnam samayam  yathābalam karissāmi attha saṃvaṇṇanam subham
translated: The tradition of the residents of the Great Monastery, which is free from error.🔽I shall expound the meaning as well as I can, in a manner that is good,

original: Sakkaccaṃ bhāsato taṃ me, nisāmayatha sādhavoti.🔽Tattha petavatthūti seṭṭhiputtādikassa tassa tassa sattassa petabhāvahetubhūtaṃ kammaṃ,
analyzed: sakkaccam tam me nisāmayatha sādhavaḥ iti  tattha peta vatthu ti seṭṭhi putta ādikassa tassa tassa sattassa peta bhāva hetu bhūtam kammaṃ
translated: So listen attentively, all of you who are virtuous.🔽Herein, the “stories of the ghosts” are the kamma that is the cause for a certain being, such as the son of a money-lender, to become a ghost.

original: tassa pana pakāsanavasena pavatto “khettūpamā arahanto”tiādikā pariyattidhammo idha
analyzed: tassa pana pakāsana vasena pavatto khettūpamā arahanto ti ādikā pariyatti dhammaḥ idha
translated: But the pariyattidhamma, the Dhamma of the scriptures, which is found in the text beginning with the words “The arahats are like a field of merit” and which is expounded in order to reveal that kamma,

original: “petavatthū”ti adhippeto.
analyzed: adhippetaḥ
translated: is what is intended here by the words “stories of the ghosts.”

original: Tayidaṃ petavatthu kena bhāsitaṃ, kattha bhāsitaṃ, kadā bhāsitaṃ, kasmā ca bhāsitanti?
analyzed: tayā idam peta vatthu kena bhāsitam kattha bhāsitam kadā bhāsitam kasmā ca bhāsitanti
translated: Now, by whom was this “stories of the ghosts” spoken? Where was it spoken? When was it spoken? And why was it spoken?

original: Vuccate – idañhi petavatthu duvidhena pavattaṃ aṭṭhuppattivasena, pucchāvissajjanavasena
analyzed: vuccate idam hi peta vatthu duvidhena pavattam aṭṭhuppatti vasena pucchā vissajjana vasena
translated: It may be stated as follows: This “stories of the ghosts” is twofold in occurrence: as an origin story and as an answer to a question.

original: ca. Tattha yaṃ aṭṭhuppattivasena pavattaṃ, taṃ bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ, itaraṃ nāradattherādīhi🔽pucchitaṃ tehi tehi petehi bhāsitaṃ. Satthā pana yasmā nāradattherādīhi tasmiṃ tasmiṃ
analyzed: ca tattha yam aṭṭhuppatti vasena pavattam tam bhagavatā bhāsitam itaram nāradatthera ādīhi  pucchitam tehi tehi petehi bhāsitam satthā pana yasmā nāradatthera ādīhi tasmin tasmin
translated: Herein, what occurred as a cause for the questions was spoken by the Blessed One, while the rest was spoken by the Elder Nārada and the other ghosts who were asked.

original: pucchāvissajjane ārocite taṃ taṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā sampattaparisāya dhammaṃ desesi,
analyzed: pucchā vissajjane ārocite tam tam aṭṭhuppattim katvā sampatta parisāya dhammaṃ desesi
translated: But when the Elder Nārada and the others had given their replies to the questions, the Master, in order to teach the Dhamma to the assembly that had come together, made that and that occurrence the occasion for doing so.

original: tasmā sabbampetaṃ petavatthu satthārā bhāsitameva nāma jātaṃ. Pavattitavaradhammacakke🔽hi satthari tattha tattha rājagahādīsu viharante yebhuyyena tāya tāya aṭṭhuppattiyā
analyzed: tasmā sabbampetam peta vatthu satthārā bhāsitam eva nāma jātam pavattita vara dhamma cakke  hi satthari tattha tattha rāja gaha ādīsu viharante yebhuyyena tāya tāya aṭṭhuppattiyā
translated: So all this is called “spoken by the Master.”

original: pucchāvissajjanavasena sattānaṃ kammaphalapaccakkhakaraṇāya taṃ taṃ petavatthu desanāruḷhanti
analyzed: pucchā vissajjana vasena sattānam kamma phala paccakkha karaṇāya tam tam peta vatthu desanā ruḷhanti
translated: For when the Master had set the Wheel of the Dhamma rolling, he stayed here and there, in Rājagaha and so on, and then, as a rule, he taught the Dhamma to beings by means of the questions and replies about this or that occurrence, in order to make them see for themselves the fruit of kamma.🔽So this and that ghost-story came to be included in the teaching.

original: ayaṃ tāvettha “kena bhāsita”ntiādīnaṃ padānaṃ sādhāraṇato vissajjanā. Asādhāraṇato
analyzed: ayam tāva ettha kena bhāsita nti ādīnam padānam sādhāraṇataḥ vissajjanā asādhāraṇataḥ
translated: This, firstly, is the general explanation of the words “Who spoke it? ” and the rest.

original: pana tassa tassa vatthussa atthavaṇṇanāyameva āgamissati.
analyzed: pana tassa tassa vatthussa attha vaṇṇanāyam eva āgamissati
translated: But the particular explanation will come in the commentary on the meaning of the individual passages.

original: Taṃ panetaṃ petavatthu vinayapiṭakaṃ suttantapiṭakaṃ abhidhammapiṭakanti tīsu piṭakesu🔽suttantapiṭakapariyāpannaṃ, dīghanikāyo majjhimanikāyo saṃyuttanikāyo aṅguttaranikāyo
analyzed: tam pana itam peta vatthu vinaya piṭakam suttanta piṭakam abhidhamma piṭakam ti tīsu piṭakesu  suttanta piṭaka pariyāpannam dīgha nikāyaḥ majjhima nikāyaḥ saṃyutta nikāyaḥ aṅguttara nikāyaḥ
translated: namely, the Basket of Discourses, the Basket of Discipline, and the Basket of Further-Dhammas.🔽It is included in the Basket of Discourses,

original: khuddakanikāyoti pañcasu nikāyesu khuddakanikāyapariyāpannaṃ, suttaṃ geyyaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: khuddaka nikāyaḥ ti pañcasu nikāyesu khuddaka nikāya pariyāpannam suttam geyyam veyyākaraṇam
translated: and in the five Collections of Discourses, it is included in the Collection of Minor Discourses.🔽It is a verse included in the nine limbs of the Dispensation,🔽namely, discourse, verse, declaration,🔽exposition,🔽utterance, birth story, marvel,

original: gāthā udānaṃ itivuttakaṃ jātakaṃ abbhutadhammaṃ vedallanti navasu sāsanaṅgesu gāthāsaṅgahaṃ.
analyzed: gāthāḥ udānam itivuttakam jātakam abbhuta dhammam navasu sāsanaṅgesu gāthā saṅgaham
translated: and further-Dhammas.🔽“I have learned from the Buddha eighty-two thousand dhammas,

original: “Dvāsīti buddhato gaṇhiṃ, dve sahassāni bhikkhuto;
analyzed: buddhataḥ dve sahassāni bhikkhutaḥ
translated: and two thousand from the bhikkhus,

original: Caturāsīti sahassāni, ye me dhammā pavattino”ti. –
analyzed: catur asīti sahassāni ye me dhammā pavattino ti
translated: and eighty-four thousand dhammas that have occurred to me.”🔽Thus, among the eighty-four thousand dhammas that he declared to be the storehouse of the Dhamma,

original: Evaṃ dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena paṭiññātesu caturāsītiyā dhammakkhandhasahassesu katipayadhammakkhandhasaṅgahaṃ,
analyzed: evam dhamma bhaṇḍāgārikena paṭiññātesu caturāsītiyā dhamma kkhandha sahassesu katipaya dhamma kkhandha saṅgaham
translated: it is a collection of a few dhammas,

original: bhāṇavārato catubhāṇavāramattaṃ, vaggato – uragavaggo ubbarivaggo cūḷavaggo mahāvaggoti
analyzed: bhāṇa vārataḥ catu bhāṇa vāra mattam vaggataḥ uraga vaggo ubbari vaggo cūḷa vaggo mahā vaggo ti
translated: and in terms of the recitation, it is just one quarter of a recitation, and in terms of the chapters, it is the chapter on the snake, the chapter on the flood, the short chapter, and the long chapter.

original: catuvaggasaṅgahaṃ. Tesu paṭhamavagge dvādasa vatthūni, dutiyavagge terasa vatthūni,
analyzed: catu vagga saṅgaham tesu paṭhama vagge dvādasa vatthūni dutiya vagge terasa vatthūni
translated: In the first vagga there are twelve items, in the second, thirteen,

original: tatiyavagge dasa vatthūni, catutthavagge soḷasa vatthūnīti vatthuto ekapaññāsavatthupaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya vagge dasa vatthūni catuttha vagge soḷasa vatthūni iti vatthutaḥ ekapaññāsa vatthu paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: in the third, ten, and in the fourth, sixteen. So it is adorned with fifty-one items in all.

original: Tassa vaggesu uragavaggo ādi, vatthūsu khettūpamapetavatthu ādi, tassāpi “khettūpamā
analyzed: tassa vaggesu uraga vaggo ādi vatthūsu khettu upama peta vatthu ādi tassa api khettu upamā
translated: In the vaggas, the “Snake” is the first. In the items, the “Field-simile Ghost” is the first.

original: arahanto”ti ayaṃ gāthā ādi.🔽1. Uragavaggo
analyzed: ayam gāthā ādi  uraga vaggaḥ
translated: And in that, the verse “The Arahants are like a field” is the first.🔽The “Snake” vagga

original: 1. Khettūpamapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: khettu upama peta vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The “Field-simile Ghost” story

original: Taṃ panetaṃ vatthuṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharanto veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe aññataraṃ🔽seṭṭhiputtapetaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Rājagahe kira aññataro aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo
analyzed: tam pana itam vatthum bhagavā rājagahe viharantaḥ veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe aññataram  seṭṭhi putta petam ārabbha kathesi rājagahe kira aññataraḥ aḍḍhaḥ mahat dhanaḥ mahā bhogo
translated: The Blessed One, while staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove in the Squirrels’ Feeding-Ground, told this story about a certain ghost🔽who was the son of a treasurer. In Rājagaha, it seems, there was a certain rich man, a great merchant,

original: pahūtavittūpakaraṇo anekakoṭidhanasannicayo seṭṭhi ahosi. Tassa mahādhanasampannatāya
analyzed: pahūta vittu upakaraṇaḥ aneka koṭi dhana sannicayo seṭṭhi ahosi tassa mahādhana sampanna tāya
translated: who was wealthy, had great property, great riches, and a great store of food and wealth, and he had amassed a great fortune. Because of his great wealth

original: “mahādhanaseṭṭhi”tveva samaññā ahosi. Ekova putto ahosi, piyo manāpo. Tasmiṃ viññutaṃ
analyzed: mahādhana seṭṭhi tvā iva samaññā ahosi ekaḥ iva putto ahosi piyaḥ manāpaḥ tasmim viññutam
translated: he was known as the “Great Wealthy Merchant.” He had one son, who was dear to him and beloved. When the son

original: patte mātāpitaro evaṃ cintesuṃ – “amhākaṃ puttassa divase divase sahassaṃ sahassaṃ
analyzed: patte mātā pitaraḥ evam cintesuṃ amhākam puttassa divase divase sahassam sahassam
translated: His parents thought to themselves, “Even if our son were to spend a thousand pieces of money a day,

original: paribbayaṃ karontassa vassasatenāpi ayaṃ dhanasannicayo parikkhayaṃ na gamissati,
analyzed: paribbayam karontassa vassa satena api ayam dhana sannicayaḥ parikkhayam na gamissati
translated: this wealth of ours would not be exhausted in a hundred years.

original: kiṃ imassa sippuggahaṇaparissamena, akilantakāyacitto yathāsukhaṃ bhoge paribhuñjatū”ti
analyzed: kim imassa sippu gahaṇa parissamena a kilanta kāya cittaḥ yathāsukham bhoge paribhuñjatu uti
translated: What is the use of his learning a craft? Let him enjoy himself, with a happy and carefree mind.”

original: sippaṃ na sikkhāpesuṃ. Vayappatte pana kularūpayobbanavilāsasampannaṃ kāmābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: sippam na sikkhāpesum vaya patte pana kula rūpa yobbana vilāsa sampannam kāma abhimukham
translated: So they did not have him learn a craft. But when he had reached the age of discretion, they brought him a wife, a young woman of good family, who was beautiful,🔽and who was devoted to sensual pleasures and averse to the Dhamma.

original: dhammasaññāvimukhaṃ kaññaṃ ānesuṃ. So tāya saddhiṃ abhiramanto dhamme cittamattampi🔽anuppādetvā, samaṇabrāhmaṇagurujanesu anādaro hutvā, dhuttajanaparivuto rajjamāno🔽pañcakāmaguṇe rato giddho mohena andho hutvā kālaṃ vītināmetvā, mātāpitūsu kālakatesu
analyzed: dhamma saññā vimukham kaññam ānesum saḥ tāya saddhim abhiramantaḥ dhamme citta mattam pi  an uppādetvā samaṇa brāhmaṇa guru janesu anādaraḥ hutvā dhutta jana parivutaḥ rajjamānaḥ  pañca kāmaguṇe rataḥ giddhaḥ mohena andhaḥ hutvā kālam mātā pitūsu kāla katesu
translated: He took delight in her, and never gave a thought to the Dhamma.🔽He became disrespectful to ascetics and brahmins, to his parents and to his superiors, and surrounded himself with rogues.🔽He spent his time in the enjoyment of the fivefold sensepleasures, intoxicated and blinded by his folly.

original: naṭanāṭakagāyakādīnaṃ yathicchitaṃ dento dhanaṃ vināsetvā nacirasseva pārijuññappatto
analyzed: naṭa nāṭaka gāyaka ādīnam yathicchitam dentaḥ dhanam vināsetvā nacirassa eva pārijuñña ppatto
translated: When his parents died, he squandered his wealth on actors, dancers, and singers, and soon he was reduced to poverty.

original: hutvā, iṇaṃ gahetvā jīvikaṃ kappento puna iṇampi alabhitvā iṇāyikehi codiyamāno tesaṃ🔽attano khettavatthugharādīni datvā, kapālahattho bhikkhaṃ caritvā bhuñjanto tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: hutvā iṇam gahetvā jīvikam kappento punar iṇam pi a labhitvā iṇāyikehi codiyamāno tesam  khetta vatthu ghara ādīni da tvā kapāla hatthaḥ bhikkham caritvā bhuñjantaḥ tasmiṃ yeva
translated: and after he had done so, he went about his business, borrowing money on interest. But he was not able to pay the interest, and the creditors,

original: nagare anāthasālāyaṃ vasati.
analyzed: nagare anāthasālāyam vasati
translated: giving him no respite, took possession of his fields, his land, his house, and so forth. He went about begging with a bowl in his hand, and he lived in a poorhouse in the same city.

original: Atha naṃ ekadivasaṃ corā samāgatā evamāhaṃsu – “ambho purisa, kiṃ tuyhaṃ iminā dujjīvitena,🔽taruṇo tvamasi thāmajavabalasampanno, kasmā hatthapādavikalo viya acchasi? Ehi amhehi🔽saha corikāya paresaṃ santakaṃ gahetvā sukhena jīvikaṃ kappehī”ti. So “nāhaṃ corikaṃ
analyzed: atha naṃ eka divasam corā samāgatā evam āhaṃsu ambho purisa kim tuyham iminā dujjīvitena  taruṇaḥ tvam asi thāma java bala sampanno kasmā hattha pāda vikalaḥ viya acchasi ehi amhehi  saha corikāya paresam santakam gahetvā sukhena jīvikam kappehi iti saḥ na aham corikam
translated: One day some thieves met together and said to him, “Good man, what is the use of your living this miserable life?

original: kātuṃ jānāmī”ti āha. Corā “mayaṃ taṃ sikkhāpema, kevalaṃ tvaṃ amhākaṃ vacanaṃ karohī”ti
analyzed: kātum jānāmi iti āha corāḥ mayam tam sikkhāpema kevalam tvam amhākam vacanam karohi iti
translated: You are young and strong, and yet you go about on crutches as though you were crippled. Come with us and live happily by plundering the property of others.” “I do not know how to steal,” said he. “We will teach you,” said the thieves. “You have only to do as we tell you.”🔽“Very well,” said he, and he went with them. Then the thieves took him with them

original: āhaṃsu. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā tehi saddhiṃ agamāsi. Atha te corā tassa hatthe
analyzed: āhaṃsu saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā tehi saddhim agamāsi atha te corā tassa hatthe
translated: and taught him their trade.

original: mahantaṃ muggaraṃ datvā sandhiṃ chinditvā gharaṃ pavisanto taṃ sandhimukhe ṭhapetvā
analyzed: mahantam muggaram da tvā sandhim chinditvā gharam pavisantaḥ tam sandhi mukhe ṭhapetvā
translated: and gave him a big hammer, saying, “Cut the bolt, enter the house, and place the hammer in the door-way.

original: āhaṃsu – “sace idha añño koci āgacchati, taṃ iminā muggarena paharitvā ekappahāreneva
analyzed: āhaṃsu sace idha aññaḥ koci āgacchati tam iminā muggarena paharitvā eka ppahārena iva
translated: If anyone else comes here, strike him with this hammer and kill him at a single blow.”

original: mārehī”ti. So andhabālo hitāhitaṃ ajānanto paresaṃ āgamanameva olokento tattha aṭṭhāsi.🔽Corā pana gharaṃ pavisitvā gayhūpagaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā gharamanussehi ñātamattāva
analyzed: mārehi iti saḥ andha bālaḥ hita ahitam a jānanto paresam āgamanam eva olokento tattha aṭṭhāsi  corā pana gharam pavisitvā gayhūpagam bhaṇḍam gahetvā ghara manussehi
translated: The foolish blind man, not knowing what was good for him or what was not, stood there looking for someone to come.🔽The thieves entered the house, took the valuables, and fled in all directions as soon as the inmates of the house became aware of what had happened.

original: ito cito ca palāyiṃsu. Gharamanussā uṭṭhahitvā sīghaṃ sīghaṃ dhāvantā ito cito ca🔽olokentā taṃ purisaṃ sandhidvāre ṭhitaṃ disvā “hare duṭṭhacorā”ti gahetvā hatthapāde🔽muggarādīhi pothetvā rañño dassesuṃ – “ayaṃ, deva, coro sandhisukhe gahito”ti. Rājā
analyzed: itas citas ca palāyiṃsu ghara manussāḥ uṭṭhahitvā sīgham sīgham dhāvantāḥ itas citas ca  olokentā tam purisam sandhi dvāre ṭhitam disvā hare duṭṭha corā ti gahetvā hattha pāde  muggara ādīhi pothetvā raññaḥ dassesuṃ ayam deva coraḥ sandhi sukhe gahitaḥ iti rājā

translated: This is the meaning. “Like farmers” means like farmers. Just as a farmer, having ploughed and harrowed a field,

original: vuttudakadānanīharaṇanidhānarakkhaṇādīhi appamajjanto uḷāraṃ vipulañca sassaphalaṃ🔽paṭilabhati, evaṃ dāyakopi arahantesu deyyadhammapariccāgena pāricariyāya ca appamajjanto
analyzed: vutta udaka dāna nīharaṇa nidhāna rakkhaṇa ādīhi appamajjantaḥ uḷāram vipulam ca sassa phalam  paṭilabhati evam dāyakaḥ api arahantesu deyya dhamma pariccāgena pāricariyāya ca appamajjanto
translated: obtains an abundant and excellent harvest of grain by not being negligent in timely sowing of the seed, in timely watering, in keeping away weeds, in timely harvesting, in timely threshing, in timely winnowing, in timely storing, and in timely protection,

original: uḷāraṃ vipulañca dānaphalaṃ paṭilabhati. Tena vuttaṃ “dāyakā kassakūpamā”ti.
analyzed: uḷāram vipulam ca dāna phalam paṭilabhati tena vuttam dāyakā kassakūpamā ti
translated: so too the givers, by not being negligent in the giving of requisites and in attendance on the Arahants, obtain an abundant and excellent fruit of giving. Hence it was said above, “The givers are like farmers.”

original: Bījūpamaṃ deyyadhammanti liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, bījasadiso deyyadhammoti attho.
analyzed: bīja upamam deyya dhamman ti liṅga vipallāsena vuttam bīja sadisaḥ deyya dhammaḥ ti attho
translated: “The gift is like seed” is said by a reversal of the terms. The meaning is: the gift is like a seed.

original: Annapānādikassa hi dasavidhassa dātabbavatthuno etaṃ nāmaṃ. Etto nibbattate phalanti🔽etasmā dāyakapaṭiggāhakadeyyadhammapariccāgato dānaphalaṃ nibbattati ceva uppajjati
analyzed: anna pāna ādikassa hi dasavidhassa dātabba vatthunaḥ etam nāmam ettas nibbattate phalanti  etasmā dāyaka paṭiggāhaka deyya dhamma pariccāgataḥ dāna phalam nibbattati ca iva uppajjati
translated: This is a name for the ten kinds of things to be given, beginning with food and drink.🔽The fruit is generated from this

original: ca, ciratarapabandhavasena pavattati cāti attho. Ettha ca yasmā pariccāgacetanābhisaṅkhatassa🔽annapānādivatthuno bhāvo, na itarassa, tasmā “bījūpamaṃ deyyadhamma”nti deyyadhammaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ca ciratara pabandha vasena pavattati ca ati atthaḥ ettha ca yasmā pariccāga cetanā abhisaṅkhatassa  anna pāna ādi vatthunaḥ bhāvaḥ na itarassa tasmai bīja upamam deyya dhammanti deyya dhamma ggahaṇam
translated: The fruit of giving is generated and arises and occurs for a long time, in other words, from the giving by the giver, the receiving by the receiver, and the thing given.🔽And here, since the thing given, such as food and drink, is the state of what is resolved by the volition of giving, not the other, the words “the thing given is like a seed” are stated.

original: kataṃ. Tena deyyadhammāpadesena deyyadhammavatthuvisayāya pariccāgacetanāyayeva bījabhāvo🔽daṭṭhabbo. Sā hi paṭisandhiādippabhedassa tassa nissayārammaṇappabhedassa ca phalassa
analyzed: katam tena deyya dhamma apadesena deyya dhamma vatthu visayāya pariccāga cetanāyayā iva bīja bhāvaḥ  daṭṭhabbo sā hi paṭisandhi ādi ppabhedassa tassa nissaya ārammaṇa ppabhedassa ca phalassa
translated: So the state of being a seed should be seen in the volition of giving, which has as its domain the thing given, by the words “the thing given.”

original: nipphādikā, na deyyadhammoti.
analyzed: nipphādikā na deyya dhammā ti
translated: For that is what generates the fruit classed as rebirth-linking, etc., and classed as its support and object, not the thing given.🔽This seed, the field, the ploughing,

original: 2. Etaṃ bījaṃ kasī khettanti yathāvuttaṃ bījaṃ, yathāvuttañca khettaṃ, tassa bījassa
analyzed: etam bījam kasī khettanti yathāvuttam bījam yathāvuttam ca khettam tassa bījassa
translated: The seed, as stated, is the thing given, and the field is the receiver, as stated.

original: tasmiṃ khette vapanapayogasaṅkhātā kasi cāti attho. Etaṃ tayaṃ kesaṃ icchitabbanti
analyzed: tasmin khette vapana payoga saṅkhātā ca ati etam tayam kesam icchitabbanti
translated: In that field, the sowing is the effort called ploughing. This is the meaning. Whose is this field, sowing, seed, and ploughing?

original: āha “petānaṃ dāyakassa cā”ti. Yadi dāyako pete uddissa dānaṃ deti, petānañca dāyakassa
analyzed: āha petānam dāyakassa ca ati yadi dāyakaḥ pete uddissa dānam deti petānam ca dāyakassa
translated: The answer is: “The givers’ and the dead relatives’.” If the giver gives the gift dedicated to the dead relatives, it is for the dead relatives and for the giver.

original: ca, yadi na pete uddissa dānaṃ deti, dāyakasseva etaṃ bījaṃ esā kasi etaṃ khettaṃ🔽upakārāya hotīti adhippāyo. Idāni taṃ upakāraṃ dassetuṃ “taṃ petā paribhuñjanti,
analyzed: ca yadi na uddissa dānam deti dāyakassa iva etam bījam esā etam khettam  upakārāya hoti iti adhippāyaḥ idāni tam upakāram dassetum tam petā paribhuñjanti
translated: If he does not give the gift dedicated to the dead relatives, it is only for the giver. This is the seed, this is the sowing, this is the field for the benefit of the giver.

original: dātā puññena vaḍḍhatī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha taṃ petā paribhuñjantīti dāyakena pete uddissa🔽dāne dinne yathāvuttakhettakasibījasampattiyā anumodanāya ca yaṃ petānaṃ upakappati,
analyzed: dātā puññena vaḍḍhati iti vuttam tattha tam petā paribhuñjanti iti dāyakena pete uddissa  dāne dinne yathāvutta khetta kasi bīja sampattiyāḥ anumodanāya ca yam upakappati
translated: This is the intention. Now, in order to show that benefit, it is said: “The dead relatives enjoy it, and the giver grows in merit.” Herein, the dead relatives enjoy it means that when the giver gives the gift dedicated to the dead relatives, the dead relatives enjoy the fruit of the gift, which is a benefit to them, by means of the excellence of the field, the excellence of the seed, and the joy of the giver.

original: taṃ dānaphalaṃ petā paribhuñjanti. Dātā puññena vaḍḍhatīti dātā pana attano dānamayapuññanimittaṃ
analyzed: tam dāna phalam petā paribhuñjanti dātā puññena vaḍḍhati iti dātā pana attanaḥ dāna maya puñña nimittam
translated: The giver grows in merit means that the giver grows in the fruit of merit by means of the merit consisting in the gift.

original: devamanussesu bhogasampattiādinā puññaphalena abhivaḍḍhati. Puññaphalampi hi “kusalānaṃ,
analyzed: deva manussesu bhoga sampatti ādinā puñña phalena abhivaḍḍhati puñña phalam pi hi kusalānam
translated: He grows in the fruit of merit such as the excellence of wealth in the heavenly and human worlds. For the fruit of merit is called “the excellence of the fruit of the wholesome

original: bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ samādānahetu evamidaṃ puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatī”tiādīsu puññanti vuccati.🔽3. Idheva kusalaṃ katvāti anavajjasukhavipākaṭṭhena kusalaṃ petānaṃ uddisanavasena
analyzed: bhikkhave dhammānam samādāna hetu evam idam puññam pavaḍḍhati itiādīsu puññanti vuccati  idha iva kusalam katvā ati anavajja sukha vipāka ṭṭhena kusalam uddisana vasena
translated: “It is by the taking up of these things, bhikkhus, that merit increases” .🔽Here in this very life, having made merit consisting in giving, which is called “good” in the sense of being blameless and productive of a happy result,

original: dānamayaṃ puññaṃ upacinitvā idheva imasmiṃyeva attabhāve. Pete ca paṭipūjiyāti pete
analyzed: dāna mayam puññam upacinitvā idhā iva imasmiṃyeva attabhāve pete ca paṭipūjiyāti pete
translated: and having worshipped the dead by giving to them,

original: uddissa dānena sammānetvā anubhuyyamānadukkhato te mocetvā. Pete hi uddissa diyyamānaṃ
analyzed: uddissa dānena sammānetvā anubhuyyamāna dukkhataḥ te mocetvā pete hi uddissa diyyamānam
translated: he has freed them from suffering, which they were undergoing, by giving to them with the dead in mind.

original: dānaṃ tesaṃ pūjā nāma hoti. Tenāha – “amhākañca katā pūjā”ti, “petānaṃ pūjā ca katā🔽uḷārā”ti ca. “Pete cā”ti ca-saddena “piyo ca hoti manāpo, abhigamanīyo ca hoti vissāsanīyo,🔽bhāvanīyo ca hoti garukātabbo, pāsaṃso ca hoti kittanīyo viññūna”nti evamādike diṭṭhadhammike
analyzed: dānam tesam pūjā nāma hoti tena āha amhākam ca katā pūjā ati petānam pūjā ca katā  uḷārā ati ca pete ca ati ca saddena piyaḥ ca hoti manāpaḥ abhigamanīyaḥ ca hoti vissāsanīyaḥ  bhāvanīyaḥ ca hoti garukātabbo pāsaṃso ca hoti kittanīyaḥ viññūnanti evamādike diṭṭhadhammike
translated: For the giving of gifts with the dead in mind is worship of them. That is why he said, “And worship done to us” and “And worship done to the dead is great” .🔽And by the word “and” he includes the visible benefits of giving, which are stated in the passage beginning, “He is dear, he is beloved, he is respected, he is honoured” , and ending, “He is a recipient of gifts, a performer of sacrifices” .

original: dānānisaṃse saṅgaṇhāti. Saggañca kamati ṭhānaṃ, kammaṃ katvāna bhaddakanti kalyāṇaṃ
analyzed: dāna anisaṃse saṅgaṇhāti saggam ca kamati ṭhānam kammam katvāna bhaddakanti kalyāṇam
translated: And he goes to heaven, to the place of good deeds, having done good deeds.

original: kusalakammaṃ katvā dibbehi āyuādīhi dasahi ṭhānehi suṭṭhu aggattā “sagga”nti laddhanāmaṃ
analyzed: kusala kammam katvā dibbehi āyu ādīhi dasahi ṭhānehi suṭṭhu agga ttā saggaṃ ti laddha nāmam
translated: and having done profitable deeds, he has been reborn in the deva world, which is called “heaven” because of the excellence of the ten sense objects such as visible forms, sounds, etc.,

original: katapuññānaṃ nibbattanaṭṭhānaṃ devalokaṃ kamati upapajjanavasena upagacchati.🔽Ettha ca “kusalaṃ katvā”ti vatvā puna “kammaṃ katvāna bhaddaka”nti vacanaṃ “deyyadhammapariccāgo
analyzed: kata puññānam nibbattana ṭṭhānam deva lokam kamati upapajjana vasena upagacchati  ettha ca kusalam katvā iti vatvā puna kammam katvāna bhaddakam ti vacanam deyya dhamma pariccāgaḥ
translated: Having done profitable action, he goes to the deva world, the place of rebirth of those who have done merit, by rebirth, by being reborn, after going to the deva world, which has the name “heaven” because of its pre-eminence in the ten respects of life span, etc., which are excellent.

original: viya pattidānavasena dānadhammapariccāgopi dānamayakusalakammamevā”ti dassanatthanti
analyzed: viya patti dāna vasena dāna dhamma pariccāgaḥ api dāna maya kusala kammam eva ati dassana tthanti
translated: And the words “having done profitable action” and again “having done kamma, good sir” should be regarded as stated in order to show that the giving of a gift is profitable action consisting in giving, just as the giving up of an offering of alms is.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Keci panettha “petāti arahanto adhippetā”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam keci pana ittha petā ati arahantaḥ adhippetā ti vadanti tam tesam matimattam
translated: But some say that “petas” here are intended as arahats. That is their opinion,

original: “petā”ti khīṇāsavānaṃ āgataṭṭhānasseva abhāvato, bījādibhāvassa ca dāyakassa viya🔽tesaṃ ayujjamānattā, petayonikānaṃ yujjamānattā ca. Desanāpariyosāne devaputtaṃ sulasañca
analyzed: khīṇāsavānam āgata ṭṭhānassa iva abhāvataḥ bīja ādi bhāvassa ca dāyakassa viya  tesam a yujjamāna ttā peta yonikānam yujjamāna ttā ca desanā pariyosāne devaputtam sulasam ca
translated: but it is not correct because there is no such state of being a “peta” for those who are arahats, and because the state of being a seed, etc., is not appropriate to them as it is to givers,

original: ādiṃ katvā caturāsītiyā pāṇasahassānaṃ dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: ādim katvā caturāsītiyā pāṇa sahassānam dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: and because it is appropriate to those in the peta realm. At the end of the teaching the divine being and the four assemblies of eight hundred thousand each attained the first path.

original: Khettūpamapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khettu upama peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Field-Demon is finished.

original: 2. Sūkaramukhapetavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽Kāyo te sabbasovaṇṇoti idaṃ satthari rājagahaṃ upanissāya veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe🔽viharante aññataraṃ sūkaramukhapetaṃ ārabbha vuttaṃ. Atīte kira kassapassa bhagavato
analyzed: sūkara mukha peta vatthu vaṇṇanā  kāyaḥ te sabbaso vaṇṇaḥ ti idam satthari rājagaham upanissāya veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe  viharante aññataram sūkara mukhapetam ārabbha vuttam atīte kira kassapassa bhagavato
translated: The Story of the Pig-Faced Ghost

original: sāsane eko bhikkhu kāyena saññato ahosi, vācāya asaññato, bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati.
analyzed: sāsane ekaḥ bhikkhu kāyena saññataḥ ahosi vācāya asaññataḥ bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati
translated: Your body is all gold: this was said by the Teacher while he was in residence at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove in the squirrels’ feeding ground, in reference to a certain pig-faced ghost. In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, it seems, a certain monk was self-controlled in body but not in speech; he reviled and abused the monks.

original: So kālaṃ katvā niraye nibbatto, ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ tattha paccitvā tato cavitvā imasmiṃ🔽buddhuppāde rājagahasamīpe gijjhakūṭapabbatapāde tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena
analyzed: saḥ kālam katvā niraye nibbattaḥ ekam buddha antaram tattha paccitvā tatas cavitvā imasmin  buddhuppāde rājagaha samīpe gijjhakūṭa pabbata pāde tassa eva kammassa vipāka avasesena
translated: When he died, he was reborn in hell. After suffering torment there for an entire cycle of time, he was reborn in this world in the dispensation of the present Buddha.

original: khuppipāsābhibhūto peto hutvā nibbatti. Tassa kāyo suvaṇṇavaṇṇo ahosi, mukhaṃ sūkaramukhasadisaṃ.
analyzed: khuppipāsā abhibhūto petaḥ hutvā nibbatti tassa kāyo suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ ahosi mukham sūkara mukha sadisam
translated: Through the remainder of his kamma he was reborn as a ghost on the slope of the Vulture Peak near Rājagaha, oppressed by hunger and thirst. His body was of a golden color, but his face was like the face of a pig.

original: Athāyasmā nārado gijjhakūṭe pabbate vasanto pātova sarīrapaṭijagganaṃ katvā pattacīvaramādāya
analyzed: atha ayasmā nāradaḥ gijjhakūṭe pabbate vasantaḥ pātova sarīra paṭijagganam katvā patta cīvaram ādāya
translated: Now the Venerable Nārada, who was in residence on the Vulture Peak, rose early in the morning, performed his toilet, took bowl and robe, and went to the monastery of the nuns.

original: rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya gacchanto antarāmagge taṃ petaṃ disvā tena katakammaṃ pucchanto –
analyzed: rājagaham piṇḍāya gacchantaḥ antara āmagge tam petam disvā tena kata kammam pucchantaḥ
translated: saying:🔽“Your whole body is gold,

original: “Kāyo te sabbasovaṇṇo, sabbā obhāsate disā;
analyzed: kāyaḥ te sabbaso vaṇṇaḥ sabbāḥ obhāsate disāḥ
translated: all quarters shine;🔽Your face is like a pig’s,

original: Mukhaṃ te sūkarasseva, kiṃ kammamakarī pure”ti. –
analyzed: mukham te sūkarassa iva kim kammam akarī purā iti
translated: what deed did you do in the past?”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha kāyo te sabbasovaṇṇoti tava kāyo deho sabbo suvaṇṇavaṇṇo uttattakanakasannibho.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha kāyaḥ te sabba sovaṇṇaḥ ti tava kāyaḥ dehaḥ sabbaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ uttatta kanaka sannibhaḥ
translated: He spoke this verse. Herein, your whole body is gold means your whole body, your frame, is the colour of gold, like refined gold.🔽All quarters shine means all quarters, all around, shine, glow, with its radiance.

original: Sabbā obhāsate disāti tassa pabhāya sabbāpi disā samantanto obhāsati vijjotati. Obhāsateti🔽vā antogadhahotuatthamidaṃ padanti “te kāyo sabbasovaṇṇo sabbā disā obhāseti vijjotetī”ti
analyzed: sabbā obhāsate disā ti tassa pabhāya sabbā api disā samantantaḥ obhāsati vijjotati obhāsata iti  vā antogadha hotu attham idam te kāyaḥ sabbaso vaṇṇaḥ sabbāḥ disāḥ obhāseti vijjoteti iti
translated: Obhāsate means

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Mukhaṃ te sūkarassevāti mukhaṃ pana te sūkarassa viya, sūkaramukhasadisaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo mukham te sūkarassa iva ati mukham pana te sūkarassa viya sūkara mukha sadisam
translated: this is a word that includes the inside. So the meaning should be regarded as follows: “Your body, being all gold, shines, glows, all around, in all quarters.” Your face is like a pig’s means your face is like a pig’s, similar to a pig’s face.

original: tava mukhanti attho. Kiṃ kammamakarī pureti “tvaṃ pubbe atītajātiyaṃ kīdisaṃ kammaṃ akāsī”ti pucchati.
analyzed: tava mukham ti atthaḥ kim kammam akarī purā iti tvam pubbe atīta jātiyam kīdisam kammam akāsi iti pucchati
translated: Your face means your face. What deed did you do in the past? He asks: “What kind of deed did you do in a past birth?”

original: Evaṃ therena so peto katakammaṃ puṭṭho gāthāya vissajjento –
analyzed: evam therena saḥ peto kata kammam puṭṭhaḥ gāthāya vissajjentaḥ
translated: When the departed one was thus asked by the Elder, he replied in verse:

original: “Kāyena saññato āsiṃ, vācāyāsimasaññato;
analyzed: kāyena saññataḥ āsim vācāya āsim a saññataḥ
translated: “I was restrained in body, I was unrestrained in speech,

original: Tena metādiso vaṇṇo, yathā passasi nāradā”ti. –
analyzed: tena mā itādisaḥ vaṇṇaḥ yathā passasi nārada ati
translated: Therefore I have such a complexion as you see, Nārada.”

original: Āha. Tattha kāyena saññato āsinti kāyikena saṃyamena saṃyato kāyadvārikena saṃvarena
analyzed: āha tattha kāyena saññataḥ āsinti kāyikena saṃyamena saṃyataḥ kāyadvārikena saṃvarena
translated: Herein, I was restrained in body means I was restrained by bodily restraint, I was restrained by the bodily door’s restraint,

original: saṃvuto ahosiṃ. Vācāyāsimasaññatoti vācāya asaññato vācasikena asaṃvarena samannāgato🔽ahosiṃ. Tenāti tena ubhayena saṃyamena asaṃyamena ca. Meti mayhaṃ. Etādiso vaṇṇoti
analyzed: saṃvutaḥ ahosim vācāya asim asaññato ti vācāya asaññataḥ vācasikena asaṃvarena samannāgataḥ  ahosim tena ati tena ubhayena saṃyamena asaṃyamena ca mā iti mayham etādiso vaṇṇoti
translated: I was restrained by the bodily door’s restraint. I was unrestrained in speech means I was unrestrained in speech, I was unrestrained by verbal restraint,

original: ediso. Yathā tvaṃ, nārada, paccakkhato passasi, evarūpo, kāyena manussasaṇṭhāno suvaṇṇavaṇṇo,
analyzed: edisaḥ yathā tvam nārada paccakkhataḥ passasi evarūpaḥ kāyena manussa saṇṭhānaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ
translated: I was unrestrained by the verbal door’s restraint. Therefore means because of both the restraint and the lack of restraint. Me means my. I have such a complexion as you see, Nārada means I have such a complexion as you see with your own eyes, Nārada. I was of human shape in body, golden-hued,

original: mukhena sūkarasadiso āsinti yojanā. Vaṇṇasaddo hi idha chaviyaṃ saṇṭhāne ca daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: mukhena sūkara sadisaḥ āsin ti yojanā vaṇṇa saddo hi idha chaviyam saṇṭhāne ca daṭṭhabbo
translated: but my face was like a pig’s. The word complexion should be understood here as referring to skin and shape.

original: Evaṃ peto therena pucchito tamatthaṃ vissajjetvā tameva kāraṇaṃ katvā therassa ovādaṃ dento –
analyzed: evam petaḥ therena pucchito tam attham vissajjetvā tam eva kāraṇam katvā therassa ovādam dentaḥ
translated: When the departed one had thus replied to the Elder’s question, he gave him advice, making that very reason the subject.

original: “Taṃ tyāhaṃ nārada brūmi, sāmaṃ diṭṭhamidaṃ tayā;
analyzed: tam tyā aham nārada brūmi sāmam diṭṭham idam tayā
translated: “I tell you this, Nārada, you have seen it with your own eyes;

original: Mākāsi mukhasā pāpaṃ, mā kho sūkaramukho ahū”ti. –🔽Gāthamāha. Tattha tanti tasmā. Tyāhanti te ahaṃ. Nāradāti theraṃ ālapati. Brūmīti
analyzed: mā akāsi mukhasā pāpam mā khalu sūkara mukhaḥ  gātham āha te aham ālapati brūmi iti
translated: Do not do evil with your mouth, do not become one with a pig’s face.”

original: kathemi. Sāmanti sayameva. Idanti attano sarīraṃ sandhāya vadati. Ayañhettha attho
analyzed: kathemi sāman ti sayam eva idam ti attanaḥ sarīram sandhāya vadati ayam ha ittha atthaḥ

original: chavivaṇṇaṃ. Dhāresīti vahasi. Vehāyasaṃ tiṭṭhasi antalikkheti vehāyasasaññite antalikkhe🔽tiṭṭhasi. Keci pana “vihāyasaṃ tiṭṭhasi antalikkhe”ti pāṭhaṃ vatvā vihāyasaṃ obhāsento
analyzed: chavi vaṇṇam dhāresi iti vahasi vehāyasam tiṭṭhasi antalikkha iti vehāyasa saññite antalikkhe  tiṭṭhasi keci pana vihāyasam tiṭṭhasi antalikkha iti pāṭham vatvā vihāyasam obhāsento
translated: “You are of the colour of a corpse.” “You bear” means you carry. “You stand in the sky” means you stand in the sky which is called the “sky.”

original: antalikkhe tiṭṭhasīti vacanasesena atthaṃ vadanti. Pūtigandhanti kuṇapagandhaṃ, duggandhanti🔽attho. Kiṃ kammamakāsi pubbeti paramaduggandhaṃ te mukhaṃ kimayo khādanti, kāyo ca
analyzed: antalikkhe tiṭṭhasi iti vacana sesena attham vadanti pūti gandhanti kuṇapa gandham duggandhanti  attho kim kammam akāsi pubbā iti parama duggandham te mukham khādanti ca
translated: But some, having stated the reading “vihāyasaṃ tiṭṭhasi antalikkhe,” explain the meaning by the expression “you stand in the sky which is called the ‘sky.’”

original: suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, kīdisaṃ nāma kammaṃ evarūpassa attabhāvassa kāraṇabhūtaṃ pubbe tvaṃ akāsīti pucchi.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ kīdisam nāma kammam evarūpassa atta bhāvassa kāraṇa bhūtam pubbe tvam akāsi iti pucchi
translated: “You have a foul smell” means you have the smell of a corpse, the meaning is you have a bad smell. “What deed did you do in the past?” means what kind of deed did you do in the past that was the cause for your having such a body?

original: Evaṃ therena so peto attanā katakammaṃ puṭṭho tamatthaṃ vissajjento –
analyzed: evam therena saḥ petaḥ attanā kata kammam puṭṭhaḥ tam attham vissajjentaḥ
translated: Thus, having been asked by the Elder about the deed he had done, he, in explaining the matter, said:

original: “Samaṇo ahaṃ pāpotiduṭṭhavāco, tapassirūpo mukhasā asaññato;
analyzed: samaṇaḥ aham tapassi rūpaḥ mukhasā asaññataḥ
translated: “I was a monk, a slanderer, a bad speaker, a hypocrite,

original: Laddhā ca me tamasā vaṇṇadhātu, mukhañca me pesuṇiyena pūtī”ti. –
analyzed: laddhā ca me tamasā vaṇṇa dhātu mukham ca me pesuṇiyena pūti iti
translated: and having obtained that complexion of darkness, my mouth was made foul by slander.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha samaṇo ahaṃ pāpoti ahaṃ lāmako samaṇo pāpabhikkhu ahosiṃ. Atiduṭṭhavācoti
analyzed: gātham āha tattha samaṇaḥ aham pāpo ti aham lāmako samaṇo pāpa bhikkhu ahosim ati duṭṭha vācā iti
translated: Herein, I was a monk, I was a monk who had gone forth, I was a bad monk. I was a man of very bad speech:

original: atiduṭṭhavacano, pare atikkamitvā laṅghitvā vattā, paresaṃ guṇaparidhaṃsakavacanoti
analyzed: ati duṭṭha vacano pare atikkamitvā laṅghitvā vattā paresam guṇa paridhaṃsaka vacanaḥ ti
translated: he was a man of very bad speech, he spoke transgressing and overstepping others, he was a man who spoke disparagingly of others’ virtues.

original: attho. “Atidukkhavāco”ti vā pāṭho, ativiya pharusavacano musāvādapesuññādivacīduccaritanirato.🔽Tapassirūpoti samaṇapatirūpako. Mukhasāti mukhena. Laddhāti paṭiladdhā. Ca-kāro sampiṇḍanattho.
analyzed: atthaḥ ati dukkha vācaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ ati viya pharusa vacanaḥ musāvāda pesuñña ādi vacī duccarita nirataḥ  tapassi rūpaḥ ti samaṇa pati rūpakaḥ mukhasā ati mukhena laddhā ati paṭiladdhā cakāro sampiṇḍana ttho
translated: The meaning is: or the reading is atidukkhavāco, he was a man of very harsh speech, devoted to verbal misconduct such as lying and slander.🔽Ascetic in form: he was a mere semblance of an ascetic. With my mouth: with my mouth. I obtained: I received. The ca-syllable has the meaning of inclusion.

original: Meti mayā. Tapasāti brahmacariyena. Pesuṇiyenāti pisuṇavācāya. Putīti pūtigandhaṃ.
analyzed: mā iti mayā tapasā ati brahmacariyena pesuṇiyena ati pisuṇa vācāya puti iti pūti gandham
translated: Me: by me. Ascetic: by the life of chastity. By slander: by slanderous speech. Putrid: stinking.

original: Evaṃ so peto attanā katakammaṃ ācikkhitvā idāni therassa ovādaṃ dento –
analyzed: evam saḥ petaḥ attanā kata kammam ācikkhitvā idāni therassa ovādam dentaḥ
translated: Thus, having described the deed he had done, he now gave advice to the Elder:

original: “Tayidaṃ tayā nārada sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: tayā idam tayā nārada sāmam diṭṭham
translated: “This, indeed, you have seen, Nārada,

original: Anukampakā ye kusalā vadeyyuṃ;
analyzed: anukampakāḥ ye kusalāḥ vadeyyum
translated: Those who are compassionate would speak of what is skillful;

original: Mā pesuṇaṃ mā ca musā abhāṇi,
analyzed: mā pesuṇam mā ca musā abhāṇi
translated: Do not slander, do not speak falsely,

original: Yakkho tuvaṃ hohisi kāmakāmī”ti. –
analyzed: yakkhaḥ tuvam hohisi kāma kāmī iti
translated: You will become a yakkha, one who desires sense pleasures.”

original: Osānagāthamāha. Tattha tayidanti taṃ idaṃ mama rūpaṃ. Anukampakā ye kusalā vadeyyunti
analyzed: osāna gātham āha tattha tam idam mama rūpam anukampakāḥ ye kusalāḥ
translated: Herein, “what the compassionate, the skilled would say” means

original: ye anukampanasīlā kāruṇikā parahitapaṭipattiyaṃ kusalā nipuṇā buddhādayo yaṃ vadeyyuṃ,
analyzed: ye anukampana sīlā kāruṇikā para hita paṭipattiyam kusalāḥ nipuṇāḥ buddha ādayaḥ yam vadeyyuṃ
translated: what the compassionate, the merciful, the skilled, the clever Buddhas and so forth would say,

original: tadeva vadāmīti adhippāyo. Idāni taṃ ovādaṃ dassento “mā pesuṇaṃ mā ca musā abhāṇi,
analyzed: tat eva vadāmi iti adhippāyaḥ idāni tam ovādam dassentaḥ mā pesuṇam mā ca musā abhāṇi
translated: I say that, I do not say what is otherwise, is the meaning. Now, showing that advice, he said: “Do not slander, do not speak falsely,

original: yakkho tuvaṃ hohisi kāmakāmī”ti āha. Tassattho – pesuṇaṃ pisuṇavacanaṃ musā ca mā
analyzed: yakkho tuvam hohisi kāma kāmī iti āha tassa atthaḥ pesuṇam pisuṇa vacanam musā ca mā
translated: you will become a yakkha, one who desires sensual pleasures.”🔽Its meaning is this: Do not slander, do not speak falsely.

original: abhāṇi mā kathehi. Yadi hi tvaṃ musāvādaṃ pisuṇavācañca pahāya vācāya saññato bhaveyyāsi,
analyzed: abhāṇi mā kathehi yadi hi tvam musā vādam pisuṇa vācam ca pahāya vācāya saññataḥ bhaveyyāsi
translated: If you, abandoning false speech and slanderous speech, were to be restrained in speech,🔽you will become a yakkha, a god, or a deva. Desiring sensual pleasures,

original: yakkho vā devo vā devaññataro vā tvaṃ bhavissasi, kāmaṃ kāmitabbaṃ uḷāraṃ dibbasampattiṃ
analyzed: yakkhaḥ vā devaḥ vā devaññataraḥ vā tvam bhavissasi kāmam kāmitabbam uḷāram dibba sampattim
translated: obtaining the excellent divine fortune,

original: paṭilabhitvā tattha kāmanasīlo yathāsukhaṃ indriyānaṃ paricaraṇena abhiramaṇasīloti.
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā kāmana sīlaḥ yathāsukham paricaraṇena abhiramaṇa sīlaḥ ti
translated: you will become one who delights in the enjoyment of sensual pleasures, one who delights in the enjoyment of the faculties by way of doing as one pleases.🔽Having heard that, the Elder, having gone to Rājagaha, having gone for alms, after returning from almsround,

original: Taṃ sutvā thero tato rājagahaṃ gantvā piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto
analyzed: tam sutvā theraḥ tatas rājagaham gantvā piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto
translated: after his meal, having set his dwelling in order,

original: satthu tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Satthā taṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā dhammaṃ desesi. Sā desanā
analyzed: satthu tam attham ārocesi satthā tam aṭṭhuppattim katvā dhammam desesi sā desanā
translated: The Teacher related the incident to the monks. The Teacher expounded the Law,

original: sampattaparisāya sātthikā ahosīti.🔽Pūtimukhapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sampatta parisāya sātthikā ahosi iti  pūtimukha peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: and the discourse was profitable unto the multitude of hearers.🔽The story of the Ghost with the Putrid Face is finished.

original: 4. Piṭṭhadhītalikapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Ghost that had been a Carrier of Heavy Burdens on his Head

original: Yaṃ kiñcārammaṇaṃ katvāti idaṃ satthā sāvatthiyaṃ jetavane viharanto anāthapiṇḍikassa🔽gahapatino dānaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Anāthapiṇḍikassa kira gahapatino dhītu dhītāya
analyzed: yam kiñca ārammaṇam katvā ati idam satthā sāvatthiyam jetavane viharantaḥ anāthapiṇḍikassa  gahapatino dānam ārabbha kathesi anāthapiṇḍikassa kira gahapatino dhītu dhītāya
translated: Now when a man has any object in view, this story was told by the Master while he was in residence at Jetavana about Anāthapiṇḍika the treasurer.🔽Anāthapiṇḍika the treasurer had a daughter, and this daughter had a daughter of her own.🔽The nurse gave the child a doll, saying, “Here, take this and play with it.”

original: dārikāya dhāti piṭṭhadhītalikaṃ adāsi “ayaṃ te dhītā, imaṃ gahetvā kīḷassū”ti. Sā
analyzed: dārikāya dhāti piṭṭhadhītalikam adāsi ayam te dhītā imam gahetvā kīḷassu iti sā
translated: The child conceived the idea that the doll was her own child.

original: tattha dhītusaññaṃ uppādesi. Athassā ekadivasaṃ taṃ gahetvā kīḷantiyā pamādena patitvā
analyzed: tattha dhītu saññam uppādesi athassāḥ eka divasam tam gahetvā kīḷantiyā pamādena patitvā
translated: One day as she was playing with it, she dropped it and broke it.

original: bhijji. Tato dārikā “mama dhītā matā”ti parodi. Taṃ rodantiṃ kocipi gehajano saññāpetuṃ
analyzed: bhijji tatas dārikā mama dhītā matā ati parodi tam rodantim koci pi geha jano saññāpetuṃ
translated: Then the child began to cry, saying, “My child is dead.” No one in the house was able to console her.

original: nāsakkhi. Tasmiñca samaye satthā anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatino gehe paññatte āsane
analyzed: na asakkhi tasmin ca samaye satthā anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatino gehe paññatte āsane
translated: Now at this time the Master was seated in the house of Anāthapiṇḍika the treasurer,

original: nisinno hoti, mahāseṭṭhi ca bhagavato samīpe nisinno ahosi. Dhāti taṃ dārikaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: nisinnaḥ hoti mahāseṭṭhi ca bhagavato samīpe nisinnaḥ ahosi dhāti tam dārikam gahetvā
translated: and the Great Steward was sitting near the Fortunate One. The nurse took the girl

original: seṭṭhissa santikaṃ agamāsi. Seṭṭhi taṃ disvā “kissāyaṃ dārikā rodatī”ti āha. Dhāti🔽taṃ pavattiṃ seṭṭhissa ārocesi. Seṭṭhi taṃ dārikaṃ aṅke nisīdāpetvā “tava dhītudānaṃ🔽dassāmī”ti saññāpetvā satthu ārocesi – “bhante, mama nattudhītaraṃ piṭṭhadhītalikaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭhissa santikam agamāsi seṭṭhi tam disvā kissa ayam dārikā rodati iti āha dhāti  tam pavattim seṭṭhissa ārocesi seṭṭhi tam dārikam aṅke nisīdāpetvā tava dhītu dānam  dassāmi iti saññāpetvā satthu ārocesi bhante mama nattudhītaram piṭṭhadhītalikam
translated: and went to the Steward. The Steward, after seeing her, said: “Why is this girl crying?” The nurse

original: uddissa dānaṃ dātukāmo, taṃ me pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ svātanāya adhivāsethā”ti.
analyzed: uddissa dānam dātu kāmo tam me pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim svātanāya adhivāsetha ati
translated: told the Steward the reason. The Steward, after placing the girl on his lap, after making her understand: “I will give a gift for your daughter,” he informed the Teacher, (saying): “Venerable Sir, I wish to give a gift for my daughter who is a baby girl, please accept it with five hundred monks for tomorrow’s meal.”

original: Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
analyzed: adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena
translated: The Fortunate One accepted by remaining silent.

original: Atha bhagavā dutiyadivase pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ seṭṭhissa gharaṃ gantvā bhattakiccaṃ katvā anumodanaṃ karonto –
analyzed: atha bhagavā dutiya divase pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim seṭṭhissa gharam gantvā bhatta kiccam katvā anumodanam karontaḥ
translated: Then the Fortunate One, after going to the Steward’s house with five hundred monks on the second day, after completing the meal, while making the declaration of rejoicing, (said):

original: “Yaṃ kiñcārammaṇaṃ katvā, dajjā dānaṃ amaccharī;
analyzed: yam kiñca ārammaṇam katvā dajjā dānam amaccharī
translated: “Having made any object, one should give a gift without stinginess;

original: Pubbapete ca ārabbha, atha vā vatthudevatā.
analyzed: pubba pete ca ārabbha atha vā vatthu devatā
translated: Or having made the ancestors, or the gods of the place.

original: “Cattāro ca mahārāje, lokapāle yasassine;
analyzed: cattāraḥ ca mahā rāje lokapāle yasassine
translated: “And the four great kings, the world’s guardians, glorious,

original: Kuveraṃ dhataraṭṭhañca, virūpakkhaṃ virūḷhakaṃ;
analyzed: kuveram dhataraṭṭham ca virūpakkham virūḍhakam
translated: Kuvera, Dhataraṭṭha, Virūpakkha, Virūḷhaka,

original: Te ceva pūjitā honti, dāyakā ca anipphalā.
analyzed: te ca iva pūjitāḥ honti dāyakā ca anipphalā
translated: They too are worshipped, and the givers are not barren.

original: “Na hi ruṇṇaṃ vā soko vā, yā caññā paridevanā;
analyzed: na hi ruṇṇam vā sokaḥ vā yā caññā paridevanā
translated: “For neither weeping nor sorrow, nor any other lamentation,

original: Na taṃ petassa atthāya, evaṃ tiṭṭhanti ñātayo.
analyzed: na tam petassa atthāya evam tiṭṭhanti ñātayaḥ
translated: Are of any use to the dead, so relatives stand by.

original: “Ayañca kho dakkhiṇā dinnā, saṅghamhi suppatiṭṭhitā;
analyzed: ayañca kho dakkhiṇā dinnā saṅghamhi su patiṭṭhitā
translated: “And this gift given, well established in the Community,

original: Dīgharattaṃ hitāyassa, ṭhānaso upakappatī”ti. – imā gāthā abhāsi;
analyzed: dīgharattam hitāyassa ṭhānasaḥ upakappati iti imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: Is for the long-lasting benefit of the dead, it helps as it stands.”

original: 10. Tattha yaṃ kiñcārammaṇaṃ katvāti maṅgalādīsu aññataraṃ yaṃ kiñci ārabbha uddissa.🔽Dajjāti dadeyya. Amaccharīti attano sampattiyā parehi sādhāraṇabhāvāsahanalakkhaṇassa🔽maccherassa abhāvato amaccharī, pariccāgasīlo macchariyalobhādicittamalaṃ dūrato
analyzed: tattha yam kiñca ārammaṇam katvā iti maṅgala ādīsu aññataram yam kiñci ārabbha uddissa  dajjāti dadeyya amacchari iti attanaḥ sampattiyā parehi sādhāraṇa bhāva a sahana lakkhaṇassa  maccherassa abhāvataḥ a maccharī pariccāga sīlaḥ macchariya lobha ādi citta malam dūratas
translated: Herein, with regard to any object whatever means with regard to any one of the good omens, etc., which is the reason.🔽He should give is he should give a gift. Not grudging is the meaning.🔽The intention is that he should give a gift without the stain of stinginess in his mind, which is characterized by inability to share one’s own good fortune with others, and which is the opposite of generosity.

original: katvā dānaṃ dadeyyāti adhippāyo. Pubbapete ca ārabbhāti pubbakepi pete uddissa. Vatthudevatāti
analyzed: katvā dānam dadeyya āti adhippāyaḥ pubba pete ca ārabbha ati pubbake api pete uddissa vatthu devatā ti
translated: And with regard to the dead of old is with regard to the dead of the past too.

original: gharavatthuādīsu adhivatthā devatā ārabbhāti yojanā. Atha vāti iminā aññepi devamanussādike
analyzed: ghara vatthu ādīsu adhivatthāḥ devatāḥ ārabbhā ati yojanā atha vā iti iminā aññe pi deva manussa ādike
translated: The interpretation is that the deities who are the residents of the house, etc., are the ones referred to.

original: ye keci ārabbha dānaṃ dadeyyāti dasseti.
analyzed: ye keci ārabbha dānam dadeyya ati dassa iti
translated: Or else, by the words “or else” the Master shows that one may give gifts in the name of other deities as well, such as the gods, men, etc.

original: 11. Tattha devesu tāva ekacce pākaṭe deve dassento “cattāro ca mahārāje”ti vatvā
analyzed: tattha devesu tāva ekacce pākaṭe deve dassento cattāro ca mahā rāja iti vatvā
translated: Herein, showing some of the gods who are well known, he says “the Four Great Kings.”

original: puna te nāmato gaṇhanto “kuvera”ntiādimāha. Tattha kuveranti vessavaṇaṃ. Dhataraṭṭhantiādīni
analyzed: puna te nāmataḥ gaṇhantaḥ kuvera nti ādim āha tattha kuvera nti vessavaṇam dhataraṭṭha nti ādīni
translated: Then, taking them up by name, he says “Kuvera,” etc. Herein, Kuvera is Vessavaṇa. Dhataraṭṭha, etc.,🔽are the names of the other three world-protectors.

original: sesānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ lokapālānaṃ nāmāni. Te ceva pūjitā hontīti te ca mahārājāno pubbapetavatthudevatāyo
analyzed: sesānam tiṇṇam lokapālānam nāmāni te ca iva pūjitāḥ honti iti te ca mahā rājāno pubba peta vatthu devatāyo
translated: They are worshipped, and the deities of the previous-births story are honoured by the offering.

original: ca uddisanakiriyāya paṭimānikā honti. Dāyakā ca anipphalāti ye dānaṃ denti, te dāyakā
analyzed: ca uddisana kiriyāya paṭimānikāḥ honti dāyakā ca ye dānam denti te dāyakā
translated: And the givers are not without fruit. Those who give gifts, the givers,

original: ca paresaṃ uddisanamattena na nipphalā, attano dānaphalassa bhāgino eva honti.
analyzed: ca paresam uddisana mattena na nipphalāḥ attanaḥ dāna phalassa bhāginaḥ eva honti
translated: are not without fruit even by merely offering in the name of others; they themselves become partakers of the fruit of their own gifts.

original: 12. Idāni “ye attano ñātīnaṃ maraṇena rodanti paridevanti socanti, tesaṃ taṃ niratthakaṃ,
analyzed: idāni ye attanaḥ ñātīnam maraṇena rodanti paridevanti socanti tesam tam niratthakam
translated: Now, those who weep, wail, lament, and mourn over the death of their relatives, that is useless for them,

original: attaparitāpanamattamevā”ti dassetuṃ “na hi ruṇṇaṃ vā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha ruṇṇanti🔽ruditaṃ assumocanaṃ na hi kātabbanti vacanaseso. Sokoti socanaṃ cittasantāpo, antonijjhānanti🔽attho. Yā caññā paridevanāti yā ca ruṇṇasokato aññā paridevanā, “kahaṃ ekaputtakā”tiādivācāvippalāpo,🔽sopi na kātabboti attho. Sabbattha vā-saddo vikappanattho. Na taṃ petassa atthāyāti
analyzed: atta paritāpanam attam eva ati dassetum na hi ruṇṇam vā ti gātham āha tattha ruṇṇam ti  ruditam assumocanam na hi kātabbanti vacana seso soko ti socanam citta santāpaḥ antonijjhānanti  atthaḥ yā caññā paridevanā ati yā ca ruṇṇa sokataḥ aññā paridevanā kaham eka puttaka ati ādi vācā vippalāpo  saḥ api na kātabbaḥ iti atthaḥ sabbattha vā saddaḥ vikappana atthaḥ na tam petassa atthāya ati
translated: “It is only self-affliction.” To show this, he uttered the stanza, “For weeping and for wailing,” etc. Herein, weeping is crying, shedding tears, grieving; for: this should not be done is the remainder of the sentence. Sorrow is grieving, mental anguish; the meaning is, inward brooding. And all the other kinds of lamenting: and all the other kinds of lamenting apart from weeping and sorrow, the garrulousness of speech such as, “Where is my only son?” this too should not be done is the meaning. Or else, in every instance the word vā has the meaning of “alternatively.” It is not for the sake of the dead person:🔽

original: yasmā ruṇṇaṃ vā soko vā paridevanā vāti sabbampi taṃ petassa kālakatassa atthāya
analyzed: yasmā ruṇṇam vā sokaḥ vā paridevanā vāti sabbam pi tam petassa kālakatassa atthāya
translated: “It is only self-affliction.” To show this, he uttered the stanza, “For weeping and for mourning,” etc. Herein, weeping is crying, weeping, lamenting; for mourning, etc., is the remainder of the words. Sorrow is the sorrow of the mind, the burning of the mind. The meaning is, “the inward burning.” And for any other kind of wailing: any other kind of wailing than weeping and mourning is the garrulousness of speech such as “Where is my only son?” The meaning is, “that too should not be done.” Or else, in every instance the word vā has the meaning of “alternatively.” It is not for the sake of the dead: because weeping and mourning and wailing, all that is not for the sake of the dead,

original: upakārāya na hoti, tasmā na hi taṃ kātabbaṃ, tathāpi evaṃ tiṭṭhanti ñātayo aviddasunoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: upakārāya na hoti tasmā na hi tam kātabbam tathā api evam tiṭṭhanti ñātayaḥ a viddasuno ti adhippāyaḥ

analyzed: evam ruṇṇa ādīnam niratthaka bhāvam dassetvā idāni yā pubba peta ādike ārabbha dāyakena

analyzed: saṅghassa dakkhiṇā dinnā tassā sātthaka bhāvam dassento ayam ca kho dakkhiṇā iti gātham āha
translated: He said the verse “And this gift given to the Community” in order to show the profitable nature of the gift given to the Community.

original: Tattha ayanti dāyakena taṃ dinnaṃ dānaṃ paccakkhato dassento vadati. Ca-saddo byatirekattho,
analyzed: tattha ayanti dāyakena tam dinnam dānam paccakkhatas dassentaḥ vadati ca saddaḥ byatireka atthaḥ
translated: Herein, this is a gift given by a giver, he said, showing it by himself. The word and is in the sense of a conjunction.

analyzed: tena yathā ruṇṇa ādi petassa na kassaci atthāya hoti na evam ayam ayam pana dakkhiṇā
translated: By means of that he shows the distinction that is about to be stated, namely, that this gift is not like the food, etc., of a dead man that is of no use to anyone, but that this gift

analyzed: dīgharattam hita āyassa hoti iti vakkhamānam eva visesam jotā iti kho ti avadhāraṇe dakkhiṇāti

analyzed: dānam saṅghamhi su patiṭṭhitā ati anuttare puñña kkhette saṅghe suṭṭhu patiṭṭhitā
