translated: as eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting. ‘When it is set out’ means when it is set out, prepared, ready to hand;

original: Na tesaṃ koci sarati sattānanti tesaṃ pettivisaye uppannānaṃ sattānaṃ koci mātā vā🔽pitā vā putto vā nattā vā na sarati. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Kammapaccayāti, attanā katassa adānadānapaṭisedhanādibhedassa
analyzed: na tesam koci sarati sattānam ti tesam petti visaye uppannānam sattānam koci mātā vā  pitā vā puttaḥ vā nattā vā na sarati kim kāraṇā kamma paccayā ati attanā katassa adāna dāna paṭisedhana ādi bhedassa
translated: ‘No one remembers any of them’ means that no mother, father, son, or grandson remembers them,

original: kadariyakammassa kāraṇabhāvato. Tañhi kammaṃ tesaṃ ñātīnaṃ sarituṃ na deti.
analyzed: kadariya kammassa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ tat hi kammam tesam ñātīnam saritum na deti
translated: because of the reason of kamma. For that kamma does not allow them to be remembered by their relatives.

original: 16. Evaṃ bhagavā anappakepi annapānādimhi vijjamāne ñātīnaṃ paccāsīsantānaṃ petānaṃ
analyzed: evam bhagavā anappake pi anna pāna ādimhi vijjamāne ñātīnam paccāsīsantānam petānam
translated: Thus the Blessed One, having shown how, even though there is no lack of food and drink, etc., for the departed relatives who are reborn in the ghost realm,🔽yet they are unable to eat or drink because of the absence of the condition for eating and drinking, namely, the thought of relatives,

original: kammaphalena ñātakānaṃ anussaraṇamattassāpi abhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni pettivisayupapanne
analyzed: kamma phalena ñātakānam anussaraṇa mattassa api abhāvam dassetvā idāni petti visaya upapanne
translated: now shows how, even though they are unable to remember their relatives,

original: ñātake uddissa raññā dinnadānaṃ pasaṃsanto “evaṃ dadanti ñātīna”nti tatiyagāthamāha.🔽Tattha evanti upamāvacanaṃ. Tassa dvidhā sambandho – tesaṃ sattānaṃ kammapaccayā🔽asarantesupi kesuci keci dadanti ñātīnaṃ, ye evaṃ anukampakā hontīti ca, mahārāja,
analyzed: ñātake uddissa raññā dinna dānam pasaṃsantaḥ evam dadanti ñātīnam ti tatiya gātham āha  tattha evam ti upamā vacanam tassa dvidhā sambandhaḥ tesam sattānam kamma paccayā  a sarantesu pi kesucid keci dadanti ñātīnam ye evam anukampakāḥ honti iti ca mahā rāja
translated: Praising the gift given by the King in honour of his kinsmen, he uttered the third stanza, “Thus do they give to kinsmen.”

original: yathā tayā dinnaṃ, evaṃ suciṃ paṇītaṃ kālena kappiyaṃ pānabhojanaṃ dadanti ñātīnaṃ,🔽ye honti anukampakāti ca. Tattha dadantīti denti uddisanti niyyātenti. Ñātīnanti🔽mātito ca pitito ca sambandhānaṃ. Yeti ye keci puttādayo. Hontīti bhavanti. Anukampakāti
analyzed: yathā tayā dinnam evam sucim paṇītam kālena kappiyam pāna bhojanam dadanti ñātīnam  ye honti anukampakā ati ca tattha dadanti iti denti uddisanti  ca pititaḥ ca ye iti ye keci putta ādayaḥ honti iti bhavanti anukampakāḥ ati
translated: Herein, thus is a term of comparison. It has a twofold application: in the first place, it applies to the beings who give; in the second place, it applies to the giving. The first application is as follows. It is because of the kamma of those beings that some give to some, even though they are not related, for some are compassionate. And the second application is as follows. They give to kinsmen thus, O King, in the way you give, with pure, excellent, timely, allowable food and drink,

original: atthakāmā hitesino. Sucinti suddhaṃ manoharaṃ dhammikañca. Paṇītanti uḷāraṃ. Kālenāti🔽dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ paribhogayoggakālena, ñātipetānaṃ vā tirokuṭṭādīsu āgantvā ṭhitakālena.
analyzed: attha kāmāḥ hita īsinaḥ sucinti suddham manoharam dhammikam ca paṇītam ti uḷāram kālena ati 🔽dakkhiṇeyyānam paribhoga yogga kālena ñāti petānam vā tiro kuṭṭa ādīsu āgantvā ṭhita kālena
translated: and they are compassionate. Herein, they give is they give, they dedicate, they assign. To kinsmen is to those related by birth or suckling. They are is they who are sons and so on. Compassionate is those who are desirous for their welfare, who are well-wishers. Pure is clean, delightful, righteous. Excellent is noble. Timely is at the time suitable for the enjoyment of those worthy of gifts, or at the time when kinsmen who have died come and stand within the threshold, and so on.

original: Kappiyanti anucchavikaṃ patirūpaṃ ariyānaṃ paribhogārahaṃ. Pānabhojananti pānañca
analyzed: anucchavikam patirūpam ariyānam paribhoga araham pāna bhojananti pānañca
translated: “What is proper” : what is suitable, fitting, worthy of being used by Noble Ones. “Drink and food” :

original: bhojanañca, tadupadesena cettha sabbaṃ deyyadhammaṃ vadati.🔽17. Idāni yena pakārena tesaṃ petānaṃ dinnaṃ nāma hoti, taṃ dassento “idaṃ vo ñātīnaṃ
analyzed: bhojanam ca tad upadesena ca ittha sabbam deyya dhammam vadati  idāni yena pakārena tesam petānam dinnam nāma hoti tam dassento idam vaḥ ñātīnam
translated: drink and food. By the mention of these he mentions all the requisites of a monk.

original: hotu, sukhitā hontu ñātayo”ti catutthagāthāya pubbaḍḍhaṃ āha. Taṃ tatiyagāthāya pubbaḍḍhena sambandhitabbaṃ –
analyzed: hotu sukhitāḥ hontu ñātayaḥ ti catuttha gāthāya pubbaḍḍham āha tam tatiya gāthāya pubbaḍḍhena sambandhitabbam
translated: Now, showing the manner in which it is given to the departed relatives, he says the first half of the fourth stanza, “This to your relatives, may it be for their well-being, may your relatives be happy.” This should be connected with the first half of the third stanza:

original: “Evaṃ dadanti ñātīnaṃ, ye honti anukampakā;
analyzed: evam dadanti ñātīnam ye honti anukampakā
translated: “Thus they give to their relatives, those who are compassionate.

original: Idaṃ vo ñātīnaṃ hotu, sukhitā hontu ñātayo”ti.🔽Tena “idaṃ vo ñātīnaṃ hotūti evaṃ pakārena dadanti, no aññathā”ti ākāratthena evaṃsaddena dātabbākāranidassanaṃ kataṃ hoti.
analyzed: idam vaḥ ñātīnam hotu sukhitāḥ hontu ñātayaḥ iti  tena idam vaḥ ñātīnam hotu uti evam pakārena dadanti no aññathā ti ākāra atthena evaṃsaddena dātabba ākāra nidassanam katam hoti
translated: This to your relatives, may it be for their well-being, may your relatives be happy.”🔽By the word “thus” in the sense of manner, the manner of giving is shown: “They give in this manner, not in any other.”

original: Tattha idanti deyyadhammanidassanaṃ. Voti nipātamattaṃ “yehi vo ariyā”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: tattha idam ti deyya dhamma nidassanam vaḥ ti nipāta mattam yehi vaḥ ariyāti ādīsu viya
translated: Herein, “this” shows the gift to be given. “To your” is a mere particle, like “to your Noble Ones” in the lines beginning “To your Noble Ones, to your kinsmen.”

original: Ñātīnaṃ hotūti pettivisaye uppannānaṃ ñātakānaṃ hotu. “No ñātīna”nti ca paṭhanti,
analyzed: ñātīnam hotu uti petti visaye uppannānam ñātakānam hotu no ñātīnam ti ca paṭhanti
translated: Some read “no ñātīna” .

original: amhākaṃ ñātīnanti attho. Sukhitā hontu ñātayoti te pettivisayūpapannā ñātayo idaṃ
analyzed: amhākam ñātīnam ti attho sukhitāḥ hontu ñātayaḥ ti te pettivisayu upapannāḥ ñātayaḥ idam
translated: The meaning is: “for our relatives.” May my relatives be happy: may those relatives who have been reborn in the ghost realm, experiencing this result,

original: phalaṃ paccanubhavantā sukhitā sukhappattā hontu.
analyzed: phalam paccanubhavantā sukhitā sukha ppattā hontu
translated: be happy, may they attain happiness.

original: Yasmā “idaṃ vo ñātīnaṃ hotū”ti vuttepi aññena katakammaṃ na aññassa phaladaṃ hoti,🔽kevalaṃ pana tathā uddissa dīyamānaṃ taṃ vatthu ñātipetānaṃ kusalakammassa paccayo
analyzed: yasmai idam vaḥ ñātīnam hotu uti vutte pi aññena kata kammam na aññassa phala dam hoti  kevalam pana tathā uddissa dīyamānam tat vatthu ñāti petānam kusala kammassa paccayaḥ
translated: Because when it is said, “May this be for your relatives,” the result of another’s kamma does not come to another,🔽but the object given in this way becomes a condition for the kamma of merit of the relatives who are ghosts.

original: hoti, tasmā yathā tesaṃ tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ tasmiṃyeva khaṇe phalanibbattakaṃ kusalakammaṃ
analyzed: hoti tasmai yathā tesam tasmim vatthusmim tasmin yeva khaṇe phala nibbattakam kusala kammam
translated: Therefore, showing how at that very moment when the object is given, the kamma of merit that produces the result

original: hoti, taṃ dassento “te ca tattho”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha teti ñātipetā. Tatthāti yattha dānaṃ dīyati, tattha. Samāgantvāti “ime no
analyzed: hoti tam dassento te ca tattha utiādim āha  tattha te iti ñāti petā tattha ati yattha dānam dīyati tattha samāgantvā iti ime no
translated: for them is done, he said, “And they, having come there,” etc.

original: ñātayo amhākaṃ atthāya dānaṃ uddisantī”ti anumodanatthaṃ tattha samāgatā hutvā. Pahūte
analyzed: ñātayaḥ amhākam atthāya dānam uddisanti iti anumodana attham tattha samāgatāḥ hutvā pahūte
translated: There, they means the relatives who are ghosts. There means where the gift is given. Having come there means having come there for the purpose of rejoicing, thinking, “Our relatives are dedicating a gift for our sake.”

original: annapānamhīti attano uddissa dīyamāne tasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ. Sakkaccaṃ anumodareti kammaphalaṃ🔽abhisaddahantā cittīkāraṃ avijahantā avikkhittacittā hutvā “idaṃ no dānaṃ hitāya
analyzed: anna pānamhi iti attanaḥ uddissa dīyamāne tasmin vatthusmin sakkaccam kamma phalam  abhisaddahantā cittīkāram a vijahantā a vikkhitta cittā hutvā idam naḥ dānam hitāya
translated: In the food and drink: in that object given for his sake.

original: sukhāya hotū”ti modanti anumodanti pītisomanassajātā honti.
analyzed: sukhāya hotu uti modanti anumodanti pīti somanassa jātāḥ honti
translated: They rejoice with a pure heart: they rejoice, they are glad, they are full of joy, thinking, “May this gift of ours be for the welfare and happiness of all beings,” having faith in kamma and its results and being free from doubt and distraction.🔽May they live long: may they be long-lived, may they have a long life span.

original: 18. Ciraṃ jīvantūti ciraṃ jīvino dīghāyukā hontu. No ñātīti amhākaṃ ñātakā. Yesaṃ
analyzed: ciram jīvantu uti ciram jīvinaḥ dīgha āyukāḥ hontu naḥ ñātī iti amhākam ñātakāḥ
translated: Our relatives: our kinsmen.🔽For whose sake: for whose reason, for whose cause.

original: hetūti yesaṃ kāraṇā ye nissāya. Labhāmaseti īdisaṃ sampattiṃ paṭilabhāma. Idañhi🔽uddisanena laddhasampattiṃ anubhavantānaṃ petānaṃ attano ñātīnaṃ thomanākāradassanaṃ.🔽Petānañhi attano anumodanena, dāyakānaṃ uddisanena, ukkhiṇeyyasampattiyā cāti tīhi
analyzed: hetū ti yesam kāraṇāḥ ye nissāya labhāmase iti īdisam sampattim paṭilabhāmaḥ idam hi  uddisanena laddha sampattim anubhavantānam petānam attanaḥ ñātīnam thomana ākāra dassanam  petānam hi attanaḥ anumodanena dāyakānam uddisanena ukkhiṇeyya sampattiyā ca ati tīhi
translated: We have received: we have obtained such prosperity.🔽For this is the way the ancestors see the prosperity they have received through the dedication.🔽For the ancestors’ rejoicing in it, the donors’ dedication of it, and the prosperity of the gift are the three factors that cause the gift to produce results immediately.

original: aṅgehi dakkhiṇā taṅkhaṇaññeva phalanibbattikā hoti. Tattha dāyakā visesahetu. Tenāha
analyzed: aṅgehi dakkhiṇā phala nibbattikā hoti tattha dāyakā visesa hetu tena āha
translated: Here the donors are the special cause. Hence it is said:

original: “yesaṃ hetu labhāmase”ti. Amhākañca katā pūjāti “idaṃ vo ñātīnaṃ hotū”ti evaṃ uddisantehi
analyzed: hetu labhāmase iti amhākam ca katā pūjā ati idam vaḥ ñātīnam hotu iti evam uddisanta hi
translated: “And worship has been done for us” means that the givers have announced it thus: “Let this be for our relatives and friends.”

original: dāyakehi amhākañca pūjā katā, te dāyakā ca anipphalā yasmiṃ santāne pariccāgamayaṃ
analyzed: dāyakehi amhākam ca pūjā katā te dāyakā ca a nipphalā yasmin santāne pariccāgamayam
translated: And those givers are not disappointed, since the deed of giving that has arisen in that continuity

original: kammaṃ nibbattaṃ tassa tattheva phaladānato.
analyzed: kammam nibbattam tassa tattha iva phala dānato
translated: gives its fruit there itself.🔽Here it may be asked: But do only relatives reborn in the ghost realm get the things given by reason of them, or others as well?

original: Etthāha – “kiṃ pana pettivisayūpapannā eva ñātī hetusampattiyo labhanti, udāhu aññepī”ti? Na cettha amhehi vattabbaṃ, atthi bhagavatā evaṃ byākatattā. Vuttañhetaṃ –-🔽“Mayamassu, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā nāma dānāni dema, puññāni karoma ‘idaṃ dānaṃ petānaṃ
analyzed: ettha āha kim pana petti visaya upapannāḥ eva ñātī hetu sampattiyaḥ labhanti udāhu aññe pi iti na ca ittha amhehi vattabbam atthi bhagavatā evam byākata ttā vuttam ha etam  bho gotama brāhmaṇāḥ nāma dānāni dema puññāni karoma idam dānam petānam
translated: For this is not something that we can say, since it has been stated by the Blessed One. For this is said:

original: ñātisālohitānaṃ upakappatu, idaṃ dānaṃ petā ñātisālohitā paribhuñjantū’ti. Kacci
analyzed: ñāti sālohitānam upakappatu idam dānam petāḥ ñāti sālohitā paribhuñjantu uti kacci
translated: “We, Reverend Gotama, are called brahmans. We give gifts and make merit, thinking: ‘Let this gift be for our relatives and friends who have passed away and departed this life.’🔽Do those relatives and friends who have passed away and departed this life

original: taṃ, bho gotama, dānaṃ petānaṃ ñātisālohitānaṃ upakappati, kacci te petā ñātisālohitā
analyzed: tam bho gotama dānam petānam ñāti sālohitānam upakappati kacci te petāḥ ñāti sālohitā
translated: benefit by that gift?”

original: taṃ dānaṃ paribhuñjantīti? Ṭhāne kho, brāhmaṇa, upakappati, no aṭṭhāneti.
analyzed: tam dānam paribhuñjanti iti ṭhāne kho brāhmaṇaḥ upakappati no aṭṭhāne ti
translated: “But, Master Gotama, does that gift benefit him when he is enjoying the fruits of a lower realm?” “It does, brahmin, if he is in a place where it is useful, not if he is in a place where it is not useful.”

original: “Katamaṃ pana, bho gotama, ṭhānaṃ, katamaṃ aṭṭhānanti? Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco pāṇātipātī🔽hoti…pe… micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā nirayaṃ upapajjati. Yo
analyzed: katamam pana bho gotama ṭhānam katamam aṭṭhānam ti idha brāhmaṇaḥ ekacco pāṇātipātī  hoti pe micchādiṭṭhikaḥ hoti so kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā nirayam upapajjati yaḥ
translated: “But, Master Gotama, what is a place where it is useful, and what is a place where it is not useful?” “Here, brahmin, someone is a killer of living beings,🔽he is a taker of what is not given, he is a misuser of sexual activity, he is a speaker of what is false, he is a backbiter, he is a harsh speaker, he is a chatterer, he is covetous, he is malevolent, he has wrong view. On the dissolution of the body, after death, he reappears in hell.

original: nerayikānaṃ sattānaṃ āhāro, tena so tattha yāpeti, tena so tattha tiṭṭhati. Idaṃ
analyzed: nerayikānam sattānam āhāro tena so tattha yāpeti tena saḥ tattha tiṭṭhati idam
translated: There he subsists on the food of hell,

original: kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ, yattha ṭhitassa taṃ dānaṃ na upakappati.🔽“Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti…pe… micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, so kāyassa
analyzed: kho brāhmaṇa aṭṭhānam yattha ṭhitassa tam dānam na upakappati  idha pana brāhmaṇaḥ ekaccaḥ pāṇa atipātī hoti pe micchādiṭṭhikaḥ hoti saḥ kāyassa
translated: that is where he is useful. That is a place where it is not useful to give a gift to someone.🔽“Here, brahmin, someone is a killer of living beings…he has wrong view. On the dissolution of the body, after death, he reappears in an animal womb.

original: bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṃ upapajjati. Yo tiracchānayonikānaṃ sattānaṃ āhāro,🔽tena so tattha yāpeti, tena so tattha tiṭṭhati. Idampi kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ, yattha
analyzed: bhedā param maraṇā tiracchānayonim upapajjati yaḥ tiracchānayonikānam sattānam āhāraḥ  tena saḥ tattha yāpeti tena saḥ tattha tiṭṭhati idam api kho brāhmaṇa aṭṭhānam yattha
translated: There he subsists on the food of animals,

original: ṭhitassa taṃ dānaṃ na upakappati.
analyzed: ṭhitassa tat dānam na upakappati
translated: that is where he is useful. That is a place where it is not useful to give a gift to someone.

original: “Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti…pe… sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, so
analyzed: idha pana brāhmaṇaḥ ekaccaḥ pāṇātipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti pe sammādiṭṭhikaḥ hoti so
translated: “There is the case where a certain person abstains from killing living beings, abstains from taking what is not given, abstains from misconduct in sensual pleasures, abstains from false speech, abstains from wine, liquor, & intoxicants, which are the basis of negligence. He has right view, not wrong view.

original: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati…pe… devānaṃ sahabyataṃ
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā manussānam sahabyatam upapajjati pe devānam sahabyatam
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in companionship with human beings.

original: upapajjati. Yo devānaṃ āhāro, tena so tattha yāpeti, tena so tattha tiṭṭhati. Idampi
analyzed: upapajjati yaḥ devānam āhāro tena so tattha yāpeti tena so tattha tiṭṭhati idam pi
translated: He eats the food of humans, drinks the drinks of humans, wears the clothes of humans, & makes use of the bedding of humans. This is the food by which he subsists, by which he lives.

original: kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ, yattha ṭhitassa taṃ dānaṃ na upakappati.🔽“Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco pāṇātipātī hoti…pe… micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, so kāyassa🔽bhedā paraṃ maraṇā pettivisayaṃ upapajjati. Yo pettivisayikānaṃ sattānaṃ āhāro, tena🔽so tattha yāpeti, tena so tattha tiṭṭhati. Yaṃ vā panassa ito anupavecchenti mittāmaccā🔽vā ñātisālohitā vā, tena so tattha yāpeti, tena so tattha tiṭṭhati. Idaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa,
analyzed: kho brāhmaṇa aṭṭhānam yattha ṭhitassa tam dānam na upakappati 🔽idha pana brāhmaṇaḥ ekaccaḥ pāṇa atipātī hoti pe micchādiṭṭhikaḥ hoti saḥ kāyassa 🔽bhedā param maraṇā petti visayam upapajjati yaḥ petti visayikānam sattānam āhāro tena 🔽so tattha yāpeti tena saḥ tattha tiṭṭhati yam vā panassaḥ itas anupavecchenti mitta amaccā 🔽vā ñātisālohitā vā tena saḥ tattha yāpeti tena saḥ tattha tiṭṭhati idam kho brāhmaṇa
translated: This is the other instance where one does not receive almsfood without having made it available.

original: ṭhānaṃ, yattha ṭhitassa taṃ dānaṃ upakappatī”ti.
analyzed: ṭhānam yattha ṭhitassa tam dānam upakappati iti
translated: where it would be of benefit to him.”

original: “Sace pana, bho gotama, so peto ñātisālohito taṃ ṭhānaṃ anupapanno hoti, ko taṃ dānaṃ🔽paribhuñjatī”ti? “Aññepissa, brāhmaṇa, petā ñātisālohitā taṃ ṭhānaṃ upapannā honti,
analyzed: sace pana bho gotama saḥ petaḥ ñāti sālohito tam ṭhānam anupapannaḥ hoti kaḥ tam dānam  paribhuñjati iti aññe pissa brāhmaṇa petā ñāti sālohitā tam ṭhānam upapannā honti
translated: “But if that departed relative has not been reborn in that place,

original: te taṃ dānaṃ paribhuñjantī”ti.
analyzed: te tam dānam paribhuñjanti iti
translated: who then enjoys that offering?”🔽“Other departed relatives and family members who have been reborn there🔽will enjoy it.”

original: “Sace pana, bho gotama, so ceva peto ñātisālohito taṃ ṭhānaṃ anupapanno hoti, aññepissa
analyzed: sace pana bho gotama saḥ ca iva petaḥ ñāti sālohito tam ṭhānam anupapannaḥ hoti aññepissa
translated: “But if that departed relative has not been reborn there, nor any other departed relatives and family members,

original: petā ñātisālohitā taṃ ṭhānaṃ anupapannā honti, ko taṃ dānaṃ paribhuñjatī”ti? “Aṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: petāḥ ñāti sālohitā tam ṭhānam anupapannāḥ honti kaḥ tam dānam paribhuñjati iti aṭṭhānam
translated: who then enjoys that offering?”🔽“It’s impossible, brahmin, it cannot happen that that place would be empty of departed relatives and family members.

original: kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anavakāso, yaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ vivittaṃ assa iminā dīghena addhunā
analyzed: kho etam brāhmaṇa anavakāsaḥ yat tam ṭhānam vivittam assa iminā dīghena addhunā
translated: For a long time, brahmin, that place will not be empty of departed relatives and family members.

original: yadidaṃ petehi ñātisālohitehi, apica, brāhmaṇa, dāyakopi anipphalo”ti.
analyzed: yat idam petehi ñāti sālohitehi apica brāhmaṇa dāyakaḥ api
translated: And the donor too will not be without reward.”

original: 19. Idāni pettivisayūpapannānaṃ tattha aññassa kasigorakkhādino sampattipaṭilābhakāraṇassa abhāvaṃ ito dinnena yāpanañca dassetuṃ “na hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni petti visaya upapannānam tattha aññassa kasi gorakkha ādino sampatti paṭilābha kāraṇassa abhāvam itas dinnena yāpanam ca dassetum na hi itiādi vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show that there is no other means of acquiring prosperity there, such as agriculture, cattle-tending, etc., and that they live on what is given here, the following tetrad is stated.

original: Tattha na hi tattha kasi atthīti tasmiṃ pettivisaye kasi na hi atthi, yaṃ nissāya🔽petā sukhena jīveyyuṃ. Gorakkhettha na vijjatīti ettha pettivisaye na kevalaṃ kasiyeva
analyzed: tattha na hi tattha kasi atthi iti tasmin petti visaye kasi na hi atthi yam nissāya  sukhena jīveyyum gorakkhā ittha na vijjati iti ettha petti visaye na kevalam kasiyā iva
translated: There is no agriculture there, by which🔽the ghosts could live happily. Cattle-tending is not found there.

original: natthi, atha kho gorakkhāpi na vijjati, yaṃ nissāya te sukhena jīveyyuṃ. Vaṇijjā🔽tādisī natthīti vaṇijjāpi tādisī natthi, yā tesaṃ sampattipaṭilābhahetu bhaveyya.
analyzed: natthi atha kho gorakkhā api na vijjati yam nissāya te sukhena jīveyyum vaṇijjā  tādisī natthi iti vaṇijjā api tādisī natthi yā tesam sampatti paṭilābha hetu bhaveyya
translated: Not only is there no agriculture there, but cattle-tending is also not found there, by which they could live happily.🔽There is no such trade, which could be the cause of their acquiring prosperity.

original: Hiraññena kayākayanti hiraññena kayavikkayampi tattha tādisaṃ natthi, yaṃ tesaṃ sampattipaṭilābhahetu
analyzed: hiraññena kayākayanti hiraññena kaya vikkayam pi tattha tādisam na atthi yam tesam sampatti paṭilābha hetu
translated: There is no such buying and selling of gold there, which could be the cause of their acquiring prosperity.

original: bhaveyya. Ite dinnena yāpenti, petā kālagatā tahinti kevalaṃ pana ito ñātīhi vā mittāmaccehi
analyzed: bhaveyya ite dinnena kālagatā kevalam pana itas ñātīhi vā mitta amaccehi
translated: The ghosts who have died live on what is given here.

original: vā dinnena yāpenti, attabhāvaṃ pavattenti. Petāti pettivisayūpapannā sattā. Kālagatāti
analyzed: vā dinnena yāpenti atta bhāvam pavattenti petā ati sattā kālagatā ati
translated: they maintain themselves, they keep themselves going, with what is given by others. Departed: beings who have arisen in the Ghost Realm. Dead:

original: attano maraṇakālena gatā. “Kālakatā”ti vā pāṭho, katakālā katamaraṇā maraṇaṃ sampattā.
analyzed: maraṇa kālena gatā kālakatā ati vā kata kālā kata maraṇā maraṇam sampattā
translated: They maintain themselves, they keep themselves going. Departed: beings reborn in the Ghost Realm. Passed away: gone by the time of their death. Or the reading is kālakatā, which is the same as the former. They have reached death, they have reached the time of death, they have reached dying.

original: Tahinti tasmiṃ pettivisaye.
analyzed: tahinti tasmin petti visaye
translated: There: in that Ghost Realm.

original: 20-21. Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ upamāhi pakāsetuṃ “unname udakaṃ vuṭṭha”nti gāthādvayamāha.
analyzed: idāni yathāvuttam attham upamāhi pakāsetum unname udakam vuṭṭhanti gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Now, in order to make clear by means of similes the meaning just stated, he gave the two verses beginning with “The water that falls on high ground.”

original: Tassattho – yathā unname thale unnatappadese meghehi abhivuṭṭhaṃ udakaṃ yathā ninnaṃ
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yathā unname thale unnata ppadese meghehi abhivuṭṭham udakam yathā ninnam
translated: The meaning is this. Just as the water that falls on high ground, on high places, on elevated ground, flows down to the low-lying places,

analyzed: pavattati yaḥ bhūmi bhāgaḥ ninnaḥ oṇataḥ tam upagacchati evam eva itas dinnam dānam petānam
translated: just as it goes to the place that is low-lying, depressed, so too the gift given here comes to the departed,

original: upakappati, phaluppattiyā viniyujjati. Ninnamiva hi udakappavattiyā ṭhānaṃ petaloko
analyzed: upakappati phala uppattiyā viniyujjati ninnam iva hi udaka ppavattiyā ṭhānam peta lokaḥ
translated: it is directed to the production of fruit. For the Ghost Realm is, as it were, a place for the falling of the water of the gift that produces fruit,

original: dānūpakappanāya. Yathāha – “idaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, ṭhānaṃ, yattha ṭhitassa taṃ dānaṃ
analyzed: dāna upakappanāya yathā āha idam kho brāhmaṇa ṭhānam yattha ṭhitassa tam dānam
translated: just as the low-lying place is for the falling of the water. As it is said: “This, brahman, is the place where that gift comes to the departed,

original: upakappatī”ti. Yathā ca kandarapadarasākhapasākhakusobbhamahāsobbhe hi ogalitena
analyzed: upakappati iti yathā ca kandara padara sākha pasākha kusobbha mahāsobbhe hi ogalitena
translated: And it is of help to them.

original: udakena vārivahā mahānajjo pūrā hutvā sāgaraṃ paripūrenti, evaṃ ito dinnadānaṃ pubbe🔽vuttanayena petānaṃ upakappatīti.🔽22. Yasmā petā “ito kiñci labhāmā”ti āsābhibhūtā ñātigharaṃ āgantvāpi “idaṃ nāma
analyzed: udakena vāri vahāḥ mahā najjaḥ pūrāḥ hutvā sāgaram paripūrenti evam itas dinna dānam pubbe  vutta nayena petānam upakappati iti  yasmai petāḥ itas kiñci labhāmāti āsa abhibhūtāḥ ñāti gharam āgantvā api idam nāma
translated: And just as the great rivers, the Ganges, the Yamunā, etc., fill up the ocean when they reach it, so too the gift given here is of help to the departed relatives in the way already described.

original: no dethā”ti yācituṃ na sakkonti, tasmā tesaṃ imāni anussaraṇavatthūni anussaranto
analyzed: naḥ detha iti yācitum na sakkonti tasmā tesam imāni anussaraṇa vatthūni anussarantaḥ
translated: Since the departed relatives are overwhelmed by craving for the thought “We shall get something from there,” they do not even dare to ask for something, saying “Give this to us,” when they come to the house of their relatives. Therefore, the clansman who remembers these grounds for remembering,

original: kulaputto dakkhiṇaṃ dajjāti dassento “adāsi me”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tassattho – idaṃ nāma me dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā adāsi, idaṃ nāma me kiccaṃ attanāyeva🔽yogaṃ āpajjanto akāsi, “asuko me mātito vā pitito vā sambandhattā ñāti, sinehavasena
analyzed: kula puttaḥ dakkhiṇam dajjāti dassentaḥ adāsi mā iti gātham āha  tassa atthaḥ idam nāma me dhanam vā dhaññam vā adāsi idam nāma me kiccam attanāya iva  yogam āpajjantaḥ akāsi asukaḥ me mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ vā sambandhattā sineha vasena
translated: giving the gift, shows that he gives the gift, saying “He gave to me.”

analyzed: tāṇa samattha tāya mittaḥ asukaḥ me saha paṃsukīḷaka sahāyaḥ sakhā iti ca etam sabbam anussarantaḥ
translated: The meaning is this: “He gave to me such and such wealth or grain; he did such and such a service for me, taking the trouble to do it himself; such a one is my relative on my mother’s or father’s side; such a one is my friend through affection, because he is able to protect me through his love; such a one is my companion, with whom I shared even the scraps of my food.” Remembering all this,

original: petānaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ dajjā dānaṃ niyyāteyya. “Dakkhiṇā dajjā”ti vā pāṭho, petānaṃ dakkhiṇā
analyzed: petānam dakkhiṇam dajjā dānam niyyāteyya dakkhiṇā dajjā iti vā pāṭhaḥ petānam dakkhiṇā
translated: He should give a gift to the dead, he should dedicate it to them.

original: dātabbā, tena “adāsi me”tiādinā nayena pubbe katamanussaraṃ anussaratāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: dātabbā tena adāsi mā iti ādinā nayena pubbe katamanussaram anussaratā iti vuttam hoti
translated: The reading “dakkhiṇā dajjā” is also allowable. The meaning is that he should not remember what he did for them in the past by the method beginning, “He gave to me.”

original: Karaṇatthe hi idaṃ paccattavacanaṃ.
analyzed: karaṇa atthe hi idam paccatta vacanam
translated: For this is a reflexive pronoun in the instrumental case.

analyzed: ye pana sattāḥ ñāti maraṇena ruṇṇa soka ādi pare eva hutvā tiṭṭhanti na tesam atthāya
translated: But those beings who stand by weeping and wailing and so on without giving anything for their sake,

analyzed: kiñci denti tesam tam ruṇṇa soka ādi kevalam atta paritāpanam attam eva hoti tam na petānam  kañci attham sādheti iti dassentaḥ na hi ruṇṇam vāti gātham vatvā puna magadha rājena
translated: their weeping and so on is only a torment of themselves; it does not accomplish any good for the dead.

analyzed: idāni yasmai imam dakkhiṇam dentena raññā ñātīnam ñātīhi kattabba kicca karaṇena

analyzed: ñāti dhammaḥ nidassitaḥ bahu janassa pākaṭaḥ kataḥ nidassanam pākaṭam katam tumhehi pi
translated: The duty of kinsmen has been shown, made plain to the multitude, the demonstration and the making plain has been made: “You too

analyzed: evam eva ñātīsu ñāti dhammo paripūretabbo ti te ca pete dibba sampattim
translated: should fulfil the duty of kinsmen in the same way.” And by their attaining divine prosperity the departed kinsmen were worshipped with great

analyzed: petānam pūjā katā uḷārā buddha ppamukham bhikkhu saṅgham anna pāna ādīhi santappentena
translated: worship, and by their gratifying the Community of monks with food, drink, etc.,

analyzed: bhikkhūnam balam anuppadinnam anukampā ādi guṇa parivāram ca cāga cetanam nibbattentena
translated: the monks were given strength, and by their generating the thought of renunciation, which is surrounded by the qualities of compassion, etc.,

analyzed: anappakam puññam pasutam tasmai bhagavā imehi yathābhucca guṇehi rājānam sampahaṃsentaḥ
translated: much merit was made to grow. Therefore the Blessed One, in praising the King with these true qualities,

analyzed: saḥ ñāti dhammaḥ ti osāna gātham āha
translated: said the verse of conclusion, “So the duty of kinsmen.”

original: Tattha ñātidhammoti ñātīhi ñātīnaṃ kattabbakaraṇaṃ. Uḷārāti phītā samiddhā. Balanti
analyzed: tattha ñāti dhammaḥ ti ñātīhi ñātīnam kattabba karaṇam uḷārā ati phītā samiddhā
translated: Herein, the duty of kinsmen is the doing by kinsmen of what should be done for kinsmen. Greatly: abundantly, fully. Strength:

analyzed: kāya balam pasutanti upacitam ettha ca so ñāti dhammo ca ayam nidassito ti etena

analyzed: bhagavā rājānam dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi ñāti dhamma dassanam ha ittha sandassanam
translated: The Blessed One instructed the King with a talk on Dhamma. Herein, the instruction was the showing of the Dhamma of the relatives.

original: “Petāna pūjā ca katā uḷārā”ti iminā samādapesi. “Uḷārā”ti pasaṃsanañhettha punappunaṃ🔽pūjākaraṇe samādapanaṃ. “Balañca bhikkhūnamanuppadinna”nti iminā samuttejesi. Bhikkhūnaṃ🔽balānuppadānañhettha evaṃvidhānaṃ balānuppadāne ussāhavaḍḍhanena samuttejanaṃ. “Tumhehi
analyzed: petāna pūjā ca katā uḷārā ati iminā samādapesi uḷārā ati pasaṃsanam ha itthā punappunam  pūjā karaṇe samādapanam balam ca bhikkhūnam an uppadinnam ti iminā samuttejesi bhikkhūnam  bala an uppadānam ha itthā evaṃvidhānam bala an uppadāne ussāha vaḍḍhanena samuttejanam tumhehi
translated: “And worship of the departed ones has been performed on a great scale” : by this he exhorted him. “Great scale” is praise here.🔽Exhortation is the repeated urging to perform the worship. “And strength has been given to the bhikkhus” : by this he aroused him.

original: puññaṃ pasutaṃ anappaka”nti iminā sampahaṃsesi. Puññapasavanakittanañhettha tassa
analyzed: puññam pasutam anappakam ti iminā sampahaṃsesi puñña pasavana kittanam ha ittha tassa
translated: Herein, the arousing is the increase of zeal in the giving of strength to the bhikkhus in such a way that they will give strength. “And merit has been made by you not a little” : by this he gladdened him. Herein, the gladdening is the repeated expression of approval of the merit made by him.

original: yathābhuccaguṇasaṃvaṇṇanabhāvena sampahaṃsananti evamettha yojanā veditabbā.🔽Desanāpariyosāne ca pettivisayūpapattiādīnavasaṃvaṇṇanena saṃviggahadayānaṃ yoniso
analyzed: yathābhucca guṇa saṃvaṇṇana bhāvena sampahaṃsanam ti evam ettha yojanā veditabbā  desanā pariyosāne ca petti visayu upapatti ādīnava saṃvaṇṇanena saṃviggaha dayānam yonisas
translated: This is how the construction should be understood here.

original: padahataṃ caturāsītiyā pāṇasahassānaṃ dhammābhisamayo ahosi. Dutiyadivasepi devamanussānaṃ
analyzed: pada hatam caturāsītiyā pāṇa sahassānam dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi dutiya divase pi deva manussānam
translated: And at the conclusion of the teaching, eighty-four thousand breathing things became vision-endowed by rightly grasping the Dhamma, stirred in heart by the exposition of the danger in rebirth in the realm of the petas and so on. On the following day too,

analyzed: idam eva tirokuṭṭa desanam desesi evam yāva satta divasā tādisaḥ iva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: He taught the Discourse on the Other Side of the Wall. Thus for seven days there was the same kind of penetration of the Dhamma.

original: Tirokuṭṭapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tirokuṭṭa peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Ghost in the Wall is finished.

original: 6. Pañcaputtakhādakapetivatthuvaṇṇanā🔽Naggā dubbaṇṇarūpāsīti idaṃ satthari sāvatthiyaṃ viharante pañcaputtakhādakapetiṃ
analyzed: naggā dubbaṇṇa rūpā asi iti idam satthari sāvatthiyam viharante pañca putta khādaka petim
translated: The Story of the Ghost who Devoured her Children

original: ārabbha vuttaṃ. Sāvatthiyā kira avidūre gāmake aññatarassa kuṭumbikassa bhariyā vañjhā
analyzed: ārabbha vuttam sāvatthiyā kira avidūre gāmake aññatarassa kuṭumbikassa bhariyā vañjhā
translated: “Lean, of ugly appearance” . This story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana about a ghost who devoured her children. In a village not far from Sāvatthi lived a certain farmer. His wife was barren.

original: ahosi. Tassa ñātakā etadavocuṃ – “tava pajāpati vañjhā, aññaṃ te kaññaṃ ānemā”ti.
analyzed: tassa ñātakāḥ etat avocuṃ tava pajāpati vañjhāḥ aññam te kaññam ānema ati
translated: Her relatives said to her, “Your husband’s wife is barren. We will bring him another wife.”

original: So tasso bhariyāya sinehena na icchi. Athassa bhariyā taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā sāmikaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tassaḥ bhariyāya sinehena na icchi athassa bhariyā tam pavattim sutvā sāmikam
translated: But he would not consent, out of love for his wife. Now his wife heard what was going on, and said to her husband,

original: evamāha – “sāmi, ahaṃ vañjhā, aññā kaññā ānetabbā, mā te kulavaṃso upacchijjī”ti.
analyzed: evam āha sāmi aham vañjhā aññā kaññā ānetabbā mā te kula vaṃsaḥ upacchijji iti
translated: “Husband, I am barren. You must bring another wife, lest your family line be broken.”

original: So tāya nippīḷiyamāno aññaṃ kaññaṃ ānesi. Sā aparena samayena gabbhinī ahosi. Vañjhitthī
analyzed: so tāya nippīḷiyamānaḥ aññam kaññam ānesi sā aparena samayena gabbhinī ahosi vañjhitthī
translated: Being pressed by her, he brought another wife. In due time she became pregnant. The barren wife,

original: – “ayaṃ puttaṃ labhitvā imassa gehassa issarā bhavissatī”ti issāpakatā tassā gabbhapātanūpāyaṃ
analyzed: ayam puttam labhitvā imassa gehassa issarā bhavissati iti issāpaka tā tassāḥ gabbha pātana upāyam
translated: “If she gets a son, she will be the mistress of this house,” and out of envy she sought a means of causing her to miscarry.

original: pariyesantī aññataraṃ paribbājikaṃ annapānādīhi saṅgaṇhitvā tāya tassā gabbhapātanaṃ
analyzed: pariyesantī aññataram paribbājikam anna pāna ādīhi saṅgaṇhitvā tāya tassāḥ gabbha pātanam
translated: She got hold of a certain female wanderer by giving her food and drink, etc., and had her give her a potion to cause an abortion.

original: dāpesi. Sā gabbhe patite attano mātuyā ārocesi, mātā attano ñātake samodhānetvā tamatthaṃ
analyzed: dāpesi sā gabbhe patite attanaḥ mātuyā ārocesi mātā attanaḥ ñātake samodhānetvā tam attham
translated: When the child was dead, she told her mother, and her mother assembled her relatives and informed them of the matter.

original: nivedesi. Te vañjhitthiṃ etadavocuṃ – “tayā imissā gabbho pātito”ti? “Nāhaṃ pātemī”ti.
analyzed: nivedesi te vañjhitthim etat avocuṃ tayā imissā gabbho pātito ti na aham pātemi iti
translated: They said to the barren woman, “You caused her to miscarry.” “I did not.”

original: “Sace tayā gabbho na pātito, sapathaṃ karohī”ti. “Sace mayā gabbho pātito, duggatiparāyaṇā
analyzed: sace tayā gabbhaḥ na pātitaḥ sapatham karohi iti sace mayā gabbhaḥ pātitaḥ duggati parāyaṇā

analyzed: ca pubbena ca lohitena ca makkhitā hutvā putta maṃsāni khādāmi iti yojanā  evam sā petī attano kamma vipākam pavedetvā puna there evam āha aham bhante imasmiṃyeva

translated: and had them sit down on seats, and began to feed them with choice food. The Elders told the householder what had happened,🔽and had him dedicate that gift to the ghost of his wife. At that very moment the ghost was freed from her suffering,

analyzed: maccharinī bhikkhū na sakkaccam upaṭṭhāti saḥ tam disvā tassāya iva kaniṭṭha bhaginim  ānetvā attanaḥ gehe issariyam niyyādesi sā saddhā pasannā hutvā sakkaccam bhikkhū
translated: She was stingy and did not serve the monks properly. When her husband saw this, he brought in her younger sister

translated: His hair was black, long, soft, glossy, and curled in rings, and hung in tresses to his eyebrows.

original: kalāpā olambanti. Taṃ tassā kesasobhaṃ disvā taruṇajano yebhuyyena tassaṃ paṭibaddhacitto
analyzed: kalāpāḥ olambanti tam tassā kesa sobham disvā taruṇa janaḥ yebhuyyena tassam paṭibaddha cittaḥ
translated: His hair was so beautiful that the young men of the neighborhood were for the most part in love with him.

original: ahosi. Athassā taṃ kesasobhaṃ asahamānā issāpakatā katipayā itthiyo mantetvā tassā
analyzed: ahosi athassā tam kesa sobham a sahamānā issā pakatā katipayāḥ itthiyaḥ mantetvā tassā
translated: She could not bear her rival’s beauty, and incited by envy, she and some other women, after bribing her maid with gifts of food,

original: eva paricārikadāsiṃ āmisena upalāpetvā tāya tassā kesūpapātanaṃ bhesajjaṃ dāpesuṃ.🔽Sā kira dāsī taṃ bhesajjaṃ nhāniyacuṇṇena saddhiṃ payojetvā gaṅgāya nadiyā nhānakāle
analyzed: eva paricārika dāsim āmisena upalāpetvā tāya tassā kesa upapātanam bhesajjam dāpesuṃ  sā kira dāsī tam bhesajjam nhāniya cuṇṇena saddhim payojetvā gaṅgāya nadiyāḥ nhāna kāle
translated: caused her to give her a medicine which would make her hair fall off.🔽The maid mixed the medicine with bathing powder, and when the time came for her to bathe in the river Ganges,

original: tassā adāsi. Sā tena kesamūlesu temetvā udake nimujji, nimujjanamatteyeva kesā samūlā🔽paripatiṃsu, sīsaṃ cassā tittakalābusadisaṃ ahosi. Atha sā sabbaso vilūnakesā luñcitamatthakā
analyzed: tassai adāsi sā tena kesa mūlesu temetvā udake nimujji nimujjana mattā iya iva kesā sa mūlā  paripatiṃsu sīsam cassā tittaka lābu sadisam ahosi atha sā sabbasas vilūna kesā luñcita matthakā
translated: she gave it to her. As soon as she bathed, her hair fell out by the roots,🔽and her head became as smooth as a shell. Then, with her hair all gone, and her head as bare as a plucked plantain tree,

original: kapotī viya virūpā hutvā lajjāya antonagaraṃ pavisituṃ asakkontī vatthena sīsaṃ veṭhetvā
analyzed: kapotī viya virūpā hutvā lajjāya antonagaram pavisitum a sakkontī vatthena sīsam veṭhetvā
translated: she became so ugly that she was like a dove. Ashamed to enter the city, she wrapped her head in her garment,

original: bahinagare aññatarasmiṃ padese vāsaṃ kappentī katipāhaccayena apagatalajjā tato nivattetvā
analyzed: bahi nagare aññatarasmim padese vāsam kappentī kati pāhaccayena apagata lajjā tatas nivattetvā
translated: and took up her abode in a certain place outside the city. After a few days, when her shame had left her, she turned back,

original: tilāni pīḷetvā telavaṇijjaṃ surāvaṇijjañca karontī jīvikaṃ kappesi. Sā ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: tilāni pīḷetvā tela vaṇijjam surā vaṇijjam ca karontī jīvikam kappesi sā eka divasam
translated: and made a living by grinding sesame seeds and selling oil and spirits.

original: dvīsu tīsu manussesu surāmattesu mahāniddaṃ okkamantesu sithilabhūtāni tesaṃ nivatthavatthāni avahari.🔽Athekadivasaṃ sā ekaṃ khīṇāsavattheraṃ piṇḍāya carantaṃ disvā pasannacittā attano🔽gharaṃ netvā paññatte āsane nisīdāpetvā telasaṃsaṭṭhaṃ doṇinimmajjaniṃ piññākamadāsi.
analyzed: dvīsu tīsu manussesu surā mattesu mahā niddam okkamantesu sithila bhūtāni tesam nivattha vatthāni avahari  atha eka divasam sā ekam khīṇāsavattheram piṇḍāya carantam disvā pasanna cittā  gharam netvā paññatte āsane nisīdāpetvā tela saṃsaṭṭham doṇi nimmajjanim piññākam adāsi
translated: When two or three men were drunk and had fallen into a deep sleep, her loosened garments slipped off.🔽One day she saw a certain Elder who had reached Arahantship, going about for alms. She was pleased with him, and she took him to her house.🔽She gave him a seat and served him with a dish of rice and curry mixed together, and with oil-cake.

original: So tassā anukampāya taṃ paṭiggahetvā paribhuñji. Sā pasannamānasā upari chattaṃ dhārayamānā
analyzed: saḥ tassāḥ anukampāya tam paṭiggahetvā paribhuñji sā pasanna mānasā upari chattam dhārayamānā
translated: Out of compassion for her the Elder accepted the food and ate it. She stood holding an umbrella over his head,

original: aṭṭhāsi. So ca thero tassā cittaṃ pahaṃsento anumodanaṃ katvā pakkāmi. Sā ca itthī
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi so ca thero tassā cittam pahaṃsentaḥ anumodanam katvā pakkāmi sā ca itthī
translated: and the Elder, in order to destroy her lust, pronounced the words of thanksgiving and departed.

original: anumodanakāleyeva “mayhaṃ kesā dīghā tanū siniddhā mudū vellitaggā hontū”ti patthanamakāsi.
analyzed: anumodana kāleya iva mayham kesāḥ dīghā tanū siniddhā mudū velli taggāḥ hontu iti patthanam akāsi
translated: At the time of the thanksgiving she made the following Earnest Wish: “May my hair be long, thick, soft, and glossy.”

original: Sā aparena samayena kālaṃ katvā missakakammassa phalena samuddamajjhe kanakavimāne
analyzed: sā aparena samayena kālam katvā missaka kammassa phalena samudda majjhe kanaka vimāne
translated: After the lapse of some time she died and was reborn in a golden palace in the midst of the ocean, as a result of the merit she had acquired by her gift of oil-cake.

original: ekikā hutvā nibbatti. Tassā kesā patthitākārāyeva sampajjiṃsu. Manussānaṃ sāṭakāvaharaṇena🔽pana naggā ahosi. Sā tasmiṃ kanakavimāne punappunaṃ uppajjitvā ekaṃ buddhantaraṃ
analyzed: ekikā hutvā nibbatti tassā kesā patthita ākārāya iva sampajjiṃsu manussānam sāṭaka avaharaṇena  pana naggā ahosi sā tasmim kanaka vimāne punappunam uppajjitvā ekam buddha antaram
translated: and she was born alone. Her hair was like a braid, and because people had stolen her clothes she was naked. She was born again and again in that golden palace, and

original: naggāva hutvā vītināmesi. Atha amhākaṃ bhagavati loke uppajjitvā pavattitavaradhammacakke🔽anupubbena sāvatthiyaṃ viharante sāvatthivāsino sattasatā vāṇijā suvaṇṇabhūmiṃ uddissa
analyzed: naggā ava hutvā vītināmesi atha amhākam bhagavati loke uppajjitvā pavattita vara dhamma cakke  anupubbena sāvatthiyam viharante sāvatthi vāsino satta satāḥ vāṇijāḥ suvaṇṇa bhūmim uddissa
translated: she spent a whole Buddha-interval in this way, always naked. Then when our Lord Buddha appeared in the world, set rolling the Wheel of the Dhamma,🔽and was staying at Sāvatthi, seven hundred merchants of Sāvatthi set out to sea in a ship,

original: nāvāya mahāsamuddaṃ otariṃsu. Tehi āruḷhā nāvā visamavātavegukkhittā ito cito ca
analyzed: nāvāya mahā samuddaṃ otariṃsu tehi āruḍhāḥ nāvāḥ visama vāta vegu khittāḥ itas ca itas ca
translated: bound for the Suvaṇṇabhūmi. The ship, driven by contrary winds, drifted hither and thither,

original: paribbhamantī taṃ padesaṃ agamāsi. Atha sā vimānapetī saha vimānena tesaṃ attānaṃ
analyzed: paribbhamantī tam padesam agamāsi atha sā vimāna petī saha vimānena tesam attānam
translated: and at last reached that spot. Then the spirit of the palace, with the palace itself,

original: dassesi. Taṃ disvā jeṭṭhavāṇijo pucchanto –
analyzed: dassesi tam disvā jeṭṭha vāṇijaḥ pucchantaḥ
translated: showed herself to them. When the chief merchant saw her, he asked her:🔽“Why do you stand in the palace,

original: “Kā nu antovimānasmiṃ, tiṭṭhantī nūpanikkhami;
analyzed: kā nu antar vimānasmiṃ tiṭṭhantī nu upanikkhami
translated: but not come out?

original: Upanikkhamassu bhadde, passāma taṃ bahiṭṭhita”nti. –
analyzed: upanikkhamassu bhadde passāma tam bahiṭṭhitanti
translated: Come out, fair lady, that we may see you.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha kā nu antovimānasmiṃ tiṭṭhantīti vimānassa anto abbhantare tiṭṭhantī
analyzed: gātham āha tattha kā nu antar vimānasmin tiṭṭhanti iti vimānassa antar abbhantare tiṭṭhantī
translated: Herein, what is it that stands within the mansion? It stands within the mansion, inside it.

original: kā nu tvaṃ, kiṃ manussitthī, udāhu amanussitthīti pucchati. Nūpanikkhamīti vimānato🔽na nikkhami. Upanikkhamassu, bhadde, passāma taṃ bahiṭṭhitanti, bhadde, taṃ mayaṃ🔽bahi ṭhitaṃ passāma daṭṭhukāmamhā, tasmā vimānato nikkhamassu. “Upanikkhamassu bhaddante”ti
analyzed: kā nu tvam kim manussitthī udāhu a manussitthī iti pucchati nu upanikkhamīti vimānataḥ  na nikkhami upanikkhamassu bhadde passāma tam bahiṭṭhitanti bhadde tam mayam  bahi ṭhitam passāma daṭṭhu kāmamhā tasmai vimānataḥ nikkhamassu upanikkhamassu bhaddanta iti
translated: What are you? Are you a human woman or a non-human woman? He asks this. I do not come out: I do not come out from the mansion.

original: vā pāṭho, bhaddaṃ te atthūti attho.
analyzed: vā pāṭhaḥ bhaddam te atthu iti atthaḥ
translated: Come out, good lady, we will see you standing outside. Good lady, we want to see you standing outside, therefore come out from the mansion. “Come out, good lady, we will see you standing outside” is the reading, good betide you is the meaning.

original: Athassa sā attano bahi nikkhamisuṃ asakkuṇeyyataṃ pakāsentī –
analyzed: athassa sā attanaḥ bahi nikkhamisum pakāsentī
translated: Then she, showing that she was unable to come out,

original: “Aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi, naggā nikkhamituṃ bahi;
analyzed: aṭṭīyāmi harāyāmi naggā nikkhamitum bahi
translated: “I am ashamed and embarrassed, I cannot come out naked;

original: Kesehamhi paṭicchannā, puññaṃ me appakaṃ kata”nti. –
analyzed: kesa ihamhi paṭicchannā puññam me appakam katanti
translated: I am covered with hair, I have done little merit”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha aṭṭīyāmīti naggā hutvā bahi nikkhamituṃ aṭṭikā dukkhitā amhi. Harāyāmīti
analyzed: gātham āha tattha aṭṭīyāmi iti naggā hutvā bahi nikkhamitum aṭṭikā dukkhitā amhi harāyāmi iti
translated: she spoke this verse. Herein, I am ashamed means I am ashamed, I am miserable, I am embarrassed, I am distressed, I am unable to come out naked.

original: lajjāmi. Kesehamhi paṭicchannāti kesehi amhi ahaṃ paṭicchāditā pārutasarīrā. Puññaṃ
analyzed: lajjāmi kesehi amhi aham paṭicchāditā pāruta sarīrā puññam
translated: I am ashamed. I am covered with hair means I am covered with hair on my body.

original: me appakaṃ katanti appakaṃ parittaṃ mayā kusalakammaṃ kataṃ, piññākadānamattanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: me appakam katanti appakam parittam mayā kusala kammam katam piññāka dānam attanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: I am ashamed. I am covered with hair: I am covered with hair on my body. I have done little merit: I have done little, small, wholesome action, just the giving of a little alms-food, is the meaning.

original: Athassā vāṇijo attano uttarisāṭakaṃ dātukāmo –-
analyzed: athassā vāṇijaḥ attanaḥ uttari sāṭakam dātu kāmaḥ
translated: Then the merchant, wanting to give his upper robe, said:

original: “Handuttarīyaṃ dadāmi te, idaṃ dussaṃ nivāsaya;
analyzed: hanta uttarīyam dadāmi te idam dussam nivāsaya
translated: I give you this upper robe, put on this cloth;

original: Idaṃ dussaṃ nivāsetvā, ehi nikkhama sobhane;
analyzed: idam dussam nivāsetvā ehi nikkhama sobhane
translated: Having put on this cloth, come out, you who are beautiful;

original: Upanikkhamassu bhadde, passāma taṃ bahiṭṭhita”nti. –
analyzed: upanikkhamassu bhadde passāma tam bahiṭṭhitanti
translated: Come out, good lady, we will see you outside.

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha handāti gaṇha. Uttarīyanti upasaṃbyānaṃ uttarisāṭakanti attho.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha handa iti gaṇha uttarīyam iti upasaṃbyānam uttari sāṭakam ti attho
translated: He spoke this verse. Herein, hand means take. Upper robe means upper robe for covering the three cloisters, is the meaning.

original: Dadāmi teti tuyhaṃ dadāmi. Idaṃ dussaṃ nivāsayāti idaṃ mama uttarisāṭakaṃ tvaṃ nivāsehi.
analyzed: dadāmi te iti tuyham dadāmi idam dussam nivāsaya ati idam mama uttari sāṭakam tvam nivāsehi
translated: I give you means I give to you. Put on this cloth means put on this upper robe of mine.

original: Sobhaneti sundararūpe.
analyzed: sobhana iti sundara rūpe
translated: You who are beautiful means you who are of beautiful form.

original: Evañca pana vatvā attano uttarisāṭakaṃ tassā upanesi, sā tathā diyyamānassa attano anupakappanīyatañca, yathā diyyamānaṃ upakappati, tañca dassentī –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā attanaḥ uttari sāṭakam tassāḥ upanesi sā tathā diyyamānassa attanaḥ an upakappanīya tat ca yathā diyyamānam upakappati tat ca dassentī
translated: Having said this, he offered her his own upper robe. She, in accepting what was offered, showed how it was possible to accept what was offered, and she said:

original: “Hatthena hatthe te dinnaṃ, na mayhaṃ upakappati;
analyzed: hatthena hatthe te dinnam na mayham upakappati
translated: “What is given with the hand to hand, does not serve me;

original: Esetthupāsako saddho, sammāsambuddhasāvako.
analyzed: esa itthā upāsako saddho sammāsambuddha sāvako
translated: Here is a faithful lay disciple, a disciple of the Supremely Enlightened One.

original: “Etaṃ acchādayitvāna, mama dakkhiṇamādisa;
analyzed: etam mama dakkhiṇam ādisa
translated: “Having covered me with this, make my offering to the Fortunate One;

original: Tathāhaṃ sukhitā hessaṃ, sabbakāmasamiddhinī”ti. –
analyzed: tathā aham sukhitā hessam sabba kāma samiddhinī iti
translated: Thus I shall be happy, having obtained all that I desire.”

original: Gāthādvayamāha. Tattha hatthena hatthe te dinnaṃ, na mayhaṃ upakappatīti, mārisa,
analyzed: gāthā dvayam āha tattha hatthena hatthe te dinnam na mayham upakappati iti mārisa
translated: She spoke this verse. Herein, what is given with the hand to hand, does not serve me; dear Sir,

original: tava hatthena mama hatthe tayā dinnaṃ na mayhaṃ upakappati na viniyujjati, upabhogayoggaṃ
analyzed: tava hatthena mama hatthe tayā dinnam na mayham upakappati na viniyujjati upabhoga yoggam
translated: what is given by you with your hand to my hand does not serve me, does not become useful,

original: na hotīti attho. Esetthupāsako saddhoti eso ratanattayaṃ uddissa saraṇagamanena upāsako
analyzed: na hoti iti attho saddho ti esaḥ ratanattayam uddissa saraṇa gamanena upāsako
translated: does not become fit for use, is the meaning. Here is a faithful lay disciple; by going for refuge to the Three Jewels this lay disciple

original: kammaphalasaddhāya ca samannāgatattā saddho ettha etasmiṃ janasamūhe atthi. Etaṃ
analyzed: kamma phala saddhāya ca samannāgata ttā saddhaḥ ettha etasmin jana samūhe atthi etaṃ
translated: is endowed with faith in the results of action, and therefore is faithful. Here,

original: acchādayitvāna, mama dakkhiṇamādisāti etaṃ upāsakaṃ mama diyyamānaṃ sāṭakaṃ paridahāpetvā🔽taṃ dakkhiṇaṃ mayhaṃ ādisa pattidānaṃ dehi. Tathāhaṃ sukhitā hessanti tathā kate
analyzed: a chādayitvāna mama dakkhiṇam ādisāti etam upāsakam mama diyyamānam sāṭakam paridahāpetvā  tam dakkhiṇam mayham ādisa patti dānam dehi tathā aham sukhitāḥ hessanti tathā kate
translated: Having had that lay disciple dress me in the cloth,🔽announce that gift to me, the gift of the robe. In that way I will be happy.

original: ahaṃ sukhitā dibbavatthanivatthā sukhappattā bhavissāmīti.
analyzed: aham sukhitā dibba vattha nivatthā sukha ppattā bhavissāmi iti
translated: In that way, having become happy, clothed in divine cloth, having attained happiness, I will be.”

original: Taṃ sutvā vāṇijā taṃ upāsakaṃ nhāpetvā vilimpetvā vatthayugena acchādesuṃ. Tamatthaṃ pakāsentā saṅgītikārā –
analyzed: tam sutvā vāṇijā tam upāsakam nhāpetvā vilimpetvā vattha yugena acchādesum tam attham pakāsentā saṅgīti kārā
translated: Having heard that, the merchants bathed that lay disciple, anointed him, and dressed him in a pair of garments. Explaining that matter, the compilers of the Canon said:

original: “Tañca te nhāpayitvāna, vilimpetvāna vāṇijā;
analyzed: tat ca te nhāpayitvāna vilimpetvāna vāṇijā
translated: “Having bathed him and anointed him,

original: Vatthehacchādayitvāna, tassā dakkhiṇamādisuṃ.
analyzed: tassāḥ dakkhiṇam ādisuṃ
translated: the merchants dressed him, and announced the gift to her.

original: “Samanantarānuddiṭṭhe, vipāko udapajjatha;
analyzed: samanantara an uddiṭṭhe vipākaḥ udapajjatha
translated: “Immediately after the announcement, the result arose:

original: Bhojanacchādanapānīyaṃ, dakkhiṇāya idaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: bhojana chādana pānīyam dakkhiṇāya idam phalam
translated: Food, clothing, and drink—this is the fruit of the gift.

original: “Tato suddhā sucivasanā, kāsikuttamadhārinī;
analyzed: tatas suddhā suci vasanā kāsi kuttama dhārinī
translated: “Then, pure and well-dressed, wearing the finest Kāsi cloth,

original: Hasantī vimānā nikkhami, dakkhiṇāya idaṃ phala”nti. –
analyzed: hasantī vimānā nikkhami dakkhiṇāya idam phalanti
translated: she left the mansion laughing. This is the fruit of the gift.”

original: Tisso gāthāyo avocuṃ.
analyzed: tissaḥ gāthāyaḥ avocuṃ
translated: They spoke three verses.

original: 63. Tattha tanti taṃ upāsakaṃ. Ca-saddo nipātamattaṃ. Teti te vāṇijāti yojanā. Vilimpetvānāti🔽uttamena gandhena vilimpetvā. Vatthehacchādayitvānāti vaṇṇagandharasasampannaṃ sabyañjanaṃ🔽bhojanaṃ bhojetvā nivāsanaṃ uttarīyanti dvīhi vatthehi acchādesuṃ, dve vatthāni adaṃsūti
analyzed: tattha tanti tam upāsakam ca saddaḥ nipāta mattam te iti te vāṇijāti yojanāḥ  uttamena gandhena vilimpetvā vaṇṇa gandha rasa sampannam sa byañjanam  bhojanam bhojetvā nivāsanam uttarīyanti dvīhi vatthehi acchādesum dve vatthāni adaṃsuḥ iti
translated: Herein, ‘And he’: that lay follower. The word ‘and’ is merely a particle. ‘They’: those traders. ‘Having anointed her’:

original: attho. Tassā dakkhiṇamādisunti tassā petiyā taṃ dakkhiṇaṃ ādisiṃsu.
analyzed: tassā dakkhiṇam ādisunti tassā petiyā tam dakkhiṇam ādisiṃsu
translated: having anointed her with the best perfume. ‘Having clothed her in garments’: having fed her with food endowed with colour, smell, and taste, and having clothed her in two garments, a sarong and an upper robe. ‘Two garments he gave’: this is the meaning. ‘They dedicated that gift to her’: they dedicated that gift to that ghost.

original: 64. Samanantarānuddiṭṭheti anū-ti nipātamattaṃ, tassā dakkhiṇāya uddiṭṭhasamanantarameva.
analyzed: samanantarā anuddiṭṭhā iti nipāta mattam tassāḥ dakkhiṇāya uddiṭṭha samanantaram eva
translated: ‘Immediately after it was dedicated’: the word ‘anu’ is merely a particle; immediately after that gift was dedicated.

original: Vipāko udapajjathāti tassā petiyā vipāko dakkhiṇāya phalaṃ uppajji. Kīdisoti petī
analyzed: vipākaḥ udapajjatha ati tassā petiyāḥ vipākaḥ dakkhiṇāya phalam uppajji kīdisā iti petī
translated: ‘The fruit arose’: the fruit of that gift arose for that ghost. ‘What was it like?’ The ghost said:

original: āha bhojanacchādanapānīyanti. Nānappakāraṃ dibbabhojanasadisaṃ bhojanañca nānāvirāgavaṇṇasamujjalaṃ
analyzed: āha bhojana chādana pānīyanti nānappakāram dibba bhojana sadisam bhojanam ca nānā virāga vaṇṇa samujjalam
translated: ‘Food, clothing, and drink.’ Food like divine food of various kinds, and clothing

original: dibbavatthasadisaṃ vatthañca anekavidhaṃ pānakañca dakkhiṇāya idaṃ īdisaṃ phalaṃ
analyzed: dibba vattha sadisam vattham ca anekavidham pānakam ca dakkhiṇāya idam īdisam phalam
translated: shining with the various colours of the dye, and various kinds of drink. This is the kind of fruit of that gift.

original: udapajjathāti yojanā.
analyzed: udapajjatha ati yojanā
translated: The construction is: “There arose in her.”🔽After that: after the obtaining of the food, etc., as described above.

original: 65. Tatoti yathāvuttabhojanādipaṭilābhato pacchā. Suddhāti nhānena suddhasarīrā.
analyzed: tato ti yathā vutta bhojana ādi paṭilābhato pacchā suddhā ati nhānena suddha sarīrā
translated: Pure: with her body purified by bathing.🔽Well-dressed: wearing well-washed garments.

original: Sucivasanāti suvisuddhavatthanivatthā. Kāsikuttamadhārinīti kāsikavatthatopi uttamavatthadhārinī.
analyzed: suci vasanā ati su visuddha vattha nivatthā kāsika uttama dhārinī iti kāsika vatthataḥ api uttama vattha dhārinī
translated: Wearing the best of Kāsi cloth: wearing the best of garments, even better than Kāsi cloth.

original: Hasantīti “passatha tāva tumhākaṃ dakkhiṇāya idaṃ phalavisesa”nti pakāsanavasena
analyzed: hasanti iti passatha tāva tumhākam dakkhiṇāya idam phala visesanti pakāsana vasena

translated: “Slanderers” means revilers. “We enjoy ourselves” means we enjoy ourselves as we like, taking our senses from one divine sense pleasure to another, or we enjoy ourselves as we are served by our servants, who serve us as a result of our own merit.

original: sussāma, khuppipāsāhi aññamaññaṃ daṇḍābhighātehi ca sukkhā visukkhā bhavāmāti.
analyzed: sussāma khuppipāsāhi aññamaññam daṇḍa abhighātehi ca sukkhāḥ visukkhāḥ bhavāma ati
translated: “But we are dried up like a cut reed” means we are dried up, withered, and parched by hunger, thirst, and mutual blows with sticks.

original: Evaṃ attano pāpaṃ sampavedetvā “mayaṃ tuyhaṃ mātulamātulāniyo”ti ācikkhiṃsu. Taṃ🔽sutvā sāmaṇero sañjātasaṃvego “evarūpānaṃ kibbisakārīnaṃ kathaṃ nu kho bhojanāni
analyzed: evam attanaḥ pāpam sampavedetvā mayam tuyham mātula mātulāniyāḥ ti ācikkhiṃsu tam  sutvā sāmaṇeraḥ sañjāta saṃvegaḥ evarūpānam kibbisa kārīnam katham nu kho bhojanāni
translated: Having thus confessed their own wickedness, they said, “We are your mother’s and father’s brother’s sons.”

original: sijjhantī”ti pucchanto –
analyzed: sijjhanti iti pucchantaḥ
translated: Hearing this, the novice monk was overcome with remorse. “How is it,” he asked, “that the food of such wicked people is so well prepared?”

original: “Kiṃ tumhākaṃ bhojanaṃ kiṃ sayānaṃ, kathañca yāpetha supāpadhammino;
analyzed: kim tumhākam bhojanam kim sa yānam kathañca yāpetha su pāpa dhammino
translated: “What is your food? What is your bed? How do you live, you who are so wicked?

original: Pahūtabhogesu anappakesu, sukhaṃ virādhāya dukkhajja pattā”ti. –
analyzed: pahūta bhogesu anappakesu sukham virādhāya dukkhajja
translated: You have plenty of wealth and many possessions, yet you have come to grief and suffering.”

analyzed: kīdisam sayanam kim sayānā iti keci paṭhanti kīdisā sayanā kīdise sayane sayathā iti  attho katham ca yāpetha ati kena pakārena yāpetha katham vaḥ yāpetha ati pi katham
translated: Some read “Kiṃ sayānā,” what is your bed? What is your sleeping? The meaning is: what is your sleeping-place?🔽How do you get along? By what means do you get along? There is also the reading “Kathaṃ vo yāpethā,” how do you get along? The meaning is: how do you get along?

original: tumhe yāpethāti attho. Supāpadhamminoti suṭṭhu ativiya pāpadhammā. Pahūtabhogesūti
analyzed: tumhe yāpetha ati attho su pāpa dhammino ti suṭṭhu ativiya pāpa dhammā pahūta bhogesu iti
translated: You who are so very wicked: you who are so very bad.🔽Among those who have abundant wealth: among those who have unlimited, abundant wealth.

original: apariyantesu uḷāresu bhogesu santesu. Anappakesūti na appakesu bahūsu. Sukhaṃ virādhāyāti
analyzed: a pariyantesu uḷāresu bhogesu santesu anappakesu iti na appakesu bahūsu sukham virādhāya ati

analyzed: sukha hetuno puññassa a karaṇena sukham virajjhitvā virādhetvā sukhassa virādhena ati
translated: You have destroyed your happiness: you have destroyed, have caused to disappear, your happiness by not doing merit, the cause of happiness. Some read “Sukhassa virādhenā.”

original: keci paṭhanti. Dukkhajja pattāti ajja idāni idaṃ petayonipariyāpannaṃ dukkhaṃ anuppattāti.
analyzed: keci paṭhanti dukkhajja ajja idāni idam peta yoni pariyāpannam dukkham
translated: You have attained suffering: today, now, you have attained this suffering included in the realm of ghosts.

original: Evaṃ sāmaṇerena puṭṭhā petā tena pucchitamatthaṃ vissajjentā –
analyzed: evam sāmaṇerena puṭṭhā petā tena pucchitam attham vissajjentā
translated: Thus questioned by the novice monk, the ghosts, in reply to his question, said:

analyzed: aññam aññam vadhitvāna pivāma pubba lohitam
translated: “Having killed one another, we drink the blood of the other,

original: Bahuṃ vitvā na dhātā homa, nacchādimhase mayaṃ.

translated: “Thus the dead lament, those who do not give, who are destined for Yama’s place,

translated: Those who, having obtained wealth, do not enjoy it, nor make merit.

original: “Te khuppipāsūpagatā parattha, pacchā ciraṃ jhāyare ḍayhamānā;
analyzed: te khu pipāsu upagatā parattha pacchā ciram ḍayhamānā

analyzed: ittaram hi dhanam dhaññam ittaram idha jīvitam

translated: “Those people who understand thus, who are skilled in the Dhamma,

original: Pañca gāthā abhāsiṃsu.

analyzed: ñātīnam mittānam suhadayānam ca mama socanena bhātu maraṇa dukkhataḥ bhiyyas api arati dukkham eva siyāti  evam bhaginiyāḥ vacanam sutvā tassa bhariyam pucchi tuyham saḥ kim hoti iti bhattā  me sāmi iti bhadde itthiyaḥ nāma bhattari sinehāḥ honti tasmin ca mate vidhavā anāthā

translated: ” When he had heard his sister’s words, he asked his wife, “What was he to you? ” “My husband, master.” “Dear, women are full of affection for their husbands, and when they are dead they are widows, helpless. Why do you not weep? ” She too, telling the reason why she did not weep,
