original: Datvā ca me ādisa yañhi kiñci, mocehi maṃ duggatiyā bhadante”ti.
analyzed: ca me ādisa yat hi kiñci mocehi mama duggatiyā bhadanta iti
translated: And having given me something, please instruct me in what to do; deliver me from a bad destination, venerable sir.”🔽Herein, have compassion means who are helpful with a view to the future.

original: 98. Tattha anukampakāti samparāyikena atthena anuggaṇhakā. Bhanteti theraṃ ālapati.🔽Ye maṃ niyojeyyunti mātā vā pitā vā atha vā ñātakā edisā pasannacittā hutvā “samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: tattha anukampakā ati samparāyikena atthena anuggaṇhakā bhante ti theram ālapati  ye mam niyojeyyunti mātā vā pitā vā atha vā ñātakāḥ edisāḥ pasanna cittāḥ hutvā samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: Venerable sir is an address to the Elder.🔽If they were to tell me to give to recluses and brahmans,

original: dadāhi dāna”nti ye maṃ niyojeyyuṃ, tādisā anukampakā mayhaṃ nāhesunti yojanā.🔽99. Ito ahaṃ vassasatāni pañca, yaṃ evarūpā vicarāmi naggāti idaṃ sā petī ito tatiyāya
analyzed: dadāhi dānanti ye mam niyojeyyum tādisāḥ anukampakāḥ mayham yojanā  itas aham vassa satāni pañca yam evarūpā vicarāmi naggā ati idam sā petī itas tatiyāya
translated: those who are compassionate like that would not be my parents or relatives.🔽For five hundred years from now I shall wander about naked is said by the female ghost after recollecting her own state as a female ghost in her third birth from now.

original: jātiyā attano petattabhāvaṃ anussaritvā idānipi tathā pañcavassasatāni vicarāmīti
analyzed: jātiyāḥ attano petatta bhāvam anussaritvā idāni pi tathā pañca vassa satāni vicarāmi iti
translated: She says: “Even now I shall wander about naked for five hundred years.”

original: adhippāyenāha. Tattha yanti yasmā, dānādīnaṃ puññānaṃ akatattā evarūpā naggā petī
analyzed: adhippāyena āha tattha yanti yasmā dāna ādīnam puññānam a kata ttā evarūpā naggā petī
translated: He said this with a special intention. Herein, they go thus because of not doing such and such kinds of merit beginning with giving.🔽She has been wandering thus for five hundred years.

original: hutvā ito paṭṭhāya vassasatāni pañca vicarāmīti yojanā. Taṇhāyāti pipāsāya. Khajjamānāti
analyzed: hutvā itas paṭṭhāya vassa satāni pañca vicarāmi iti yojanā taṇhāya ati pipāsāya khajjamānā iti
translated: With craving : with thirst.

original: khādiyamānā, bādhiyamānāti attho.🔽100. Vandāmi taṃ ayya pasannacittāti ayya, tamahaṃ pasannacittā hutvā vandāmi, ettakameva
analyzed: khādiyamānā bādhiyamānā iti attho  vandāmi tam ayya pasanna cittā ati ayya tam aham pasanna cittā hutvā vandāmi ettakam eva
translated: Being devoured : being eaten, is the meaning.🔽I pay homage to you, venerable sir, with a serene mind : I pay homage to you, venerable sir, having become one with a serene mind. I show that I am able to do this much merit now.

original: puññaṃ idāni mayā kātuṃ sakkāti dasseti. Anukampa manti anuggaṇha mamaṃ uddissa anuddayaṃ
analyzed: puññam idāni mayā kātum sakkā ati dassa iti anukampa manti anuggaṇha mamam uddissa anuddayam
translated: Have compassion on me : favour me, have mercy on me.

original: karohi. Datvā ca me ādisa yañhi kiñcīti kiñcideva deyyadhammaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: karohi da tvā ca me ādisa yat hi kiñci iti kiñcid eva deyya dhammam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: And when you have given, announce to me whatever it may be : whatever gift of requisites you may give to ascetics and brahmans,

original: datvā taṃ dakkhiṇaṃ mayhaṃ ādisa, tena me ito petayonito mokkho bhavissatīti adhippāyena
analyzed: da tvā tam dakkhiṇam mayham ādisa tena me itas petayonitaḥ mokkhaḥ bhavissati iti adhippāyena
translated: announce that gift to me, with the intention that thereby I may be released from this destiny as a ghost.

original: vadati. Tenevāha “mocehi maṃ duggatiyā bhadante”ti.
analyzed: vadati tena iva āha mocehi mama duggatiyā bhadanta iti
translated: That is why he said ‘ Deliver me from a bad destination, venerable sir ’.

original: Evaṃ petiyā vutte yathā so thero paṭipajji, taṃ dassetuṃ saṅgītikārehi tisso gāthā vuttā –
analyzed: evam petiyā vutte yathā saḥ theraḥ paṭipajji tam dassetum saṅgīti kārehi tissaḥ gāthā vuttā
translated: When the ghost had spoken thus, the three stanzas were uttered by the compilers of the scriptures in order to show how that Elder acted.

original: “Sādhūti so paṭissutvā, sāriputtonukampako;🔽Bhikkhūnaṃ ālopaṃ datvā, pāṇimattañca coḷakaṃ;
analyzed: sādhu iti saḥ paṭissutvā sāriputta anukampakaḥ  bhikkhūnaṃ ālopam da tvā pāṇi mattam ca coḷakam
translated: “Having agreed, the compassionate Sāriputta,🔽Giving a mouthful of food and a handspan of cloth,

original: Thālakassa ca pānīyaṃ, tassā dakkhiṇamādisi.
analyzed: thālakassa ca pānīyam tassāḥ dakkhiṇam ādisi
translated: And water in a bowl, dedicated the merit to her.

original: “Samanantarānuddiṭṭhe, vipāko udapajjatha;
analyzed: samanantara an uddiṭṭhe vipākaḥ udapajjatha
translated: “As soon as he had dedicated it, the result arose:

original: Bhojanacchādanapānīyaṃ, dakkhiṇāya idaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: bhojana chādana pānīyam dakkhiṇāya idam phalam
translated: Food, clothing, and water—this was the fruit of the offering.

original: “Tato suddhā sucivasanā, kāsikuttamadhārinī;
analyzed: tatas suddhā suci vasanā kāsi kuttama dhārinī
translated: “Then, pure and well-clothed, wearing the finest Kāsi cloth,

original: Vicittavatthābharaṇā, sāriputtaṃ upasaṅkamī”ti.🔽101-103. Tattha bhikkhūnanti bhikkhuno, vacanavipallāsena hetaṃ vuttaṃ. “Ālopaṃ bhikkhuno🔽datvā”ti keci paṭhanti. Ālopanti kabaḷaṃ, ekālopamattaṃ bhojananti attho. Pāṇimattañca🔽coḷakanti ekahatthappamāṇaṃ coḷakhaṇḍanti attho. Thālakassa ca pānīyanti ekathālakapūraṇamattaṃ
analyzed: vicitta vatthā ābharaṇā sāriputtam upasaṅkamīti  tattha bhikkhūnam ti bhikkhuno vacana vipallāsena ha itam vuttam ālopam bhikkhuno  datvā iti keci paṭhanti kabaḷam eka ālopa mattam bhojananti pāṇi mattam ca  coḷakanti eka hattha ppamāṇam coḷa khaṇḍanti attho thālakassa ca pānīyam ti eka thālaka pūraṇa mattam
translated: Adorned with various garments and ornaments, she approached Sāriputta.”

original: udakaṃ. Sesaṃ khallāṭiyapetavatthusmiṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: udakam sesam khallāṭiya peta vatthusmim vutta nayam eva
translated: Herein, to the bhikkhu means to the bhikkhu. This is said by a confusion of the text. Some read: “Having given a mouthful of food to the bhikkhu.” A mouthful is a lump. The meaning is: a single mouthful of food. And a handspan of cloth means a piece of cloth a handspan in size. The meaning is: a piece of cloth one handspan in size. And water in a bowl means water filling a single bowl. The rest is in the way already stated in the Khalaṭa story .

original: Athāyasmā sāriputto taṃ petiṃ pīṇindriyaṃ parisuddhachavivaṇṇaṃ dibbavatthābharaṇālaṅkāraṃ
analyzed: atha āyasmā sāriputto tam petim pīṇi indriyam parisuddha chavi vaṇṇam dibba vattha ābharaṇa alaṅkāram
translated: Then the venerable Sariputta saw that ghost, with its faculties plump, its complexion clear,

original: samantato attano pabhāya obhāsentiṃ attano santikaṃ upagantvā ṭhitaṃ disvā paccakkhato
analyzed: samantataḥ attano pabhāya obhāsentim attano santikam upagantvā ṭhitam disvā paccakkhataḥ
translated: standing in his presence, shining with its own radiance, and having seen (him),

original: kammaphalaṃ tāya vibhāvetukāmo hutvā tisso gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: kamma phalam tāya vibhāvetu kāmaḥ hutvā tissaḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: he, desiring to make the fruit of kamma clear to it, spoke three verses:

original: “Abhikkantena vaṇṇena, yā tvaṃ tiṭṭhasi devate;
analyzed: abhikkantena vaṇṇena yā tvam tiṭṭhasi devate
translated: “With surpassing beauty, you who stand there, divine one;

original: Obhāsentī disā sabbā, osadhī viya tārakā.
analyzed: obhāsentī disā sabbā osadhī viya tārakā
translated: Shining on all sides, like a medicinal star.

original: “Kena tetādiso vaṇṇo, kena te idha mijjhati;
analyzed: kena tetādisaḥ vaṇṇo kena te idha mijjhati
translated: “By what is your beauty like this? By what are you radiant here?

original: Uppajjanti ca te bhogā, ye keci manaso piyā.
analyzed: uppajjanti ca te bhogāḥ ye keci manasaḥ piyāḥ
translated: And how do you get these riches, which are dear to the mind?

original: “Pucchāmi taṃ devi mahānubhāve, manussabhūtā kimakāsi puññaṃ;
analyzed: pucchāmi tam devi mahā anubhāve manussa bhūtā kim akāsi puññam
translated: “I ask you, divine one of great power, what merit did you make when you were a human being?

original: Kenāsi evaṃ jalitānubhāvā, vaṇṇo ca te sabbadisā pabhāsatī”ti.
analyzed: kena asi evam jalita anubhāvā vaṇṇo ca te sabbadisā pabhāsati iti
translated: By what are you so radiant, and your beauty shines in all directions?”

original: 104. Tattha abhikkantenāti atimanāpena, abhirūpenāti attho. Vaṇṇenāti chavivaṇṇena.
analyzed: tattha abhikkantena ati atimanāpena abhirūpena ati attho vaṇṇena ati chavi vaṇṇena
translated: Herein, surpassing means with surpassing loveliness, the meaning is: with surpassing beauty. Beauty means complexion.

original: Obhāsentī disā sabbāti sabbāpi dasa disā jotentī ekālokaṃ karontī. Yathā kinti āha
analyzed: obhāsentī disā sabbā ati sabbā api dasa disā jotentī ekālokam karontī yathā kim ti āha
translated: Illuminating all the directions: all the ten directions, shining, making them one light. As what?🔽He said: “Like stars, herbs.”

original: “osadhī viya tārakā”ti. Ussannā pabhā etāya dhīyati, osadhānaṃ vā anubalappadāyikāti
analyzed: osadhī viya tārakā ati ussannā pabhā etāya dhīyati osadhānam vā anubala padāyikā ati
translated: The light of stars shines forth, or they are the givers of the power of herbs,

original: katvā “osadhī”ti laddhanāmā tārakā yathā samantato ālokaṃ kurumānā tiṭṭhati, evameva
analyzed: katvā osadhī iti laddha nāmā tārakā yathā samantataḥ ālokam kurumānā tiṭṭhati evam eva
translated: and so they are called “herbs.” Just as a star stands illuminating all around,

original: tvaṃ sabbadisā obhāsentīti attho.
analyzed: tvam sabbadisā obhāsenti iti attho
translated: so you illuminate all directions.

original: 105. Kenāti kiṃ-saddo pucchāyaṃ. Hetuatthe cetaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ, kena hetunāti attho.
analyzed: kena ati kiṃsaddo pucchā ayam hetu atthe karaṇa vacanam kena hetunā iti attho
translated: By what: the word “what” is a question word. But it is a locative case in the sense of cause, thus the meaning is: by what cause?

original: Teti tava. Etādisoti ediso, etarahi yathādissamānoti vuttaṃ hoti. Kena te idha mijjhatīti
analyzed: te iti tava etādisaḥ ti edisaḥ etarahi yathā dissamānaḥ ti vuttam hoti kena te idha mijjhati iti
translated: Your: your. Such as this: such as this, such as is seen now, is what is meant. By what: by what special merit?

original: kena puññavisesena idha imasmiṃ ṭhāne idāni tayā labbhamānaṃ sucaritaphalaṃ ijjhati
analyzed: kena puñña visesena idha imasmin ṭhāne idāni tayā labbhamānam su carita phalam ijjhati
translated: Here: in this place. Now: at present. The fruit of good conduct that is obtained by you is successful,

original: nipphajjati. Uppajjantīti nibbattanti. Bhogāti paribhuñjitabbaṭṭhena “bhogā”ti laddhanāmā
analyzed: nipphajjati uppajjanti iti nibbattanti bhogā ati paribhuñjitabba ṭṭhena bhogā ati laddha nāmā
translated: it is produced. Arising: being born. Possessions: called “possessions” in the sense of what can be used.

original: vatthābharaṇādivittūpakaraṇavisesā. Ye kecīti bhoge anavasesato byāpetvā saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: vattha ābharaṇa ādi vittu upakaraṇa visesāḥ ye keci iti bhoge anavasesataḥ byāpetvā saṅgaṇhāti
translated: and the special requisites of clothing, ornaments, etc. ‘Whatever’: this includes all kinds of wealth without exception.

original: Anavasesabyāpako hi ayaṃ niddeso yathā “ye keci saṅkhārā”ti. Manaso piyāti manasā
analyzed: anavasesa byāpakaḥ hi ayam niddesaḥ yathā ye keci manasā
translated: For this is an exhaustive description, like the description ‘whatever formations there are’ . ‘Dear to the mind’ :

original: piyāyitabbā, manāpiyāti attho.
analyzed: piyāyitabbā manāpiyā atthaḥ
translated: to be cherished by the mind; pleasing, is the meaning.

original: 106. Pucchāmīti pucchaṃ karomi, ñātuṃ icchāmīti attho. Tanti tvaṃ. Devīti dibbānabhāvasamaṅgitāya,
analyzed: pucchāmi iti puccham karomi ñātum icchāmi iti tanti tvam devī iti dibbāna bhāva samaṅgi tāya
translated: ‘I ask’ : I make a question, I wish to know, is the meaning. ‘You’ : you. ‘Lady’ : endowed with divine nature,

original: devi. Tenāha “mahānubhāve”ti. Manussabhūtāti manussesu jātā manussabhāvaṃ pattā.
analyzed: devi tena āha mahā anubhāvā iti manussa bhūtā ati manussesu jātā manussa bhāvam pattā
translated: lady. Hence ‘of great majesty’ is said. ‘As a human being’ : born among humans, attained human state.

original: Idaṃ yebhuyyena sattā manussattabhāve ṭhitā puññāni karontīti katvā vuttaṃ. Ayametāyaṃ🔽gāthānaṃ saṅkhepato attho, vitthārato pana paramatthadīpaniyaṃ vimānavatthuaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: idam yebhuyyena sattāḥ manussatta bhāve ṭhitā puññāni karonti iti katvā vuttam ayam eta ayam  gāthānam saṅkhepataḥ atthaḥ vitthārato pana paramattha dīpaniyam vimāna vatthu aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: This is said because for the most part beings who have attained human state do meritorious deeds. This

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: is the meaning in brief of the verses. But in detail it should be understood in the way stated in the commentary on the Vimāna-Vatthu, which illustrates the ultimate meaning .

original: Evaṃ puna therena puṭṭhā petī tassā sampattiyā laddhakāraṇaṃ pakāsentī sesagāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: evam puna therena puṭṭhā petī tassā sampattiyā laddha kāraṇam pakāsentī sesa gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: When the Elder asked again, the ghost, in order to show the reason for her attainment of that state of bliss, spoke the remaining verses:

original: “Uppaṇḍukiṃ kisaṃ chātaṃ, naggaṃ sampatitacchaviṃ;
analyzed: uppaṇḍukim kisam chātam naggam sampatita chavim
translated: “A hunchback, emaciated, weak, naked, with skin stuck to my bones,

original: Muni kāruṇiko loke, taṃ maṃ addakkhi duggataṃ.
analyzed: muni kāruṇikaḥ loke tam mama addakkhi duggatam
translated: The sage, the compassionate one in the world, saw me, wretched.

original: “Bhikkhūnaṃ ālopaṃ datvā, pāṇimattañca coḷakaṃ;
analyzed: bhikkhūnaṃ ālopam da tvā pāṇi mattam ca coḷakam
translated: “Having given a mouthful to the monks, and a handspan of cloth,

original: Thālakassa ca pānīyaṃ, mama dakkhiṇamādisi.
analyzed: thālakassa ca pānīyam mama dakkhiṇam ādisi
translated: And water in a bowl, he dedicated the offering to me.

original: “Ālopassa phalaṃ passa, bhattaṃ vassasataṃ dasa;
analyzed: ālopassa phalam passa bhattam vassa satam dasa
translated: “See the fruit of that mouthful, food for a hundred and ten years,

original: Bhuñjāmi kāmakāminī, anekarasabyañjanaṃ.
analyzed: bhuñjāmi kāma kāminī aneka rasa byañjanam
translated: I eat as I like, with many flavors and condiments.

original: “Pāṇimattassa coḷassa, vipākaṃ passa yādisaṃ;
analyzed: pāṇi mattassa coḷassa vipākam passa yādisam
translated: “See the result of that handspan of cloth,

original: Yāvatā nandarājassa, vijitasmiṃ paṭicchadā.
analyzed: yāvatā nanda rājassa vijitasmin paṭicchadā
translated: As much as was in King Nāḷāgiri’s realm, the covering.

original: “Tato bahutarā bhante, vatthānacchādanāni me;
analyzed: tatas bahutarā bhante vatthāna chādanāni me
translated: “Even more than that, reverend Sir, are my clothes and coverings,

original: Koseyyakambalīyāni, khomakappāsikāni ca.
analyzed: koseyya kambalīyāni khoma kappāsikāni ca
translated: Fine silk blankets, linen and cotton.

original: “Vipulā ca mahagghā ca, tepākāsevalambare;
analyzed: vipulā ca ca
translated: “And they are extensive and expensive, the clothes hanging in the wardrobe,

original: Sāhaṃ taṃ paridahāmi, yaṃ yañhi manaso piyaṃ.
analyzed: sā aham tam paridahāmi yam yat hi manasaḥ piyam
translated: I give them away, whatever is dear to the mind.

original: “Thālakassa ca pānīyaṃ, vipākaṃ passa yādisaṃ;
analyzed: thālakassa ca pānīyam vipākam passa yādisam
translated: “See the result of that water in the bowl,

original: Gambhīrā caturassā ca, pokkharañño sunimmitā.
analyzed: gambhīrā catur assā ca pokkharañño su nimmitā
translated: Deep, with four steps, well-made, of the lotus pond.

original: “Setodakā suppatitthā, sītā appaṭigandhiyā;
analyzed: seta udakā suppatitthā sītā appaṭigandhiyā
translated: “With clear water, good fords, cool, and without bad smells,

original: Padumuppalasañchannā, vārikiñjakkhapūritā.
analyzed: paduma uppala sañchannā vāri kiñjakkha pūritā
translated: and covered with lotuses, and filled with water and mud.

original: “Sāhaṃ ramāmi kīḷāmi, modāmi akutobhayā;
analyzed: sā aham ramāmi kīḍāmi modāmi akutobhayā
translated: I rejoice, I play, I delight, fearless,

original: Muniṃ kāruṇikaṃ loke, bhante vanditumāgatā”ti.
analyzed: munim kāruṇikam loke bhante vanditum āgatā ati
translated: and I have come, Sir, to worship the Sage, the compassionate one in the world.”

original: 107. Tattha uppaṇḍukinti uppaṇḍukajātaṃ. Chātanti bubhukkhitaṃ khudāya abhibhūtaṃ.
analyzed: tattha uppaṇḍukinti uppaṇḍuka jātam chātam ti bubhukkhitam khudāya abhibhūtam
translated: Herein, the word uppaṇḍuka means “having a distended belly.” Chātā means “hungry,” overcome by hunger.

original: Sampatitacchavinti chinnabhinnasarīracchaviṃ. Loketi idaṃ “kāruṇiko”ti ettha vuttakaruṇāya
analyzed: sampatita chavim ti chinna bhinna sarīra chavim loka iti idam ettha vutta karuṇāya
translated: Sampatitacchā means “having a body with broken and torn skin.” Loke means “in the world.” This is a reference to the compassion mentioned in the words “the compassionate one.”

original: visayadassanaṃ. Taṃ manti tādisaṃ mamaṃ, vuttanayena ekantato karuṇaṭṭhāniyaṃ maṃ.
analyzed: visaya dassanam tam manti tādisam mamam vutta nayena ekantataḥ karuṇa ṭṭhāniyam mamam
translated: Taṃ man means “that one, me.” In the way stated, I am a fit object for compassion.

original: Duggatanti duggatiṃ gataṃ.
analyzed: duggatam ti duggatim gatam
translated: Duggatā means “gone to a bad destination.”

original: 108-109. Bhikkhūnaṃ ālopaṃ datvātiādi therena attano karuṇāya katākāradassanaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: bhikkhūnam ālopam therena attano karuṇāya kata ākāra dassanam tattha
translated: Having given a mouthful to the bhikkhus … means that the Elder showed the way in which he had acted out of compassion. Herein,

original: bhattanti odanaṃ, dibbabhojananti attho. Vassasataṃ dasāti dasa vassasatāni, vassasahassanti
analyzed: bhattam ti odanam dibba bhojananti attho vassa satam dasa ati dasa vassa satāni vassa sahassanti
translated: bhatta means rice; the meaning is, divine food. Vassasataṃ dasa means “ten times a hundred years,” that is, a thousand years.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Accantasaṃyoge cetaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Bhuñjāmi kāmakāminī, anekarasabyañjananti
analyzed: vuttam hoti upayoga vacanam bhuñjāmi kāma kāminī aneka rasa byañjana ti
translated: This is a statement of the use in the case of the highest connection. Bhuñjāmi kāmakāminī, anekarasabyañjanā means “I eat, desiring what I like, having many flavors and condiments.”

original: aññehipi kāmetabbakāmehi samannāgatā anekarasabyañjanaṃ bhattaṃ bhuñjāmīti yojanā.
analyzed: aññehi pi kāmetabba kāmehi samannāgatā aneka rasa byañjanam bhattam bhuñjāmi iti yojanā

analyzed: kāretvā gandha dāru ādīhi sarīra kiccam kāretvā dhātuyaḥ gahetvā cetiyam patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: and after the funeral rites had been performed, the relics were enshrined in a monument.

original: “evarūpānampi nāma mahānubhāvānaṃ mahesīnaṃ maraṇaṃ bhavissati, kimaṅgaṃ pana mādisāna”nti
analyzed: evarūpānam pi nāma mahā anubhāvānam mahesīnam maraṇam bhavissati kimaṅgam pana
translated: “If such mighty and powerful kings as these must die, what of us?”

original: saṃvegajāto jeṭṭhaputtaṃ rajje patiṭṭhāpetvā sayaṃ tāpasapabbajjaṃ pabbaji. Devīpi
analyzed: saṃvega jātaḥ jeṭṭha puttam rajje patiṭṭhāpetvā sayam tāpasapabbajjam pabbaji
translated: and he established his eldest son in the kingdom, and himself retired from the world and became a forest hermit. The queen,

original: “raññe pabbajite ahaṃ kiṃ karissāmī”ti pabbaji. Dvepi uyyāne vasantā jhānāni nibbattetvā
analyzed: raññe pabbajite aham kim karissāmi iti pabbaji dve api uyyāne vasantā jhānāni nibbattetvā
translated: thinking, “What is there for me to do now that the king has retired from the world?” also retired from the world.🔽Both of them lived in the pleasure garden, developed the jhānas,

original: jhānasukhena vītināmetvā āyupariyosāne brahmaloke nibbattiṃsu. So kira nandarājā
analyzed: jhāna sukhena āyu pariyosāne brahmaloke nibbattiṃsu saḥ kira nanda rājā
translated: and passed away in the bliss of jhāna. At the end of their lives they were reborn in the Brahmā-world. It is said that the king

original: amhākaṃ satthu mahāsāvako mahākassapatthero ahosī, tassa aggamahesī bhaddā kāpilānī nāma.🔽Ayaṃ pana nandarājā dasa vassasahassāni sayaṃ dibbavatthāni paridahanto sabbameva
analyzed: amhākam satthu mahāsāvakaḥ mahākassapa theraḥ ahosi tassa aggamahesī bhaddā kāpilānī nāma  ayam pana nanda rājā dasa vassa sahassāni sayam dibba vatthāni paridahantaḥ sabbam eva
translated: was our Master’s great disciple, the Elder Kassapa the Great, and that his chief queen was Bhaddā Kāpilānī.🔽But this King Nemi, for ten thousand years,

original: attano vijitaṃ uttarakurusadisaṃ karonto āgatāgatānaṃ manussānaṃ dibbadussāni adāsi.
analyzed: attanaḥ vijitam uttarakuru sadisam karontaḥ āgata āgatānam manussānam dibba dussāni adāsi
translated: himself distributing divine garments, made his whole kingdom like the Northern Kurus, and gave divine garments to all who came to him.

original: Tayidaṃ dibbavatthasamiddhiṃ sandhāya sā petī āha “yāvatā nandarājassa, vijitasmiṃ🔽paṭicchadā”ti. Tattha vijitasminti raṭṭhe. Paṭicchadāti vatthāni. Tāni hi paṭicchādenti
analyzed: tayā idam dibbavattha samiddhim sandhāya sā petī āha yāvatā nanda rājassa vijitasmin  tattha vijitasmin ti raṭṭhe paṭicchadā ati vatthāni tāni hi paṭicchādenti
translated: The ghost said, “As many as there are in the realm of King Nala,

original: etehīti “paṭicchadā”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: etehi iti vuccanti
translated: and more besides, are mine to cover me.” Herein, in the realm means in the kingdom. And more besides are mine to cover me means that there are more than those belonging to King Nala. For they are called “coverings” because they cover .

original: 111. Idāni sā petī “nandarājasamiddhitopi etarahi mayhaṃ samiddhi vipulatarā”ti dassentī
analyzed: idāni sā petī nanda rāja samiddhitaḥ api etarahi mayham samiddhi vipulatarā ati dassentī
translated: Now, the ghost said, “Sir, my covering is more abundant than that of King Nala,” and she spoke the third stanza:

original: “tato bahutarā, bhante, vatthānacchādanāni me”tiādimāha. Tattha tatoti nandarājassa🔽pariggahabhūtavatthatopi bahutarāni mayhaṃ vatthacchādanānīti attho. Vatthānacchādanānīti🔽nivāsanavatthāni ceva pārupanavatthāni ca. Koseyyakambalīyānīti koseyyāni ceva kambalāni
analyzed: tatas bahutarā bhante vatthāna chādanāni mā iti ādim āha tattha tatas iti nanda rājassa  pariggaha bhūta vatthataḥ pi bahutarāni mayham vattha chādanāni iti attho vattha ana chādanāni iti  nivāsana vatthāni ca iva pārupana vatthāni ca koseyya kambalīyāni iti koseyyāni ca iva kambalāni
translated: “More numerous than those are my coverings to cover me.”

original: ca. Khomakappāsikānīti khomavatthāni ceva kappāsamayavatthāni ca.
analyzed: ca khoma kappāsikāni iti khoma vatthāni ca iva kappāsa maya vatthāni ca
translated: Herein, more numerous than those means that my coverings to cover me are more numerous than those belonging to King Nala. My coverings to cover me means my undergarments and upper garments. Silk and wool means silk and woolen cloth. Cotton and linen means cotton cloth and linen cloth.

original: 112. Vipulāti āyāmato ca vitthārato ca vipulā. Mahagghāti mahagghavasena mahantā
analyzed: vipulā ati āyāmataḥ ca vitthārataḥ ca vipulā mahagghā ati mahaggha vasena
translated: Abundant means extensive in length and breadth. Costly means valuable.

original: mahārahā. Ākāsevalambareti ākāseyeva olambamānā tiṭṭhanti. Yaṃ yañhi manaso piyanti
analyzed: mahā rahā ākāsevalambarā iti ākāseyā iva olambamānā tiṭṭhanti yam yam hi manasaḥ piyanti
translated: are of great value. Hanging in the sky: they stand hanging in the sky.🔽Whatever is dear to my mind:

original: yaṃ yaṃ mayhaṃ manaso piyaṃ, taṃ taṃ gahetvā paridahāmi pārupāmi cāti yojanā.
analyzed: yam yam manasaḥ piyam tam tam gahetvā paridahāmi pārupāmi ca ati yojanā
translated: the construction is: “whatever is dear to my mind, I take it and cover myself with it, I clothe myself with it.”🔽And water in a bowl:

original: 113. Thālakassa ca pānīyaṃ, vipākaṃ passa yādisanti thālakapūraṇamattaṃ pānīyaṃ dinnaṃ🔽anumoditaṃ, tassa pana vipākaṃ yādisaṃ yāva mahantaṃ passāti dassentī “gambhīrā caturassā
analyzed: thālakassa ca pānīyam vipākam passa thālaka pūraṇa mattam pānīyam dinnam  anumoditam tassa pana vipākam yādisam yāva mahantam passāti dassentī gambhīrā caturassā
translated: see what the result is like. He gave water filling a bowl,🔽and he rejoiced in it. See what the result is like, how great it is.🔽She says, “Deep, with four corners,” etc., to show this. Herein, deep means unfathomable.

original: cā”tiādimāha. Tattha gambhīrāti agādhā. Caturassāti caturassasaṇṭhānā. Pokkharaññoti
analyzed: ca atiādim āha tattha gambhīrā ati agādhā catur assā ati catur assa saṇṭhānā pokkharañño ti
translated: With four corners means having the shape of a square.🔽Lakes means ponds.

original: pokkharaṇiyo. Sunimmitāti kammānubhāveneva suṭṭhu nimmitā.
analyzed: pokkharaṇiyaḥ su nimmitā ati kamma anubhāvena iva suṭṭhu nimmitā
translated: Well laid out means well laid out by the power of kamma.🔽With clear water means with clear water, strewn with white sand.

original: 114. Setodakāti setaudakā setavālukasamparikiṇṇā. Suppatitthāti sundaratitthā. Sītāti
analyzed: setodakā ati seta odakā seta vāluka samparikiṇṇā suppatitthā ati sundaratitthā sītā ati
translated: With pleasant means with a pleasant bank.🔽Cool means with cool water.🔽Odorless means free from bad smells, fragrant.

original: sītalodakā. Appaṭigandhiyāti paṭikūlagandharahitā surabhigandhā. Vārikiñjakkhapūritāti
analyzed: sītala udakā appaṭigandhiyā ati paṭikūla gandha rahitā surabhi gandhā vāri kiñjakkha pūritā ati
translated: Filled with means

original: kamalakuvalayādīnaṃ kesarasañchannena vārinā paripuṇṇā.
analyzed: kamala kuvalaya ādīnam kesara sañchannena vārinā paripuṇṇā
translated: and filled with water covered with the filaments of lotuses, blue and white lotuses, and so on.

original: 115. Sāhanti sā ahaṃ. Ramāmīti ratiṃ vindāmi. Kīḷāmīti indriyāni paricāremi. Modāmīti
analyzed: sā ahanti sā aham ramāmi iti ratim vindāmi kīḍāmi iti indriyāni paricāremi modāmi iti
translated: I am she, I am that one. I enjoy myself, I find delight. I make merry, I indulge my senses. I am glad,

original: bhogasampattiyā pamuditā homi. Akutobhayāti kutocipi asañjātabhayā, serī sukhavihārinī🔽homi. Bhante, vanditumāgatāti, bhante, imissā dibbasampattiyā paṭilābhassa kāraṇabhūtaṃ
analyzed: bhoga sampattiyā pamuditā homi akutobhayā ati asañjāta bhayā serī sukha vihārinī  homi bhante vanditum āgatā ati bhante imissā dibba sampattiyā paṭilābhassa kāraṇa bhūtam
translated: I am happy with the wealth of my enjoyments. I have no fear from anywhere, I am fearless, I am happy, I am comfortable.🔽Venerable Sir, I have come to pay homage to you. The meaning is: I have come to you to pay homage, because you are the cause of my obtaining this divine wealth.

original: tvaṃ vandituṃ āgatā upagatāti attho. Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ tattha tattha vuttameva.
analyzed: tvam vanditum āgatā upagatā iti atthaḥ yam pana ittha atthataḥ avibhattam tam tattha tattha vuttam eva
translated: But what is not explained here is given in the appropriate places.

original: Evaṃ tāya petiyā vutte āyasmā sāriputto iṭṭhakavatiyaṃ dīgharājiyanti gāmadvayavāsikesu🔽attano santikaṃ upagatesu manussesu imamatthaṃ vitthārato kathento saṃvejetvā saṃsāramocanapāpakammato
analyzed: evam tāya petiyā vutte āyasmā sāriputto iṭṭhakavatiyam gāma dvayavāsikesu  attano santikam upagatesu manussesu imam attham vitthārataḥ kathentaḥ saṃvejetvā saṃsāra mocana pāpa kammato
translated: When the female ghost had spoken thus, the venerable Sāriputta, in order to instruct the people who had come to him from the two villages of Iṭṭhakka and Navatittha,🔽having aroused their sense of spiritual urgency by expounding this matter in detail, and having delivered them from the evil deed of rebirth-linking,

original: mocetvā upāsakabhāve patiṭṭhāpesi. Sā pavatti bhikkhūsu pākaṭā jātā. Taṃ bhikkhū
analyzed: mocetvā upāsaka bhāve patiṭṭhāpesi sā pavatti bhikkhūsu pākaṭā jātā tam bhikkhū
translated: established them in the state of lay followers. This event became well known among the bhikkhus. The bhikkhus

original: bhagavato ārocesuṃ. Bhagavā tamatthaṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā sampattaparisāya dhammaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ ārocesum bhagavā tam attham aṭṭhuppattim katvā sampatta parisāya dhammaṃ
translated: They told this matter to the Teacher. The Teacher, having made the occasion one of the reasons for a discourse,

original: desesi, sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosīti.
analyzed: desesi sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosi iti
translated: preached the Dhamma to the assembled multitude. That discourse was of great profit to the multitude.

original: Saṃsāramocakapetivatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The Story of the Ghost who was Freed from Samsāra is finished.

original: 2. Sāriputtattheramātupetivatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāriputta thera mātu peti vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Ghost who was the Mother of the Elder Sāriputta

original: Naggā dubbaṇṇarūpāsīti idaṃ satthari veḷuvane viharante āyasmato sāriputtattherassa
analyzed: naggā dubbaṇṇa rūpā asi iti idam satthari veḷuvane viharante āyasmataḥ sāriputta therassa
translated: “Lean, of ugly appearance” . This story was told by the Teacher while he was in residence at Veḷuvana, concerning the Elder Sāriputta,

original: ito pañcamāya jātiyā mātubhūtaṃ petiṃ ārabbha vuttaṃ. Ekadivasaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto
analyzed: itas pañcamāya jātiyā mātu bhūtam petim ārabbha vuttam eka divasam āyasmā ca sāriputto
translated: and a ghost who had been his mother in his fifth previous existence. One day the venerable Sāriputta,

original: āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca kappino rājagahassa avidūre
analyzed: āyasmā ca mahāmoggallānaḥ āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca kappino rājagahassa avidūre
translated: the venerable Mahā Moggallāna, the venerable Anuruddha, and the venerable Kappina were dwelling in a certain forest not far from Rājagaha.

original: aññatarasmiṃ araññāyatane viharanti. Tena ca samayena bārāṇasiyaṃ aññataro brāhmaṇo
analyzed: aññatarasmim arañña āyatane viharanti tena ca samayena bārāṇasiyam aññataraḥ brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: At that time there lived in Bārāṇasī a certain Brahman

original: aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavanibbakayācakānaṃ opānabhūto
analyzed: aḍḍhaḥ mahat dhanaḥ mahā bhogo samaṇa brāhmaṇaka paṇaddhika va nibbaka yācakānaṃ opāna bhūtaḥ
translated: who was rich, possessed of great wealth, and a patron of recluses and brahmans, of beggars and wayfarers.

original: annapānavatthasayanādīni deti. Dento ca āgatāgatānaṃ yathākālaṃ yathārahañca pādodakapādabbhañjanādidānānupubbakaṃ
analyzed: anna pāna vattha sayana ādīni deti dento ca āgata āgatānam yathākālam yathāraham ca pāda udaka pāda bbhañjana ādi dāna anupubbakam
translated: He gave food, drink, clothes, beds, etc., and when people came he gave them water to wash their feet and foot salve, etc.,

original: sabbābhideyyaṃ paṭipanno hoti, purebhattaṃ bhikkhū annapānādinā sakkaccaṃ parivisati.
analyzed: sabbābhideyyam paṭipannaḥ hoti purebhattam bhikkhū anna pāna ādinā sakkaccam parivisati
translated: and he gave them everything they needed. Before meals he served the monks with food, drink, etc., respectfully.

original: So desantaraṃ gacchanto bhariyaṃ āha – “bhoti, yathāpaññattaṃ imaṃ dānavidhiṃ aparihāpentī
analyzed: saḥ desantaram gacchantaḥ bhariyam āha bhoti yathā paññattam imam dāna vidhim a parihāpentī
translated: When he was going away to another country, he said to his wife, “Wife, do not neglect the giving of gifts as arranged.

original: sakkaccaṃ anupatiṭṭhāhī”ti. Sā “sādhū”ti paṭissuṇitvā tasmiṃ pakkante eva tāva bhikkhūnaṃ🔽paññattaṃ dānavidhiṃ pacchindi, addhikānaṃ pana nivāsatthāya upagatānaṃ gehapiṭṭhito
analyzed: sakkaccam anupatiṭṭhāhi iti sā sādhu uti paṭissuṇitvā tasmin pakkante eva tāva bhikkhūnam  paññattam dāna vidhim addhikānam pana nivāsa atthāya upagatānam geha piṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Do not be negligent, but be respectful.” She agreed, saying, “I will not,” but as soon as he had gone she stopped the giving of gifts to the monks as arranged.

original: chaḍḍitaṃ jarasālaṃ dassesi “ettha vasathā”ti. Annapānādīnaṃ atthāya tattha addhikesu
analyzed: chaḍḍitam jarasālam dassesi ettha vasatha ati anna pāna ādīnam atthāya tattha addhikesu
translated: But when strangers came to stay, she showed them an old stable that stood at the back of the house, saying, “You can stay there.”

original: āgatesu “gūthaṃ khādatha, muttaṃ pivatha, lohitaṃ pivatha, tumhākaṃ mātu matthaluṅgaṃ
analyzed: āgatesu gūtham khādatha muttam pivatha lohitam pivatha tumhākam mātu matthaluṅgam
translated: When the strangers came for food and drink, etc., she said, “Eat dung, drink urine, drink blood, eat your mother’s privy parts,🔽eat your father’s privy parts, eat your sister’s privy parts, eat your brother’s privy parts, eat your wife’s privy parts, eat your son’s privy parts.”

original: khādathā”ti yaṃ yaṃ asuci jegucchaṃ, tassa tassa nāmaṃ gahetvā niṭṭhuraṃ vadati.
analyzed: khādatha ati yam yam asuci jeguccham tassa tassa nāmam gahetvā niṭṭhuram vadati
translated: and he would call out the names of the various kinds of excrement and urine and say, “Eat this!”

original: Sā aparena samayena kālaṃ katvā kammānubhāvukkhittā petayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā attano
analyzed: sā aparena samayena kālam katvā kamma anubhāva ukkhittā peta yoniyam nibbattitvā attanaḥ
translated: After some time she died and was reborn in the realm of the petas as a result of her evil kamma.🔽There she experienced suffering in accordance with her evil speech.

original: vacīduccaritānurūpaṃ dukkhaṃ anubhavantī purimajātisambandhaṃ anussaritvā āyasmato
analyzed: vacī duccarita anurūpam dukkham anubhavantī purima jāti sambandham anussaritvā āyasmataḥ
translated: Remembering her former connection with the Elder, she desired to approach him.

original: sāriputtassa santikaṃ upasaṅkamitukāmā tassa vihāradvāraṃ sampāpuṇi, tassa vihāradvāradevatāyo
analyzed: sāriputtassa santikam upasaṅkamitu kāmā tassa vihāra dvāram sampāpuṇi tassa vihāra dvāra devatāyo
translated: When she reached the door of his dwelling, the deities who stood guard at the door prevented her from entering.

original: vihārappavesanaṃ nivāresuṃ. Sā kira ito pañcamāya jātiyā therassa mātubhūtapubbā,
analyzed: vihāra pavesanam nivāresum sā kira itas pañcamāya jātiyā therassa mātu bhūta pubbā
translated: For she had been the Elder’s mother five times in his previous existences.🔽Therefore they said to her, “We will not allow you to enter. You are the Elder’s mother, but you are a peta, and a foul stench proceeds from your body.”

original: tasmā evamāha – “ahaṃ ayyassa sāriputtattherassa ito pañcamāya jātīyā mātā, detha
analyzed: tasmai evam āha aham ayyassa sāriputta therassa itas pañcamāya jātīyā mātā detha
translated: She replied, “I am the Elder’s mother, but I am now a peta. Allow me to enter and see the Elder.”

original: me dvārappavesanaṃ theraṃ daṭṭhu”nti. Taṃ sutvā devatā tassā pavesanaṃ anujāniṃsu.
analyzed: me dvāra ppavesanam theram daṭṭhunti tam sutvā devatā tassā pavesanam anujāniṃsu
translated: When the deities heard this, they allowed her to enter.🔽When she entered, she stood at the end of the walk and showed herself to the Elder.

original: Sā pavisitvā caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ṭhatvā therassa attānaṃ dassesi. Thero taṃ disvā karuṇāya
analyzed: sā pavisitvā caṅkamana koṭiyam ṭhatvā therassa attānam dassesi thero tam disvā karuṇāya
translated: When the Elder saw her, he was moved with pity.

original: sañcoditamānaso hutvā –
analyzed: sañcodita mānasaḥ hutvā
translated: and, his mind being moved, he asked her in a verse:

original: “Naggā dubbaṇṇarūpāsi, kisā dhamanisanthatā;
analyzed: naggā dubbaṇṇa rūpā asi kisā
translated: “You are lean, of a bad colour, and your veins stand out all over your body;🔽You are panting, and your ribs are like the sides of a winnowing basket;

original: Upphāsulike kisike, kā nu tvaṃ idha tiṭṭhasī”ti. –
analyzed: upphāsulike kisike kā nu tvam idha tiṭṭhasi iti
translated: what are you, standing here?”

original: Gāthāya pucchi. Sā therena puṭṭhā paṭivacanaṃ dentī –
analyzed: gāthāya pucchi sā therena puṭṭhā paṭivacanam dentī
translated: When she was asked by the Elder in a verse, she gave this reply in a verse:

original: “Ahaṃ te sakiyā mātā, pubbe aññāsu jātīsu;
analyzed: aham te sakiyā mātā pubbe aññāsu jātīsu
translated: “I am your mother, your own flesh and blood, in former births;

original: Upapannā pettivisayaṃ, khuppipāsasamappitā.
analyzed: upapannā petti visayam khuppipāsa samappitā
translated: I have been reborn in the realm of ghosts, oppressed by hunger and thirst.

original: “Chaḍḍitaṃ khipitaṃ kheḷaṃ, siṅghāṇikaṃ silesumaṃ;
analyzed: chaḍḍitam khipitam kheḷam siṅghāṇikam silesumam
translated: “Spittle that is thrown away, and snot, and what is on the finger-nails,

original: Vasañca ḍayhamānānaṃ, vijātānañca lohitaṃ.
analyzed: vasan ca ḍayhamānānam vijātānam ca lohitam
translated: And the blood of those who are being flogged, and the blood of those who are being executed,

original: “Vaṇikānañca yaṃ ghāna-sīsacchinnāna lohitaṃ;
analyzed: vaṇikānam ca yam lohitam
translated: “And the blood of those who are killed by thieves, and of those who are killed by the sword,

original: Khudāparetā bhuñjāmi, icchipurisanissitaṃ.
analyzed: bhuñjāmi icchi purisa nissitam
translated: I eat, being oppressed by hunger, and depending on the breath of life.

original: “Pubbalohitaṃ bhakkhāmi, pasūnaṃ mānusāna ca;
analyzed: pubba lohitam bhakkhāmi pasūnam mānusāna ca
translated: “I eat the old blood of cattle and of men,

original: Aleṇā anagārā ca, nīlamañcaparāyaṇā.
analyzed: aleṇā anagārā ca nīla mañca parāyaṇā
translated: and I am without a house, without a home, and I am dependent on a blue couch.

original: “Dehi puttaka me dānaṃ, datvā anvādisāhi me;
analyzed: dehi puttaka me dānam da tvā anvādisāhi me
translated: “Give me a gift, my son; having given, instruct me;🔽perhaps I may be released from eating old blood.”

original: Appeva nāma mucceyyaṃ, pubbalohitabhojanā”ti. – pañcagāthā abhāsi;

analyzed: tattha aham te sakiyā mātā ati aham tuyham janani bhāvataḥ sakiyā mātā pubbe aññāsu  jātīsu iti mātā honti ipi na imissam jātiyam atha kho pubbe aññāsu jātīsu itas  daṭṭhabbam upapannā pettivisayanti paṭisandhi vasena peta lokam upagatā khuppipāsa samappitā ati

For five hundred times, is to be taken as five hundred births. I was reborn in the ghost realm, is I was reborn in the ghost world by rebirth-linking. Afflicted with hunger and thirst,

original: khudāya ca pipāsāya ca abhibhūtā, nirantaraṃ jighacchāpipāsāhi abhibhuyyamānāti attho.🔽118-119. Chaḍḍitanti ucchiṭṭhakaṃ, vantanti attho. Khipitanti khipitena saddhiṃ mukhato🔽nikkhantamalaṃ. Kheḷanti niṭṭhubhaṃ. Siṅghāṇikanti matthaluṅgato vissanditvā nāsikāya🔽nikkhantamalaṃ. Silesumanti semhaṃ. analyzed: khudāya ca pipāsāya ca abhibhūtā nirantaram jighacchā pipāsāhi abhibhuyyamānā iti attho  chaḍḍitanti ucchiṭṭhakam vantanti attho khipitanti khipitena saddhim mukhataḥ  nikkhanta malam kheḷanti niṭṭhubham siṅghāṇikanti mattha luṅgataḥ vissanditvā nāsikāya  nikkhanta malam silesumanti semham vasan ca citakasmin
translated: Herein, I am your mother by kinship, I am your mother by kinship from the time of your birth. In former births: though she has been your mother in other births, it is not in this one, but in former births, which should be regarded as being five in number. She has been reborn in the Ghost Realm: she has gone to the ghost realm by rebirth-linking. Afflicted with hunger and thirst: overcome by hunger and thirst; the meaning is, constantly oppressed by hunger and thirst.

original: kaḷevarānaṃ vasātelañca. Vijātānañca lohitanti pasūtānaṃ itthīnaṃ lohitaṃ, gabbhamalaṃ
analyzed: vasātelam ca vijātānam ca pasūtānam itthīnam lohitam gabbha malam
translated: Spat out: what has been discarded, what has been vomited up, is the meaning. Sput: what has come out of the mouth together with phlegm. Slobber: what has dripped from the mouth. And the blood of those who have died: the blood of women who have died in childbirth and the blood of the womb.

original: ca-saddena saṅgaṇhāti. Vaṇikānanti sañjātavaṇānaṃ. Yanti yaṃ lohitanti sambandho.

original: Ghānasīsacchinnānanti ghānacchinnānaṃ sīsacchinnānañca yaṃ lohitaṃ, taṃ bhuñjāmīti
analyzed: ghāna sīsa chinnānanti ghāna chinnānan sīsa chinnānan ca yam lohitam tam bhuñjāmi iti

original: bhuñjāmiyeva. Tathā “vaṇikāna”nti iminā tesampi lohitaṃ saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā vaṇikānam ti iminā tesam pi lohitam saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ

original: Gāthāya katakammaṃ pucchi. Puna itarā –
analyzed: gāthāya kata kammam pucchi punar itarā
translated: In this verse she asked about the deed she had done. Then the other,

analyzed: āsinti tam aham duruttam dubbhāsitam niratthaka vacanam itas param pi
translated: I was means I was. That means that. Hard to say means what was badly spoken, meaningless speech. From here on

analyzed: sabbam aham pi jānāmi yathā tvam caṇḍikā ahu
translated: I know all that you were fierce,

analyzed: tava gandhañca mālañca paccagghañca vilepanam
translated: “Your scent, your garland, your unguent,

original: Tassakammavipākena, tenamhi gūthagandhinī.

translated: “With your surpassing beauty, goddess, you stand

analyzed: tava dinnena dānena modāmi akutobhayā

translated: Having uprooted the stain of stinginess, go to the praiseworthy heavenly place.”

analyzed: tattha sabbam aham pi jānāmi yathā tvam caṇḍikā caṇḍī ca pharusā ca asinti

analyzed: yam tayā vuttam tam sabbam aham pi jānāmi yathā tvam caṇḍikā kodhanā pharusa vacanā

analyzed: kena asi paṃsu kunthitā ati kena kammena saṅkāra paṃsu iti oguṇṭhitā sabbaso okiṇṇa sarīrā ahu iti attho  sīsaṃnhātā ati sa sīsam nhātā adhimattanti adhikataram sammā  atisayena alaṅkatā adhimattā iti vā pāṭhaḥ ativiya mattā māna mada mattā māna nissitā ati
translated: By what are you covered with dust? means by what action were you completely covered with dust, with your body all smeared with it? is the meaning.🔽You who were bathed to the crown of the head means you who were bathed with the head washed. original: attho. Tayāti bhotiyā. Sāmikena samantayīti sāmikena saddhiṃ allopasallāpavasena kathesi.

translated: You means you, lady. You who were entertained by your husband means you who conversed with your husband by means of improper conversation.

original: te ahaṃ. Apānudinti corikāya avahariṃ aggahosiṃ.🔽149. Paccagghanti abhinavaṃ, mahagghaṃ vā. Atāresinti khipiṃ. Gūthagandhinīti gūthagandhagandhinī karīsavāyinī.🔽151. Yaṃ gehe vijjate dhananti yaṃ gehe dhanaṃ upalabbhati, taṃ tuyhaṃ mayhañcāti🔽amhākaṃ ubhinna samakaṃ tulyameva āsi. Santesūti vijjamānesu. Dīpanti patiṭṭhaṃ,🔽puññakammaṃ sandhāya vadati.🔽152. original: Gāthamāha. Tattha ahaṃ nandā nandisenāti sāmi nandisena ahaṃ nandā nāma. Bhariyā te pure ahunti purimajātiyaṃ tuyhaṃ bhariyā ahosiṃ. Ito paraṃ –
analyzed: gātham āha tattha aham nandā nandisenā ati sāmi nandisena aham nandā nāma bhariyā te pure ahunti purima jātiyam tuyham bhariyā ahosim itas param
translated: Herein, I am Nandā, Nandisenā’s lord means: my lord is Nandisenā. I was your wife before means: in a previous birth I was your wife. From here on:

original: “Kiṃ nu kāyena vācāya, manasā dukkaṭaṃ kataṃ;
analyzed: kim nu kāyena vācāya manasā dukkaṭam katam
translated: What evil was done by body, speech, or mind?

original: Kissa kammavipākena, petalokaṃ ito gatā”ti. –
analyzed: kissa kamma vipākena peta lokam itas gatā ati
translated: By the result of what deed did I go from here to the world of Petas?

original: Tassa upāsakassa pucchā. Athassa sā –
analyzed: tassa upāsakassa pucchā athassa sā
translated: This was the question of the lay-follower. Then she:

original: “Caṇḍī ca pharusā cāsiṃ, tayi cāpi agāravā;
analyzed: caṇḍī ca pharusā ca asim tayi ca api agāravā
translated: You were fierce and harsh, and I had no respect for you;

original: Tāhaṃ duruttaṃ vatvāna, petalokaṃ ito gatā”ti. –
analyzed: tā aham duruttam vatvāna peta lokam itas gatā ati
translated: Having spoken harsh words, I went from here to the world of Petas.

original: Vissajjesi. Puna so –
analyzed: vissajjesi puna saḥ
translated: answered him. Again he:

original: “Handuttarīyaṃ dadāmi te, imaṃ dussaṃ nivāsaya;
analyzed: hanta uttarīyam dadāmi te imam dussam nivāsaya
translated: I will give you a fine upper garment, put on this cloth;

original: Imaṃ dussaṃ nivāsetvā, ehi nessāmi taṃ gharaṃ.
analyzed: imam dussam nivāsetvā ehi nessāmi tam gharam
translated: Having put on this cloth, come, I will take you to my home.

original: “Vatthañca annapānañca, lacchasi tvaṃ gharaṃ gatā;
analyzed: vattham ca anna pānam ca lacchasi tvam gharam gatā
translated: You will get cloth and food and drink when you have gone to my home;🔽you will see your children, and you will see your daughter-in-law.

original: Putte ca te passissasi, suṇisāyo ca dakkhasī”ti. – athassa sā –
analyzed: putte ca te passissasi suṇisāyo ca dakkhasi iti athassa sā
translated: Then she:

original: “Hatthena hatthe te dinnaṃ, na mayhaṃ upakappati;
analyzed: hatthena hatthe te dinnam na mayham upakappati
translated: What was given by hand to you is of no use to me;

original: Bhikkhū ca sīlasampanne, vītarāge bahussute.
analyzed: bhikkhū ca sīla sampanne vīta rāge bahu sute
translated: Monks who are endowed with virtue, who are free from passion, who are learned,

original: “Tappehi annapānena, mama dakkhiṇamādisa;
analyzed: tappehi anna pānena mama dakkhiṇam ādisa
translated: “Serve me with food and drink, and dedicate the offering to me;

original: Tadāhaṃ sukhitā hessaṃ, sabbakāmasamiddhinī”ti. –
analyzed: tadā aham sukhitā hessam sabba kāma samiddhinī iti
translated: Then I shall be happy, having attained all my desires.”

original: Dve gāthā abhāsi. Tato –
analyzed: dve gāthāḥ abhāsi tatas
translated: She spoke these two verses. Then –

original: “Sādhūti so paṭissutvā, dānaṃ vipulamākiri;🔽Annaṃ pānaṃ khādanīyaṃ, vatthasenāsanāni ca;
analyzed: sādhu iti saḥ paṭissutvā dānam vipulam ākiri  annam pānam khādanīyam vattha senāsanāni ca
translated: “He agreed, saying ‘Very well,’ and made a great offering;🔽Food, drink, and solid food, and robes, and lodging,

original: Chattaṃ gandhañca mālañca, vividhā ca upāhanā.
analyzed: chattam gandhañca mālañca vividhā ca upāhanā
translated: And an umbrella, and scents and garlands, and various kinds of sandals.

original: “Bhikkhū ca sīlasampanne, vītarāge bahussute;
analyzed: bhikkhū ca sīla sampanne vīta rāge bahu sute
translated: “And to the monks who were perfect in virtue, free from passion, and learned,

original: Tappetvā annapānena, tassā dakkhiṇamādisī.
analyzed: tappetvā anna pānena tassāḥ dakkhiṇam ādisī
translated: He served them with food and drink, and dedicated the offering to her.

original: “Samanantarānuddiṭṭhe, vipāko udapajjatha;
analyzed: samanantara an uddiṭṭhe vipākaḥ udapajjatha
translated: “As soon as the dedication was made, the result arose;

original: Bhojanacchādanapānīyaṃ, dakkhiṇāya idaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: bhojana chādana pānīyam dakkhiṇāya idam phalam
translated: Food, clothing, and drink – this is the fruit of the offering.

original: “Tato suddhā sucivasanā, kāsikuttamadhārinī;
analyzed: tatas suddhā suci vasanā kāsi kuttama dhārinī
translated: “Then, pure and well-clothed, wearing the finest Kāsi cloth,

original: Vicittavatthābharaṇā, sāmikaṃ upasaṅkamī”ti. –
analyzed: vicitta vattha ābharaṇā sāmikam upasaṅkamīti
translated: Adorned with various garments and ornaments, she approached her husband.”

original: Catasso gāthā saṅgītikārehi vuttā. Tato paraṃ –
analyzed: catassaḥ gāthā saṅgīti kārehi vuttā tatas param
translated: These four verses were spoken by the compilers of the canon. Then –

original: “Abhikkantena vaṇṇena, yā tvaṃ tiṭṭhasi devate;
analyzed: abhikkantena vaṇṇena yā tvam tiṭṭhasi devate
translated: “With your surpassing beauty, you who stand there, goddess;

original: Obhāsentī disā sabbā, osadhī viya tārakā.
analyzed: obhāsentī disā sabbā osadhī viya tārakā
translated: Shining on all directions, like a medicinal herb, a star.

original: “Kena tetādiso vaṇṇo, kena te idha mijjhati;
analyzed: kena tetādisaḥ vaṇṇo kena te idha mijjhati
translated: “What is the cause of your beauty, what is the cause of your glory?

original: Uppajjanti ca te bhogā, ye keci manaso piyā.
analyzed: uppajjanti ca te bhogāḥ ye keci manasaḥ piyāḥ
translated: What is the cause of your wealth, of all that is dear to your heart?

original: “Pucchāmi taṃ devi mahānubhāve, manussabhūtā kimakāsi puññaṃ;
analyzed: pucchāmi tam devi mahā anubhāve manussa bhūtā kim akāsi puññam
translated: “I ask you, O goddess of great glory, what merit did you perform when you were a human being?

original: Kenāsi evaṃ jalitānubhāvā, vaṇṇo ca te sabbadisā pabhāsatī”ti.
analyzed: kena asi evam jalita anubhāvā vaṇṇo ca te sabbadisā pabhāsati iti
translated: By what are you so radiant, and your beauty shines in all directions?”

original: “Ahaṃ nandā nandisena, bhariyā te pure ahuṃ;
analyzed: aham nandā nandisena bhariyā te pure
translated: “I was Nandā, the wife of Nandisena,

original: Pāpakammaṃ karitvāna, petalokaṃ ito gatā.
analyzed: pāpa kammam karitvāna peta lokam itas gatā
translated: and after doing evil deeds, I went from here to the realm of the dead.

original: “Tava dinnena dānena, modāmi akutobhayā;
analyzed: tava dinnena dānena modāmi akutobhayā
translated: “By the gift you gave, I rejoice, free from fear;

original: Ciraṃ jīva gahapati, saha sabbehi ñātibhi;
analyzed: ciram jīva gahapati saha sabbehi ñātibhi
translated: Live long, householder, with all your relatives,

original: Asokaṃ virajaṃ khemaṃ, āvāsaṃ vasavattinaṃ.
analyzed: asokam virajam khemam āvāsam vasavattinam
translated: in the sorrowless, dustless, safe abode of the powerful gods.

original: “Idha dhammaṃ caritvāna, dānaṃ datvā gahapati;
analyzed: idha dhammam caritvāna dānam da tvā gahapati
translated: “Having practiced the Dhamma here, having given a gift, householder,

original: Vineyya maccheramalaṃ samūlaṃ, anindito saggamupehi ṭhāna”nti. –
analyzed: vineyya macchera malam sa mūlam aninditaḥ saggam upehi
translated: having uprooted the stain of stinginess, go blameless to a heavenly state.”

original: Upāsakassa ca petiyā ca vacanapaṭivacanagāthā.
analyzed: upāsakassa ca petiyā ca vacana paṭivacana gāthā
translated: The verses of the reply to the questions of the lay follower and the ghost.

original: 176. Tattha dānaṃ vipulamākirīti ukkhiṇeyyakhette deyyadhammabījaṃ vippakiranto viya mahādānaṃ pavattesi. Sesaṃ anantaravatthusadisameva.
analyzed: tattha dānam vipulam ākiri iti ukkhiṇeyya khette deyya dhamma bījam vippakirantaḥ viya mahādānam pavattesi sesam anantara vatthu sadisam eva
translated: 176.Herein, he made a great gift means that he made a great gift as if sowing seed in a field that was to be ploughed. The rest is similar to the foregoing.

original: Evaṃ sā attano dibbasampattiṃ tassā ca kāraṇaṃ nandisenassa vibhāvetvā attano vasanaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: evam sā attanaḥ dibba sampattim tassā ca kāraṇam nandisenassa vibhāvetvā attanaḥ vasana ṭhānam eva
translated: So after revealing her own divine glory and the reason for it to Nandisenā, she went to her own abode.

original: gatā. Upāsako taṃ pavattiṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ārocesi, bhikkhū bhagavato ārocesuṃ. Bhagavā
analyzed: gatā upāsako tam pavattim bhikkhūnam ārocesi bhikkhū bhagavataḥ ārocesum bhagavā
translated: The lay devotee told the monks what had happened, and the monks told the Blessed One.

original: tamatthaṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā sampattaparisāya dhammaṃ desesi. Sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosīti.
analyzed: tam attham aṭṭhuppattim katvā sampatta parisāya dhammaṃ desesi sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosi iti
translated: The Blessed One made that the occasion for a discourse and preached the Dhamma to the assembled company. That preaching of the Dhamma was profitable to the multitude.

original: Nandāpetivatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nandāpeti vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of Nandā the nun is finished.

original: 5. Maṭṭhakuṇḍalīpetavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the ghost Mattaka-Kunda-Deyya

original: Alaṅkato maṭṭhakuṇḍalīti idaṃ satthari jetavane viharante maṭṭhakuṇḍalidevaputtaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkataḥ maṭṭhakuṇḍalī ti idam satthari jetavane viharante maṭṭhakuṇḍali devaputtam
translated: Adorned with earrings and a necklace means this story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana about the ghost Mattaka-Kunda-Deyya.

original: ārabbha vuttaṃ. Tattha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ paramatthadīpaniyaṃ vimānavatthuvaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha vuttam tattha yam vattabbam tam paramattha dīpaniyam vimāna vatthu vaṇṇanāyam
translated: Herein, what is to be said has been said in the commentary on the Vimāna Stories in the Paramattha-Dīpanī.

original: maṭṭhakuṇḍalīvimānavatthuvaṇṇanāya vuttameva, tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: maṭṭhakuṇḍalī vimāna vatthu vaṇṇanāya vuttam eva tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The story of the skeleton-jewel-bearer is told in the same way as the story of the skeleton-jewel-bearer, so it should be understood in the way already given.

original: Ettha ca maṭṭhakuṇḍalīdevaputtassa vimānadevatābhāvato tassa vatthu yadipi vimānavatthupāḷiyaṃ🔽saṅgahaṃ āropitaṃ, yasmā pana so devaputto adinnapubbakabrāhmaṇassa puttasokena susānaṃ🔽gantvā āḷāhanaṃ anupariyāyitvā rodantassa sokaharaṇatthaṃ attano devarūpaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā
analyzed: ettha ca maṭṭhakuṇḍalīdeva puttassa vimāna devatā bhāvataḥ tassa vatthu yadi pi vimāna vatthu pāḷiyam  saṅgaham āropitam yasmā pana saḥ deva putto adinna pubbaka brāhmaṇassa putta sokena susānam  gantvā āḷāhanam anupariyāyitvā rodantassa soka haraṇa attham attanaḥ deva rūpam paṭisaṃharitvā
translated: And here, although the story of the god Mattakundali is included in the Vimānavatthu,🔽because that god had no divine nature,🔽he went to the charnel ground,

original: haricandanussado bāhā paggayha kandanto dukkhābhibhūtākārena peto viya attānaṃ dassesi.🔽Manussattabhāvato apetattā petapariyāyopi labbhati evāti tassa vatthu petavatthupāḷiyampi
analyzed: haricandanussadaḥ bāhā paggayha kandantaḥ dukkha abhibhūta ākārena petaḥ viya attānam dassesi  manussatta bhāvataḥ apeta ttā peta pariyāyaḥ api labbhati evā ti tassa vatthu peta vatthu pāḷiyam pi
translated: and after going round the pyre, he showed himself as if he were dead, with his arms outstretched and his body covered with yellow sandalwood paste, weeping and overcome by grief, in order to remove the grief of a brahmin who had never given anything away and whose son had died.🔽And because he had no human nature, the story of the god Mattakundali is included in the Petavatthu,

original: saṅgahaṃ āropitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Maṭṭhakuṇḍalīpetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṅgaham āropitanti daṭṭhabbam  maṭṭha kuṇḍalī peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: so it should be understood that it is included in the Petavatthu as well.🔽The story of the skeleton-jewel-bearer is finished.

original: 6. Kaṇhapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaṇha peta vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the skeleton ghost

original: Uṭṭhehi kaṇha kiṃ sesīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ mataputtaṃ upāsakaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhehi kaṇha kim sesi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram mataputtam upāsakam
translated: “Rise up, Kaṇha, what is left?” The Teacher told this story while living in the Jetavana, concerning a certain lay disciple who had lost a son.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Sāvatthiyaṃ kira aññatarassa upāsakassa putto kālamakāsi. So tena🔽sokasallasamappito na nhāyati, na bhuñjati, na kammante vicāreti, na buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi sāvatthiyam kira aññatarassa upāsakassa putto kālam akāsi so tena  soka salla samappitaḥ na nhāyati na bhuñjati na kammante vicāreti na buddhupaṭṭhānam
translated: Uṭṭhehi kaṇha kiṃ sesīti. This story the Master told while sojourning at Jetavana, concerning a certain lay disciple who had lost a son. A certain lay disciple, it seems, of Sāvatthi lost a son.🔽He was so overwhelmed with grief

original: gacchati, kevalaṃ, “tāta piyaputtaka, maṃ ohāya kahaṃ paṭhamataraṃ gatosī”tiādīni
analyzed: gacchati kevalam tāta piya puttaka mama ohāya kaham paṭhamataram gataḥ asi iti ādīni
translated: that he neither bathed nor ate nor attended to his business nor went to wait upon the Buddha, but only lamented, saying, “Dear son, where have you gone, leaving me behind?”

original: vadanto vippalapati. Satthā paccūsasamaye lokaṃ olokento tassa sotāpattiphalūpanissayaṃ🔽disvā punadivase bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā katabhattakicco🔽bhikkhū uyyojetvā ānandattherena pacchāsamaṇena tassa gharadvāraṃ agamāsi. Satthu
analyzed: vadantaḥ vippalapati satthā paccūsa samaye lokaṃ olokento tassa sotāpatti phala upanissayam  disvā puna divase bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritvā kata bhatta kicco  bhikkhū uyyojetvā ānanda therena pacchā samaṇena tassa ghara dvāram agamāsi satthu
translated: The Master, surveying the world at dawn, saw that the man had a predisposition to the Fruit of Conversion,🔽and on the following day, accompanied by the company of Bhikkhus, entered Sāvatthi for alms. When he had finished his meal,🔽he dismissed the Bhikkhus, and accompanied by the Elder Ānanda, went to the house of the man.

original: āgatabhāvaṃ upāsakassa ārocesuṃ. Athassa gehajano gehadvāre āsanaṃ paññāpetvā satthāraṃ
analyzed: āgata bhāvam upāsakassa ārocesuṃ athassa geha janaḥ geha dvāre āsanam paññāpetvā satthāram
translated: The people of the house informed the lay disciple that the Master had come.

original: nisīdāpetvā upāsakaṃ pariggahetvā satthu santikaṃ upanesi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ taṃ
analyzed: nisīdāpetvā upāsakam pariggahetvā satthu santikam upanesi ekamantam nisinnam tam
translated: and having him sit down, he had the lay disciple brought into the Teacher’s presence. When the lay disciple had sat down on one side,

original: disvā “kiṃ, upāsaka, socasī”ti vatvā “āma, bhante”ti vutte, “upāsaka, porāṇakapaṇḍitā
analyzed: disvā kim upāsaka socasi iti vatvā āma bhante iti vutte upāsaka porāṇaka paṇḍitā
translated: the Teacher asked him, “Lay disciple, are you grieving?” “Yes, Reverend Sir.” “Lay disciple, in days gone by the wise men of old,

original: paṇḍitānaṃ kathaṃ sutvā mataputtaṃ nānusociṃsū”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: paṇḍitānam katham sutvā mata puttam na anusociṃsu iti vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: hearing the words of the wise men of old, did not grieve for a dead son.” So saying, he complied with the lay disciple’s request and related an old-world story.

original: Atīte dvāravatīnagare dasa bhātikarājāno ahesuṃ – vāsudevo baladevo candadevā sūriyadevo
analyzed: atīte dvāravatī nagare dasa bhātika rājānaḥ ahesuṃ  vāsudevaḥ baladevo candadevā sūriyadevo
translated: In the days of yore there were ten brothers ruling in the city of Dvāravatī, namely, Vāsudeva, Baladeva, Candadeva, Sūryadeva,

original: aggidevo varuṇadevo ajjuno pajjuno ghaṭapaṇḍito aṅkuro cāti. Tesu vāsudevamahārājassa
analyzed: aggidevaḥ varuṇadevaḥ ajjunaḥ pajjunaḥ ghaṭapaṇḍitaḥ aṅkuro ca ati tesu vāsudeva mahārājassa
translated: Aggideva, Varuṇadeva, Ajjunā, Pajjunna, Ghaṭapaṇḍita, and Aṅkura. Of these, the most excellent of all was King Vāsudeva.

original: piyaputto kālamakāsi. Tena rājā sokapareto sabbakiccāni pahāya mañcassa aṭaniṃ pariggahetvā🔽vippalapanto nipajji. Tasmiṃ kāle ghaṭapaṇḍito cintesi – “ṭhapetvā maṃ añño koci
analyzed: piya putto kālam akāsi tena rājā soka paretaḥ sabba kiccāni pahāya mañcassa aṭanim pariggahetvā  vippalapantaḥ nipajji tasmin kāle ghaṭa paṇḍito cintesi ṭhapetvā mama añño koci
translated: The beloved son of King Vāsudeva died. Thereupon the king, overwhelmed with grief, abandoned all his duties, took the legs of the bedstead in his hands,🔽and lay down, lamenting. At that moment Ghaṭapaṇḍita thought to himself, “There is no one able to remove the grief of my brother except myself.

original: mama bhātu sokaṃ pariharituṃ samattho nāma natthi, upāyenassa sokaṃ harissāmī”ti.
analyzed: mama bhātu sokam pariharitum samatthaḥ nāma na atthi upāyena assa sokam harissāmi iti
translated: I will remove his grief by a certain expedient.”

original: So ummattakavesaṃ gahetvā “sasaṃ me detha, sasaṃ me dethā”ti ākāsaṃ olokento sakalanagaraṃ
analyzed: saḥ ummattaka vesam gahetvā sasam me detha sasam me detha ati ākāsam olokentaḥ sakala nagaram
translated: He took on the appearance of a madman, and crying out, “Give me a hare, give me a hare,” he roamed all over the city, looking up into the air.

original: vicari. “Ghaṭapaṇḍito ummattako jāto”ti sakalanagaraṃ saṅkhubhi.
analyzed: ghaṭa paṇḍitaḥ ummattakaḥ sakala nagaram
translated: The whole city was in an uproar, saying, “Ghaṭa the Wise has gone mad.”

original: Tasmiṃ kāle rohiṇeyyo nāma amacco vāsudevarañño santikaṃ gantvā tena saddhiṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpento –
analyzed: tasmin kāle rohiṇeyyaḥ nāma amaccaḥ vāsudeva rañño santikam gantvā tena saddhim katham samuṭṭhāpentaḥ
translated: At that time a minister named Rohiṇeyya went to King Vāsudeva and began a conversation with him, saying,

original: “Uṭṭhehi kaṇha kiṃ sesi, ko attho supanena te;
analyzed: uṭṭhehi kaṇha kim sesi kaḥ atthaḥ supanena te
translated: “Rise up, O Kaṇha, why do you lie? What profit is there in sleeping?

original: Yo ca tuyhaṃ sako bhātā, hadayaṃ cakkhu ca dakkhiṇaṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ ca tuyham sakaḥ bhātā hadayam cakkhu ca dakkhiṇam
translated: Your own brother, whose heart and right eye are yours,

original: Tassa vātā balīyanti, sasaṃ jappati kesavā”ti. – imaṃ gāthamāha;🔽207. Tattha kaṇhāti vāsudevaṃ gottenālapati. Ko attho supanena teti supanena tuyhaṃ🔽kā nāma vaḍḍhi. Sako bhātāti sodariyo bhātā. Hadayaṃ cakkhu ca dakkhiṇanti hadayena
analyzed: tassa vātāḥ balīyanti sasam jappati kesavāti imam gātham āha  tattha kaṇhā ati vāsudevam gottena ālapati kaḥ atthaḥ supanena te iti supanena tuyham  kā nāma vaḍḍhi sakaḥ bhātā ati sodariyaḥ bhātā hadayam cakkhu ca dakkhiṇanti hadayena
translated: is being tormented by the wind, and he is muttering something about a hare.”🔽Here Kaṇha is a designation for Vāsudeva. What profit is there in sleeping? What profit is there in sleeping for you?

original: ceva dakkhiṇacakkhunā ca sadisoti attho. Tassa vātā balīyantīti tassa aparāparaṃ
analyzed: ca iva dakkhiṇa cakkhunā ca sadisaḥ ti attho tassa vātāḥ balīyanti iti tassa apara aparam
translated: What increase is there? Your own brother, your uterine brother. Whose heart and right eye are yours, whose heart and right eye are like yours. He is being tormented by the wind.

original: uppajjamānā ummādavātā balavanto honti vaḍḍhanti abhibhavanti. Sasaṃ jappatīti “sasaṃ
analyzed: uppajjamānāḥ ummāda vātāḥ balavantaḥ honti vaḍḍhanti abhibhavanti sasam jappati iti sasam
translated: The winds of madness arose in him, strong, increasing, overpowering. He chattered, saying, “Give me a hare.”

original: me dethā”ti vippalapati. Kesavāti so kira kesānaṃ sobhanānaṃ atthitāya “kesavo”ti
analyzed: me detha iti vippalapati kesava ati saḥ kira kesānam sobhanānam atthitāya kesava iti
translated: “Kesava” is so called because of the presence of beautiful hair.

original: voharīyati. Tena naṃ nāmena ālapati.
analyzed: tena nam nāmena ālapati
translated: He addressed him by that name.

original: Tassa vacanaṃ sutvā sayanato uṭṭhitabhāvaṃ dīpento satthā abhisambuddho hutvā –

translated: The Teacher, after attaining enlightenment, uttered this stanza, showing how the king arose from his bed after hearing his words:

original: “Tassa taṃ vacanaṃ sutvā, rohiṇeyyassa kesavo;
analyzed: tassa tam vacanam sutvā rohiṇeyyassa kesavaḥ
translated: “Having heard his words,🔽Kesava of the ruddy hue arose quickly,

original: Taramānarūpo vuṭṭhāsi, bhātu sokena aṭṭito”ti. – imaṃ gāthamāha;
analyzed: taramāna rūpaḥ vuṭṭhāsi bhātu sokena aṭṭitaḥ iti imam gātham āha
translated: Afflicted with grief for his brother.”

original: Rājā uṭṭhāya sīghaṃ pāsādā otaritvā ghaṭapaṇḍitassa santikaṃ gantvā ubhosu hatthesu naṃ daḷhaṃ gahetvā tena saddhiṃ sallapanto –🔽“Kiṃ nu ummattarūpova, kevalaṃ dvārakaṃ imaṃ;

translated: The king arose and quickly descended from the palace. He went to the presence of Ghaṭīkāra, seized him firmly by both hands, and, conversing with him, said:🔽“Why are you like one mad,

original: Saso sasoti lapasi, kīdisaṃ sasamicchasi.
analyzed: saso saso iti lapasi kīdisam sasam icchasi
translated: chatting alone at the gate, ‘Hare, hare’? What kind of hare do you desire?

original: “Sovaṇṇamayaṃ maṇimayaṃ, lohamayaṃ atha rūpiyamayaṃ;
analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayam maṇi mayam loha mayam atha rūpiya mayam
translated: “Golden, gem-like, iron, or silver-like,

analyzed: santi aññe pi sasakāḥ arañña vana gocarā
translated: “There are other hares, too, that range the forest and the trees.

translated: I’ll bring them to you. What sort of hare do you want?”

original: Tisso gāthāyo abhāsi.
analyzed: tissaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi

original: 209-211. Tattha ummattarūpovāti ummattako viya. Kevalanti sakalaṃ. Dvārakanti dvāravatīnagaraṃ🔽vicaranto. Saso sasoti lapasīti saso sasoti vilapasi. Sovaṇṇamayanti suvaṇṇamayaṃ.
analyzed: tattha ummatta rūpā uvāti ummattakaḥ viya kevalanti sakalam dvārakanti dvāravatī nagaram  vicarantaḥ sasaḥ sasaḥ iti lapasi iti sasaḥ sasaḥ iti vilapasi sovaṇṇa mayanti suvaṇṇa mayam
translated: Herein, as if he were mad is as if he were insane. All is entire. Dvāraka is the city of Dvāravatī.🔽Wandering about is wandering about. Hare, hare is a hare, a hare. You lament is you lament. Golden is of gold.

original: Lohamayanti tambalohamayaṃ. Rūpiyamayanti rajatamayaṃ. Yaṃ icchasi taṃ vadehi, atha
analyzed: loha mayanti tamba loha mayam rūpiya mayanti rajata mayam yam icchasi tam vadehi atha
translated: Iron is of iron. Silver is of silver. Whatever you want, say it, then

analyzed: kena socasi aññe pi araññe vanagocarā sasakā atthi te te ānayissāmi vada bhadra mukha
translated: what are you lamenting about? There are other hares, too, that range the forest and the trees. I’ll bring them to you. Tell me, good sir,

analyzed: kīdisam sasam icchasi iti ghaṭa paṇḍitam sasena atthikaḥ iti adhippāyena sasena nimantesi

original: Taṃ sutvā ghaṭapaṇḍito –
analyzed: tam sutvā ghaṭapaṇḍitaḥ
translated: Having heard that, the clever potter said:

original: “Nāhamete sase icche, ye sasā pathavissitā;
analyzed: na aham ete sase icche ye sasā
translated: “I do not want these hares that are on the ground,

original: Candato sasamicchāmi, taṃ me ohara kesavā”ti. –
analyzed: candataḥ sasam icchāmi tam me ohara kesavāti
translated: Do you take it down for me.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha oharāti ohārehi. Taṃ sutvā rājā “nissaṃsayaṃ me bhātā ummattako jāto”ti domanassappatto –
analyzed: gātham āha tattha ohara ohārehi tam sutvā rājā nissaṃsayam me bhātā ummattakaḥ jātaḥ iti domanassa patto
translated: He spoke this verse. Herein, take it down means take it down. On hearing this the king became distressed, thinking: “No doubt my brother has gone mad,” and he spoke this verse:🔽“Surely you will give up the sweet,

original: “So nūna madhuraṃ ñāti, jīvitaṃ vijahissasi;
analyzed: saḥ nūna madhuram ñāti jīvitam vijahissasi
translated: The life of a kinsman,🔽You ask for what is not to be asked for,

analyzed: apatthiyam patthayasi candataḥ sasam icchasi iti
translated: You ask the moon for the hare.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha ñātīti kaniṭṭhaṃ ālapati. Ayamettha attho – mayhaṃ piyañāti yaṃ atimadhuraṃ attano jīvitaṃ, taṃ vijahissasi maññe, yo apatthayitabbaṃ patthesīti.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha ñātī iti kaniṭṭham ālapati ayam ettha atthaḥ mayham piya ñāti yam ati madhuram attanaḥ jīvitam tam vijahissasi maññe yaḥ a patthayitabbam patthesi iti
translated: Herein, kinsman he calls his younger brother. The meaning is this: “You will surely give up the life that is so sweet to me, you who ask for what is not to be asked for.”

original: Ghaṭapaṇḍito rañño vacanaṃ sutvā niccalova ṭhatvā “bhātika, tvaṃ candato sasaṃ patthentassa
analyzed: ghaṭapaṇḍitaḥ raññaḥ vacanam sutvā niccalaḥ uva ṭhatvā bhātika tvam candataḥ sasam patthentassa
translated: On hearing the king’s words, Ghaṭīkāra stood still and thought: “Brother, you ask the moon for the hare,

analyzed: tam a labhitvā jīvita kkhayaḥ bhavissati iti jānantaḥ kasmā matam puttam a labhitvā anusocasi iti
translated: and knowing that you will die without getting it, why do you grieve for your dead son without getting him?”

original: imamatthaṃ dīpento –

translated: “If you know, O Kaṇha, as you advise,

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha evaṃ ce, kaṇha, jānāsīti, bhātika, kaṇhanāmaka mahārāja, “alabbhaneyyavatthu
analyzed: gātham āha tattha evam ce kaṇha jānāsi iti bhātika kaṇha nāmaka mahā rāja alabbhaneyya vatthu
translated: If you know this, O King, that a thing that cannot be obtained is not to be sought after,

original: nāma na patthetabba”nti yadi evaṃ jānāsi. Yathaññanti evaṃ jānantova yathā aññaṃ🔽anusāsasi, tathā akatvā. Kasmā pure mataṃ puttanti atha kasmā ito catumāsamatthake
analyzed: nāma na patthetabbanti yadi evam jānāsi yathaññanti evam jānantaḥ uva yathā aññam  anusāsasi tathā a katvā kasmai pure atha kasmai ito catu māsa matthake
translated: then, knowing this, you should not act as you do.

original: mataṃ puttaṃ ajjāpi anusocasīti.
analyzed: matam puttam ajja api anusocasi iti
translated: Why, O Kanha, do you still mourn for your dead son? ”

original: Evaṃ so antaravīthiyaṃ ṭhitakova “ahaṃ tāva evaṃ paññāyamānaṃ patthemi, tvaṃ pana apaññāyamānassatthāya socasī”ti vatvā tassa dhammaṃ desento –
analyzed: evam saḥ antara vīthiyam ṭhitakaḥ uva aham tāva evam paññāyamānam patthemi tvam pana a paññāyamānassa atthāya socasi iti vatvā tassa dhammaṃ desento
translated: Thus, standing in the middle of the street, he said, “I seek a thing that can be obtained, but you mourn for a thing that cannot be obtained.” And he preached the Law to him, saying,

original: “Na yaṃ labbhā manussena, amanussena vā pana;
analyzed: na yam labbhā manussena amanussena vā pana
translated: “That which a man or a non-human being cannot obtain,

translated: ‘Let my son be born and not die,’—how can a thing that cannot be obtained be obtained?

translated: “By incantations, by roots and herbs, by medicine, or by wealth,🔽O Kanha, you cannot recall your dead son.”

analyzed: sakkā ānayitum kaṇha yam petam anusocasi iti gāthā dvayam āha

analyzed: tattha yanti bhātika yam evam jātaḥ me putto mā mari iti manussena vā devena  vā pana na labbhā na sakkā laddhum tam tvam patthesi tam pana itam kutas labbhā kena
translated: Herein, “Brother, you are asking for what cannot be got, what cannot be acquired by a man or by a god, namely that a son born to me should not die. But how can it be got? By whom can it be acquired?

original: kāraṇena laddhuṃ sakkā. Yasmā alabbhiyaṃ alabbhaneyyavatthu nāmetanti attho.🔽216. Mantāti mantappayogena. Mūlabhesajjāti mūlabhesajjena. Osadhehīti nānāvidhehi🔽osadhehi. Dhanena vāti koṭisatasaṅkhena dhanena vāpi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ petamanusocasi,
analyzed: kāraṇena laddhum sakkā yasmai alabbhiyam alabbhaneyya vatthu nāma etat ti attho  mantā ati mantappayogena mūlabhesajjā ati mūlabhesajjena osadhehi iti nānāvidhehi  osadhehi dhanena vā ati koṭi sata saṅkhena dhanena vā api idam vuttam hoti yam petam anusocasi
translated: Herein, “What you seek, dear brother,” is what is meant, “is impossible, is unobtainable, by a man or by a god, namely, that a son born thus to me should not die.” “ Why is it impossible? Because it is an unobtainable state, an unobtainable object.”

original: taṃ etehi mantappayogādīhipi ānetuṃ na sakkāti.
analyzed: tam etehi manta ppayoga ādīhi pi ānetum na sakkā ati
translated: “By spells” : by the use of spells. “By root-medicines” : by the use of root-medicines. “By herbs” : by the use of various kinds of herbs. “By wealth” : by the use of wealth amounting to a hundred thousand or a million. What is meant is: the one you mourn cannot be brought back even by the use of spells, etc.

original: Puna ghaṭapaṇḍito “bhātika, idaṃ maraṇaṃ nāma dhanena vā jātiyā vā vijjāya vā sīlena vā bhāvanāya vā na sakkā paṭibāhitu”nti dassento –
analyzed: puna ghaṭapaṇḍitaḥ bhātika idam maraṇam nāma dhanena vā jātiyā vā vijjāya vā sīlena vā bhāvanāya vā na sakkā paṭibāhitunti dassentaḥ
translated: Again, the wise Ghaṭīkāra, in order to show that this death is not to be warded off by wealth, by birth, by knowledge, by virtue, or by development, said:

analyzed: mahat dhanāḥ mahā bhogāḥ raṭṭhavantaḥ api khattiyā
translated: “Though they are very wealthy, have great possessions,🔽And are nobles ruling a country,🔽With abundant wealth and grain,

analyzed: te pi no ajara amarā
translated: They too are not free from aging and death.

original: “Khattiyā brāhmaṇā vessā, suddā caṇḍālapukkussā;
analyzed: khattiyāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ vessāḥ suddāḥ caṇḍālapukkussāḥ
translated: “Khattiyas, brahmans, vessas, suddas, candalas, and scavengers,

analyzed: ete caññe ca jātiyā te pi no ajara amarā
translated: These and others by their birth, are not immortal and ageless.

original: “Ye mantaṃ parivattenti, chaḷaṅgaṃ brahmacintitaṃ;
analyzed: ye mantam chaṣ aṅgam brahma cintitam
translated: “Those who recite the mantras, the six-factored Brahma-meditation,

original: Ete caññe ca vijjāya, tepi no ajarāmarā.
analyzed: ete caññe ca te pi no ajara amarā
translated: These and others by their knowledge, are not immortal and ageless.

original: “Isayo vāpi ye santā, saññatattā tapassino;
analyzed: isayaḥ vā api ye santā saññatattā tapassino
translated: “Or those ascetics who are calm, self-controlled, and austere,

original: Sarīraṃ tepi kālena, vijahanti tapassino.
analyzed: sarīram te api kālena vijahanti tapassinaḥ
translated: Even they, in time, must leave their bodies, those austere ones.

original: “Bhāvitattā arahanto, katakiccā anāsavā;
analyzed: bhāvita ttāḥ arahantaḥ kata kiccāḥ anāsavā
translated: “But those who are developed arahants, their work done, without taints,

analyzed: nikkhipanti imam deham puñña pāpa parikkhayā ti
translated: They lay down this body, with the exhaustion of merit and demerit.”

original: Pañcahi gāthāhi rañño dhammaṃ desesi.
analyzed: pañcahi gāthāhi raññaḥ dhammam desesi
translated: He taught the Dhamma to the king with five stanzas.

original: 217. Tattha mahaddhanāti nidhānagatasseva mahato dhanassa atthitāya bahudhanā. Mahābhogāti
analyzed: tattha mahat dhanā ati nidhāna gatassa iva mahataḥ dhanassa atthitāya bahu dhanāḥ mahā bhogā ti
translated: Herein, he is “very wealthy” because of the existence of great wealth stored up. “Greatly rich”

original: devabhogasadisāya mahatiyā bhogasampattiyā samannāgatā. Raṭṭhavantoti sakalaraṭṭhavanto.
analyzed: deva bhoga sadisāya mahatiyā bhoga sampattiyā samannāgatāḥ raṭṭhavanto ti sakala raṭṭhavanto
translated: means he is endowed with great prosperity like the gods’. “The whole country” means the whole country.

original: Pahūtadhanadhaññāseti tiṇṇaṃ catunnaṃ vā saṃvaccharānaṃ atthāya nidahitvā ṭhapetabbassa
analyzed: pahūta dhana dhaññāseti tiṇṇam catunnam vā saṃvaccharānam atthāya nidahitvā ṭhapetabbassa
translated: “With abundant wealth and corn” means that he has stored up for three or four years.

original: niccaparibbayabhūtassa dhanadhaññassa vasena apariyantadhanadhaññā. Tepi no ajarāmarāti
analyzed: nicca paribbaya bhūtassa dhana dhaññassa vasena a pariyanta dhana dhaññā te pi no ajarā amarā ti
translated: They are not ageless and deathless,

original: tepi evaṃ mahāvibhavā mandhātumahāsudassanādayo khattiyā ajarāmarā nāhesuṃ, aññadatthu
analyzed: te pi evam mahā vibhavāḥ mandhātu mahāsudassana ādayaḥ khattiyāḥ ajara amarāḥ na ahesuṃ aññadatthu
translated: they too, though they have such great wealth, such as King Mandhātu, Mahāsudassana, and so on, are not ageless and deathless.

original: maraṇamukhameva anupaviṭṭhāti attho.
analyzed: maraṇa mukham eva anupaviṭṭhā iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are not free from death.

original: 218. Eteti yathāvuttakhattiyādayo. Aññeti aññatarā evaṃbhūtā ambaṭṭhādayo. Jātiyāti attano jātinimittaṃ ajarāmarā nāhesunti attho.
analyzed: ete iti yathā vutta khattiya ādayaḥ aññe iti aññatarāḥ evaṃbhūtāḥ ambaṭṭha ādayaḥ jātiyā iti attanaḥ jāti nimittam ajara amarāḥ na ahesun ti attho
translated: These, etc. : these aforementioned khattiyas, etc., and others, such as Ambattha, etc., who are such, are not ageless and deathless because of their birth.

original: 219. Mantanti vedaṃ. Parivattentīti sajjhāyanti vācenti ca. Atha vā parivattentīti
analyzed: mantanti vedam parivattenti iti sajjhāyanti vācenti ca atha vā parivattenti iti
translated: Mant: the Veda. Reciting: reciting it, teaching it. Or else, reciting it means

original: vedaṃ anuparivattentā homaṃ karontā japanti. Chaḷaṅganti sikkhākappaniruttibyākaraṇajotisatthachandovicitisaṅkhātehi
analyzed: vedam anuparivattentāḥ homam karontāḥ japanti chaḷaṅganti sikkhākappa nirutti byākaraṇa joti sattha chandoviciti saṅkhātehi
translated: they recite the homa rite while reciting the Veda. The six-limbed: the Veda that is endowed with the six limbs called grammar, phonetics, ritual, astronomy, history, and metrics.

original: chahi aṅgehi yuttaṃ. Brahmacintitanti brāhmaṇānamatthāya brahmanā cintitaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: chahi aṅgehi yuttam brahma cintitanti brahmanā cintitam kathitam
translated: Brahma-conceived: conceived, taught, by the brahmas for the sake of the brahmins.

original: Vijjāyāti brahmasadisavijjāya samannāgatā, tepi no ajarāmarāti attho.
analyzed: vijjāya ati brahma sadisa vijjāya samannāgatā te pi no ajara amara ati
translated: Endowed with knowledge: endowed with knowledge like that of Brahma. The meaning is that they too are not ageless and deathless.

original: 220-221. Isayoti yamaniyamādīnaṃ paṭikūlasaññādīnañca esanaṭṭhena isayo. Santāti
analyzed: isayo ti yama niyama ādīnam paṭikūla saññā ādīnam ca esana ṭṭhena isayo santā ti
translated: The seers: they are seers in the sense of seeking the observances, the moral precepts, etc., and the perception of repulsiveness, etc.🔽They are calm: they are of the nature of being calm in body and speech.🔽They are restrained: they are of restrained mind by restraint of lust, etc.

original: kāyavācāhi santasabhāvā. Saññatattāti rāgādīnaṃ saṃyamena saṃyatacittā. Kāyatapanasaṅkhāto
analyzed: rāga ādīnam saṃyamena saṃyata cittā kāya tapana saṅkhātaḥ
translated: They are ascetics: they have austerity in the sense of tormenting the body.

original: tapo etesaṃ atthīti tapassino. Puna tapassinoti saṃvarakā. Tena evaṃ tapanissitakā
analyzed: tapaḥ etesam atthi iti tapassinaḥ puna tapassinaḥ ti saṃvarakā tena evam tapa nissitakā

original: 237-38.
