analyzed: uttasantā mahattāsāḥ na dassenti kurūrino
translated: and do not show themselves to their relatives.🔽His brother, having gone forth,

original: “Tassa bhātā vitaritvā, naggo ekapathekako;
analyzed: tassa bhātā vitaritvā naggaḥ eka pathekakaḥ
translated: naked, with one robe,🔽with four sores,

original: Catukuṇḍiko bhavitvāna, therassa dassayītumaṃ.
analyzed: catu kuṇḍikaḥ therassa
translated: showed himself to the Elder.🔽The Elder, not paying attention,

original: “Thero cāmanasikatvā, tuṇhībhūto atikkami;
analyzed: thero ca a manasikatvā tuṇhībhūtaḥ atikkami
translated: passed by in silence.

original: So ca viññāpayī theraṃ, ‘bhātā petagato ahaṃ’.
analyzed: so ca theram bhātā peta gataḥ aham
translated: He then informed the Elder: “I am your brother who has become a Peta.”

original: “Mātā pitā ca te bhante, duggatā yamalokikā;
analyzed: mātā pitā ca te bhante duggatā yama lokikā
translated: “Your mother and father, reverend Sir, are in a bad way, in the World of the Dead,

original: Pāpakammaṃ karitvāna, petalokaṃ ito gatā.
analyzed: pāpa kammam karitvāna peta lokam itas gatā
translated: Having done a bad deed, they have gone from here to the Petas’ realm.

original: “Tena duggatā sūcikaṭṭā, kilantā naggino kisā;
analyzed: tena duggatā sūcikaṭṭā kilantā naggino kisā
translated: “Therefore they are in a bad way, needle-mouthed, exhausted, naked, lean,

original: Uttasantā mahattāsā, na dassenti kurūrino.
analyzed: uttasantā mahattāsāḥ na dassenti kurūrino
translated: Shivering, hungry, thirsty, they do not show themselves, Kurus!”

original: “Anukampassu kāruṇiko, datvā anvādisāhi no;
analyzed: anukampassu kāruṇikaḥ da tvā anvādisāhi naḥ
translated: “Have compassion, you who are compassionate, having given, instruct us,

original: Tava dinnena dānena, yāpessanti kurūrino”ti.🔽408-9. Tattha kuṇḍināgariyo theroti evaṃnāmake nagare jātasaṃvaḍḍhatthero, “kuṇḍikanagaro
analyzed: tava dinnena dānena yāpessanti kurūrinā iti  tattha kuṇḍināgariyaḥ thero ti evaṃnāmake nagare jāta saṃvaḍḍha thero kuṇḍikanagaro
translated: By the gift given by you, Kurus will get by.”

original: thero”tipi pāṭho, so evattho. Sāṇavāsinivāsikoti sāṇapabbatavāsī. Poṭṭhapādoti nāmenāti
analyzed: thero ti pi pāṭho saḥ evattho sāṇa vāsinivāsiko ti sāṇa pabbata vāsī poṭṭhapādaḥ ti nāmena ati
translated: Herein, the Elder Kuṇḍina-nagariyo: the Elder who was born and grew up in a town of that name. “The Elder Kuṇḍi-nagara” is also a reading, and the meaning is just the same. Sāṇavāsinivāsiko: the dweller in the Sāṇa mountain. Poṭṭhapādoti nāmenāti

original: nāmena poṭṭhapādo nāma. Samaṇoti samitapāpo. Bhāvitindriyoti ariyamaggabhāvanāya
analyzed: nāmena poṭṭhapādaḥ nāma samaṇaḥ ati samita pāpaḥ ariya magga bhāvanāya
translated: by name Poṭṭhapāda. Samaṇo: one whose evil is destroyed. Bhāvitindriyo: one who has developed the faculties of faith, etc., by the development of the Noble Path.

original: bhāvitasaddhādiindriyo, arahāti attho. Tassāti tassa sāṇavāsittherassa. Duggatāti duggatigatā.
analyzed: bhāvita saddhā ādi indriyaḥ arahā ati attho tassa ati tassa sāṇavāsi ttherassa duggatā ati duggati gatā
translated: Arahā: the meaning is, he is a Worthy One. Tassāti of that Elder Sāṇavāsi. Duggatāti gone to a bad destination.

original: 410. Sūcikaṭṭāti pūtinā lūkhagattā aṭṭakā, sūcikāti laddhanāmāya khuppipāsāya aṭṭā
analyzed: sūcikaṭṭā ati pūtinā lūkha gattā aṭṭakā sūcikā ati laddha nāmāya khuppipāsāya aṭṭā
translated: Sūcikaṭṭāti with needle-like excrement, with a body like a goat’s, with needle-like hunger and thirst, which is what the name means.

original: pīḷitā. “Sūcikaṇṭhā”ti keci paṭhanti, sūcichiddasadisamukhadvārāti attho. Kilantāti
analyzed: pīḍitā sūcikaṇṭhā iti keci paṭhanti sūci chid dasa disa mukha dvārā ati attho kilantā iti
translated: “With needle-mouths” : some read “sūcikanthā” . The meaning is: with a mouth like a needle-eye. “With withered bodies” :

original: kilantakāyacittā. Nagginoti naggarūpā niccoḷā. Kisāti aṭṭhittacamattasarīratāya kisadehā.
analyzed: kilanta kāya cittā nagginī ti nagga rūpā niccoḷā kisā ati kisa dehā
translated: with bodies and minds withered. “With the appearance of old women” : with the appearance of old women, with permanent rags. “With shrunken bodies” : with bodies shrunken through lack of movement.

original: Uttasantāti “ayaṃ samaṇo amhākaṃ putto”ti ottappena utrāsaṃ āpajjantā. Mahattāsāti🔽attanā pubbe katakammaṃ paṭicca sañjātamahābhayā. Na dassentīti attānaṃ na dassenti,
analyzed: uttasantā ati ayam samaṇaḥ amhākam putto ti ottappena āpajjantā  attanā pubbe kata kammam paṭicca sañjāta mahā bhayāḥ na dassenti iti attānam na dassenti
translated: “With shame” : with shame, thinking “This recluse is our son.” “With fear” :🔽with great fear arisen through their own past kamma. “They do not show themselves” : they do not show themselves, they do not come into his presence.

original: sammukhībhāvaṃ na gacchanti. Kurūrinoti dāruṇakammantā.
analyzed: sammukhībhāvam na gacchanti dāruṇa kammantā
translated: “Cruel” : of cruel deeds.

original: 411. Tassa bhātāti sāṇavāsittherassa bhātā. Vitaritvāti vitiṇṇo hutvā, ottappasantāsabhayāti🔽attho. Vituritvāti vā pāṭho, turito hutvā, taramānarūpo hutvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Ekapatheti

original: Idāni byākaraṇaṃ dassento “ussannapuññāpi bhavanti heke, parittapuññāpi bhavanti
analyzed: idāni byākaraṇam dassentaḥ ussanna puññāḥ api bhavanti heke paritta puññāḥ api bhavanti

analyzed: heke iti āha tassa atthaḥ ussanna kusala dhammā api idha ekacce puggalāḥ laddha paccayassa  apuññassa vasena jāti ādinā nihīnāḥ bhavanti paritta puññāḥ api appatara puñña dhammāḥ api
translated: He said: “Some people here, though they have the good things of this world, are low-born, etc., because of their demerit, which is a condition for that.🔽Some people here, though they have the good things of this world, are low-born, etc., because of their demerit, which is a condition for that.🔽

original: eke sattā khettasampattiādinā tassa puññassa mahājutikatāya uḷārā bhavantīti.🔽454. Sīvathikāyāti susāne. Aṅguṭṭhasnehenāti aṅguṭṭhato pavattasnehena, devatāya
analyzed: eke sattā khetta sampatti ādinā tassa puññassa mahā jutika tāya uḷārāḥ bhavanti iti  sīvathikāya iti susāne aṅguṭṭha snehena ati aṅguṭṭhataḥ pavatta snehena devatāya
translated: He said: “Some” . Its meaning is this: Some persons, though they have risen up to the good things of the Dhamma, are low in birth, etc., by the power of demerit acquired by them. original: aṅguṭṭhato paggharitakhīrenāti attho. Na yakkhabhūtā na sarīsapā vāti pisācabhūtā
analyzed: aṅguṭṭhato paggharita khīrena ati atthaḥ na yakkha bhūtā na sarīsapā vāti pisāca bhūtā

Neither spirits nor snakes nor reptiles : neither demons nor spirits nor snakes nor any reptiles that crawl along.

original: vā yakkhabhūtā vā sarīsapā vā ye keci sarantā gacchantā vā na viheṭhayeyyuṃ na bādheyyuṃ.🔽455. Palihiṃsu pādeti attano jivhāya pāde lihisuṃ. Dhaṅkāti kākā. Parivattayantīti
analyzed: vā yakkha bhūtā vā sarīsapā vā ye keci sarantā gacchantā vā na viheṭhayeyyum na bādheyyum  pādā iti pāde lihisum dhaṅkā ati kākā parivattayanti iti
translated: They would not harm him, would not molest him.

original: “mā naṃ kumāraṃ keci viheṭheyyu”nti rakkhantā nirogabhāvajānanatthaṃ aparāparaṃ parivattanti.
analyzed: mā nam kumāram keci viheṭheyyunti rakkhantāḥ niroga bhāva jānana attham apara aparam parivattanti
translated: They would lick his feet with their tongues. Crows : birds called “crows.” They would carry him about : they would carry him about one after another, thinking: “Let no one molest this boy,” and knowing that he was healthy.

original: Gabbhāsayanti gabbhamalaṃ. Pakkhigaṇāti gijjhakulalādayo sakuṇagaṇā. Harantīti apanenti.
analyzed: gabbhāsayanti gabbha malam pakkhi gaṇā ati gijjha kulala ādayaḥ sakuṇa gaṇā haranti iti apanenti
translated: “In the womb” means in the womb’s filth. “Flocks of birds” means flocks of vultures, etc. “They carried off” means they removed.

original: Akkhimalanti akkhigūthaṃ.
analyzed: akkhi malanti akkhi gūtham
translated: “Eye-filth” means eye-discharge.

original: 456. Kecīti keci manussā, amanussā pana rakkhaṃ saṃvidahiṃsu. Osadhanti tadā āyatiñca
analyzed: keci iti keci manussāḥ amanussāḥ pana rakkham saṃvidahiṃsu osadhanti tadā āyatim ca
translated: “Some” means some people. But the non-human beings made a protection. “Medicines” means a panacea that brings about health then and in the future.

original: ārogyāvahaṃ agadaṃ. Sāsapadhūpanaṃ vāti yaṃ jātassa dārakassa rakkhaṇatthaṃ sāsapena🔽dhūpanaṃ karonti, tampi tassa karontā nāhesunti dīpenti. Nakkhattayogampi na aggahesunti
analyzed: ārogya āvaham agadam sāsapa dhūpanam vāti yam jātassa dārakassa rakkhaṇa attham sāsapena  dhūpanam karonti tam pi tassa karontā dīpenti nakkhatta yogam pi na aggahesunti
translated: “Smoke from the burning of asafoetida” means that for the sake of protecting the child that has been born, they make smoke with asafoetida.🔽They did not do that for him either, is what they are showing. “They did not take up the conjunction of the stars” means

original: nakkhattayuttampi na gaṇhiṃsu. “Asukamhi nakkhatte tithimhi muhutte ayaṃ jāto”ti
analyzed: nakkhatta yuttam pi na gaṇhiṃsu asukamhi nakkhatte tithimhi muhutte ayam jātaḥ iti

analyzed: evam jātakammam pissa na keci akaṃsu iti atthaḥ na sabba dhaññāni api ākiriṃsu iti maṅgalam
translated: in this way, they are showing that no one did his birth horoscope. “They did not scatter all the grains” means

analyzed: karontā agada vasena yam sāsapa tela missitam sāli ādi dhaññam ākiranti tam pissa attho
translated: that they did not scatter the grains of rice, etc., mixed with asafoetida and ginger for the sake of a blessing.

original: 457. Etādisanti evarūpaṃ. Uttamakicchapattanti paramakicchaṃ āpannaṃ ativiya dukkhappattaṃ.
analyzed: etādisam ti evarūpam uttama kiccha pattam ti parama kiccham āpannam ativiya dukkha ppattam
translated: ‘Such as this’: of such a kind. ‘Has reached the ultimate suffering’: has reached the ultimate, the worst, suffering.

original: Rattābhatanti rattiyaṃ ābhataṃ. Nonītapiṇḍaṃ viyāti navanītapiṇḍasadisaṃ, maṃsapesimattatā
analyzed: rattiyam ābhatam nonīta piṇḍam viyāti navanīta piṇḍa sadisam maṃsa pesi matta tā
translated: ‘Eaten at night’: eaten at night. ‘Like a lump of butter’: like a lump of fresh butter.🔽This is said because of the size of the piece of meat.

analyzed: evam vuttam pavedhamānanti dubbala bhāvena pakampamānam sasaṃsayanti jīvati nu
translated: ‘Shaking’: shaking because of weakness. ‘In doubt’: in doubt as to whether he is alive or not.

original: kho na nu kho jīvatī”ti saṃsayitatāya saṃsayavantaṃ. Jīvitasāvasesanti jīvitaṭṭhitiyā🔽hetubhūtānaṃ sādhanānaṃ abhāvena kevalaṃ jīvitamattāvasesakaṃ.
analyzed: kho na nu kho jīvati iti saṃsayitatāya saṃsayavantam jīvita sāvasesanti jīvita ṭṭhitiyā  hetu bhūtānam sādhanānam abhāvena kevalam jīvita matta avasesakam
translated: ‘The remainder of his life’: the remainder of his life alone, because there is no longer any means of prolonging it.

analyzed: agga kulikaḥ bhavissati bhogataḥ ca ati bhoga nimittam bhogassa vasena agga kulikaḥ seṭṭha kulikaḥ bhavissati iti attho  kissa vatanti ayam gāthā satthu santike ṭhitehi upāsakehi tena kata kammassa
translated: ‘He will be the chief of the family in wealth’: he will be the chief of the family, the best of the family, because of wealth, for the sake of wealth.🔽‘What is this?’: this verse was spoken by lay followers who were standing in the presence of the Teacher in the way of asking about the deed he had done.

analyzed: kim assa vatanti vata samādānam puna kissa ati kīdisassa su ciṇṇassa vatassa brahmacariyassa  ca ati vibhattim vipariṇāmetvā yojanāḥ etādisanti gaṇikāya kucchiyāḥ nibbattanam su sāne  evarūpam anattham tādisanti tathārūpam aṅguṭṭha snehena
translated: What is it? It is the result of the observance of the holy life. Again, what is it? translated: Herein, people is a multitude of people, a group of laymen is the meaning. Therein is in that worship.

translated: The mind of that boy was otherwise, the mind was different from what it had been in a previous existence.

translated: they prepared a great quantity of food, such as sesamum, rice, etc., and such condiments as ghee, fresh butter, honey, etc., and set rolling the great wheel of giving.🔽Now at that time this courtesan was without faith, without confidence, her heart overspread with the tangle of cupidity-attachment. translated: And those who are ever-attentive: the meaning in brief of this verse of conclusion is this: I, too, who am restrained from killing breathing things even at night, experience such prosperity. But those who are men who are constantly and firmly devoted to the Buddha, the Blessed One’s Dispensation, which is headed by the Higher Virtue, they, being meritorious, experience only the happiness of the world, which is unmixed with the happiness of the worlds, and which is called the ‘unformed element’ .🔽

original: laddhanāmaṃ amatameva adhigacchanti maññe, natthi tesaṃ tadadhigame koci vibandhoti.

translated: Ye ca te satatānuyoginoti. The meaning of this verse, which is the last of the series, is as follows: “I, who am free from the sin of killing living creatures, even I have experienced such prosperity. But those who are constantly and firmly devoted to the practice of the higher morality, etc., in the Dispensation of the Sugata, the Buddha, the Blessed One, who are devoted to it constantly and at all times, they, being virtuous, attain the Deathless, which is called the ‘unformed state’ because it is not mixed with the happiness of the world, and which is, as it were, their own. There is no obstacle to their attaining it.”

translated: “Gentle” : mild. “Easy to speak to” : easy to converse with. “Easy to live with” : easy to associate with. “Humble” : his speech is humble. “Not a grumbler” : he does not grumble. “Not envious” : he is not jealous. “Not fraudulent” : he is not deceitful. “Not obstinate” : he is not obstinate. “Not domineering” : he is not overbearing. “Not fawning” : he is not a flatterer. “Not devious” : he is not crooked. “Not a cheat” : he is not a deceiver. “Not a liar” : he is not a liar. “Not a slanderer” : he does not slander others. “Not a talebearer” : he does not carry tales. “Not greedy” : he is not greedy. “Not malicious” : he is not malicious. “Not given to conceit” : he is not conceited. “Content” : he is satisfied. “Easy to support” : he is easy to maintain. “Not haughty” : he is not proud. “Not wrapped up in a tangle” : he is not wrapped up in a tangle of defilements. “Not agitated” : he is not agitated by defilements. “Not excitable” : he is not excitable by defilements. “Not muddle-minded” : he is not muddle-minded by defilements. “Not weak-willed” : he is not weak-willed by defilements. “Not a rebel” : he is not a rebel against the Teacher, the Dhamma, the Sangha, and the training. “Not a murmurer” : he does not murmur against the Teacher, the Dhamma, the Sangha, and the training. “Not a hypocrite” : he is not a hypocrite by way of bodily action, etc. “Not a deceiver of families” : he does not deceive families by way of bodily action, etc. “Not contemptuous” : he is not contemptuous by way of bodily action, etc. “Not envious” : he is not envious of gains, honour, etc. “Not fraudulent” : he is not fraudulent by way of bodily action, etc

original: 551. Disvāpi na ca sujānoti gambhīrabhāvena disvāpi “evaṃsīlo, evaṃdhammo, evaṃpañño”ti
analyzed: disvā api na ca su jānoti gambhīra bhāvena disvā api evaṃsīlaḥ evaṃdhammo evaṃpañño ti
translated: Though seeing him, one cannot know him well,🔽by reason of his profundity.🔽The yakkhas know him, and those who are passionless,

original: na suviññeyyo. Jānanti taṃ yakkhabhūtā anejanti yakkhabhūtā ca anejaṃ nittaṇhaṃ “arahā”ti
analyzed: na su viññeyyaḥ jānanti tam yakkha bhūtāḥ anejanti yakkha bhūtā ca anejam nittaṇham arahāti
translated: The yakkhas and those who are passionless, who are free from craving, know him as an Arahant.🔽He of good character,

analyzed: tam jānanti sundara sīla ādi guṇam
translated: He of good character, of good virtue, etc.,🔽His,🔽His, the Elder Kappina Maha Thera’s,

original: 552. Tassāti tassa kappitakamahātherassa. Ekayuganti ekaṃ vatthayugaṃ. Duve vāti
analyzed: tassa ati tassa kappitaka mahā therassa eka yugam ti ekam vattha yugam duve vā
translated: one pair of garments,🔽two pairs of garments,🔽and let them be accepted by me.

original: dve vā vatthayugāni. Mamuddisitvānāti mamaṃ uddisitvā. Paṭiggahītāni ca tāni assūti🔽tāni vatthayugāni tena paṭiggahitāni ca assu bhaveyyuṃ. Sannaddhadussanti dussena
analyzed: dve vā vattha yugāni uddisitvā na ati uddisitvā paṭiggahītāni ca tāni assu iti  tāni vattha yugāni tena paṭiggahitāni ca assu bhaveyyum sannaddha dussanti dussena
translated: And let them be accepted by him.🔽Clad in a robe,

original: katasannāhaṃ, laddhavatthaṃ nivatthapārutadussanti attho.
analyzed: kata sannāham laddha vattham nivattha pāruta dussanti
translated: Clad in a robe, having put on a robe, having clothed himself, having covered himself with a robe, is the meaning.

original: Tato rājā –🔽“Kasmiṃ padese samaṇaṃ vasantaṃ, gantvāna passemu mayaṃ idāni;
analyzed: tatas rājā  kasmin padese samaṇam vasantam gantvāna passemu mayam idāni
translated: Then the king said:🔽“In what region may we now go and see the recluse,🔽Who will remove my doubt, my uncertainty,

original: Yo majja kaṅkhaṃ vicikicchitañca, diṭṭhīvisūkāni vinodayeyyā”ti. –
analyzed: yaḥ majja kaṅkham vicikicchitam ca diṭṭhī visūkāni vinodayeyyāti
translated: And the dart of false views?”

original: Therassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ pucchi. Tattha kasmiṃ padeseti katarasmiṃ padese. Yo majjāti yo ajja, ma-kāro padasandhikaro.
analyzed: therassa vasanaṭṭhānam pucchi tattha kasmin padese iti katarasmin padese yaḥ majja ati yaḥ ajja makāro pada sandhi karo
translated: He asked where the Elder’s dwelling-place was. There, in what region? In what place? Yo majjā means he who today; the syllable ma- is a syllable used to link phrases.

original: Tato peto –
analyzed: tataḥ pa itaḥ
translated: Then the ghost

original: “Eso nisinno kapinaccanāyaṃ, parivārito devatāhi bahūhi;
analyzed: esaḥ nisinnaḥ parivāritaḥ devatāhi bahūhi
translated: “Here sits the one called Sacca, surrounded by many a god,

original: Dhammiṃ kathaṃ bhāsati saccanāmo, sakasmimācerake appamatto”ti. –
analyzed: dhammim katham bhāsati sacca nāmo sakasmim ācerake appamatto ti
translated: In a little forest grove, heedful, he speaks a discourse on Dhamma.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha kapinaccanāyanti kapīnaṃ vānarānaṃ naccanena “kapinaccanā”ti laddhavohāre
analyzed: gātham āha tattha laddha vohāre
translated: He spoke this verse. Herein, in a little forest grove means in a place that has the name “a little forest grove” because of the dancing of the monkeys, the apes.

original: padese. Saccanāmoti jhāyī susīlo arahā vimuttotiādīhi guṇanāmehi yāthāvanāmo aviparītanāmo.
analyzed: padese sacca nāmo ti jhāyī su sīlaḥ arahā vimutto ti ādīhi guṇa nāmehi yāthāva nāmo aviparīta nāmo
translated: The one called Sacca means the one who is called “true” by such names of special qualities as “one who has attained jhāna,” “one of good virtue,” “a perfected one,” “a liberated one,” and so on, and who is called “true” in the true sense, not falsely.

original: Evaṃ petena vutte rājā tāvadeva therassa santikaṃ gantukāmo –
analyzed: evam petena vutte rājā tāvat eva therassa santikam gantu kāmo
translated: When the ghost had spoken thus, the king, who was eager to go straight away to the Elder’s presence,

analyzed: paṭiggahītāni ca tāni assu tuvam ca passemu sannaddha dussanti
translated: And let them be accepted by him; and let us see you in your armour.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha kassāmīti karissāmi.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha kassāmi iti karissāmi
translated: He spoke this verse. Herein, I will do it means I will go and do it.

original: Atha peto “devatānaṃ thero dhammaṃ deseti, tasmā nāyaṃ upasaṅkamanakālo”ti dassento –
analyzed: atha peto devatānam theraḥ dhammam deseti tasmā na ayam upasaṅkamana kālo ti dassento
translated: Then the ghost, thinking “The Elder is preaching the Dhamma to the deities, so this is not the time to approach him,” showed the king the way to the Elder by reciting the following stanza:

original: “Mā akkhaṇe pabbajitaṃ upāgami, sādhu vo licchavi nesa dhammo;
analyzed: mā akkhaṇe pabbajitam upāgami sādhu vaḥ licchavi na isa dhammo
translated: “Do not approach the monk at the wrong time; it is not right for you, Licchavi king,

analyzed: tato ca kāle upasaṅkamitvā tattha iva passāhi raho nisinnanti
translated: To do so. But when the time is right, approach him, and you will see him sitting in seclusion.”

original: Gāthamāha. Tattha sādhūti āyācane nipāto. Vo licchavi nesa dhammoti, licchavirāja, tumhākaṃ rājūnaṃ esa dhammo na hoti, yaṃ akāle upasaṅkamanaṃ. Tatthevāti tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha sādhu iti āyācane nipātaḥ vaḥ licchavi na isa dhammo ti licchavi rāja tumhākam esa dhammo na hoti yam akāle upasaṅkamanam tattha iva ati tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne
translated: In this stanza, the word sādhū is an exclamation. The words vo Licchavi nesa dhammo mean, “Licchavi king, this is not the right thing for you to do, namely, to approach the Elder at the wrong time.” The words tattheva mean “in that very place.”

original: Evaṃ petena vutte rājā “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā attano nivesanameva gantvā puna yuttapattakāle🔽aṭṭha vatthuyugāni gāhāpetvā theraṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisinno paṭisanthāraṃ
analyzed: evam petena vutte rājā sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā attanaḥ nivesanam eva gantvā puna yutta patta kāle  aṭṭha vatthu yugāni gāhāpetvā theram upasaṅkamitvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ paṭisanthāram
translated: When the ghost had spoken thus, the king assented by saying “Sādhu.” He then returned to his own residence and, when the time was right,

original: katvā “imāni, bhante, aṭṭha vatthayugāni paṭiggaṇhā”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā thero kathāsamuṭṭhāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: katvā imāni bhante aṭṭha vattha yugāni paṭiggaṇhāti āha tam sutvā theraḥ kathā samuṭṭhāpana tham
translated: had eight sets of garments brought and approached the Elder. Sitting down to one side, he exchanged greetings with the Elder and then said, “Venerable sir, please accept these eight sets of garments.” In order to begin the discussion, the Elder asked the king,🔽“Great king, where did you get these garments?”

original: “mahārāja, pubbe tvaṃ adānasīlo samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ viheṭhanajātikova kathaṃ paṇītāni🔽vatthāni dātukāmo jāto”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā rājā tassa kāraṇaṃ ācikkhanto petena samāgamaṃ,
analyzed: mahā rāja pubbe tvam a dāna sīlaḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇānam viheṭhana jātikaḥ uva katham paṇītāni  vatthāni dātu kāmaḥ jātaḥ iti āha tam sutvā rājā tassa kāraṇam ācikkhantaḥ petena samāgamam
translated: “Great king, formerly you were of a niggardly disposition, and you were given to persecuting recluses and brahmans. How is it that you have now become so generous as to give away such fine garments?”🔽Hearing this, the king told the Elder the reason why, and related the conversation he had had with the ghost.

original: tena ca attanā ca kathitaṃ sabbaṃ therassa ārocetvā vatthāni datvā petassa uddisi.
analyzed: tena ca attanā ca kathitam sabbam therassa ārocetvā vatthāni da tvā petassa uddisi
translated: Then he gave the garments to the Elder, and directed him to give them to the ghost.🔽Thereupon the ghost, clad in celestial garments, adorned with celestial ornaments, mounted on a celestial steed,

original: Tena peto dibbavatthadharo alaṅkatapaṭiyatto assāruḷho therassa ca rañño ca purato🔽pātubhavi. Taṃ disvā rājā attamano pamudito pītisomanassajāto “paccakkhato vata mayā
analyzed: tena petaḥ dibba vattha dharaḥ alaṅkata paṭiyattaḥ assa āruḷho therassa ca rañño ca puratas  pātubhavi tam disvā rājā atta manaḥ pamuditaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ paccakkhataḥ vata mayā
translated: appeared before the Elder and the king.

original: kammaphalaṃ diṭṭhaṃ, na dānāhaṃ pāpaṃ karissāmi, puññameva karissāmī”ti vatvā tena🔽petena sakkhiṃ akāsi. So ca peto “sace, tvaṃ licchavirāja, ito paṭṭhāya adhammaṃ
analyzed: kamma phalam diṭṭham na dāna aham pāpam karissāmi puññam eva karissāmi iti vatvā tena  petena sakkhim akāsi saḥ ca peto sace tvam licchavi rāja itas paṭṭhāya adhammaṃ
translated: Seeing him, the king was filled with joy and gladness, and said, “Now have I seen with my own eyes the fruit of deeds. Henceforth I will do no evil, but will do only that which is good.” So saying, he made a solemn asseveration to the ghost.

original: pahāya dhammaṃ carasi, evāhaṃ tava sakkhiṃ karissāmi, santikañca te āgamissāmi, sūlāvutañca
analyzed: pahāya dhammam carasi eva aham tava sakkhim karissāmi santikam ca te āgamissāmi sūlāvutam ca
translated: The ghost replied, “If, Licchavi king, you will henceforth abandon unrighteousness and follow the path of righteousness, I will make a solemn asseveration to you, and will come and visit you, and will bring you a skein of thread.”

original: purisaṃ sīghaṃ sūlato mocehi, evaṃ so jīvitaṃ labhitvā dhammaṃ caranto dukkhato muccissati,
analyzed: purisam sīgham sūlataḥ mocehi evam saḥ jīvitam labhitvā dhammam carantaḥ dukkhataḥ muccissati

original: therañca kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ suṇanto puññāni karohī”ti vatvā gato.
analyzed: theram ca kālena kālam upasaṅkamitvā dhammam suṇanto puññāni karohi iti vatvā gataḥ
translated: And from time to time go and visit the Elder and listen to the Law and perform works of merit.” So saying, he departed.

analyzed: atha rājā theram vanditvā nagaram pavisitvā sīgham sīgham liccha viparisam sannipātetvā

analyzed: theram ca upasaṅkamitvā pucchi siyā nu kho bhante niraya gāmi kammam katvā ṭhitassa

analyzed: nirayataḥ mutti iti siyā mahā rāja sace uḷāram puññam karoti muccati iti vatvā thero
translated: “Yes, great king, if he performs works of merit on a grand scale.” So saying, the Elder

analyzed: rājānam saraṇesu ca sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpesi saḥ tattha patiṭṭhitaḥ therassa ovāde ṭhatvā
translated: established the king in the Refuges and the Precepts. The king, established therein, followed the advice of the Elder,

analyzed: sotāpanno ahosi sūlāvutaḥ pana puriso arogaḥ hutvā saṃvega jātaḥ bhikkhūsu pabbajitvā
translated: and became a Stream-enterer. The man who had been impaled, having been restored to health, was filled with remorse, and retired from the world and became a monk under the monks.

analyzed: nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi tam attham dassentā saṅgīti kārā
translated: and in no long time attained Arahantship. The Reciters of the Dhamma, wishing to show this, said:

analyzed: tathā ati vatvā agamāsi tattha parivāritaḥ dāsa gaṇena licchavi
translated: “Having said ‘So it is,’ he went there, the Licchavī surrounded by a crowd of slaves.

analyzed: saḥ tam nagaram upasaṅkamitvā vāsū upagacchittha sake nivesane
translated: Having approached the city, he took up residence in his own house.

original: “Tato ca kāle gihikiccāni katvā,
analyzed: tatas ca kāle gihikiccāni katvā
translated: “Then, having done his duties as a householder,

analyzed: nhatvā pivitvā ca khaṇam labhitvā
translated: having bathed and drunk, having obtained a moment’s time,

analyzed: viceyya peḷāto ca yugāni aṭṭha
translated: having taken out eight pairs of garments from his chest,

original: Gāhāpayī dāsagaṇena licchavi.
analyzed: dāsa gaṇena licchavi
translated: the Licchavī had them given to the crowd of slaves.

original: “So taṃ padesaṃ upasaṅkamitvā, taṃ addasa samaṇaṃ santacittaṃ;
analyzed: saḥ tam padesam upasaṅkamitvā tam addasa samaṇam santa cittam
translated: “Having approached that place, he saw the ascetic of peaceful mind,

original: Paṭikkantaṃ gocarato nivattaṃ, sītibhūtaṃ rukkhamūle nisinnaṃ.
analyzed: paṭikkantam gocarataḥ nivattam sīti bhūtam rukkha mūle nisinnam
translated: returning from his alms round, sitting at the foot of a tree, cooled down.

original: “Tamenamavoca upasaṅkamitvā, appābādhaṃ phāsuvihārañca pucchi;
analyzed: tam enam avoca upasaṅkamitvā appa ābādham phāsu vihāram ca pucchi
translated: “Having approached him, he said to him: ‘Are you in good health? Do you live at ease?

original: Vesāliyaṃ licchavihaṃ bhadante, jānanti maṃ licchavi ambasakkaro.
analyzed: vesāliyam liccha viham bhadante jānanti mam licchavi ambasakkaro
translated: In Vesālī, venerable sir, the Licchavīs know me as the Licchavī Ambasakkha.

original: “Imāni me aṭṭha yugā subhāni, paṭiggaṇha bhante padadāmi tuyhaṃ;
analyzed: imāni me aṭṭha yugā subhāni paṭiggaṇha bhante padadāmi tuyhaṃ
translated: “‘These eight fine pairs of garments are mine; accept them, venerable sir, I give them to you.

analyzed: tena iva atthena idha āgataḥ asmi yathā aham atta manaḥ bhaveyyanti
translated: For that very purpose I have come here, that I may be satisfied with myself.’

original: “Dūratova samaṇā brāhmaṇā ca, nivesanaṃ te parivajjayanti;
analyzed: dūratas uva samaṇāḥ brāhmaṇā ca nivesanam te parivajjayanti
translated: “Monks and brahmans avoid your house from afar,

analyzed: pattāni bhijjanti ca te nivesane saṅghāṭiyaḥ ca api vidālayanti
translated: Your bowls break and your outer robes are torn.🔽“Then others, with their feet and hoes,

analyzed: atha apare pāda kuṭhārikāhi samaṇā pātayanti
translated: The monks fall down, heads bowed.

original: Etādisaṃ pabbajitā vihesaṃ, tayā kataṃ samaṇā pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: etādisam pabbajitāḥ vihesam tayā katam samaṇāḥ pāpuṇanti
translated: Such is the trouble that you have brought upon the monks.🔽“You did not give even oil on a measure of grass,

original: “Tiṇena telampi na tvaṃ adāsi, mūḷhassa maggampi na pāvadāsi;
analyzed: tiṇena telam pi na tvam adāsi mūḷhassa maggam pi na
translated: You did not show the way to the confused,🔽You yourself took the staff of the blind.

analyzed: andhassa daṇḍam sayam ādiyāsi etādisaḥ kadariyaḥ a saṃvutaḥ tuvam

original: Atha tvaṃ kena vaṇṇena kimeva disvā, amhehi saha saṃvibhāgaṃ karosīti.

original: “Paccemi bhante yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, vihesayiṃ samaṇe brāhmaṇe ca;

translated: “I confess, reverend Sir, what you say, I troubled monks and brahmans.

original: Khiḍḍatthiko no ca paduṭṭhacitto, etampi me dukkaṭameva bhante.
analyzed: khiḍḍatthikaḥ no ca paduṭṭha cittaḥ etam pi me dukkaṭam eva bhante
translated: I was playing, not with a wicked mind. This too, reverend Sir, is bad for me.🔽The yakkha, having played, having caused evil,

original: Khiḍḍāya yakkho pasavitvā pāpaṃ, vedeti dukkhaṃ asamattabhogī;
analyzed: khiḍḍāya yakkhaḥ pasavitvā pāpam vedeti dukkham a samatta bhogī

original: Daharo yuvā nagganiyassa bhāgī, kiṃ su tato dukkhatarassa hoti.
analyzed: daharaḥ yuvā nagganiyassa bhāgī kim su tatas dukkhatarassa hoti
translated: Young, a youth, a share of naked asceticism, what is more painful than that?”

original: “Taṃ disvā saṃvegamalatthaṃ bhante, tappaccayā vāpi dadāmi dānaṃ;
analyzed: tam disvā saṃvegam alattham bhante tad paccayā vā api dadāmi dānam
translated: “Having seen it, I was moved, Reverend Sir, and I give this gift because of that.

original: Paṭiggaṇha bhante vatthayugāni aṭṭha, yakkhassimā gacchantu dakkhiṇāyoti.
analyzed: paṭiggaṇha bhante vattha yugāni aṭṭha yakkhassa imā gacchantu dakkhiṇāya iti

original: “Addhā hi dānaṃ bahudhā pasatthaṃ, dadato ca te akkhayadhammamatthu;
analyzed: addhā hi dānam bahudhā pasattham dadataḥ ca te akkhaya dhammam atthu
translated: “Surely, this gift is praised in many ways, and may you have inexhaustible merit from giving it.

original: Paṭigaṇhāmi te vatthayugāni aṭṭha, yakkhassimā gacchantu dakkhiṇāyoti.
analyzed: paṭigaṇhāmi te vattha yugāni aṭṭha gacchantu dakkhiṇāya ti
translated: I accept these eight pairs of garments, and let the Dakkhiṇā go to the Yakkhas.”

original: “Tato hi so ācamayitvā licchavi, therassa datvāna yugāni aṭṭha;
analyzed: tatas hi saḥ ācamayitvā licchavi therassa yugāni aṭṭha
translated: “Then, after washing himself, the Licchavī, having given the eight pairs of garments to the Elder,

original: Paṭiggahītāni ca tāni assu, yakkhañca passetha sannaddhadussaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiggahītāni ca tāni assu yakkham ca passetha sannaddha dussam
translated: and they were accepted, and he saw the Yakkha, who was well-armed.

original: “Tamaddasā candanasāralittaṃ, ājaññamārūḷhamuḷāravaṇṇaṃ;
analyzed: candana sāra littam ājaññam ārūḍham uḷāra vaṇṇam
translated: “He saw him, anointed with sandalwood, the colour of a blue gem, mounted on a thoroughbred,

original: Alaṅkataṃ sādhunivatthadussaṃ, parivāritaṃ yakkhamahiddhipattaṃ.
analyzed: alaṅkatam sādhu nivattha dussam parivāritam yakkha mahiddhi pattam
translated: adorned, with well-dressed hair and clothes, surrounded by Yakkhas who had attained great psychic powers.

original: “So taṃ disvā attamano udaggo, pahaṭṭhacitto ca subhaggarūpo;
analyzed: saḥ tam disvā atta manaḥ udaggaḥ pahaṭṭha citto ca subhagga rūpaḥ
translated: “Having seen him, he was pleased and elated, and his mind was gladdened, and he was of beautiful appearance.

original: Kammañca disvāna mahāvipākaṃ, sandiṭṭhikaṃ cakkhunā sacchikatvā.
analyzed: kammañca disvāna mahā vipākam sandiṭṭhikam cakkhunā sacchikatvā
translated: Having seen the deed with great result, he saw it with his own eyes and understood it.

original: “Tamenamavoca upasaṅkamitvā, dassāmi dānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ;
analyzed: tam enam avocaḥ upasaṅkamitvā dassāmi dānam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: “I approached him and said, ‘I’ll give gifts to the contemplatives & brahmans.

original: Na cāpi me kiñci adeyyamatthi, tuvañca me yakkha bahūpakāroti.
analyzed: na ca api me kiñci adeyyam atthi tuvam ca me yakkha bahu upakārā iti

original: “Tuvañca me licchavi ekadesaṃ, adāsi dānāni amoghametaṃ;
analyzed: tuvam ca me licchavi ekadesam adāsi dānāni amogham etam
translated: “‘You, sir, are a part of me. My giving gifts is not in vain.

original: Svāhaṃ karissāmi tayāva sakkhiṃ, amānuso mānusakena saddhinti.
analyzed: svā aham karissāmi tayā ava sakkhim amānusaḥ mānusakena saddhinti

original: “Gatī ca bandhū ca parāyaṇañca, mitto mamāsi atha devatā me;
analyzed: gatī ca bandhū ca parāyaṇañca mittaḥ mama asi atha devatā me
translated: “‘You are my destiny, my kinsman, my refuge. You are my friend, and a god to me.

analyzed: yācāmi tam pañjalikaḥ bhavitvā icchāmi tam yakkha punapi daṭṭhunti

original: “Sace tuvaṃ assaddho bhavissasi, kadariyarūpo vippaṭipannacitto;
analyzed: sace tuvam assaddhaḥ bhavissasi kadariya rūpaḥ vippaṭipanna cittaḥ
translated: “‘If you are faithless, stingy, and your mind is bent on wrong,

translated: you won’t even get to see me. Even if you did, I wouldn’t speak to you.

analyzed: sace pana tvam bhavissasi dhamma gāravaḥ dāne rataḥ
translated: “‘But if you are respectful of the Dhamma, delighting in giving, your mind bent on right,

original: Opānabhūto samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ, evaṃ mamaṃ lacchasi dassanāya.
analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇānam evam lacchasi dassanāya
translated: you’ll get to see me.

analyzed: disvā ca tam ālapissam bhadante imam ca sūlataḥ lahum pamuñca
translated: “‘Seeing you, I’ll speak to you, good sir. And let go of this net right now.

original: Yatonidānaṃ akarimha sakkhiṃ, maññāmi sūlāvutakassa kāraṇā.
analyzed: yatonidānam akarimha sakkhim maññāmi sūlāvutakassa kāraṇā
translated: Because of which we made a pact, I think, for the sake of the one impaled.

original: “Te aññamaññaṃ akarimha sakkhiṃ, ayañca sūlato lahuṃ pamutto;
analyzed: te aññam aññam akarimha sakkhim ayam ca sūlataḥ lahum pamuttaḥ
translated: “We made a pact with each other, and he was quickly released from the stake.

original: Sakkacca dhammāni samācaranto, mucceyya so nirayā ca tamhā;
analyzed: sakkacca dhammāni samācarantaḥ mucceyya saḥ nirayā ca tamhā
translated: Conducting himself earnestly in the Dhamma, he would be released from hell.

original: Kammaṃ siyā aññatra vedanīyaṃ.
analyzed: kammam siyāḥ aññatra vedanīyam
translated: His kamma might be experienced elsewhere.

original: “Kappitakañca upasaṅkamitvā, teneva saha saṃvibhajitvā kāle;
analyzed: kappitakam ca upasaṅkamitvā tena iva saha saṃvibhajitvā kāle

original: “So tattha rahassaṃ samullapitvā, sakkhiṃ karitvāna amānusena;
analyzed: saḥ tattha rahassam samullapitvā sakkhim karitvāna amānusena
translated: “Having whispered to him in private, having made a pact with a non-human,

translated: He left for the presence of the Licchavīs, and then spoke to the assembly seated together.

original: “‘Suṇantu bhonto mama ekavākyaṃ, varaṃ varissaṃ labhissāmi atthaṃ;
analyzed: suṇantu bhontaḥ mama eka vākyam varam varissam labhissāmi attham
translated: “‘Listen, sirs, to my one statement, I will choose a boon, I will obtain a benefit;

original: Sūlāvuto puriso luddakammo, paṇihitadaṇḍo anusattarūpo.
analyzed: sūlāvutaḥ purisaḥ ludda kammaḥ paṇihita daṇḍaḥ anusatta rūpo
translated: A man impaled on a stake, a butcher, a man with a sword, a man with a noose,

original: “‘Ettāvatā vīsatirattimattā, yato āvuto neva jīvati na mato;
analyzed: ettāvatā vīsati ratti mattāḥ yatas na iva jīvati na
translated: ‘To this extent, twenty-one days have passed since he was impaled. He is neither alive nor dead.

original: Tāhaṃ mocayissāmi dāni, yathāmatiṃ anujānātu saṅgho’ti.
analyzed: tā aham mocayissāmi dāni yathāmatim anujānātu saṅghaḥ iti
translated: I will now release him. If it seems right to the Sangha, I will do so.’

original: “‘Etañca aññañca lahuṃ pamuñca, ko taṃ vadetha tathā karontaṃ;
analyzed: etam ca aññam ca lahum pamuñca kaḥ tam vadetha tathā karontam
translated: ‘Release him and anything else that is tied up. Who will accuse you of doing this?

original: “So taṃ padesaṃ upasaṅkamitvā, sūlāvutaṃ mocayi khippameva;
analyzed: saḥ tam padesam upasaṅkamitvā sūlāvutam mocayi khippam eva

original: “Sūlāvuto puriso luddakammo, paṇītadaṇḍo anusattarūpo;
analyzed: sūlāvutaḥ purisaḥ ludda kammaḥ paṇīta daṇḍaḥ anusatta rūpo
translated: ‘A man impaled on a stake, a butcher, a man with a sword, a man with a noose,

original: Ettāvatā vīsatirattimattā, yato āvuto neva jīvati na mato.
analyzed: ettāvatā vīsati ratti mattāḥ yatas na iva jīvati na
translated: To this extent, twenty-one days have passed since he was impaled. He is neither alive nor dead.’

original: “So mocito gantvā mayā idāni, etassa yakkhassa vaco hi bhante;
analyzed: saḥ mocitaḥ gantvā mayā idāni etassa yakkhassa vacaḥ hi bhante

translated: he would be freed from that hell, the deed could be experienced elsewhere.”

translated: Advise me, instruct me, you who are of great wisdom, so that I will not go to hell.”

analyzed: evam ca dhammāni samācarantaḥ sakkacca rattindivam appamatto
translated: “Thus practicing the Dhamma, diligent day and night,

original: “Cīvaraṃ piṇḍapātañca, paccayaṃ sayanāsanaṃ;
analyzed: cīvaram piṇḍapātañca paccayam sayana āsanam
translated: “The robe, almsfood, and the requisite of medicine when sick,

analyzed: annam pānam khādanīyam vattha senāsanāni ca

translated: “The monks who are endowed with virtue, who are free from passion, and who are learned,

analyzed: etādisā sappurisāna sevanā mahapphalā hoti satam vijānatam

original: bhadante”tiādikaṃ avoca.
analyzed: bhadanta iti ādikam avoca
translated: Lord, we are not able to live in concord” .

original: 562-3. Vidālayantīti viphālayanti. Pādakuṭhārikāhīti pādasaṅkhātāhi kuṭhārīhi. Pātayantīti paripātayanti.🔽564. Tiṇenāti tiṇaggenāpi. Mūḷhassa maggampi na pāvadāsīti maggamūḷhassa maggampi
analyzed: vidālayanti iti viphālayanti pāda kuṭhārikāhi iti pāda saṅkhātāhi kuṭhārīhi pātayanti iti paripātayanti  tiṇena ati tiṇaggena api mūḷhassa maggam pi na pāvadāsi iti magga mūḷhassa maggam pi
translated: Herein, they would split means they would break up. With axes in the form of feet means with axes called feet. They would fall means they would fall down.

original: tvaṃ na kathayasi “evāyaṃ purisā ito cito ca paribbhamatū”ti. Keḷīsīlo hi ayaṃ rājā.
analyzed: tvam na kathayasi eva ayam purisāḥ itas citas ca paribbhamatu uti keḷīsīlaḥ hi ayam rājā
translated: With grass means even with a grass-blade. You do not show the path to one who is blind means you do not say, “This man should wander here and there” , to one who is blind to the path. For this king is of a playful disposition.

original: Sayamādiyāsīti andhassa hatthato yaṭṭhiṃ sayameva acchinditvā gaṇhasi. Saṃvibhāgaṃ
analyzed: sayam ādiyāsi iti andhassa hatthataḥ yaṭṭhim sayam eva a chinditvā gaṇhasi saṃvibhāgam
translated: You take it yourself means you take the staff from the blind man’s hand by yourself. You do not share it with him.

original: karosīti attanā paribhuñjitabbavatthuto ekaccāni datvā saṃvibhajasi.
analyzed: karosi iti attanā paribhuñjitabba vatthutaḥ ekaccāni da tvā saṃvibhajasi
translated: You do it: you give some things to be used by yourself and you share some.

original: 565. Paccemi, bhante, yaṃ tvaṃ vadesīti “bhante, tvaṃ pattāni bhijjantī”tiādinā yaṃ
analyzed: paccemi bhante yam tvam vadesi iti bhante tvam pattāni bhijjanti itiādinā yam
translated: I admit, venerable sir, what you say: “Venerable sir, I admit what you say about the bowls breaking, etc.,

original: vadesi, taṃ paṭijānāmi, sabbamevetaṃ mayā kataṃ kārāpitañcāti dasseti. Etampīti etaṃ
analyzed: vadesi tam paṭijānāmi sabbam eva etam mayā katam kārāpitam ca ati dassa iti etam pi iti etam
translated: I show that all that was done by me and caused to be done.” This too:

original: khiḍḍādhippāyena katampi.
analyzed: khiḍḍa adhippāyena katam pi
translated: this too, done with the aim of playing.

original: 566-7. Khiḍḍāti khiḍḍāya. Pasavitvāti upacinitvā. Vedetīti anubhavati. Asamattabhogīti
analyzed: khiḍḍā ati khiḍḍāya pasavitvā iti upacinitvā veda iti iti anubhavati a samatta bhogī iti
translated: Playing: for the sake of playing. Having stored up: having accumulated. He knows: he experiences. Not having enjoyed himself:

original: aparipuṇṇabhogo. Tameva aparipuṇṇabhogataṃ dassetuṃ “daharo yuvā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Nagganiyassāti
analyzed: tam eva a paripuṇṇa bhoga tam dassetum daharaḥ yuvā itiādi vuttam nagganiyassa ati
translated: not having had his fill. In order to show that very lack of having had his fill, “young, in the prime of life” is said. Nakedness:

original: naggabhāvassa. Kiṃ su tato dukkhatarassa hotīti kiṃ su nāma tato naggabhāvato dukkhataraṃ
analyzed: nagga bhāvassa kim su tatas dukkhatarassa hoti iti kim su nāma tatas nagga bhāvato dukkhataram
translated: of the state of nakedness. What is more painful than that? What, indeed, is more painful than that nakedness for that dead man?

original: assa petassa hoti. Yakkhassimā gacchantu dakkhiṇāyoti imā mayā diyyamānavatthadakkhiṇāyo🔽petassa upakappantu.
analyzed: assa petassa hoti yakkhassa imāḥ gacchantu dakkhiṇāyaḥ iti imāḥ mayā diyyamāna vattha dakkhiṇāyaḥ 🔽pa itassa upakappantu
translated: Let the spirits take this offering: let these offerings given by me be of use to the dead man.

original: 568-72. Bahudhā pasatthanti bahūhi pakārehi buddhādīhi vaṇṇitaṃ. Akkhayadhammamatthūti
analyzed: bahudhā pasatthanti bahūhi pakārehi buddha ādīhi vaṇṇitam
translated: “Much praised” : praised in many ways by the Buddhas, etc. “May it be of imperishable merit” :

original: aparikkhayadhammaṃ hotu. Ācamayitvāti hatthapādadhovanapubbakaṃ mukhaṃ vikkhāletvā.
analyzed: a parikkhaya dhammam hotu ācamayitvā ati hattha pāda dhovana pubbakam mukham vikkhāletvā
translated: may it be of merit that does not perish. “Having sipped water” : having washed his mouth after washing his hands and feet.

original: Candanasāralittanti sārabhūtacandanalittaṃ. Uḷāravaṇṇanti seṭṭharūpaṃ. Parivāritanti
analyzed: sāra bhūta candana littam uḷāra vaṇṇanti seṭṭha rūpam
translated: “Anointed with the essence of sandalwood” : smeared with the essence of sandalwood. “Of sublime beauty” : of the best form. “Surrounded” :

original: anukulavuttinā parijanena parivāritaṃ. Yakkhamahiddhipattanti mahatiṃ yakkhiddhiṃ,
analyzed: anu kula vuttinā parijanena parivāritam yakkha mahiddhi pattanti mahatim yakkha iddhim
translated: surrounded by a retinue that behaved in a pleasing manner. “Having attained great power among the yakkhas” : having attained great power among the yakkhas,

original: deviddhiṃ patvā ṭhitaṃ. Tamenamavocāti tamenaṃ avoca.
analyzed: deviddhim patvā ṭhitam tam enam avoca ati tam enam avoca
translated: having attained the power of a deva, he stood there. “Then he said to him” : then he said to him.

original: 573. Ekadesaṃ adāsīti catūsu paccayesu ekadesabhūtaṃ vatthadānaṃ sandhāya vadati. Sakkhinti sakkhibhāvaṃ.
analyzed: ekadesam adāsi iti catūsu paccayesu ekadesa bhūtam vattha dānam sandhāya vadati sakkhin ti sakkhibhāvam
translated: “He gave a portion” : he gave a portion of the robe, which was one of the four requisites. “As a witness” : as a witness to the fact.

original: 574. Mamāsīti me āsi. Devatā meti mayhaṃ devatā āsīti yojanā.
analyzed: mama asi iti me āsi devatā mā iti mayham devatā āsi iti yojanā
translated: “Was mine” : was mine. “Was my deva” : was my deva. This is the interpretation.

original: 575-7. Vippaṭipannacittoti micchādiṭṭhiṃ paṭipannamānaso, dhammiyaṃ paṭipadaṃ pahāya adhammiyaṃ paṭipadaṃ paṭipannoti attho. Yatonidānanti yannimittaṃ yassa santikaṃ āgamanahetu.
analyzed: vippaṭipanna cittaḥ ti micchādiṭṭhim paṭipanna mānasaḥ dhammiyam paṭipadam pahāya adhammiyam paṭipadam paṭipannaḥ ti attho yatonidānam ti yad nimittam yassa santikam āgamana hetu
translated: ‘With a perverted mind’: with a mind perverted to wrong view; the meaning is, having abandoned the way of practice that is in conformity with the Dhamma, he is practicing the way of practice that is contrary to the Dhamma. ‘For the sake of which’: for the sake of which, for the sake of whose presence.

original: 579. Saṃvibhajitvāti dānasaṃvibhāgaṃ katvā. Sayaṃ mukhenūpanisajja pucchāti aññe purise apesetvā upinisīditvā sammukheneva puccha.
analyzed: saṃvibhajitvā iti dāna saṃvibhāgam katvā sayam mukhena upanisajja puccha ati aññe purise apesetvā upinisīditvā sammukhena iva puccha
translated: ‘Having shared’: having made a sharing of the gift. ‘Having sat down right in front of him and questioned him’: having sat down right in front of him, having approached him, having gone right up to him, without sending other men.

original: 581-3. Sannisinnanti sannipatitavasena nisinnaṃ. Labhissāmi atthanti mayā icchitampi
analyzed: sannisinnam ti sannipatita vasena nisinnam labhissāmi attham ti mayā icchitam pi
translated: ‘Sitting together’: sitting together in the sense of having assembled. ‘I will get what is good for me’: I will get the good that I desire.

original: atthaṃ labhissāmi. Paṇihitadaṇḍoti ṭhapitasarīradaṇḍo. Anusattarūpoti rājini anusattasabhāvo.
analyzed: attham labhissāmi paṇihita daṇḍo ti ṭhapita sarīra daṇḍaḥ anusatta rūpo ti rājini anusatta sabhāvo
translated: ‘With his staff laid down’: with his staff laid down on the ground. ‘With a humble manner’: with a manner humble towards the king.

original: Vīsatirattimattāti vīsatimattā rattiyo ativattāti attho. Tāhanti taṃ ahaṃ. Yathāmatinti mayhaṃ yathāruci.
analyzed: vīsati ratti mattā ati vīsati mattāḥ rattiyaḥ ativattā ati attho tāhanti tam aham yathāmatinti mayham yathāruci
translated: ‘After twenty nights’: the meaning is, after twenty nights have passed. ‘I’: I, that one. ‘As I like’: as I desire.

original: 584. Etañca aññañcāti etaṃ sūle āvutaṃ purisaṃ aññañca yassa rājāṇā paṇihitā, tañca.
analyzed: etam ca aññam ca ati etam sūle āvutam purisam aññam ca yassa rājāṇā paṇihitā tañca
translated: ‘This and the other’: this man impaled on the stake and the other for whom the king has laid down his staff.

original: Lahuṃ pamuñcāti sīghaṃ mocehi. Ko taṃ vadetha tathā karontanti tathā dhammiyakammaṃ
analyzed: lahum pamuñcāti sīgham mocehi ko tam vadetha tathā karontanti tathā dhammiya kammaṃ
translated: “Quickly let go” means “quickly release him.” “Who will blame you for doing so?” means “who will blame you for doing a procedure in accordance with the Teaching?”

original: karontaṃ taṃ imasmiṃ vajjiraṭṭhe ko nāma “na pamocehī”ti vadeyya, evaṃ vattuṃ kocipi na labhatīti attho.
analyzed: karontam tam imasmin vajji raṭṭhe kaḥ nāma na pamocehi iti vadeyya evam vattum koci pi na labhati iti attho
translated: He quickly releases: he quickly frees. Who would blame him for doing so? : who in this royal domain would say, “He should not release him”? The meaning is that no one is fit to say this.

original: 585. Tikicchakānañcāti tikicchake ca.
analyzed: tikicchakānam ca ati tikicchake ca
translated: And the physicians: and the physicians.

original: 588. Yakkhassa vacoti petassa vacanaṃ, tassa, bhante, petassa vacanena evamakāsinti dasseti.
analyzed: yakkhassa vacaḥ uti petassa vacanam tassa bhante petassa vacanena dasseti
translated: The spirit’s word: the ghost’s word. He shows that he acted thus on the word of that ghost, venerable sir.

original: 590. Dhammānīti pubbe kataṃ pāpakammaṃ abhibhavituṃ samatthe puññadhamme. Kammaṃ🔽siyā aññatra vedanīyanti yaṃ tasmiṃ pāpakamme upapajjavedanīyaṃ, taṃ ahosikammaṃ
analyzed: dhammāni iti pubbe katam pāpa kammam abhibhavitum samatthe puñña dhamme kammam  siyā aññatra yam tasmin pāpa kamme upapajja vedanīyam tam ahosikammaṃ
translated: The Dhamma: the meritorious Dhamma that is able to overcome the evil deed done previously.🔽The kamma may be otherwise than what is to be experienced: the kamma that is to be experienced on rebirth in that evil deed is called “done kamma.”

original: nāma hoti. Yaṃ pana aparapariyāyavedanīyaṃ, taṃ aññatra aparapariyāye vedayitabbaphalaṃ🔽hoti sati saṃsārappavattiyanti attho.
analyzed: nāma hoti yam pana apara pariyāya vedanīyam tam aññatra apara pariyāye vedayitabba phalam  hoti sati saṃsāra ppavattiyanti attho
translated: But that which is to be experienced in some other existence is kamma that is to be experienced in some other existence.🔽The meaning is that it is kamma that is to be experienced in some other existence, provided that there is a continuation of the round of rebirths.

original: 593. Imañcāti attanā vuccamānaṃ tāya āsannaṃ paccakkhaṃ vāti katvā vuttaṃ. Ariyaṃ
analyzed: iman ca iti attanā vuccamānam tāya āsannam paccakkham vā iti katvā vuttam ariyam
translated: And this: he speaks as if he were making a statement about something that is near to himself and is evident to himself.

original: aṭṭhaṅgavarenupetanti parisuddhaṭṭhena ariyaṃ, pāṇātipātāveramaṇiādīhi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi
analyzed: parisuddha ṭṭhena ariyam pāṇātipāta averamaṇi ādīhi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi
translated: Endowed with eight factors: it is noble in the sense of being purified, and it is endowed with, united with, the eight factors beginning with abstention from killing living beings.🔽The Uposatha observance is the supreme virtue. Wholesome: blameless.

original: upetaṃ yuttaṃ uttamaṃ uposathasīlaṃ. Kusalanti anavajjaṃ. Sukhudrayanti sukhavipākaṃ.
analyzed: upetam yuttam uttamam uposatha sīlam kusalanti anavajjam sukhudrayanti sukha vipākam
translated: Pleasant: productive of pleasant results.

original: 595. Sadā puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatīti sakideva puññaṃ katvā “alamettāvatā”ti aparituṭṭho🔽hutvā aparāparaṃ sucaritaṃ pūrentassa sabbakālaṃ puññaṃ abhivaḍḍhati, aparāparaṃ
analyzed: sadā puññam pavaḍḍhati iti sakid eva puññam katvā alam ettāvatā iti a parituṭṭhaḥ  hutvā apara aparam su caritam pūrentassa sabbakālam puññam abhivaḍḍhati apara aparam
translated: Merit always increases: having done merit on one day, being dissatisfied with the thought, “This much is enough,”

original: vā sucaritaṃ pūrentassa puññasaṅkhātaṃ puññaphalaṃ uparūpari vaḍḍhati paripūretīti attho.
analyzed: vā su caritam pūrentassa puñña saṅkhātam puñña phalam upari upari vaḍḍhati paripūreti iti attho
translated: he who fulfills the good conduct again and again, merit increases for him all the time. Or the meaning is that for him who fulfills the good conduct again and again, the fruit of merit, called merit, increases more and more, is fulfilled.

original: 597. Evaṃ therena vutte rājā apāyadukkhato utrastacitto ratanattaye puññadhamme ca🔽abhivaḍḍhamānapasādo tato paṭṭhāya saraṇāni sīlāni ca samādiyanto “ajjeva buddhaṃ
analyzed: evam therena vutte rājā apāya dukkhataḥ utrasta cittaḥ rata nattaye puñña dhamme ca  abhivaḍḍhamāna pasādo tatas paṭṭhāya saraṇāni sīlāni ca samādiyantaḥ ajja iva buddham
translated: When the Elder had spoken thus, the king, his mind terrified by the suffering of the states of woe, and his confidence in the Three Jewels and in meritorious deeds

original: saraṇaṃ upemī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: saraṇam upemi iti ādim āha
translated: increasing, from then on, observing the Refuges and the precepts, said, “Even today I go for refuge to the Buddha,” etc.

original: 601. Tattha etādisoti ediso yathāvuttarūpo. Vesāliyaṃ aññataro upāsakoti vesāliyaṃ
analyzed: tattha etādisaḥ ti edisaḥ yathā vutta rūpaḥ vesāliyam aññataraḥ upāsako ti vesāliyam
translated: Herein, such as this: such as this, of the kind described. A certain lay follower in Vesali: a certain lay follower in Vesali.

original: anekasahassesu upāsakesu aññataro upāsako hutvā. Saddhotiādi kalyāṇamittasannissayena🔽tassa purimabhāvato aññādisataṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Pubbe hi so assaddho kakkhaḷo bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: aneka sahassesu upāsakesu aññataraḥ upāsakaḥ hutvā saddho tiādi kalyāṇa mitta sannissayena  tassa purima bhāvataḥ añña ādi satam dassetum vuttam pubbe hi so assaddhaḥ kakkhaḷaḥ bhikkhūnam
translated: and he was one of many thousands of lay followers. “Faithful” and so on:

original: akkosakārako saṅghassa ca anupaṭṭhāko ahosi. Idāni pana saddho muduko hutvā bhikkhusaṅghañca
analyzed: akkosa kārako saṅghassa ca anupaṭṭhākaḥ ahosi idāni pana saddhaḥ mudukaḥ hutvā bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: this is said in order to show the hundredfold increase in the opposite qualities to those he had in the past. For previously he had been faithless, harsh, and abusive to the bhikkhus, and he had not served the Sangha. But now he was faithful and gentle, and he served the Sangha

original: sakkaccaṃ tadā upaṭṭhahīti. Tatta kārakaroti upakārakārī.
analyzed: sakkaccam tadā upaṭṭhahi iti upakāra kārī
translated: and did good to it. “He did what was to be done”: he did what was helpful.

original: 602. Ubhopīti dvepi sūlāvuto rājā ca. Sāmaññaphalāni ajjhagunti yathārahaṃ sāmaññaphalāni
analyzed: ubho upi iti dve api sūlāvutaḥ rājā ca sāmañña phalāni ajjhagunti yathāraham sāmañña phalāni
translated: “Both”: both the king and the man impaled. “The fruits of asceticism”: the fruits of recluseship.🔽They attained the fruits of recluseship as befitted them.

original: adhigacchiṃsu. Tayidaṃ yathārahaṃ dassetuṃ “sūlāvuto aggaphalaṃ aphassayi, phalaṃ
analyzed: adhigacchiṃsu tayā idam yathāraham dassetum sūlāvutaḥ agga phalam aphassayi phalam
translated: In order to show this as befitted them, it is said: “The impaled man experienced the highest fruit,

original: kaniṭṭhaṃ pana ambasakkaro”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha phalaṃ kaniṭṭhanti sotāpattiphalaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: kaniṭṭham pana ambasakkaroti vuttam tattha phalam kaniṭṭham ti sotāpatti phalam sandhāya āha
translated: but the king attained the lesser fruit.” Herein, by “the lesser fruit” he means the fruit of stream-entry.

original: Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: yam pana ittha atthataḥ a vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: What has not been analyzed in meaning here can be understood in the same way as in the case of the “Great Chapter.”

original: Evaṃ raññā petena attanā ca vuttamatthaṃ āyasmā kappitako satthāraṃ vandituṃ sāvatthiṃ🔽gato bhagavato ārocesi. Satthā tamatthaṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā sampattaparisāya dhammaṃ
analyzed: evam raññā petena attanā ca vutta mattham āyasmā kappitako satthāram vanditum sāvatthim  gataḥ bhagavataḥ ārocesi satthā tam attham aṭṭhuppattim katvā sampatta parisāya dhammaṃ
translated: The venerable Kappina, having thus related the matter as it had been told him by the king and by himself, went to Sāvatthi to pay his respects to the Teacher.🔽The Teacher, having made that the occasion for a discourse, preached the Law to the assembled multitude.

original: desesi. Sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosīti.
analyzed: desesi sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosi iti
translated: In this way the venerable Kappaṭa went to Sāvatthi to pay homage to the Master and told him what had been said by the king and by himself. The Master made this the occasion for preaching the Law to the assembled multitude, and his discourse was of such profit to the people.

original: Ambasakkarapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: amba sakkara peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of the Ghost who was a King in his day is ended.

original: 2. Serīsakapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: serīsaka peta vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Ghost who was a Merchant

original: 604-57. Suṇotha yakkhassa vāṇijānañcāti idaṃ serīsakapetavatthu. Taṃ yasmā serīsakavimānavatthunā🔽nibbisesaṃ, tasmā tattha aṭṭhuppattiyaṃ gāthāsu ca yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ paramatthadīpaniyaṃ
analyzed: suṇotha yakkhassa vāṇijānam ca ati idam serīsaka peta vatthu tam yasmā serīsaka vimāna vatthunā  nibbisesam tasmā tattha aṭṭhuppattiyam gāthāsu ca yat vattabbam tam paramattha dīpaniyam
translated: Listen to the story of the ghost and the merchants. This is the story of the Ghost who was a Merchant. Since it is identical with the story of the ghost who lived in the Serīsa tree,🔽the circumstances which led to the preaching of the Law, and the verses, are the same. Therefore, in the commentary on the Vimāna stories,

original: vimānavatthuvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttameva, tasmā tattha vuttanayena veditabbanti.
analyzed: vimāna vatthu vaṇṇanāyam vuttam eva tasmā tattha vutta nayena veditabbanti
translated: in the section dealing with the Vimāna of the Serīsa tree, I have explained the matter in detail. Therefore it should be understood in the same way as there.

original: Serīsakapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: serīsaka peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of the Ghost who was a Merchant is ended.

original: 3. Nandakapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Ghost Nandaka

original: Rājā piṅgalako nāmāti idaṃ nandakapetavatthu. Tassa kā uppatti? Satthu parinibbānato
analyzed: rājā piṅgalakaḥ nāma ati idam nandaka peta vatthu tassa kā uppatti satthu parinibbānato
translated: The king was named Piṅgalaka.

original: vassasatadvayassa accayena suraṭṭhavisaye piṅgalo nāma rājā ahosi. Tassa senāpati
analyzed: vassa sata dvayassa accayena suraṭṭha visaye piṅgalaḥ nāma rājā ahosi tassa senāpati
translated: At the end of two hundred years there was a king named Piṅgala in the country of Suratta. His general

original: nandako nāma micchādiṭṭhī viparītadassano “natthi dinna”ntiādinā micchāgāhaṃ paggayha
analyzed: nandakaḥ nāma micchā diṭṭhī viparīta dassanaḥ natthi dinna nti ādinā micchāgāham paggayha
translated: was named Nandaka. He was a heretic, and he held the wrong view that there is no such thing as giving.🔽He went about proclaiming this wrong view. His daughter,

original: vicari. Tassa dhītā uttarā nāma upāsikā patirūpe kule dinnā ahosi. Nandako pana kālaṃ
analyzed: vicari tassa dhītā uttarā nāma upāsikā pati rūpe kule dinnā ahosi nandakaḥ pana kālam
translated: the lay devotee Uttarā, was married to a suitable husband. But when Nandaka died,
