analyzed: catur kaṇṇam catu dvāram vibhattam bhāgasaḥ mitam
translated: With four corners and four doors, divided into parts, measured,

original: Ayopākārapariyantaṃ, ayasā paṭikujjitaṃ.
analyzed: ayaḥ upākāra pariyantam ayasā paṭikujjitam
translated: Surrounded by an iron fence, covered with iron above.

original: “Tassa ayomayā bhūmi, jalitā tejasā yutā;
analyzed: tassa ayaḥ mayā bhūmi jalitā tejasā yutā
translated: The ground there is made of iron, burning, full of flames,

original: Samantā yojanasataṃ, pharitvā tiṭṭhati sabbadā.
analyzed: samantā yojana satam pharitvā tiṭṭhati sabbadā
translated: Extending all around a hundred leagues, it stands always.

original: “Vassāni satasahassāni, ghoso suyyati tāvade;
analyzed: vassāni sata sahassāni ghosaḥ suyyati tāvade
translated: “For a hundred thousand years, for that long the sound is heard,

original: Lakkho eso mahārāja, satabhāgavassakoṭiyo.
analyzed: lakkhaḥ esaḥ mahā rāja sata bhāga vassa koṭiyaḥ
translated: That is a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand years, great king.

original: “Koṭisatasahassāni, niraye paccare janā;
analyzed: koṭi sata sahassāni niraye paccare janā
translated: “A hundred thousand times a hundred thousand years, people are cooked in hell,

original: Micchādiṭṭhī ca dussīlā, ye ca ariyūpavādino.
analyzed: micchā diṭṭhī ca dussīlāḥ ye ca ariya yūpa vādinaḥ
translated: Those with wrong views and bad conduct, and those who slander the noble ones.

original: “Tatthāhaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ, dukkhaṃ vedissa vedanaṃ;
analyzed: tattha aham dīgham addhānam dukkham vedissa vedanaṃ
translated: “There I will experience pain for a long time,

original: Phalaṃ pāpassa kammassa, tasmā socāmahaṃ bhusaṃ.
analyzed: phalam pāpassa kammassa tasmai socāmaham bhusam
translated: The result of bad kamma, therefore I grieve greatly.

original: “Taṃ suṇohi mahārāja, arindama raṭṭhavaḍḍhana;
analyzed: tam suṇohi mahā rāja arindama raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: “Listen to that, great king, subduer of enemies, increaser of the country;

original: Dhītā mayhaṃ mahārāja, uttarā bhaddamatthu te.
analyzed: dhītā mayham mahā rāja uttarā te
translated: My daughter, great king, may you be fortunate, Uttara.

original: “Karoti bhaddakaṃ kammaṃ, sīlesuposathe ratā;
analyzed: karoti bhaddakam kammam sīlesu uposathe ratā
translated: “She does good deeds, delights in the precepts and fasts,

original: Saññatā saṃvibhāgī ca, vadaññū vītamaccharā.
analyzed: saññatā saṃvibhāgī ca vadaññū vītamaccharā
translated: Self-controlled, sharing, generous, free from stinginess.

original: “Akhaṇḍakārī sikkhāya, suṇhā parakulesu ca;
analyzed: akhaṇḍa kārī sikkhāya suṇhā para kulesu ca
translated: “She does not break the training, and is well-behaved in other families,

original: Upāsikā sakyamunino, sambuddhassa sirīmato.
analyzed: upāsikā sakyamuninaḥ sambuddhassa sirīmataḥ
translated: A lay follower of the Sakyan Sage, the Fully Awakened One, the Glorious One.

original: “Bhikkhu ca sīlasampanno, gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi;
analyzed: bhikkhu ca sīla sampannaḥ gāmam piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: “And a monk endowed with virtue enters the village for alms,

original: Okkhittacakkhu satimā, guttadvāro susaṃvuto.
analyzed: okkhitta cakkhu satimā gutta dvāro su saṃvuto
translated: With eyes cast down, mindful, with guarded sense faculties, well-restrained.

original: “Sapadānaṃ caramāno, agamā taṃ nivesanaṃ;
analyzed: sa padānam caramānaḥ agama tam nivesanam
translated: “Wandering for alms, he came to your house,

original: Tamaddasa mahārāja, uttarā bhaddamatthu te.
analyzed: tam addasa mahā rājaḥ uttarā bhaddamatthu te
translated: saw her, great king, may you be fortunate, Uttara.

original: “Pūraṃ pānīyasarakaṃ, pūve vitte ca sā adā;
analyzed: pūram pānīya sarakam pūve vitte ca sā adā
translated: “She gave a full water-pot, and sweetmeats and money,

original: Pitā me kālakato bhante, tassetaṃ upakappatu.
analyzed: pitā me kāla kataḥ bhante tassa etam upakappatu
translated: ‘My father has died, reverend Sir, may this be of benefit to him.’

original: “Samanantarānuddiṭṭhe, vipāko udapajjatha;
analyzed: samanantara an uddiṭṭhe vipākaḥ udapajjatha
translated: “Immediately after she had dedicated (the gift), the result arose,

original: Bhuñjāmi kāmakāmīhaṃ, rājā vessavaṇo yathā.
analyzed: bhuñjāmi kāma kāmī iham rājā vessavaṇaḥ yathā
translated: I enjoy (myself) here, desiring sensual pleasures, like the King Vessavaṇa.

original: “Taṃ suṇohi mahārāja, arindama raṭṭhavaḍḍhana;
analyzed: tam suṇohi mahā rāja arindama raṭṭhavaḍḍhana
translated: “Listen to this, great king, subduer of foes, increaser of the country,

original: Sadevakassa lokassa, buddho aggo pavuccati;
analyzed: sa devakassa lokassa buddhaḥ aggaḥ pavuccati
translated: In the world with its gods, the Buddha is said to be the foremost;

original: Taṃ buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gaccha, saputtadāro arindama.
analyzed: tam buddham saraṇam gaccha sa putta dāraḥ arindama
translated: Go for refuge to that Buddha, subduer of foes, together with your children and wives.

original: “Aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena, phusanti amataṃ padaṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena phusanti amatam padam
translated: “By the path with its eight factors, they touch the deathless state;

original: Taṃ dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gaccha, saputtadāro arindama.
analyzed: tam dhammam saraṇam gaccha sa putta dāraḥ arindama
translated: Go for refuge to that Dhamma, subduer of foes, together with your children and wives.

original: “Cattāro ca paṭipannā, cattāro ca phale ṭhitā;
analyzed: cattāraḥ ca paṭipannā cattāraḥ ca phale ṭhitā
translated: “There are four who are practising, and four who are established in the fruit;

original: Esa saṅgho ujubhūto, paññāsīlasamāhito;
analyzed: esa saṅghaḥ uju bhūto paññā sīla samāhito
translated: This is the upright Saṅgha, who are intent on virtue and concentration;

original: Taṃ saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gaccha, saputtadāro arindama.
analyzed: tam saṅgham saraṇam gaccha sa putta dāraḥ arindama
translated: Go for refuge to that Saṅgha, subduer of foes, together with your children and wives.

original: “Pāṇātipātā viramassu khippaṃ, loke adinnaṃ parivajjayassu;
analyzed: pāṇa atipātāḥ viramassu khippam loke adinnam parivajjayassu
translated: “Quickly refrain from killing living creatures, avoid taking what has not been given in the world,

original: Amajjapo mā ca musā abhāṇi, sakena dārena ca hohi tuṭṭhoti.
analyzed: a majja paḥ mā ca musā abhāṇi sakena dārena ca hohi tuṭṭha uti
translated: Drink not the brew that makes for heedlessness, nor speak a falsehood, be content with thine own wife.

original: “Atthakāmosi me yakkha, hitakāmosi devate;
analyzed: attha kāmo asi me yakkha hita kāmo asi devate
translated: “Thou art my friend, O Yakkha, thou art my helper, O Devatā,

original: Karomi tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ, tvaṃsi ācariyo mama.
analyzed: karomi vacanam mama
translated: I do as thou hast bidden me, for thou art my teacher.

original: “Upemi saraṇaṃ buddhaṃ, dhammañcāpi anuttaraṃ;
analyzed: upemi saraṇam buddham dhammam ca api anuttaram
translated: “I go for refuge to the Buddha, and to the Norm incomparable,

original: Saṅghañca naradevassa, gacchāmi saraṇaṃ ahaṃ.
analyzed: saṅghañca naradevassa gacchāmi saraṇam aham
translated: And to the Order of the Enlightened One’s disciples. I go for refuge.

original: “Pāṇātipātā viramāmi khippaṃ, loke adinnaṃ parivajjayāmi;
analyzed: pāṇa atipātā viramāmi khippam loke adinnam parivajjayāmi
translated: “I abstain from taking life, I shun the world’s gifts that are not given,

original: Amajjapo no ca musā bhaṇāmi, sakena dārena ca homi tuṭṭho.
analyzed: a majja paḥ no ca musā bhaṇāmi sakena dārena ca homi tuṭṭho
translated: I drink not the brew that makes for heedlessness, I speak not a falsehood, I am content with my own wife.

original: “Ophuṇāmi mahāvāte, nadiyā sīghagāmiyā;
analyzed: ophuṇāmi mahā vāte nadiyā sīghagāmiyā
translated: “I am blown about by the great wind, I am carried away by the swift-flowing river,

original: Vamāmi pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ, buddhānaṃ sāsane rato.
analyzed: vamāmi pāpikam diṭṭhim buddhānam sāsane rataḥ
translated: I vomit forth the evil view, I delight in the Enlightened One’s Dispensation.

original: “Idaṃ vatvāna soraṭṭho, viramitvā pāpadassanā;
analyzed: idam vatvāna soraṭṭhaḥ viramitvā pāpa dassanā
translated: “Having thus spoken, Suraṭṭha, having abstained from evil views,

original: Namo bhagavato katvā, pāmokkho rathamāruhī”ti. – gāthāyo avocuṃ;
analyzed: namaḥ bhagavataḥ katvā pāmokkhaḥ ratham āruhi iti gāthāyaḥ avocuṃ
translated: Having paid homage to the Blessed One, the foremost, he mounted his chariot.”

original: 658-9. Tattha rājā piṅgalako nāma, suraṭṭhānaṃ adhipati ahūti piṅgalacakkhutāya “piṅgalo”ti
analyzed: tattha rājā piṅgalakaḥ nāma suraṭṭhānam adhipati ahū ti piṅgala cakkhu tāya piṅgaloti
translated: Herein, the king was named Piṅgala, and he was the lord of Suraṭṭha. Because of his tawny eyes he was called Piṅgala.

original: pākaṭanāmo suraṭṭhadesassa issaro rājā ahosi. Moriyānanti moriyarājūnaṃ, dhammāsokaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Suraṭṭhaṃ punarāgamāti suraṭṭhassa visayaṃ uddissa suraṭṭhagāmimaggaṃ
analyzed: pākaṭa nāmaḥ suraṭṭha desassa issaraḥ rājā ahosi moriya ananti moriya rājūnam dhamma āsokam  sandhāya vadati suraṭṭham punar āgamāti suraṭṭhassa visayam uddissa suraṭṭha gāmi maggaṃ
translated: The king who was the lord of the country of Suratta was well-known by the name of Sura. Moriyānanti means the Moriya kings.

original: paccāgañchi. Paṅkanti mudubhūmiṃ. Vaṇṇupathanti petena nimmitaṃ marūbhūmimaggaṃ.
analyzed: paccāgañchi mudu bhūmim petena nimmitam marū bhūmi maggam
translated: He says this referring to Dhammāsoka. Suraṭṭhaṃ punarāgamā ti he returned to the country of Suratta. Paṅkaṃ means soft ground. Vaṇṇupathaṃ means the path of the gods created by the dead.

original: 660. Khemoti nibbhayo. Sovatthikoti sotthibhāvāvaho. Sivoti anupaddavo. Suraṭṭhānaṃ santike itoti iminā maggena gacchantā mayaṃ suraṭṭhavisayassa samīpeyeva.
analyzed: khemaḥ iti nibbhayaḥ sovatthikaḥ ti sotthi bhāva āvahaḥ sivaḥ ti anupaddavaḥ suraṭṭhānam santike itoti iminā maggena gacchantā mayam suraṭṭha visayassa
translated: . Khemaṃ means free from fear. Sovatthikaṃ means bringing about welfare. Sivo means free from danger. Suraṭṭhānaṃ santike ito ti by this path we are going near the country of Suratta.

original: 661-2. Soraṭṭhoti suraṭṭhādhipati. Ubbiggarūpoti utrastasabhāvo. Bhiṃsananti bhayajananaṃ. Lomahaṃsananti bhiṃsanakabhāvena lomānaṃ haṃsāpanaṃ.
analyzed: soraṭṭhaḥ ti suraṭṭha adhipatiḥ ubbigga rūpaḥ iti utrasta sabhāvaḥ bhaya jananam bhiṃsanaka bhāvena lomānam haṃsāpanam
translated: -. Soraṭṭho means the lord of Suratta. Ubbiggarūpo means having a frightened nature. Bhiṃsananti means frightening. Lomahaṃsananti means the raising of the hairs of the body through fear.

original: 663. Yamapurisāna santiketi petānaṃ samīpe vattāma. Amānuso vāyati gandhoti petānaṃ
analyzed: yamapurisāna santikā iti petānam samīpe vattāma amānusaḥ vāyati gandhaḥ iti petānam
translated: . Yamapurisāna santiketi we are near the dead. Amānuso vāyati gandho ti the smell of the dead🔽.

original: sarīragandho vāyati. Ghoso suyyati dāruṇoti paccekanirayesu kāraṇaṃ kāriyamānānaṃ
analyzed: sarīra gandhaḥ vāyati ghosaḥ suyyati dāruṇo ti paccekanirayesu kāraṇam
translated: The smell of the body is wafted. The sound is heard, terrible.

original: sattānaṃ ghorataro saddo suyyati.
analyzed: sattānam ghorataraḥ saddaḥ suyyati
translated: The sound of the beings who are being punished in the individual hells is heard more terrible.

original: 666. Pādapanti pādasadisehi mūlāvayavehi udakassa pivanato “pādapo”ti laddhanāmaṃ
analyzed: pādapanti pāda sadisehi mūla avayavehi udakassa pivanato pādapaḥ ti laddha nāmaṃ
translated: . A tree is called a “tree” because it drinks water with its root-like parts.🔽It is endowed with shade. It is like the color of a blue cloud.

original: taruṃ. Chāyāsampannanti sampannacchāyaṃ. Nīlabbhavaṇṇasadisanti vaṇṇena nīlameghasadisaṃ.🔽Meghavaṇṇasirīnibhanti meghavaṇṇasaṇṭhānaṃ hutvā khāyamānaṃ.
analyzed: tarum chāyā sampannanti sampanna chāyam nīla abbha vaṇṇa sadisanti vaṇṇena nīla megha sadisam  megha vaṇṇa sirī nibhanti megha vaṇṇa saṇṭhānam hutvā khāyamānam
translated: It is like the color of a cloud. It is shining.

original: 670. Pūraṃ pānīyasarakanti pānīyena puṇṇaṃ pānīyabhājanaṃ. Pūveti khajjake. Vitteti vittijanane madhure manuññe tahiṃ tahiṃ sarāve pūretvā ṭhapitapūve addasa.
analyzed: pūram pānīya sarakanti pānīyena puṇṇam pānīya bhājanam pūva iti khajjake vitta iti vitti janane madhure manuññe tahim tahim sarāve pūretvā ṭhapita pūve addasa
translated: It is filled with water and juice. It is filled with water. It is a water vessel. It is a cake. It is a cake-making. It is sweet. It is delicious. It is filled here and there. It is a cake that is placed after being filled.

original: 672. Atho te adurāgatanti ettha athoti nipātamattaṃ, avadhāraṇatthe vā, mahārāja,
analyzed: atho te ettha atho ti nipāta mattam avadhāraṇa atthe vā mahā rāja
translated: . And they have come not far. Here “and” is just a particle, or it is for emphasis. Or, “Great King,

original: te āgataṃ durāgataṃ na hoti, atha kho svāgatamevāti mayaṃ sampaṭicchāmāti attho.
analyzed: te āgatam durāgatam na hoti atha kho svāgatam eva ati mayam sampaṭicchāma ati
translated: their coming is not far, rather it is a good coming,” is the meaning.

original: Arindamāti arīnaṃ damanasīla.
analyzed: arindama ati arīnam damana sīla
translated: The tamer of foes.

original: 677. Amaccā pārisajjāti amaccā pārisajjā ca vacanaṃ suṇantu, brāhmaṇo ca tuyhaṃ purohito taṃ suṇātūti yojanā.
analyzed: amaccā pārisajjā ati amaccā pārisajjā ca vacanam suṇantu brāhmaṇaḥ ca tuyham purohitaḥ tam suṇātu iti yojanā
translated: ‘Ministers and counsellors’: let the ministers and counsellors listen, and let your chaplain listen too.

original: 678. Suraṭṭhasmiṃ ahanti suraṭṭhadese ahaṃ. Devāti rājānaṃ ālapati. Micchādiṭṭhīti
analyzed: suraṭṭhasmin aham ti suraṭṭha dese aham deva ati rājānam ālapati micchādiṭṭhī iti
translated: ‘In the land of Suratta’: in the Suratta country. ‘God’: he addresses the king. ‘With wrong view’:

original: natthikadiṭṭhiyā viparītadassano. Dussīloti nissīlo. Kadariyoti thaddhamaccharī.
analyzed: natthika diṭṭhiyā viparīta dassanaḥ dussīlaḥ ti nissīlaḥ kadariyaḥ ti thaddhamaccharī
translated: with perverted vision through nihilism. ‘Immoral’: without virtue. ‘Stingy’: hard and miserly.

original: Paribhāsakoti samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ akkosako.
analyzed: paribhāsakaḥ ti samaṇa brāhmaṇānam akkosakaḥ
translated: ‘Abusive’: abusive of ascetics and brahmans.

original: 679. Vārayissanti vāresiṃ. Antarāyakaro ahanti dānaṃ dadantānaṃ upakāraṃ karontānaṃ
analyzed: vārayissanti vāresim antarāya karaḥ ahanti dānam dadantānam upakāram karontānam
translated: ‘I have obstructed’: I have obstructed. ‘I have been an obstacle’: I have been an obstacle to those giving gifts and doing services,

original: antarāyakaro hutvā aññesañca paresaṃ dānaṃ dadamānānaṃ dānamayapuññato ahaṃ bahujanaṃ
analyzed: antarāya karaḥ hutvā aññesam ca paresam dānam dadamānānam dāna maya puññataḥ aham bahu janam
translated: and I have obstructed many people from the merit of giving gifts by being an obstacle to others giving gifts.

original: vārayissaṃ vāresinti yojanā.🔽680. Vipāko natthi dānassātiādi vāritākāradassanaṃ. Tattha vipāko natthi dānassāti
analyzed: vārayissam vāresinti yojanā  vipākaḥ natthi dānassa atiādi vārita ākāra dassanam tattha vipākaḥ natthi dānassa ati
translated: ‘I have obstructed’: the construction is ‘I have obstructed by obstructing’.🔽‘There is no outcome from giving’ and so on is the showing of the way in which he obstructed. Herein, ‘There is no outcome from giving’ is the denial of outcome.

original: dānaṃ dadato tassa vipāko āyatiṃ pattabbaphalaṃ natthīti vipākaṃ paṭibāhati. Saṃyamassa
analyzed: dānam dadataḥ tassa vipākaḥ āyatim pattabba phalam natthi iti vipākam paṭibāhati saṃyamassa
translated: ‘From self-control’

original: kuto phalanti sīlassa pana kuto nāma phalaṃ, sabbena sabbaṃ taṃ natthīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: kutas phalanti sīlassa pana kutas nāma phalam sabbena sabbam tat natthi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: But how can there be any fruit of virtue? The intention is that all that is completely non-existent.

original: Natthi ācariyo nāmāti ācārasamācārasikkhāpako ācariyo nāma koci natthi. Sabhāvato
analyzed: natthi ācariyaḥ nāma ati ācāra samācāra sikkhāpako ācariyaḥ nāma koci natthi sabhāvato
translated: There is no teacher called: there is no teacher called who teaches the training in good behaviour and right conduct. The intention is that creatures are by nature

original: eva hi sattā dantā vā adantā vā hontīti adhippāyo. Tenāha “adantaṃ ko damessatī”ti.
analyzed: eva hi sattāḥ dantāḥ vā adantāḥ vā honti iti adhippāyaḥ tena āha adantam kaḥ damessati iti
translated: either tamed or untamed. Hence he said: “Who will tame the untamed?”

original: 681. Samatulyāni bhūtānīti ime sattā sabbepi aññamaññaṃ samasamā, tasmā jeṭṭho eva
analyzed: sama tulyāni bhūtāni iti ime sattā sabbe pi aññam aññam samasamā tasmā jeṭṭhaḥ eva
translated: All beings are equal: all these beings are equal to each other. Therefore there is no elder,

original: natthi, kuto jeṭṭhāpacāyiko, jeṭṭhāpacāyanapuññaṃ nāma natthīti attho. Natthi balanti🔽yamhi attano bale patiṭṭhitā sattā vīriyaṃ katvā manussasobhagyataṃ ādiṃ katvā yāvaarahattaṃ
analyzed: natthi kutas jeṭṭhāpacāyikaḥ jeṭṭhāpacāyana puññam nāma natthi iti atthaḥ natthi balam ti  yamhi attanaḥ bale patiṭṭhitā sattā vīriyam katvā manussa sobhagyatam ādim katvā yāva arahattam
translated: how then can there be one who shows respect to elders? The meaning is that there is no merit in showing respect to elders. There is no strength:

original: sampattiyo pāpuṇanti, taṃ vīriyabalaṃ paṭikkhipati. Vīriyaṃ vā natthi kuto uṭṭhānaporisanti
analyzed: sampattiyaḥ pāpuṇanti tam vīriya balam paṭikkhipati vīriyam vā natthi kutas uṭṭhāna porisanti
translated: he denies the strength of energy by which creatures, established in their own strength, attain the various kinds of excellence, beginning with the good fortune of being a human being and ending with arahatship, by exerting energy. Or else, there is no energy, how then can there be the strength of exertion?

original: idaṃ no purisavīriyena purisakārena pavattanti evaṃ pavattavādapaṭikkhepavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idam no purisa vīriyena purisakārena pavattanti evam pavatta vāda paṭikkhepa vasena vuttam
translated: This is said by way of denying the doctrine that it is by means of human energy and human strength that one acts.

original: 682. Natthi dānaphalaṃ nāmāti dānassa phalaṃ nāma kiñci natthi, deyyadhammapariccāgo
analyzed: na atthi dāna phalam nāma ati dānassa phalam nāma kiñci na atthi deyya dhamma pariccāgaḥ
translated: There is no fruit of giving: there is no fruit of giving at all; the giving away of an object of giving

original: bhasmanihitaṃ viya nipphalo evāti attho. Na visodheti verinanti ettha verinanti veravantaṃ
analyzed: bhasma nihitam viya nipphalaḥ evā ti atthaḥ na visodheti verinanti ettha veravantam
translated: is fruitless, as if it were thrown on ashes—this is the meaning. It does not purify the hater: here, the hater is the one who has hate.

original: verānaṃ vasena pāṇātipātādīnaṃ vasena ca katapāpaṃ puggalaṃ dānasīlādivatato na visodheti,🔽kadācipi suddhaṃ na karoti. Pubbe “vipāko natthi dānassā”tiādi dānādito attano paresaṃ
analyzed: vasena pāṇātipāta ādīnam vasena ca kata pāpam puggalam dāna sīla ādi vatataḥ na visodheti  kadāci pi suddham na karoti pubbe vipākaḥ natthi dānassa atiādi dāna āditaḥ attanaḥ paresam
translated: The giving of gifts, etc., does not purify a person who has committed evil by means of hate or by means of killing breathing things, etc.,

original: nivāritākāradassanaṃ, “natthi dānaphalaṃ nāmā”tiādi pana atthano micchābhinivesadassananti
analyzed: nivārita ākāra dassanam natthi dāna phalam nāma atiādi pana atthanaḥ micchā abhinivesa dassananti
translated: it never makes him pure. The view shown above in the passage beginning, “There is no ripening of giving” , was the view that the giving, etc., of others is not a cause of preventing his own evil. But the view stated in the passage beginning, “There is no fruit of giving” , is his own wrong adherence.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Laddheyyanti laddhabbaṃ. Kathaṃ pana laddhabbanti āha “niyatipariṇāmaja”nti.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam laddheyyam ti laddhabbam katham pana laddhabbam nti āha niyati pariṇāma janti
translated: What is to be obtained: what is to be got. But how is it to be got? He said, “It is born of the transformation of fate.”

original: Ayaṃ satto sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā labhanto niyativipariṇāmavaseneva labhati, na kammassa
analyzed: ayam satto sukham vā dukkham vā labhantaḥ niyati vipariṇāma vasena iva labhati na kammassa
translated: The intention is this: when this being obtains pleasure or pain, he obtains it only by the transformation of fate, not by the doing of kamma,

original: katattā, na issarādinā cāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: kata ttā na issara ādinā ca ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: not by a supreme god, etc.

original: 683. Natthi mātā pitā bhātāti mātādīsu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāvaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Loko natthi ito paranti ito idhalokato paraloko nāma koci natthi,
analyzed: na atthi mātā pitā bhātā ati mātā ādīsu sammā paṭipattim icchā paṭipattīnam phala abhāvam  sandhāya vadati lokaḥ natthi ito paranti itas idha lokato para lokaḥ nāma koci natthi
translated: “There is no mother, no father, no creatures reborn in the world through spontaneous generation” : he says this with reference to the non-existence of the fruit of right and wrong conduct in the case of mother, father, and spontaneous generation.🔽“There is no world beyond” : the meaning is that there is no such thing as a world beyond, a world hereafter, for beings cease to exist right here.

original: tattha tattheva sattā ucchijjantīti adhippāyo. Dinnanti mahādānaṃ. Hutanti pahenakasakkāro,
analyzed: tattha tattha iva sattāḥ ucchijjanti iti adhippāyaḥ dinnanti mahādānam hutanti pahenaka sakkāro
translated: “No gift” : a great gift. “No sacrifice” : the honouring of a departed relative.

original: tadubhayampi phalābhāvaṃ sandhāya “natthī”ti paṭikkhipati. Sunihitanti suṭṭhu nihitaṃ.🔽Na vijjatīti yaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ dānaṃ nāma “anugāmikanidhī”ti vadanti, taṃ na
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi phala abhāvam sandhāya natthi iti paṭikkhipati su nihitam ti suṭṭhu nihitam  na vijjati iti yam dānam nāma anugāmika nidhi iti vadanti tam na
translated: With reference to the non-existence of the fruit of these two he denies them, saying “there is no.”🔽“No store of merit” :

original: vijjati. Tesaṃ taṃ vācāvatthumattamevāti adhippāyo.🔽684. Na koci kañci hanatīti yo puriso paraṃ purisaṃ haneyya, parassa purisassa sīsaṃ
analyzed: vijjati tesam tam vācāvatthumattam eva ati adhippāyaḥ  na koci kañci hanati iti yaḥ puriso param purisam haneyya parassa purisassa sīsam
translated: he denies this, saying “there is no,” with reference to the non-existence of the store of merit which the ascetics and brahmins call “the inexhaustible treasure.” The meaning is that it is merely a verbal expression.

original: chindeyya, tattha paramatthato na koci kañci hanati, sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ chiddabhāvato
analyzed: chindeyya tattha paramatthataḥ na koci kañci hanati sattannam kāyānam chidda bhāvato
translated: “No one cuts off another’s life” : if a man were to kill another, to cut off the head of another person, then in the ultimate sense no one cuts off the life of another, because of the absence of a self in the seven types of beings.

original: hananto viya hoti. Kathaṃ satthapahāroti āha “sattannaṃ vivaramantare”ti. Pathavīādīnaṃ🔽sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ vivarabhūte antare chidde satthaṃ pavisati, tena sattā asiādīhi
analyzed: hanantaḥ viya hoti katham sattha pahāraḥ ti āha vivaram antareti pathavī ādīnam  kāyānam vivara bhūte antare chidde sattham pavisati tena sattā
translated: He is as if struck. How is he as if pierced by a weapon? He says, “In the interstice of the seven” .

original: pahatā viya honti, jīvo viya pana sesakāyāpi niccasabhāvattā na chijjantīti adhippāyo.🔽685. Acchejjābhejjo hi jīvoti ayaṃ sattānaṃ jīvo satthādīhi na chinditabbo na bhinditabbo
analyzed: pahatāḥ viya honti jīvaḥ viya pana sesa kāyā api nicca sabhāva ttā na chijjanti iti adhippāyaḥ  acchejja abhejjaḥ hi jīvaḥ ti ayam sattānam jīvaḥ sattha ādīhi na chinditabbaḥ na bhinditabbaḥ
translated: In the interstice, the opening, of the seven bodies beginning with the earth body, the weapon enters, and so beings are as if struck by swords, etc. But the intention is that the remaining bodies, like the life principle, are not cut because they have the nature of permanence.🔽For the life principle is not cut or broken,🔽This life principle of beings is not to be cut by a weapon, etc., or broken, because it has the nature of permanence.🔽It is eight-faceted, globular,

original: niccasabhāvattā. Aṭṭhaṃso guḷaparimaṇḍaloti so pana jīvo kadāci aṭṭhaṃso hoti kadāci
analyzed: nicca sabhā vattā aṭṭhaṃso guḷa parimaṇḍalo ti so pana jīvo kadāci aṭṭhaṃso hoti kadāci
translated: and sometimes it is eight-faceted, sometimes globular.🔽It is five hundred leagues in extent,

original: guḷaparimaṇḍalo. Yojanānaṃ sataṃ pañcāti kevalībhāvaṃ patto pañcayojanasatubbedho🔽hoti. Ko jīvaṃ chettumarahatīti niccaṃ nibbikāraṃ jīvaṃ ko nāma satthādīhi chindituṃ
analyzed: guḷa parimaṇḍalaḥ yojanānam satam pañca ati kevalībhāvam  hoti kaḥ jīvam chettum arahati iti niccam nibbikāram jīvam kaḥ nāma sattha ādīhi chinditum
translated: when it has reached the state of being complete it is five hundred leagues in height.🔽Who is able to cut the life principle?

original: arahati, na so kenaci vikopaneyyoti vadati.
analyzed: arahati na saḥ kenacid vadati
translated: Who is able to cut the life principle, which is permanent and without function, with a weapon, etc.? He says that it is not to be disturbed by anyone.

original: 686. Suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe. Khitteti nibbeṭhanavasena khitte. Nibbeṭhentaṃ
analyzed: sutta guḷe iti veṭhetvā kata sutta guḷe khitte iti nibbeṭhana vasena khitte nibbeṭhentam
translated: ‘A ball of thread’: a ball of thread made by twisting together. ‘Thrown’: thrown by unravelling.

original: palāyatīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā nibbeṭhiyamānaṃ khittaṃ suttaguḷaṃ nibbeṭhentameva
analyzed: palāyati iti pabbate vā rukkha gge vā ṭhatvā nibbeṭhiyamānam khittam sutta guḷam nibbeṭhentam eva
translated: ‘It runs while it is being unraveled’: a ball of thread thrown by being unraveled from the top of a rock or from the fork of a tree runs while it is being unraveled;

original: gacchati, sutte khīṇe na gacchati. Evamevanti yathā taṃ suttaguḷaṃ nibbeṭhiyamānaṃ🔽gacchati, sutte khīṇe na gacchati, evameva so jīvo “cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassānī”ti
analyzed: gacchati sutte khīṇe na gacchati evam evanti yathā tam sutta guḷam nibbeṭhiyamānam  gacchati sutte khīṇe na gacchati evam eva saḥ jīvaḥ mahā kappino sata sahassāni iti
translated: it does not run when the thread is exhausted. ‘So too’: just as that ball of thread runs while it is being unraveled and does not run when the thread is exhausted,

original: vuttakālameva attabhāvaguḷaṃ nibbeṭhento palāyati pavattati, tato uddhaṃ na pavattati.🔽687. Evameva ca so jīvoti yathā koci puriso attano nivāsagāmato nikkhamitvā tato
analyzed: vutta kālam eva atta bhāva guḷam nibbeṭhento palāyati pavattati tatas uddham na pavattati  evam eva ca saḥ jīvaḥ ti yathā koci purisaḥ attanaḥ nivāsa gāmataḥ nikkhamitvā tatas
translated: so too, that living being runs away, moves, while it is being unraveled from the ball of the material body for the time stated thus, ‘…a hundred thousand great eons for every eighty thousand’ , and it does not move beyond that.

original: aññaṃ gāmaṃ pavisati kenacideva karaṇīyena, evameva so jīvo ito sarīrato nikkhamitvā
analyzed: aññam gāmam pavisati kenacid eva karaṇīyena evam eva saḥ jīvaḥ itas sarīrataḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: ‘So too, that living being’: just as a man might leave his own village and enter another village for some business or other,

original: aññaṃ aparaṃ sarīraṃ niyatavasena pavisatīti adhippāyo. Bondinti kāyaṃ.
analyzed: aññam aparam sarīram niyata vasena pavisati iti adhippāyaḥ bondinti kāyam
translated: so too, that living being leaves this body and enters another body in the way stated. This is the meaning. ‘Bond’: body.

original: 689. Cullāsītīti caturāsīti. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Tattha “ekamhā mahāsarā
analyzed: cullāsītī iti mahākappino ti mahākappānam tattha ekamhā mahāsarā
translated: Eighty-four thousand great eons: eighty-four thousand great eons.

original: anotattādito vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharante iminā upakkamena
analyzed: vassa sate vassa sate kusaggena ekekam udaka bindum nīharante iminā upakkamena
translated: In this connection they say: “When a single drop of water is removed from the great ocean every hundred years with a lotus leaf,

original: sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake jāte eko mahākappo nāma hotī”ti vatvā “evarūpānaṃ
analyzed: sattakkhattum tamhi sare nirudake jāte ekaḥ mahākappaḥ nāma hoti iti vatvā
translated: by this method, when the ocean has dried up seven times, a single great eon has passed.”🔽They say that the measure of the round of rebirths is eighty-four thousand

original: mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni saṃsārassa parimāṇa”nti vadanti. Ye bālā ye
analyzed: mahākappānam catur asīti sata sahassāni saṃsārassa parimāṇanti vadanti ye bālāḥ ye
translated: great eons of this kind.🔽The foolish and the wise: the blind fools and the wise ones.

original: ca paṇḍitāti ye andhabālā, ye ca sappaññā, sabbepi te. Saṃsāraṃ khepayitvānāti yathāvuttakālaparicchedaṃ
analyzed: ca paṇḍitā ati ye andha bālā ye ca sappaññā sabbe pi te saṃsāram khepayitvā na ati yathā vutta kāla paricchedam
translated: Having exhausted the round of rebirths: having exhausted the round of rebirths, the measure of which has been stated,

original: saṃsāraṃ aparāparuppattivasena khepetvā. Dukkhassantaṃ karissareti vaṭṭadukkhassa🔽pariyantaṃ pariyosānaṃ karissanti. Paṇḍitāpi antarā sujjhituṃ na sakkonti, bālāpi
analyzed: saṃsāram apara apara uppatti vasena khepetvā dukkha ssantam vaṭṭa dukkhassa  pariyantam pariyosānam karissanti paṇḍitā api antarā sujjhitum na sakkonti bālā api
translated: by passing from one existence to another. They will make an end of suffering: they will make an end of the suffering of the round.

original: tato uddhaṃ nappavattantīti tassa laddhi.
analyzed: tatas uddham na ppavattanti iti tassa laddhi
translated: The foolish are unable to purify themselves in the interval, and the wise do not revolve in the round beyond that. This is the opinion of the Andhakas.

original: 690. Mitāni sukhadukkhāni, doṇehi piṭakehi cāti sattānaṃ sukhadukkhāni nāma doṇehi
analyzed: mitāni sukha dukkhāni doṇehi piṭakehi ca ati sattānam sukha dukkhāni nāma doṇehi
translated: Happiness and suffering are measured out, As in a measure, in a basket, in a pot.

original: piṭakehi mānabhājanehi mitāni viya yathāvuttakālaparicchedeneva parimitattā paccekañca
analyzed: piṭakehi māna bhājanehi mitāni viya yathāvutta kāla paricchedena iva parimita ttā paccekam ca
translated: The happiness and suffering of beings are measured out, as it were, by measures, by baskets, by pots, by containers for measuring, because they are limited to the time stated, and they are limited to each being, being born with his kamma.

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tāni niyatipariṇāmajāni parimitāni. Tayidaṃ jino sabbaṃ pajānāti
analyzed: tesam tesam sattānam tāni niyati pariṇāma jāni parimitāni tayidam jino sabbam pajānāti
translated: The Victor knows all this,

original: jinabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito kevalaṃ pajānāti saṃsārassa samatikkantattā. Saṃsāre pana paribbhamati
analyzed: jina bhūmiyam ṭhitaḥ kevalam pajānāti saṃsārassa samatikkanta ttā saṃsāre pana paribbhamati
translated: and he knows it only when he is on the plane of a Buddha, because he has transcended the round of rebirths. But in the round of rebirths he wanders,

original: sammūḷhāyaṃ itarā pajā.
analyzed: sammūḍhā ayam itarā pajā
translated: And other people are confused.

original: 691. Evaṃdiṭṭhi pure āsinti yathāvuttanatthikadiṭṭhiko pubbeva ahaṃ ahosiṃ. Sammūḷho🔽mohapārutoti yathāvuttāya diṭṭhiyā hetubhūtena sammohena sammūḷho, taṃsahajātena
analyzed: evaṃdiṭṭhi pure āsin ti yathāvutta natthika diṭṭhiko pubbā iva aham ahosim sammūḷho  moha pārutaḥ ti yathā vuttāya diṭṭhiyāḥ hetu bhūtena sammohena sammūḍhaḥ tad sahajātena
translated: He had such a view in the past: he had the view of the kind stated in the passage beginning, “I was in the past” .

original: pana mohena pāruto, paṭicchāditakusalabījoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pana mohena pāruto paṭicchādita kusala bījo ti adhippāyo
translated: Confused, he was carried away by delusion: confused by the delusion that is the cause of the view stated in the way beginning, “I was in the past” , he was carried away by the delusion that is associated with that . The meaning is that he has concealed the seed of profitable action.

original: 692. Evaṃ pubbe yā attano uppannā pāpadiṭṭhi, tassā vasena kataṃ pāpakammaṃ dassetvā idāni attanā āyatiṃ anubhavitabbaṃ tassa phalaṃ dassento “oraṃ me chahi māsehī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: evam pubbe yā attanaḥ uppannā pāpa diṭṭhi tassāḥ vasena katam pāpa kammam dassetvā idāni attanā āyatim anubhavitabbam tassa phalam dassentaḥ oram me chahi māsehi iti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the evil action done by himself in the past by the evil view that had arisen in himself, he now said “In six months’ time” in order to show the fruit of that action which he himself would have to experience in the future.

original: 695-7. Tattha vassāni satasahassānīti vassānaṃ satasahassāni, atikkamitvāti vacanaseso.
analyzed: tattha vassāni sata sahassāni iti vassānam sata sahassāni atikkamitvā iti vacana sesaḥ
translated: Herein, for a hundred thousand years means for a hundred thousand years, the rest of the words being understood.

original: Bhummatthe vā etaṃ paccattavacanaṃ, vassesu satasahassesu vītivattesūti attho. Ghoso🔽suyyati tāvadeti yadā ettako kālo atikkanto hoti, tāvadeva tasmiṃ kāle “idha paccantānaṃ
analyzed: bhumma tthe vai etam paccatta vacanam vassesu sata sahassesu vītivattesu iti atthaḥ ghosaḥ  tāvat eti yadā ettakaḥ kālo atikkanto hoti tāvat eva tasmin kāle idha paccantānam
translated: Or this is a locative of time, the meaning being: “When a period of a hundred thousand years has elapsed.”

original: vo mārisā vassasatasahassaparimāṇo kālo atīto”ti evaṃ tasmiṃ niraye saddo suyyati.🔽Lakkho eso, mahārāja, satabhāgavassakoṭiyoti satabhāgā satakoṭṭhāsā vassakoṭiyo,
analyzed: vaḥ mārisāḥ vassa sata sahassa parimāṇaḥ kālaḥ atītaḥ ti evam tasmin niraye saddo suyyati  lakkhaḥ eso mahā rāja sata bhāga vassa koṭiyaḥ ti sata bhāgā sata koṭṭhāsāḥ vassa koṭiyaḥ
translated: The sound is heard thus far: when that much time has elapsed, at that time the sound is heard in that hell thus: “Good sirs, a period of a hundred thousand years has elapsed for you who are cooking here.”

original: mahārāja, niraye paccantānaṃ sattānaṃ āyuno eso lakkho eso paricchedoti attho. Idaṃ
analyzed: mahā rāja niraye paccantānam sattānam āyunaḥ esaḥ lakkhaḥ esaḥ paricchedaḥ ti atthaḥ idam
translated: This is the measure, great king, of a hundred thousand years: a hundred times a hundred thousand years, great king, is the measure, is the limit, of the life of beings who cook in hell.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – dasadasakaṃ sataṃ nāma, dasa satāni sahassaṃ nāma, dasadasasahassāni
analyzed: vuttam hoti dasadasakam satam nāma dasa satāni sahassam nāma dasa dasa sahassāni
translated: The meaning is: a hundred times ten is a hundred, a hundred times a hundred is a thousand, a hundred times a thousand is

original: satasahassaṃ nāma, satasatasahassāni koṭi nāma, tāsaṃ koṭīnaṃ vasena satasahassavassakoṭiyo🔽satabhāgā vassakoṭiyo. Sā ca kho nerayikānaṃyeva vassagaṇanāvasena veditabbā, na
analyzed: sata sahassam nāma sata sata sahassāni koṭi nāma tāsam koṭīnam vasena sata sahassa vassa koṭiyaḥ  sata bhāgāḥ vassa koṭiyaḥ sā ca kho nerayikānam yeva vassa gaṇanā vasena veditabbā na
translated: a hundred thousand, a hundred times a hundred hundred is a million, a hundred times a million is an aḷaha, a hundred times an aḷaha is a koṭi.🔽The life-span of beings in the hells is measured in terms of these koṭis.🔽It should be understood that this is according to the reckoning of the hells, not according to the reckoning of men or gods.

original: manussānaṃ, devānaṃ vā. Īdisāni anekāni vassakoṭisatasahassāni nerayikānaṃ āyu. Tenāha
analyzed: manussānam devānam vā īdisāni anekāni vassa koṭi sata sahassāni nerayikānam āyu tena āha
translated: Such are the many hundreds of thousands of koṭis of years that beings spend being boiled in the hells. Therefore it is said:

original: “koṭisatasahassāni, niraye paccare janā”ti. Yādisena pana pāpena sattā evaṃ nirayesu
analyzed: koṭi sata sahassāni niraye paccare janāti yādisena pana pāpena sattāḥ evam nirayesu
translated: “For hundreds of thousands of koṭis of years, beings are boiled in the hells.”🔽In order to show by way of conclusion the kind of evil by which beings are boiled in the hells, it is said:

original: paccanti, taṃ nigamanavasena dassetuṃ “micchādiṭṭhī ca dussīlā, ye ca ariyūpavādino”ti
analyzed: paccanti tam nigamana vasena dassetum micchā diṭṭhī ca dussīlāḥ ye ca ari yūpa vādino ti
translated: “Those of wrong view and those of bad conduct, and those who revile the noble ones.”

original: vuttaṃ. Vedissanti anubhavissaṃ.🔽698-706. Evaṃ āyatiṃ attanā anubhavitabbaṃ pāpaphalaṃ dassetvā idāni “kena te brahmacariyena,
analyzed: vuttam vedissanti anubhavissam 🔽evam āyatim attanā anubhavitabbam pāpa phalam dassetvā idāni kena te brahmacariyena
translated: They will experience: they will undergo.

original: ānubhāvo ayaṃ tavā”ti raññā pucchitamatthaṃ ācikkhitvā taṃ saraṇesu ceva sīlesu ca🔽patiṭṭhāpetukāmo “taṃ suṇohi mahārājā”tiādimāha. Tattha sīlesuposathe ratāti niccasīlesu
analyzed: ānubhāvaḥ ayam tava ati raññā pucchitam attham ācikkhitvā tam saraṇesu ca iva sīlesu ca  patiṭṭhāpetu kāmo tam suṇohi mahā rāja iti ādim āha tattha sīlesu uposathe ratā ti nicca sīlesu
translated: The king asked the meaning of the words, and the Elder explained.🔽Then he wished to establish the king in the Refuges and Precepts, and so he said, “Listen, great king,” etc. Herein, in the precepts and the fast-day observances he delights, he is always virtuous,

original: ca uposathasīlesu ca abhiratā. Adāti adāsi. Taṃ dhammanti taṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ amatapadañca.🔽709-12. Evaṃ petena saraṇesu sīlesu ca samādapito rājā pasannamānaso tena attano
analyzed: ca uposatha sīlesu ca abhiratā adāti tam dhamman ti tam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam amata padam ca  evam petena saraṇesu sīlesu ca samādapitaḥ rājā pasanna mānasaḥ tena
translated: “This is your majesty’s majesty.” When the king asked the meaning of the words, he explained the matter to him, and then, desiring to establish him in the Refuges and in the Precepts, he said, “Listen, great king,” and so on. Herein, delighting in the precepts and the fast-day observances means delighting in the precepts of the eight-factored path and in the precepts of the fast-day observance. I gave means I gave. That Dhamma means that eight-factored path and the state of deathlessness.

original: kataṃ upakāraṃ tāva kittetvā saraṇādīsu patiṭṭhahanto “atthakāmo”tiādikā tisso gāthā
analyzed: katam upakāram tāva kittetvā saraṇa ādīsu patiṭṭhahantaḥ attha kāmaḥ ti ādikā tissaḥ gāthā
translated: Thus, having been exhorted by the ghost in the Refuges and in the Precepts, the king, his mind pleased, first extolled the help he had received from him, and then, establishing himself in the Refuges and so on, he spoke three stanzas beginning with “One who desires good for himself.”

original: vatvā pubbe attanā gahitāya pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā paṭinissaṭṭhabhāvaṃ pakāsento “ophuṇāmī”ti gāthamāha.🔽Tattha ophuṇāmi mahāvāteti mahante vāte vāyante bhusaṃ viya taṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ,
analyzed: vatvā pubbe attanā gahitāya pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā paṭinissaṭṭha bhāvam pakāsentaḥ ophuṇāmi iti gātham āha  tattha ophuṇāmi mahā vāta iti mahante vāte vāyante bhusam viya tam pāpakam diṭṭhim
translated: Having thus made clear his own rejection of the evil view he had previously held, he spoke the stanza, “I blow out the evil view.”

original: yakkha, tava dhammadesanāvāte ophuṇāmi niddhunāmi. Nadiyā vā sīghagāmiyāti sīghasotāya
analyzed: yakkha tava dhamma desanā vāte ophuṇāmi niddhunāmi nadiyā vā sīgha gāmiyā ati sīgha sotāya
translated: Herein, I blow out the evil view means I blow out that evil view as if it were a flame in a great wind blowing, O ghost, I blow out, I blow away, by the wind of your Dhamma-teaching. Or as a swift-flowing river means as a river with a swift current.

original: mahānadiyā vā tiṇakaṭṭhapaṇṇakasaṭaṃ viya pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ pavāhemīti adhippāyo. Vamāmi
analyzed: mahānadiyāḥ vā tiṇa kaṭṭha paṇṇaka saṭam viya pāpikam diṭṭhim pavāhemi iti adhippāyaḥ vamāmi
translated: The meaning is, I vomit out the evil view as one would a mass of grass, sticks, leaves, and so on, from the great ocean.

original: pāpikaṃ diṭṭhinti mama manomukhagataṃ pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ ucchaḍḍayāmi. Tattha kāraṇamāha
analyzed: pāpikam diṭṭhim ti mama manaḥ mukha gatam pāpikam diṭṭhim ucchaḍḍayāmi tattha kāraṇam āha
translated: I vomit out the evil view: I throw out the evil view that has arisen in my mind. Herein, he gives the reason:

original: “buddhānaṃ sāsane rato”ti. Yasmā ekaṃsena amatāvahe buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ sāsane
analyzed: buddhānam sāsane yasmai ekaṃsena buddhānam bhagavantānam sāsane
translated: “Delighting in the Dispensation of the Buddhas.” Since I delight, I am delighted, in the Dispensation of the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, which is entirely conducive to the Deathless,

original: rato abhirato, tasmā taṃ diṭṭhisaṅkhātaṃ visaṃ vamāmīti yojanā.
analyzed: rataḥ tasmai tam diṭṭhi saṅkhātam visam vamāmi iti yojanā
translated: therefore I vomit out the poison called view. This is the construction.

original: 713. Ti osānagāthā saṅgītikārehi ṭhapitā. Tattha pāmokkhotipācīnadisābhimukho hutvā.🔽Rathamāruhīti rājā gamanasajjaṃ attano rājarathaṃ abhiruhi, āruyha yakkhānubhāvena
analyzed: ti osāna gāthā saṅgīti kārehi ṭhapitā tattha pāmokkhaḥ ti pācīna disa abhimukhaḥ hutvā  ratham āruhi iti rājā gamana sajjam rāja ratham āruyha yakkha anubhāvena
translated: The concluding verse was placed there by the compilers of the canon.🔽Facing east: facing the eastern direction.🔽He mounted the chariot: the king mounted his royal chariot, which was ready for a journey. Having mounted it, he reached his city by the power of the yakkha

original: taṃ divasameva attano nagaraṃ patvā rājabhavanaṃ pāvisi. So aparena samayena imaṃ
analyzed: tam divasam eva nagaram patvā rāja bhavanam saḥ aparena samayena imam
translated: and entered his palace on that very day. After some time he told the monks about this incident,

original: pavattiṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ārocesi, bhikkhū taṃ therānaṃ ārocesuṃ, therā tatiyasaṅgītiyaṃ saṅgahaṃ āropesuṃ.
analyzed: pavattim bhikkhūnaṃ ārocesi bhikkhū tam therānam ārocesuṃ therā tatiyasaṅgītiyam saṅgaham āropesuṃ
translated: and the monks told the elders. The elders included it in the third council.

original: Nandakapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nandaka peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of Nandaka the Ghost is finished.

original: 4. Revatīpetavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Ghost Revati

original: 714-36. Uṭṭhehi, revate, supāpadhammeti idaṃ revatīpetavatthu. Taṃ yasmā revatīvimānavatthunā🔽nibbisesaṃ, tasmā yadettha aṭṭhuppattiyaṃ gāthāsu ca vattabbaṃ, taṃ paramatthadīpaniyaṃ🔽vimānavatthuvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idañhi nandiyassa devaputtassa vasena🔽vimānavatthupāḷiyaṃ saṅgahaṃ āropitampi revatīpaṭibaddhāya gāthāya vasena “revatīpetavatthu”nti
analyzed: uṭṭhehi revate su pāpa dhamme ti idam revatī peta vatthu tam yasmai revatī vimāna vatthunā  nibbisesam tasmā yat ettha aṭṭhuppattiyam gāthāsu ca vattabbam tam paramattha dīpaniyam  vimāna vatthu vaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena iva veditabbam idam hi nandiyassa devaputtassa vasena  vimāna vatthu pāḷiyam saṅgaham āropitam pi revatī paṭibaddhāya gāthāya vasena revatī peta vatthunti
translated: “Rise up, Revati, you of evil conduct!” This is the story of the ghost Revati. Since it is not different from the story of the mansion of Revati,🔽what is to be said about the origin of the story and the verses should be understood in the way stated in the commentary on the mansion of Revati. For this story,🔽though included in the text of the mansions by way of the god Nandiya,

original: petavatthupāḷiyampi saṅgahaṃ āropitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: peta vatthu pāḷiyam pi saṅgaham āropitan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: is included in the text of the stories by way of the verse connected with Revati.

original: Revatīpetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽5. Ucchupetavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽Idaṃ mama ucchuvanaṃ mahantanti idaṃ ucchupetavatthu. Tassa kā uppatti? Bhagavati
analyzed: revatīpeta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā         idam mama ucchuvanam idam ucchupeta vatthu tassa kā uppatti bhagavati
translated: The Story of the Ghost Revati is finished.🔽The Story of the Ghost Ucchu

original: veḷuvane viharante aññataro puriso ucchukalāpaṃ khandhe katvā ekaṃ ucchuṃ khādanto
analyzed: veḷuvane viharante aññataraḥ puriso ucchu kalāpam khandhe katvā ekam ucchum khādanto
translated: “This my Ucchuvana is great!” This is the story of the ghost Ucchu. What is the origin of the story? When the Blessed One was dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, a certain man, having made a bundle of Ucchu grass, was eating one stalk of Ucchu grass,🔽and carrying the rest on his shoulder.

original: gacchati. Atha aññataro upāsako sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo bāladārakena saddhiṃ tassa piṭṭhito🔽piṭṭhito gacchati. Dārako ucchuṃ passitvā “dehī”ti parodati. Upāsako dārakaṃ parodantaṃ
analyzed: gacchati atha aññataraḥ upāsakaḥ sīlavā kalyāṇa dhammo bāla dārakena saddhim tassa piṭṭhitaḥ  piṭṭhitaḥ gacchati dārakaḥ ucchum passitvā dehi iti parodati upāsakaḥ dārakam parodantam
translated: and the other went along behind him.🔽The boy saw some curd and cried out, “Give me some!”🔽The lay disciple, seeing the boy crying,

original: disvā taṃ purisaṃ saṅgaṇhanto tena saddhiṃ sallāpamakāsi. So pana puriso tena saddhiṃ
analyzed: disvā tam purisam saṅgaṇhantaḥ tena saddhim sallāpam akāsi saḥ pana puriso tena saddhim
translated: tried to make conversation with the man in order to be friendly with him. But the man did not say anything to him

original: na kiñci ālapi, dārakassa ucchukhaṇḍampi nādāsi. Upāsako taṃ dārakaṃ dassetvā “ayaṃ🔽dārako ativiya rodati, imassa ekaṃ ucchukhaṇḍaṃ dehī”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā so puriso
analyzed: na kiñci dārakassa ucchukhaṇḍam pi upāsako tam dārakam dassetvā ayam  dārakaḥ ativiya rodati imassa ekam ucchukhaṇḍam dehi iti āha tam sutvā saḥ purisaḥ
translated: and did not give the boy any curd. The lay disciple pointed to the boy and said, “This boy🔽cries so much. Give him some curd.”

original: asahanto paṭihatacittaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā anādaravasena ekaṃ ucchulaṭṭhiṃ piṭṭhito khipi.
analyzed: a sahantaḥ paṭihata cittam upaṭṭhapetvā anādara vasena ekam ucchu laṭṭhim piṭṭhitaḥ khipi
translated: When the man heard this, he could not bear it. He became angry and contemptuous, and he threw a piece of curd-skin at the boy from behind.

original: So aparena samayena kālaṃ katvā ciraṃ paribhāvitassa lobhassa vasena petesu nibbatti,
analyzed: so aparena samayena kālam katvā ciram paribhāvitassa lobhassa vasena petesu nibbatti
translated: Later, after his death, he was reborn among the petas, because of his long-standing greed.

original: tassa phalaṃ nāma sakakammasarikkhakaṃ hotīti aṭṭhakarīsamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ avattharantaṃ
analyzed: tassa phalam nāma saka kamma sarikkhakam hoti iti aṭṭhakarīsa mattam ṭhānam avattharantam
translated: The fruit of his action was that he was reborn in a place eight leagues in extent.

original: añjanavaṇṇaṃ musaladaṇḍaparimāṇehi ucchūhi ghanasañchannaṃ mahantaṃ ucchuvanaṃ nibbatti.
analyzed: añjana vaṇṇam musala daṇḍa parimāṇehi ucchūhi ghana sañchannam mahantam ucchuvanam nibbatti
translated: and a great tree, as big as a pestle, with dense foliage, the colour of collyrium, grew up.

original: Tasmiṃ khāditukāmatāya “ucchuṃ gahessāmī”ti upagatamatte taṃ ucchū abhihananti, so
analyzed: tasmin khāditu kāma tāyai ucchum gahessāmi iti upagata matte tam ucchū abhihananti saḥ
translated: As soon as he approached it, thinking to eat it, the tree struck him,

original: tena pucchito patati.
analyzed: tena pucchitaḥ patati
translated: and he fell down.

original: Athekadivasaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya gacchanto antarāmagge taṃ petaṃ addasa. So theraṃ disvā attanā katakammaṃ pucchi –
analyzed: atha eka divasam āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ rājagaham piṇḍāya gacchantaḥ antarāmagge tam petam addasa saḥ theram disvā attanā kata kammam pucchi
translated: One day the venerable Maha Moggallana, going for alms in Rajagaha, saw the ghost on the way. The ghost, seeing the Elder, asked him about the deed he had done,

original: “Idaṃ mama ucchuvanaṃ mahantaṃ, nibbattati puññaphalaṃ anappakaṃ;
analyzed: idam mama ucchuvanam mahantam nibbattati puñña phalam anappakam
translated: “This tree of mine is great, it grows, the fruit of merit is not small;

original: Taṃ dāni me na paribhogameti, ācikkha bhante kissa ayaṃ vipāko.
analyzed: tam dāni me na ācikkha bhante kissa ayam vipāko
translated: But now I cannot enjoy it, tell me, venerable sir, what is the result of this?

original: “Haññāmi khajjāmi ca vāyamāmi, parisakkāmi paribhuñjituṃ kiñci;
analyzed: haññāmi khajjāmi ca vāyamāmi parisakkāmi paribhuñjitum kiñci
translated: “I am killed, I am eaten, I am striving, I am unable to enjoy anything;

original: Svāhaṃ chinnathāmo kapaṇo lālapāmi, kissa kammassa ayaṃ vipāko.
analyzed: svāham chinna thāmaḥ kapaṇaḥ lālapāmi kissa kammassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: I am a miserable wretch, I am crying out, what is the result of this deed?

original: “Vighāto cāhaṃ paripatāmi chamāyaṃ,
analyzed: ca aham paripatāmi
translated: “I am distressed, I am wandering about on the ground,

original: Parivattāmi vāricarova ghamme;
analyzed: parivattāmi vāricarā uva ghamme
translated: I am rolling about like a fish on dry land;

original: Rudato ca me assukā niggalanti,
analyzed: rudataḥ ca me assukāḥ niggalanti
translated: And tears flow from my eyes,

original: Ācikkha bhante kissa ayaṃ vipāko.
analyzed: ācikkha bhante kissa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: Please explain, sir, what the result of this is.

original: “Chāto kilanto ca pipāsito ca, santassito sātasukhaṃ na vinde;
analyzed: chātaḥ kilantaḥ ca pipāsitaḥ ca santassitaḥ sāta sukham na vinde
translated: “I am weak, tired, and thirsty, and I find no comfort in the pleasure of rest.

original: Pucchāmi taṃ etamatthaṃ bhadante, kathaṃ nu ucchuparibhogaṃ labheyya”nti.
analyzed: pucchāmi tam etam attham bhadante katham nu ucchu paribhogam labheyyanti
translated: I ask you this, sir: how can I get to enjoy the milk?”

original: “Pure tuvaṃ kammamakāsi attanā, manussabhūto purimāya jātiyā;
analyzed: pure tuvam kammam akāsi attanā manussa bhūtaḥ purimāya jātiyā
translated: “In the past you did a deed yourself, as a human being in a former life.

original: Ahañca taṃ etamatthaṃ vadāmi, sutvāna tvaṃ etamatthaṃ vijāna.
analyzed: ahañca tam etam attham vadāmi sutvāna tvam etam attham vijāna
translated: And I tell you this: having heard this, understand it.

original: “Ucchuṃ tuvaṃ khādamāno payāto, puriso ca te piṭṭhito anvagacchi;
analyzed: ucchum tuvam khādamāno payātaḥ puriso ca te piṭṭhitaḥ anvagacchi
translated: “You were going along eating milk-rice, and a man was following behind you.

original: So ca taṃ paccāsanto kathesi, tassa tuvaṃ na kiñci ālapittha.
analyzed: saḥ ca tam paccāsanto kathesi tassa tuvam na kiñci ālapittha
translated: And he was asking you for it, but you said nothing to him.

original: “So ca taṃ abhaṇantaṃ ayāci, dehayya ucchunti ca taṃ avoca;
analyzed: saḥ ca tam a bhaṇantam ayāci dehayyaḥ ucchunti ca tam avoca
translated: “And he asked you, who were saying nothing, ‘Give me the milk-rice.’

original: Tassa tuvaṃ piṭṭhito ucchuṃ adāsi, tassetaṃ kammassa ayaṃ vipāko.
analyzed: tassa tuvam piṭṭhitaḥ ucchum adāsi tassa itam kammassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: You gave him the milk-rice from behind, and this is the result of that deed.

original: “Iṅgha tvaṃ gantvāna piṭṭhito gaṇheyyāsi, gahetvāna taṃ khādassu yāvadatthaṃ;
analyzed: tvam gantvāna piṭṭhitaḥ gaṇheyyāsi gahetvāna tam khādassu yāvadattham
translated: “Now go and take it from behind, and having taken it, eat as much as you like.

original: Teneva tvaṃ attamano bhavissasi, haṭṭho cudaggo ca pamodito cāti.
analyzed: tena iva tvam atta manaḥ bhavissasi haṭṭhaḥ cudaggo ca pamoditaḥ ca ati
translated: By that you will be satisfied, delighted, elated, and full of joy.”

original: “Gantvāna so piṭṭhito aggahesi, gahetvāna taṃ khādi yāvadatthaṃ;
analyzed: gantvāna saḥ piṭṭhitaḥ aggahesi gahetvāna tam khādi yāvadattham
translated: “He went and seized him from behind, and having seized him he ate him to his heart’s content.

original: Teneva so attamano ahosi, haṭṭho cudaggo ca pamodito cā”ti. –
analyzed: tena iva saḥ atta manaḥ ahosi haṭṭhaḥ cudaggo ca pamoditaḥ ca ati
translated: Thereby he became satisfied, glad, elated, and delighted.”

original: Vacanapaṭivacanagāthā petena therena ca vuttā.🔽737-8. Tattha kissāti kīdisassa, kammassāti adhippāyo. Haññāmīti vihaññāmi vighātaṃ
analyzed: vacana paṭivacana gāthā petena therena ca vuttā  tattha kissa ati kīdisassa kammassa ati adhippāyaḥ haññāmi iti vihaññāmi vighātam
translated: The verse of question and answer was spoken by the Elder Petan.

original: āpajjāmi. Vihaññāmīti vā vibādhiyāmi, visesato pīḷiyāmīti attho. Khajjāmīti khādiyāmi,
analyzed: āpajjāmi vihaññāmi iti vā vibādhiyāmi visesataḥ pīḷiyāmi iti attho khajjāmi iti khādiyāmi
translated: Herein, kissā means of what kind, kammassā means of what aim. Haññāmīti vihaññāmi vighātaṃ āpajjāmi. Vihaññāmīti vā vibādhiyāmi, visesato pīḷiyāmīti attho. Khajjāmīti khādiyāmi,

original: asipattasadisehi nisitehi khādantehi viya ucchupattehi kantiyāmīti attho. Vāyamāmīti
analyzed: asi patta sadisehi nisitehi khādantehi viya ucchu pattehi kantiyāmi iti attho vāyamāmi iti
translated: asipattasadisehi nisitehi khādantehi viya ucchupattehi kantiyāmīti attho. Vāyamāmīti

original: ucchuṃ khādituṃ vāyāmaṃ karomi. Parisakkāmīti payogaṃ karomi. Paribhuñjitunti ucchurasaṃ
analyzed: ucchum khāditum vā āyāmam karomi parisakkāmi iti payogam karomi paribhuñjitum ti ucchu rasam
translated: ucchuṃ khādituṃ vāyāmaṃ karomi. Parisakkāmīti payogaṃ karomi. Paribhuñjitunti ucchurasaṃ

analyzed: paribhuñjitum ucchum khāditunti attho chinna thāmo ti chinna sahaḥ upacchinna thāmo
translated: paribhuñjituṃ, ucchuṃ khāditunti attho. Chinnathāmoti chinnasaho upacchinnathāmo,

original: parikkhīṇabaloti attho. Kapaṇoti dīno. Lālapāmīti dukkhena aṭṭito ativiya vilapāmi.
analyzed: parikkhīṇa balo ti attho kapaṇaḥ ti dīnaḥ lālapāmi iti dukkhena aṭṭitaḥ ativiya vilapāmi
translated: parikkhīṇabaloti attho. Kapaṇoti dīno. Lālapāmīti dukkhena aṭṭito ativiya vilapāmi.

original: 739. Vighātoti vighātavā, vihatabalo vā. Paripatāmi chamāyanti ṭhātuṃ asakkonto bhūmiyaṃ🔽papatāmi. Parivattāmīti paribbhamāmi. Vāricarovāti maccho viya. Ghammeti ghammasantatte thale.🔽740-4. Santassitoti oṭṭhakaṇṭhatālūnaṃ sosappattiyā suṭṭhu tasito. Sātasukhanti sātabhūtaṃ🔽sukhaṃ. Na vindeti na labhāmi. Tanti tuvaṃ. Vijānāti vijānāhi. Payātoti gantuṃ āraddho.🔽Anvagacchīti anubandhi. Paccāsantoti paccāsīsamāno. Tassetaṃ kammassāti ettha etanti
analyzed: vighātoti vighātavā vihata balaḥ vā paripatāmi chamāyanti ṭhātum a sakkontaḥ bhūmiyam  papatāmi parivattāmi iti paribbhamāmi vāricaraḥ uvāti macchaḥ viya ghammā iti ghamma santatte thale  santassito ti oṭṭha kaṇṭha tālūnam sosa ppattiyā suṭṭhu tasitaḥ sāta sukhanti sāta bhūtam  sukham na vinda iti na labhāmi tanti tuvam vijānāti vijānāhi gantum āraddhaḥ  anvagacchi iti anubandhi paccāsanto ti paccāsīsamāno tassa etam kammassa ati ettha etat ti
translated: ‘Distressed’ means distressed or with strength destroyed. ‘I fall down’ means I am unable to stand on the ground and so I fall down. ‘I roll’ means I roll about. ‘I am like a fish out of water’ means like a fish on dry land. ‘I am exhausted’ means I am exhausted by the heat on dry land.🔽‘I am scorched’ means I am scorched by the heat of the sun. ‘I am burnt up’ means I am burnt up by the heat of the sun. ‘I am not refreshed’ means I do not get refreshed. ‘I do not find’ means I do not find. ‘You know’ means you know. ‘I am leaving’ means I am starting to go.🔽‘I followed’ means I followed. ‘I will go back’ means I will go back. ‘This is the result of that action’ means here the word ‘that’

original: Saddetiādīsupi eseva nayo.

original: 754. Evaṃ sādhāraṇato vuttamatthaṃ asādhāraṇato niyametvā dassento “naccaṃ gīta”ntiādimāha. Tattha ratinti kāmaratiṃ. Khiḍḍanti sahāyakādīhi keḷiṃ. Giribbajanti rājagahaṃ.🔽755. Isinti asekkhānaṃ sīlakkhandhādīnaṃ esanaṭṭhena isiṃ. Sunettanti evaṃnāmakaṃ🔽paccekabuddhaṃ. Attadantanti uttamena damathena damitacittaṃ. Samāhitanti arahattaphalasamādhinā🔽samāhitaṃ. Uñche pattagate ratanti uñchena bhikkhācārena laddhe pattagate pattapariyāpanne
analyzed: evam sādhāraṇataḥ vuttam attham asādhāraṇataḥ niyametvā dassentaḥ naccam gītam ti ādim āha tattha rati nti kāma ratim khiḍḍanti sahāyaka ādīhi keḷim giribbajanti rājagaham  isim ti asekkhānam sīlakkhandha ādīnam esana ṭṭhena isim su nettam ti evaṃnāmakam  paccekabuddham uttamena damathena damita cittam samāhitanti arahatta phala samādhinā  samāhitam uñche patta gate ratanti uñchena bhikkhācārena laddhe patta gate patta pariyāpanne
translated: Having thus shown the meaning stated in general, he shows it in particular by the words “dancing, singing,” etc. Herein, rati means sensual delight. Khiḍḍā means play with friends, etc. Giribbaja means Rājagaha.

original: āhāre rataṃ santuṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: āhāre ratam santuṭṭham
translated: Isīti means a seer in the sense of seeking the aggregates of virtue, etc., of the adepts. Sunettam means the paccekabuddha of that name. Attadantanti means one whose mind is tamed by the highest taming. Samāhitanti means concentrated by the concentration of the fruit of arahantship. Uñche pattagate ratanti means delighting in, being satisfied with, the food obtained by the alms round, which is included in the bowl, which is contained in the bowl.

original: 756. Laddhā, bhanteti cābravīti “api, bhante, bhikkhā laddhā”ti vissāsajananatthaṃ kathesi. Uccaṃ paggayhāti uccataraṃ katvā pattaṃ ukkhipitvā.
analyzed: laddhā bhante iti ca ābravīti api bhante bhikkhā laddhā iti vissāsa janana attham kathesi uccam paggayha ati uccataram katvā pattam ukkhipitvā
translated: ‘“I have received almsfood, venerable sir,” he said, meaning to inspire confidence. ‘“He raised his bowl high up” means he raised his bowl higher than his head.

original: 757. Thaṇḍile pattaṃ bhinditvāti kharakaṭhine bhūmippadese khipanto pattaṃ bhinditvā.🔽Apakkamīti thokaṃ apasakki. Apasakkanto ca “akāraṇeneva andhabālo mahantaṃ anatthaṃ🔽attano akāsī”ti karuṇāyanavasena olokentaṃ paccekabuddhaṃ rājaputto āha “rañño kitavassāhaṃ
analyzed: thaṇḍile pattam bhinditvā ati khara kaṭhine bhūmi ppadese khipantaḥ pattam bhinditvā  apakkamīti thokam apasakki apasakkantaḥ ca akāraṇena iva andha bālaḥ mahantam anattham  attanaḥ akāsi iti karuṇāyana vasena olokentam paccekabuddham rāja putto āha rañño kitavassa aham
translated: ‘“He broke his bowl on a hard surface” means he broke his bowl by throwing it on a hard, stony surface.

original: putto, kiṃ maṃ bhikkhu karissasī”ti.
analyzed: putto kim mama bhikkhu karissasi iti
translated: ‘“He went away” means he went a little way. And as he was going away, looking back at the Paccekabuddha with compassion, thinking “For no reason at all this blind fool has brought about his own great misfortune,” the prince said, “I am the king’s son, monk, what can you do to me?”

original: 758. Pharusassāti dāruṇassa. Kaṭukoti aniṭṭho. Yanti yaṃ vipākaṃ. Samappitoti allīno.
analyzed: pharusassa ati dāruṇassa kaṭukaḥ ti aniṭṭhaḥ yanti yam vipākam samappito ti allīnaḥ
translated: ‘“Harsh” means cruel. “Bitter” means unpleasant. “You will reap” means you will experience. “You are bound” means you are caught.

original: 759. Chaḷeva caturāsīti, vassāni nahutāni cāti uttāno nipanno caturāsītivassasahassāni,

translated: ‘“Six times eighty-four thousand years” means lying on his back for eighty-four thousand years,

original: nikujjo, vāmapassena, dakkhiṇapassena, uddhaṃpādo, olambiko, yathāṭhito cāti evaṃ
analyzed: nikujjaḥ vāma passena dakkhiṇa passena uddhaṃpādaḥ olambikaḥ yathā ṭhitaḥ ca ati evam
translated: on his chest, on his left side, on his right side, on his head, hanging upside down, and standing.

original: cha caturāsītisahassāni vassāni honti. Tenāha –
analyzed: cha caturāsīti sahassāni vassāni honti tena āha

translated: But since those years were many myriads, it is said ‘many myriads’. ‘He has gone to great suffering’: he has met with very great suffering.

Then the venerable Maha Moggallana, seeing this, asked the ghost,

original: 772. Tattha tassevāti tasseva mayhaṃ pubbe kulūpakabhikkhubhūtassa petassa. Pāpakammassāti
analyzed: tattha tassa iva ati tassa iva mayham pubbe kulūpaka bhikkhu bhūtassa petassa pāpa kammassa ati
translated: Herein, his: of that evil-doer who was my benefactor in the past, being a bhikkhu.

original: pāpasamācārassa. Sīse tiṭṭhāmi matthaketi sīse tiṭṭhāmi, tiṭṭhanto ca matthake eva
analyzed: pāpa samācārassa sīse tiṭṭhāmi matthake iti sīse tiṭṭhāmi tiṭṭhantaḥ ca matthake eva
translated: On the head of him: I stand on his head. Standing, I stand on his head.

original: tiṭṭhāmi, na sīsappamāṇe ākāseti attho. Paravisayaṃ pattoti manussalokaṃ upādāya
analyzed: tiṭṭhāmi na sīsa ppamāṇe ākāse ti attho para visayam patto ti manussa lokam upādāya
translated: I stand, not in the space the height of a man, but in the space the height of a man and a half.’🔽He has reached the realm of others: he has reached the realm of ghosts, which is the realm of others compared to the human realm.

original: paravisayabhūtaṃ pettivisayaṃ patto. Mamevāti mayhaṃ eva paricārako ahosīti vacanaseso.
analyzed: para visaya bhūtam petti visayam pattaḥ mama eva ati mayham eva paricārakaḥ ahosi iti vacana sesaḥ
translated: He was my attendant: the meaning is, ‘he was my attendant alone.’

original: 773. Yaṃ bhadante hadantaññeti bhadante, ayya mahāmoggalāna, tassaṃ vaccakuṭiyaṃ
analyzed: yam bhadante hadantaññā iti bhadante ayya mahāmoggalāna tassam vaccakuṭiyam
translated: Whatever, revered sir, is eaten by the ghosts: revered sir, venerable Mahā Moggallāna, whatever is eaten by the ghosts in that privy-hole,🔽that is my food day after day.

original: yaṃ aññe uhadanti vaccaṃ ossajanti. Etaṃ me hoti bhojananti etaṃ vaccaṃ mayhaṃ divase🔽divase bhojanaṃ hoti. Yaṃ hadāmīti taṃ pana vaccaṃ khāditvā yampahaṃ vaccaṃ karomi.
analyzed: yam aññe uhadanti vaccam ossajanti etam me hoti etam vaccam mayham divase  divase bhojanam hoti yam hadāmi iti tam pana vaccam khāditvā yampaham vaccam karomi
translated: Whatever I eat: but whatever I eat, that is my excrement.

original: Etaṃ so upajīvatīti etaṃ mama vaccaṃ so kulūpakapeto divase divase khādanavasena
analyzed: etam saḥ upajīvati iti etam mama saḥ kulūpaka petaḥ divase divase khādana vasena
translated: He lives on that: that excrement of mine, that ghost who is my supporter, lives on it day after day as his food.

original: upajīvati, attabhāvaṃ yāpetīti attho.
analyzed: upajīvati atta bhāvam yāpeti iti
translated: He maintains his existence on it, is the meaning.

original: Tesu kuṭumbiko pesale bhikkhū “evaṃ āhāraparibhogato varaṃ tumhākaṃ gūthakhādana”nti
analyzed: tesu kuṭumbikaḥ pesale bhikkhū evam āhāra paribhogataḥ varam tumhākam gūtha khādanan ti
translated: Among them, the householder said to the good monks, ‘Better for you to eat excrement than to use requisites given by me.’

original: akkosi. Kulūpako pana kuṭumbikampi tathāvacane samādapetvā sayaṃ tathā akkosi, tenassa
analyzed: akkosi kulūpakaḥ pana kuṭumbikam pi tathāvacane samādapetvā sayam tathā akkosi tena assa
translated: The man who lived by begging from families, however, would persuade even a householder to speak in that way, and then he himself would speak in that way.

original: tatopi paṭikuṭṭhatarā jīvikā ahosi. Āyasmā mahāmoggallāno taṃ pavattiṃ bhagavato
analyzed: tatas api paṭikuṭṭhatarā jīvikā ahosi āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tam pavattim bhagavataḥ
translated: Consequently, his livelihood was even more despised than that of the man who lived by the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice. The venerable Maha Moggallana reported this matter to the Exalted One.

original: ārocesi. Bhagavā tamatthaṃ aṭṭhuppattiṃ katvā upavāde ādīnavaṃ dassetvā sampattaparisāya
analyzed: ārocesi bhagavā tam attham aṭṭhuppattim katvā upavāde ādīnavam dassetvā sampatta parisāya
translated: The Exalted One, making this matter the occasion for a discourse, pointed out the danger in reviling, and preached the Law.

original: dhammaṃ desesi. Sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosīti.
analyzed: dhammam desesi sā desanā mahājanassa sātthikā ahosi iti
translated: This preaching of the Law was of great profit to the multitude.

original: Gūthakhādakapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gūtha khādaka peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Ghost who lived on Filth is finished.

original: 9. Gūthakhādakapetivatthuvaṇṇanā🔽774-81. Gūthakūpato uggantvāti idaṃ satthari jetavane viharante aññataraṃ gūthakhādakapetiṃ🔽ārabbha vuttaṃ. Tassā vatthu anantaravatthusadisaṃ. Tattha upāsakena vihāro kāritoti
analyzed: gūtha khādaka peti vatthu vaṇṇanā  gūtha kūpataḥ uggantvā iti idam satthari jetavane viharante aññataram gūtha khādaka petim  ārabbha vuttam tassāḥ vatthu anantara vatthu sadisam tattha upāsakena vihāro kārito ti
translated: The Story of the Ghost who lived in a Filth-Heap🔽Having emerged from the filth-heap: this story was told by the Teacher while living at Jetavana about a certain ghost who lived on filth.🔽The story of this ghost is similar to the story of the preceding ghost. There it was said that a lay disciple had a monastery built;

original: upāsakassa vasena āgataṃ, idha pana upāsikāyāti ayameva viseso. Sesaṃ vatthusmiṃ
analyzed: upāsakassa vasena āgatam idha pana upāsikāya ati ayam eva visesaḥ sesam vatthusmiṃ
translated: here it is said that a laywoman had a monastery built. This is the only difference. In the story

original: gāthāsu ca apubbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: gāthāsu ca apubbam na atthi
translated: and in the stanzas there is nothing else new.

original: Gūthakhādakapetivatthuvaṇṇānā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gūthakhādakapetivatthu vaṇṇānā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Father who ate Excrement is finished.

original: 10. Gaṇapetavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Ghost in a Crowd

original: Naggā dubbaṇṇarūpātthāti idaṃ satthari jetavane viharante sambahule pete ārabbha
analyzed: naggāḥ dubbaṇṇa rūpāḥ attha idam satthari jetavane viharante sambahule pete ārabbha
translated: Nagga, of bad appearance, of bad colour, of bad form: this was said by the Teacher while living at Jetavana, about a number of ghosts.

original: vuttaṃ. Sāvatthiyaṃ kira sambahulā manussā gaṇabhūtā assaddhā appasannā maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitacittā
analyzed: vuttam sāvatthiyam kira sambahulāḥ manussāḥ gaṇa bhūtāḥ assaddhāḥ appasannāḥ macchera mala pariyuṭṭhita cittāḥ
translated: In Savatthi, it seems, a number of people, having become a crowd, were without faith, without confidence, their minds full of the stain of avarice,

original: dānādisucaritavimukhā hutvā ciraṃ jīvitvā kāyassa bhedā nagarassa samīpe petayoniyaṃ
analyzed: dāna ādi su carita vimukhāḥ hutvā ciram jīvitvā kāyassa bhedā nagarassa samīpe petayoniyam
translated: and they turned their backs on good conduct such as giving. After living a long time, at the break-up of the body they were reborn in the ghost realm

original: nibbattiṃsu. Athekadivasaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya gacchanto antarāmagge pete disvā –
analyzed: nibbattiṃsu atha eka divasam āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya gacchantaḥ antarāmagge pete disvā
translated: near the city. Then one day, the venerable Maha Moggallana, while going to Savatthi for alms, saw the ghosts on the way and asked them:

original: “Naggā dubbaṇarūpāttha, kisā dhamanisanthatā;
analyzed: naggā kisā
translated: “Nagga, of bad appearance, of bad colour, of bad form,

analyzed: upphāsulikā kisikā ke nu tumhā ittha mārisa

original: Gāthāya pucchi. Tattha dubbaṇṇarūpātthāti dubbaṇṇasarīrā hotha. Ke nu tumhetthāti tumhe ke nu nāma bhavatha. Mārisāti te attano sāruppavasena ālapati.
analyzed: gāthāya pucchi tattha dubbaṇṇa rūpā attha ati dubbaṇṇa sarīrāḥ hotha ke nu tumhe itthā ati tumhe ke nu nāma bhavatha mārisa ati te attano sāruppa vasena ālapati
translated: He asked with this verse. Herein, of bad appearance means be of bad-coloured bodies. Who are you means what are you called? Sirs is an address in conformity with their state.

original: Taṃ sutvā petā –
analyzed: tam sutvā petā
translated: Having heard that, the ghosts said this:

original: “Mayaṃ bhadante petamhā, duggatā yamalokikā;
analyzed: mayam bhadante duggatā yama lokikā
translated: “We are wretched, reverend Sir, we have gone to the realm of suffering,

analyzed: pāpa kammam karitvāna peta lokam itas gatā ati

analyzed: gāthāya peta bhāvam pakāsetvā puna therena
translated: Having shown the Elder her own state of being a ghost with this verse, she asked the Elder again with this verse:

analyzed: kim nu kāyena vācāya manasā dukkaṭam katam
translated: “What bad deed was done by body, speech, or mind?

original: Kissakammavipākena, petalokaṃ ito gatā”ti. –
analyzed: kissa kamma vipākena peta lokam itas gatā ati
translated: By the result of what deed have we gone from here to the realm of suffering?”

original: Gāthāya katakammaṃ pucchitā –
analyzed: gāthāya kata kammam pucchitā
translated: Having been asked about the deed she had done with this verse, she said this:

original: “Anāvaṭesu titthesu, vicinimhaddhamāsakaṃ;
analyzed: an āvaṭesu titthesu
translated: “At the fords where there was no bridge, we searched for half a penny;

original: Santesu deyyadhammesu, dīpaṃ nākamha attano.
analyzed: santesu deyya dhammesu dīpam na akamha attanaḥ
translated: While there were things to be given, we did not light a lamp for ourselves.

original: “Nadiṃ upema tasitā, rittakā parivattati;
analyzed: nadim upema tasitā rittakā parivattati
translated: “We went to the river, exhausted, but it was turned back, empty;

translated: “The wind, burning, blew, as if it were the colour of fire;

original: Etañca bhante arahāma, aññañca pāpakaṃ tato.
analyzed: etat ca bhante arahāma aññañca pāpakam tato
translated: This, reverend Sir, we deserve, and something worse than that.

original: “Api yojanāni gacchāma, chātā āhāragedhino;
analyzed: api yojanāni gacchāma chātāḥ āhāra gedhinaḥ

analyzed: a laddha ava nivattāma aho naḥ appapuñña tā
translated: Not having obtained (what we wanted), we turned back, alas! our merit is small.

original: “Chātā pamucchitā bhantā, bhūmiyaṃ paṭisumbhitā;
analyzed: chātā pamucchitā bhantā bhūmiyam paṭisumbhitā
translated: “We are exhausted, reverend Sir, we are thirsty, we are fallen on the ground;

original: Uttānā paṭikirāma, avakujjā patāmase.
analyzed: uttānā paṭikirāma avakujjā patāmase
translated: We lie on our backs, we are turned over, we are fallen on our faces.

original: “Te ca tattheva patitā, bhūmiyaṃ paṭisumbhitā;
analyzed: te ca tattha iva patitāḥ bhūmiyam paṭisumbhitā
translated: And lay upon the ground,🔽And beat our breasts and heads,

original: Uraṃ sīsañca ghaṭṭema, aho no appapuññatā.
analyzed: uram sīsam ca ghaṭṭema aho naḥ appa puñña tā
translated: Alas, our lack of merit!🔽“And this, Lord, we deserve,

original: “Etañca bhante arahāma, aññañca pāpakaṃ tato;
analyzed: etat ca bhante arahāma aññañca pāpakam tato
translated: And worse as well, for we🔽Had things to give to those in need,

original: Santesu deyyadhammesu, dīpaṃ nākamha attano.
analyzed: santesu deyya dhammesu dīpam na akamha attanaḥ
translated: But gave not, for our own reward.🔽“But now, if we can only get

original: “Te hi nūna ito gantvā, yoniṃ laddhāna mānusiṃ;
analyzed: te hi nūnar itas gantvā yonim mānusim
translated: A human birth again,🔽We’ll be generous, virtuous,

analyzed: vadaññū sīla sampannā kāhāma kusalam bahunti
translated: And make much merit then.”

original: Attanā katakammaṃ kathesuṃ.
analyzed: attanā kata kammam kathesuṃ
translated: They told of the deeds they had done.🔽Here is the commentary on the words.🔽They went many leagues, even many hundreds of leagues, is what is meant.

original: 788. Tattha api yojanāni gacchāmāti anekānipi yojanāni gacchāma. Kathaṃ? Chātā āhāragedhinoti,

translated: How? They went on, famished, greedy for food,

analyzed: cira kālam jighacchāya jighacchitāḥ āhāre giddhāḥ abhigijjhantāḥ hutvā evam gantvā api

analyzed: kiñci āhāram a laddhāya iva nivattāma appa puñña tā ati apuñña tā a kata kalyāṇa tā
translated: Lack of merit: lack of merit, non-performance of good deeds.🔽They lay there, stretched out,

analyzed: te ca ati te mayam uram sīsam ca ghaṭṭema ati avakujjā hutvā patitāḥ uṭṭhātum asakkontā vedhantā vedanā appattāḥ attanaḥ attanaḥ uram sīsam ca paṭighaṃsāma sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva

analyzed: theraḥ tam pavattim bhagavataḥ ārocesi bhagavā tam attham aṭṭhuppattim katvā sampatta parisāya dhammaṃ desesi tam sutvā mahā janaḥ macchera malam pahāya dāna ādi su carita nirataḥ ahosi iti
translated: The Elder told this matter to the Exalted One. The Exalted One, making this matter the occasion for a discourse, preached the Law to the assembled company. original: Gaṇapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gaṇa peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

analyzed: deva lokam an upapajjitvā itthiyā paṭibaddha citta tāya samudda majjhe vimāna petaḥ hutvā  nibbatti pana saḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ sā itthī suvaṇṇa bhūmi gāminim nāvam abhiruyha

analyzed: amanussiddhiyā yāvatatiyam tassāḥ eva itthiyā pāpuṇi so paṭibaddha citto taṃ  disvā vāṇijāḥ veḷu kalāpam samudde otāretvā tassa upari tam itthim otāresuṃ itthiyā
translated: By the power of the ghost, it fell three times on that very woman, to whom he was attached. They🔽saw her, and after throwing a bundle of reeds into the ocean, they threw that woman on top of it. As soon as the woman

analyzed: otārita mattāya nāvā vegena suvaṇṇa bhūmim abhimukhā pāyāsi amanussaḥ tam itthim attanaḥ

translated: own divine palace, enjoyed himself with her.

analyzed: sā ekam saṃvaccharam atikkamitvā nibbinna rūpā tam petam yācantī āha aham idha  vasantī samparāyikam attham kātum na labhāmi sādhu mārisa mam pāṭaliputtam eva

analyzed: nehi iti saḥ tāya yācitaḥ
