original: “Diṭṭhā tayā nirayā tiracchānayoni, petā asurā athavāpi mānusā devā;
analyzed: diṭṭhā tayā asurāḥ athavā api mānusāḥ devā
translated: “You have seen the hells, the animal kingdom, the ghosts, the titans, and the human and heavenly worlds.

original: Sayamaddasa kammavipākamattano, nessāmi taṃ pāṭaliputtamakkhataṃ;
analyzed: sayam addasa kamma vipākam attanaḥ nessāmi tam pāṭaliputtam akkhatam
translated: You have seen the ripening of your own deeds. I will take you to Pāṭaliputta.🔽Go there and do good deeds.”

original: Tattha gantvā kusalaṃ karohi kamma”nti. –🔽Gāthamāha. Tattha diṭṭhā tayā nirayāti ekacce paccekanirayāpi tayā diṭṭhā. Tiracchānayonīti🔽mahānubhāvā nāgasupaṇṇāditiracchānāpi diṭṭhā tayāti yojanā. Petāti khuppipāsādibhedā
analyzed: tattha gantvā kusalam karohi kammanti  gātham āha tattha diṭṭhā tayā nirayā ati ekacce pacceka nirayā api tayā diṭṭhā tiracchānayonī iti  mahā anubhāvā diṭṭhā tayā iti yojanā petā iti khuppipāsā ādi bhedā
translated: He spoke this verse:🔽“You have seen the hells. You have seen the animal kingdom, the ghosts, the titans, and the human and heavenly worlds. You have seen the ripening of your own deeds. I will take you to Pāṭaliputta. Go there and do good deeds.”

original: petā. Asurāti kālakañcikādibhedā asurā. Devāti ekacce cātumahārājikā devā. So kira
analyzed: kālakañcika ādi bhedāḥ asurāḥ devāḥ ati ekacce cātumahārājikāḥ devā so kira
translated: Here, “You have seen the hells” means that you have seen some of the individual hells. “You have seen the animal kingdom” means that you have seen some of the powerful nāgas and supaṇṇas. “You have seen the ghosts” means that you have seen some of the ghosts who are tormented by hunger and thirst. “You have seen the titans” means that you have seen some of the titans who are tormented by the quarrels of Kālakañcikā. “You have seen the human and heavenly worlds” means that you have seen some of the gods of the four great kings.

original: attano ānubhāvena antarantarā taṃ gahetvā paccekanirayādike dassento vicarati, tena🔽evamāha. Sayamaddasa kammavipākamattanoti nirayādike visesato gantvā passantī sayameva
analyzed: ānubhāvena antar antarā tam gahetvā pacceka niraya ādike dassentaḥ vicarati tena  evam āha sayam addasa kamma vipākam attano ti niraya ādike visesataḥ gantvā passantī sayam eva
translated: and he himself, by his own power, sometimes taking her, sometimes not, wandered about showing her the individual hells, etc.🔽Therefore he said: “I myself saw the ripening of my own deeds.”

original: attanā katakammānaṃ vipākaṃ paccakkhato addasa adakkhi. Nessāmi taṃ pāṭaliputtamakkhatanti
analyzed: attanā kata kammānam vipākam paccakkhataḥ addasa adakkhi nessāmi tam pāṭaliputtam akkhatanti
translated: Having gone to the hells, etc., in particular, she herself saw, she herself looked at, the ripening of her own deeds.🔽I will lead you to Pāṭaliputta, unhurt.

original: idānāhaṃ taṃ akkhataṃ kenaci aparikkhataṃ manussarūpeneva pāṭaliputtaṃ nayissāmi.
analyzed: idānā aham tam akkhatam kenacid a parikkhatam manussa rūpena iva pāṭaliputtam nayissāmi
translated: Now I will lead you there, unhurt, not injured by anyone, in human form.

original: Tvaṃ pana tattha gantvā kusalaṃ karohi kammaṃ, kammavipākassa paccakkhato diṭṭhattā
analyzed: tvam pana tattha gantvā kusalam karohi kammam kamma vipākassa paccakkhataḥ diṭṭha ttā
translated: But you, having gone there, do good deeds, for you have seen the ripening of deeds with your own eyes.

original: yuttapayuttā puññaniratā hohīti attho.
analyzed: yutta payuttā puñña niratā hohi iti attho
translated: Therefore you should be diligent and devoted to meritorious deeds. This is the meaning.

original: Atha sā itthī tassa vacanaṃ sutvā attamanā –
analyzed: atha sā itthī tassa vacanam sutvā attamanā
translated: Then that woman, having heard his words, was pleased and said:

original: “Atthakāmosi me yakkha, hitakāmosi devate;
analyzed: attha kāmo asi me yakkha hita kāmo asi devate
translated: “You are a benefactor to me, Yakkha, you are a deity who wishes me well;

original: Karomi tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ, tvaṃsi ācariyo mama.
analyzed: karomi vacanam mama
translated: I will do your bidding, for you are my teacher.

original: “Diṭṭhā mayā nirayā tiracchānayoni, petā asurā athavāpi mānusā devā;
analyzed: diṭṭhāḥ mayā asurāḥ athavā api mānusāḥ devā
translated: “I have seen the hells, the animal realm, the ghosts, the asuras, and also humans and gods;

original: Sayamaddasaṃ kammavipākamattano, kāhāmi puññāni anappakānī”ti. –
analyzed: sayam addasam kamma vipākam attano puññāni anappakāni iti
translated: I see the fruit of my own deeds. What good works shall I do, not a few?”

original: Gāthamāha.
analyzed: gātham āha
translated: And he spoke this verse:

original: Atha so peto taṃ itthiṃ gahetvā ākāsena gantvā pāṭaliputtanagarassa majjhe ṭhapetvā
analyzed: atha saḥ peto tam itthim gahetvā ākāsena gantvā pāṭaliputta nagarassa majjhe ṭhapetvā
translated: Then the ghost, taking the woman, went through the air and set her down in the middle of the city of Pāṭaliputta.

original: pakkāmi. Athassā ñātimittādayo taṃ disvā “mayaṃ pubbe samudde pakkhittā matāti assumha.
analyzed: pakkāmi athassāḥ ñāti mitta ādayaḥ tam disvā mayam pubbe samudde pakkhittāḥ matā ati assumha
translated: And her relatives and friends, seeing her, were delighted, saying, “We thought that she had been drowned in the sea and had died.

analyzed: sā ayam diṭṭhā vata bho sotthinā āgatā ati abhinandamānā samāgantvā tassā pavattim

analyzed: kho te vāṇijāḥ anukkamena sāvatthim upagata kāle satthu santikam upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā
translated: after they had gradually reached Sāvatthi, went to the Teacher, saluted him,

analyzed: ekamantam nisinnā tam pavattim bhagavataḥ ārocesum bhagavā tam attham aṭṭhuppattim
translated: and sat down respectfully on one side. Then they told the Teacher all that had happened. The Teacher made that the occasion for setting forth the Law in the following manner:

original: Pāṭaliputtapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

His wife died,

The householder placed this daughter in the house of a friend, and with a hundred pieces of money borrowed on interest,🔽took merchandise and set out on a trading expedition with a caravan. analyzed: dhana lobhena tattha iva petaḥ hutvā nibbatti  vāṇijā sāvatthim gantvā tassa dhītuyā tam pavattim ārocesuṃ sā pitu maraṇena ājīvikā bhayena

analyzed: pitunaḥ gehe viyaḥ imasmin gehe avimanāḥ abhiramassu iti vatvā samassāsesi sā tassa

original: 15. Seṭṭhiputtapetavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽Saṭṭhivassasahassānīti idaṃ seṭṭhiputtapetavatthu. Tassa kā uppatti? Bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭhi putta peta vatthu vaṇṇanā  saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni iti idam seṭṭhi putta peta vatthu tassa kā uppatti bhagavā sāvatthiyam
translated: The story of the merchant’s son who was a ghost🔽“For sixty-thousand years”: this is the story of the merchant’s son who was a ghost.🔽How did it arise? The Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove.

original: viharati jetavane. Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo alaṅkatappaṭiyatto
analyzed: viharati jetavane tena khalu pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalaḥ alaṅkata paṭiyattaḥ
translated: On that occasion King Pasenadi of Kosala,🔽having adorned himself,

analyzed: hatthi kkhandha vara gataḥ mahatiyā rājiddhiyā mahantena rāja anubhāvena nagaram anusañcarantaḥ  aññatarasmim gehe upari pāsāde vātapānam vivaritvā tam rājavibhūtim olokentim rūpa sampattiyā
translated: mounted his elephant, and went around the city with great royal pomp and splendor.🔽He saw a woman in a certain house,🔽who was looking out at the royal pomp from an upper window. She was the equal of a divine beauty.🔽When he saw her, he was suddenly overcome by lust,

original: devaccharāpaṭibhāgaṃ ekaṃ itthiṃ disvā adiṭṭhapubbe ārammaṇe sahasā samuppannena
analyzed: deva charā paṭibhāgam ekam itthim disvā a diṭṭha pubbe ārammaṇe sahasā samuppannena
translated: which had arisen in regard to an object he had never seen before.

original: kilesasamudācārena pariyuṭṭhitacitto satipi kularūpācārādiguṇavisesasampanne antepurajane
analyzed: kilesa samudācārena pariyuṭṭhita cittaḥ sati pi kula rūpa ācāra ādi guṇa visesa sampanne antepura jane
translated: Even though the women in his harem were endowed with the special qualities of family, beauty, conduct, and so on,🔽his mind, which was easily satisfied,

analyzed: sabhāva lahukassa pana duddamassa cittassa vasena tassam itthiyam paṭibaddha mānasaḥ

original: hutvā pacchāsane nisinnassa purisassa “imaṃ pāsādaṃ imañca itthiṃ upadhārehī”ti saññaṃ
analyzed: hutvā pacchā āsane nisinnassa purisassa imam pāsādam imañca itthim upadhārehi iti saññam
translated: and after he had done so, he gave the man sitting behind him the sign, “Think of this palace and this woman.”

original: datvā rājagehaṃ paviṭṭho. Aññaṃ sabbaṃ ambasakkarapetavatthumhi āgatanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: da tvā rāja geham paviṭṭhaḥ aññam sabbam amba sakkara peta vatthumhi āgata nayena iva veditabbam
translated: and then he entered the royal palace. All the rest of the story is to be understood in the way already given in the story of the Ghost of the Mango Tree.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – idha puriso sūriye anatthaṅgateyeva āgantvā nagaradvāre thakite
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ āgantvā nagara dvāre thakite
translated: But there is this difference. Here the man came while the sun was still shining. He knocked at the city gate,

original: attanā ānītaṃ aruṇavaṇṇamattikaṃ uppalāni ca nagaradvārakavāṭe laggetvā nipajjituṃ🔽jetavanaṃ agamāsi. Rājā pana sirisayane vāsūpagato majjhimayāme sa-iti na-iti du-iti
analyzed: attanā ānītam aruṇa vaṇṇa mattikam uppalāni ca nagara dvāra kavāṭe laggetvā nipajjitum  jetavanam agamāsi rājā pana sirisayane vāsūpagataḥ majjhima yāme sa eti na eti
translated: and after he had fastened to the city gate a piece of clay the colour of dawn and some blue lotuses which he had brought with him, he lay down.🔽and went to Jetavana to lie down. But the king, who had gone to bed on his royal couch, heard in the middle watch of the night a sound as if these four syllables, “sa-iti na-iti du-iti so-iti,”

original: so-iti ca imāni cattāri akkharāni mahatā kaṇṭhena uccāritāni viya vissaravasena assosi.
analyzed: ca imāni cattāri akkharāni mahatā kaṇṭhena uccāritāni viya vissara vasena assosi
translated: had been uttered with a loud voice.

original: Tāni kira atīte kāle sāvatthivāsīhi catūhi seṭṭhiputtehi bhogamadamattehi yobbanakāle
analyzed: tāni kira atīte kāle sāvatthi vāsīhi catūhi seṭṭhi puttehi bhoga mada mattehi yobbana kāle
translated: It seems that in the past, in the days when the four sons of the leading merchants of Sāvatthī were in the prime of youth,🔽they had committed much sin in the way of adultery,

original: pāradārikakammavasena bahuṃ apuññaṃ pasavetvā aparabhāge kālaṃ katvā tasseva nagarassa
analyzed: pāradārika kamma vasena bahum apuññam pasavetvā aparabhāge kālam katvā tassa iva nagarassa
translated: and after they had died, they were reborn in that very city

original: samīpe lohakumbhiyaṃ nibbattitvā paccamānehi lohakumbhiyā mukhavaṭṭiṃ patvā ekekaṃ🔽gāthaṃ vatthukāmehi uccāritānaṃ tāsaṃ gāthānaṃ ādiakkharāni, te paṭhamakkharameva
analyzed: samīpe loha kumbhiyam nibbattitvā paccamānehi loha kumbhiyāḥ mukha vaṭṭim patvā ekekam  gātham vatthu kāmehi uccāritānam tāsam gāthānam ādi akkharāni te paṭhama akkharam eva
translated: and they were reborn in a nearby iron cauldron and were being boiled. The first letters of the verses they had recited out of desire for sensual pleasures🔽struck the lid of the cauldron, and the letters, beginning with the first letter,

original: vatvā vedanāppattā hutvā lohakumbhiṃ otariṃsu.
analyzed: vatvā vedanā appattāḥ hutvā lohakumbhim otariṃsu
translated: fell into the cauldron, and they suffered pain.

original: Rājā pana taṃ saddaṃ sutvā bhītatasito saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto taṃ rattāvasesaṃ dukkhena
analyzed: rājā pana tam saddam sutvā bhīta tasitaḥ saṃviggaḥ loma haṭṭha jātaḥ tam ratta avasesam dukkhena
translated: The king, hearing this sound, was frightened and terrified, and his hair stood on end. He spent the rest of the night in misery,

original: vītināmetvā vibhātāya rattiyā purohitaṃ pakkosāpetvā taṃ pavattiṃ kathesi. Purohito
analyzed: vītināmetvā vibhātāya rattiyā purohitam pakkosāpetvā tam pavattim kathesi purohitaḥ
translated: and when the night had passed, he summoned his chief priest and told him what had happened. The priest,

original: rājānaṃ bhītatasitaṃ ñatvā lābhagiddho “uppanno kho ayaṃ mayhaṃ brāhmaṇānañca lābhuppādanupāyo”ti
analyzed: rājānam bhīta tasitam ñatvā lābha giddhaḥ uppannaḥ kho ayam mayham brāhmaṇānam ca lābha uppāda nupāyaḥ ti
translated: knowing that the king was frightened and terrified, and greedy for gain, thought, “This is an opportunity for me and the brahmins to get gain.”

original: cintetvā “mahārāja, mahā vatāyaṃ upaddavo uppanno, sabbacatukkaṃ yaññaṃ yajāhī”ti
analyzed: cintetvā mahā rāja mahā vata ayam upaddavaḥ uppanno sabba catukkam yaññam yajāhi iti
translated: He said, “Great king, this is a great calamity that has arisen. Perform a four-part sacrifice.”

original: āha. Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā amacce āṇāpesi “sabbacatukkayaññassa upakaraṇāni sajjethā”ti.
analyzed: āha rājā tassa vacanam sutvā amacce āṇāpesi sabba catukka yaññassa upakaraṇāni sajjetha ati
translated: The king, hearing his words, ordered his ministers, “Prepare the requisites for a four-part sacrifice.”

original: Taṃ sutvā mallikā devī rājānaṃ evamāha – “kasmā, mahārāja, brāhmaṇassa vacanaṃ sutvā
analyzed: tam sutvā mallikā devī rājānam evam āha kasmai mahā rāja brāhmaṇassa vacanam sutvā
translated: When Queen Mallikā heard this, she said to the king, “Why, sire, do you wish to do a deed of violence and bloodshed, because you have heard the words of a single brahman?

original: anekapāṇavadhahiṃsanakakiccaṃ kātukāmosi, nanu sabbattha appaṭihatañāṇacāro bhagavā
analyzed: aneka pāṇa vadha hiṃsanaka kiccam kātu kāmo asi nanu sabbattha a paṭihata ñāṇa cāraḥ bhagavā

analyzed: pucchitabbaḥ yathā ca te bhagavā byākarissati tathā paṭipajjitabbanti rājā tassā  vacanam sutvā satthu santikam gantvā tam pavattim bhagavataḥ ārocesi bhagavā na  mahā rāja tatonidānam tuyham koci antarāyo ti vatvā āditas paṭṭhāya tesam lohakumbhiniraye
translated: And as the Exalted One shall direct you, so shall you act.”🔽When the king heard her words, he went to the Teacher and told him the matter. The Teacher replied, “Sire, no harm will come to you on that account.”

original: nibbattasattānaṃ pavattiṃ kathetvā tehi paccekaṃ uccāretuṃ āraddhagāthāyo –
analyzed: nibbatta sattānam pavattim kathetvā tehi paccekam uccāretum āraddha gāthāyaḥ
translated: And beginning at the beginning, he related the story of the beings who had been reborn in the Hell of the Copper Cauldron, and he recited the verses which each of the beings had begun to recite.

original: “Saṭṭhivassasahassāni, paripuṇṇāni sabbaso;
analyzed: saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni paripuṇṇāni sabbaso
translated: “For sixty thousand years complete,🔽In hell they burn, and when, O when,

original: Niraye paccamānānaṃ, kadā anto bhavissati.
analyzed: niraye paccamānānam kadā antaḥ bhavissati
translated: Will their torment be at an end?🔽“No end, no end, there is no end,

original: “Natthi anto kuto anto, na anto paṭidissati;
analyzed: natthi antaḥ kutas antaḥ na anto paṭidissati
translated: No end is anywhere seen;

analyzed: tathā hi pakatam pāpam tuyham mayham ca mārisā
translated: So great is the sin you and I, good sir, have committed.

original: “Dujjīvitamajīvimha, ye sante na dadamhase;
analyzed: dujjīvitam ajīvimha ye sante na dadamhase
translated: “We have lived a life of difficulty, we who have not given to the good;

original: Santesu deyyadhammesu, dīpaṃ nākamha attano.
analyzed: santesu deyya dhammesu dīpam na akamha attanaḥ
translated: In the matter of gifts to the good, we have not made a light for ourselves.”

original: “Sohaṃ nūna ito gantvā, yoniṃ laddhāna mānusiṃ;
analyzed: sā uham nūnar itas gantvā yonim mā anusim
translated: “So now, having gone from here, having obtained a human state of existence,

original: Vadaññū sīlasampanno, kāhāmi kusalaṃ bahu”nti. –
analyzed: vadaññū sīla sampannaḥ kāhāmi kusalam bahunti
translated: Being generous and endowed with virtue, I will make much that is good.”

original: Paripuṇṇaṃ katvā kathesi.
analyzed: paripuṇṇam katvā kathesi
translated: and he spoke the verse, completing it.

original: 802. Tattha saṭṭhivassasahassānīti vassānaṃ saṭṭhisahassāni. Tasmiṃ kira lohakumbhiniraye
analyzed: tattha saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni iti vassānam saṭṭhi sahassāni tasmin kira lohakumbhi niraye
translated: Herein, for sixty-thousand years means for sixty-thousand years. In that Hell of the Iron Chest, it seems,

original: nibbattasatto adho ogacchanto tiṃsāya vassasahassehi heṭṭhimatalaṃ pāpuṇāti, tato
analyzed: nibbatta sattaḥ adhas ogacchantaḥ tiṃsāya vassa sahassehi heṭṭhima talam pāpuṇāti tatas
translated: the being who is reborn there reaches the lower surface in thirty-thousand years,

analyzed: uddham uggacchantaḥ api tiṃsāya eva vassa sahassehi mukhavaṭṭi padesam pāpuṇāti tāya

analyzed: saññāya saḥ saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni paripuṇṇāni sabbaso ti gātham vattu kāmo sa eti
translated: With that perception he wanted to speak the verse “For sixty-thousand years, they are completed in every way” and so he said “So”

analyzed: vatvā adhimatta vedanā appattaḥ hutvā adhomukhaḥ bhagavā pana tam rañño paripuṇṇam
translated: and then, having become one who has reached extreme pain, he fell with his face downwards. But the Blessed One completed it for the King as follows:

analyzed: katvā kathesi esa nayo sesa gāthāsu pi tattha kadā antaḥ bhavissati iti lohakumbhiniraye

original: paccamānānaṃ amhākaṃ kadā nu kho imassa dukkhassa anto pariyosānaṃ bhavissati.
analyzed: paccamānānam amhākam kadā nu kho imassa dukkhassa antaḥ pariyosānam bhavissati
translated: and he told it. So too with the rest of the verses. Herein, when will there be an end? —when will there be an end, a finish, of this suffering of ours as we are being roasted in the Hell of the Copper Cauldron?

original: 803. Tathā hīti yathā tuyhaṃ mayhañca imassa dukkhassa natthi anto, na anto paṭidissati,
analyzed: tathā hi iti yathā tuyham mayham ca imassa dukkhassa na atthi antaḥ na antaḥ paṭidissati
translated: . So too, in the same way that there is no end of this suffering for you and for me, and no end is seen,

original: tathā tena pakārena pāpakaṃ kammaṃ pakataṃ tayā mayā cāti vibhattiṃ vipariṇāmetvā vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā tena pakārena pāpakam kammam pakatam tayā mayā ca ati vibhattim vipariṇāmetvā vattabbam

analyzed: dujjīvitam ti viññūhi garahitabbam jīvitam ye santā iti ye mayam sante vijjamāne  deyya dhamme na dadamha sa iti na vuttam eva attham pākaṭataram kātum santesu
translated: . Hard to live: blameworthy living. We who are here: we who are here,

analyzed: deyya dhammesu dīpam na akamha attanaḥ ti vuttam
translated: present. If we do not give: if we do not give. The meaning is the same as that already given. The words “if we do not give” are repeated in order to make the meaning clearer. “If we do not give,🔽present, to those who ask,🔽we shall go hence to the Hell of the Copper Cauldron” .

original: 805. Sohanti so ahaṃ. Nūnāti parivitakke nipāto. Itoti imasmā lohakumbhinirayā. Gantvāti
analyzed: saḥ hanti saḥ aham nūna iti imasmai lohakumbhinirayāḥ gantvā iti
translated: . So: that I. Now: this is a particle expressing reflection. Hence: from this Hell of the Copper Cauldron. Having gone:

analyzed: apagantvā yonim mānusinti manussa yonim manussatta bhāvam labhitvā
translated: Having gone forth, having obtained a human birth.

original: pariccāgasīlo, yācakānaṃ vā vacanaññū. Sīlasampannoti sīlācārasampanno. Kāhāmi kusalaṃ
analyzed: pariccāga sīlaḥ yācakānam vā vacanaññū sīla sampannaḥ ti sīla ācāra sampannaḥ kāhāmi kusalam
translated: Generous: having the virtue of giving, or listening to the words of supplicants. Endowed with virtue: endowed with the virtue of conduct.🔽What good will I do?

original: bahunti pubbe viya pamādaṃ anāpajjitvā bahuṃ pahūtaṃ kusalaṃ puññakammaṃ karissāmi,
analyzed: bahunti pubbe viya pamādam an āpajjitvā bahum pahūtam kusalam puñña kammam karissāmi
translated: Many: without falling into heedlessness as before, I will do much good, much meritorious work.

original: upacinissāmīti attho.
analyzed: upacinissāmi iti atthaḥ
translated: I will accumulate: this is the meaning.

original: Satthā imā gāthāyo vatvā vitthārena dhammaṃ desesi, desanāpariyosāne mattikārattuppalahārako
analyzed: satthā imāḥ gāthāyaḥ vatvā vitthārena dhammam desesi desanā pariyosāne mattikā rattuppala hārakaḥ
translated: After reciting these stanzas, the Teacher related in detail the Dhamma,🔽and at the conclusion of the discourse the potter’s daughter and the garland-maker were established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: puriso sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Rājā sañjātasaṃvego parapariggahe abhijjhaṃ pahāya
analyzed: puriso sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi rājā sañjāta saṃvegaḥ para pariggahe abhijjham pahāya

original: sadārasantuṭṭho ahosīti.
analyzed: sa dāra santuṭṭhaḥ ahosi iti
translated: and with his wife was satisfied with his own property.

original: Seṭṭhiputtapetavatthuvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: seṭṭhiputta peta vatthu vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Story of the Merchant’s Son is finished.

analyzed: saṭṭhikūṭa peta vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Ghost with the Iron Bar

analyzed: kim nu ummatta rūpā uvā ti idam satthari veḷuvane viharante aññataram petam ārabbha vuttam
translated: Why do you wander about like one demented? This story was told by the Teacher while living at Jetavana about a certain ghost.

analyzed: atīte kira bārāṇasi nagare aññataro pīṭha sappī sālittaka payoge kusalo tahim sakkhara khipana sippe

analyzed: nipphattim gataḥ nagara dvāre nigrodha rukkha mūle nisīditvā sa kkhara pahārehi hatthi assa manussa ratha kūṭāgāra dhaja puṇṇa ghaṭa ādi rūpāni
translated: He had attained perfection in the art of throwing sand. Sitting at the foot of a banyan tree at the city gate, he conjured up the forms of elephants, horses, men, chariots, palanquins, flags, and pots filled with water,

analyzed: nigrodha pattesu dassa iti nagara dārakāḥ kīḷana tthāya māyakaḍḍhamāsaka ādīni

translated: and he conjured up for them whatever tricks they desired.

analyzed: atha eka divasam bārāṇasi rājā nagarataḥ nikkhamitvā tam nigrodha mūlam upagataḥ nigrodha pattesu
translated: Now one day the king of Bārāṇasī went out of the city and came to the foot of the banyan tree. Seeing the various forms, such as the form of an elephant, etc.,

analyzed: hatthi rūpa ādi vasena nānāvidha rūpa vibhattiyaḥ appitā disvā manusse pucchi kena nu  kho imesu nigrodha pattesu evam nānāvidha rūpa vibhattiyaḥ katā ati manussā tam pīṭha sappiṃ
translated: painted on the leaves of the banyan tree, he asked the people, “Who has painted these various forms

translated: And by answering questions,🔽The teaching, which is given in order,

original: Yā desanāniyāmena, sataṃ saṃvegavaḍḍhanī.
analyzed: yā desanā niyāmena satam saṃvega vaḍḍhanī
translated: A hundred times, to increase remorse.🔽Those who are skilled in the stories,

original: Yaṃ kathāvatthukusalā, supariññātavatthukā;
analyzed: yam kathā vatthu kusalā su pariññāta vatthukā
translated: Who have thoroughly mastered the stories,🔽The elders have compiled

original: Petavatthūti nāmena, saṅgāyiṃsu mahesayo.
analyzed: nāmena saṅgāyiṃsu mahesayaḥ
translated: Under the name of Petavatthu.

original: Tassa atthaṃ pakāsetuṃ, porāṇaṭṭhakathānayaṃ;
analyzed: tassa attham pakāsetum porāṇa aṭṭhakathā nayam
translated: To explain its meaning, in the ancient commentary style,

original: Nissāya yā samāraddhā, atthasaṃvaṇṇanā mayā.
analyzed: nissāya yā samāraddhā attha saṃvaṇṇanā mayā
translated: The commentary on the meaning that I have composed,

original: Yā tattha paramatthānaṃ, tattha tattha yathārahaṃ;
analyzed: yā tattha parama atthānam tattha tattha yathāraham
translated: In the case of the ultimate meanings there, as is appropriate in each case,

original: Pakāsanā paramattha-dīpanī nāma nāmato.
analyzed: pakāsanā paramatthadīpanī nāma nāmato
translated: The explanation of the ultimate meanings is called the “Illuminator.”

original: Sampattā pariniṭṭhānaṃ, anākulavinicchayā;
analyzed: sampattā pariniṭṭhānam an ākula vinicchayā
translated: Having reached completion, with the analysis unconfused,

original: Sā pannarasamattāya, pāḷiyā bhāṇavārato.
analyzed: sā panna rasa mattāya pāḷiyā bhāṇa vārataḥ
translated: It is finished in fifteen sections, according to the number of recitations of the text.

original: Iti taṃ saṅkharontena, yaṃ taṃ adhigataṃ mayā;
analyzed: iti tam yam tam adhigatam mayā
translated: Thus, by one who has composed it, whatever has been attained by me,

original: Puññaṃ tassānubhāvena, lokanāthassa sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: puññam tassa anubhāvena lokanāthassa sāsanam
translated: By the power of that merit, may the Dispensation of the Lord of the World

original: Ogāhetvā visuddhāya, sīlādipaṭipattiyā;
analyzed: ogāhetvā visuddhāya sīla ādi paṭipattiyā
translated: Having entered into the pure practice of virtue and so on,

original: Sabbepi dehino hontu, vimuttirasabhāgino.
analyzed: sabbe pi dehinaḥ hontu vimutti rasa bhāginaḥ
translated: May all beings share in the fruit of liberation.

original: Ciraṃ tiṭṭhatu lokasmiṃ, sammāsambuddhasāsanaṃ;
analyzed: ciram tiṭṭhatu lokasmim sammāsambuddha sāsanam
translated: May the Dispensation of the Fully Enlightened One long endure in the world,

original: Tasmiṃ sagāravā niccaṃ, hontu sabbepi pāṇino.
analyzed: tasmim sa gāravāḥ niccam hontu sabbe pi pāṇinaḥ
translated: And may all beings always have respect for it.

original: Sammā vassatu kālena, devopi jagatīpati;
analyzed: sammā vassatu kālena devaḥ api jagatīpati
translated: May the gods, too, the lords of the world, rain down in season,

original: Saddhammanirato lokaṃ, dhammeneva pasāsatūti.🔽Iti badaratitthavihāravāsinā munivarayatinā
analyzed: saddhamma nirataḥ lokam dhammena iva pasāsatu iti  iti badaratitthavihāravāsinā muni vara yatinā
translated: And may the world be prosperous through the true Dhamma.🔽Thus, composed by the Elder Ācariya Dhammapāla,

original: Bhadantena ācariyadhammapālena katā petavatthuatthasaṃvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bhadantena ācariya dhammapālena katā peta vatthu attha saṃvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the Petavatthu, composed by the one who dwells at the monastery of Badaratittha, the best of sages, is finished.

original: Petavatthu-aṭṭhakathā samattā.
analyzed: peta vatthu aṭṭhakathā samattā
translated: The Commentary on the Peta Stories is finished.
